headline: PEKING HAILS CHERNENKO AS AN 'OUTSTANDING LEADER'
abstract: China moved promptly today to express its condolences over the death of Konstantin U. Chernenko, calling him ''an outstanding leader of the party and the state'' and noting that relations between the two Communist nations had improved ''noticeably'' in the 13 months that Mr. Chernenko was in power.     The official News China News Agency, reporting swiftly on developments in Moscow throughout the day, followed close on the heels of Western agencies with its reports of Mr. Chernenko's death and the choice of Mikhail S. Gorbachev to succeed him as General Secretary of the Communist Party. But the agency's brief biography of the new Soviet leader gave no hint of the official reaction here to his designation.    However, there were indications last year that Peking already viewed Mr. Gorbachev as the likely successor to Mr. Chernenko. His visit to Britain in December received close coverage in the Chinese press, and Chinese leaders were said to have quizzed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher about him when she arrived here to sign the agreement on the reversion of Hong Kong a few days after meeting Mr. Gorbachev in London.

headline: PHILLIPS AND ICAHN PREPARE FOR A FIGHT
abstract: Phillips Petroleum is fighting for its life again, this time against Carl C. Icahn. Phillips, characterizing Mr. Icahn as a ''notorious takeover entrepreneur and greenmailer,'' is fighting the bid every way it can - with a new recapitalization plan, for example, and a ''poison pill'' that would require Mr. Icahn to pay as much as $1.5 billion above his original $8.1 billion bid. But Mr. Icahn, indicating he just might swallow the poison pill, continued to lock horns with Phillips. Analysts say that Phillips, still recovering from a bid by T. Boone Pickens just two months ago, may be too weak to fight for long, and may soon have to find a friendly suitor.          Stocks continued a wild ride, with Big Board volume surpassing 100 million shares a day every day last week. The Dow Jones industrial average had a relatively lackluster performance - ending the week at 1,289.97, up 12.25 - but other indexes gained. Some analysts believe the Dow is falling out of step amid investor enthusiasm for stocks in other sectors and on other exchanges.

headline: QUOTA END SPURS SHIFT AT CHRYSLER
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation, responding to the Reagan Administration's decision not to ask Japan to extend automobile export quotas, said yesterday that it was no longer interested in acquiring or building another assembly plant in the United States.     It also scaled back its planned production of what it called a ''sporty compact'' line, but said it would upgrade the line of P-cars to take them out of the low-cost end of the market. This new strategy represents Chrysler's yielding of the low-cost market to its Japanese partner, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation.

headline: New Chinese Envoy to U.S.
abstract: A Chinese Deputy Foreign Minister, Han Xu, has been designated the next Ambassador to the United States and is likely to assume the post in May, American officials said here today.

headline: 2 YEARS AFTER MASSACRE, SALVADORAN SEEKS JUSTICE
abstract: Adrian Esquino Lisco has been waiting two years for justice, but now, he says, his patience and his faith are beginning to run out.    Early on Feb. 23, 1983, as many as 200 Salvadoran Government soldiers entered the Indian farming cooperative of Las Hojas about 45 miles west of the capital of San Salvador, Mr. Esquino said, and dragged away seven of his friends.   Later that day he found the men sprawled along the bank of a nearby river with their thumbs tied behind their backs. Eleven peasants from neighboring villages were lying with them. All had been shot repeatedly in the head. Two were slashed by machetes.

headline: BEIRUT TELLS ARMY TO CRUSH MILITIAS
abstract: The Lebanese Cabinet instructed the army today to put an end to factional clashes in southern Lebanon.    The fighting has claimed the lives of at least eight people in the last 48 hours and created a new refugee problem for the Government.    The Cabinet order came out of its first meeting since Christian militia commanders revolted last week against the authority of President Amin Gemayel and his policy of cooperation with Syria, Lebanon's Moslem neighbor.

headline: U.N. Troops Confront Israelis
abstract: Irish soldiers from the United Nations peacekeeping force blocked the road in front of an Israeli convoy today to protest what the Israelis said was ''preventative gunfire.''

headline: Bomb Wounds 8 in Colombia
abstract: Two men riding a motorcycle threw a bomb at a police station here Tuesday, wounding eight people, including seven officers, the authorities said today.

headline: K Mart Offers 10-Year Notes
abstract: The K Mart Corporation yesterday offered $150 million worth of 10-year notes.

headline: Dominican Units Sold by G.&W.
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries said it had completed the sale of its sugar business and related operations in the Dominican Republic and Florida to an investor group.

headline: ANALYSTS BELIEVE PAN AM CAN SURVIVE A STRIKE, IF IT'S SHORT
abstract: Cushioned by $400 million in cash reserves, Pan American World Airways can withstand a long strike, according to several airline industry analysts.     But such a stoppage would probably cost the airline advance bookings for summer and sharply reduce its chance of making a profit this year, they said.    The airline, which was struck yesterday by its mechanics, flight dispatchers, baggage handlers and food service workers, has sustained heavy losses in recent years.

headline: Explosion in a Polish Market Is Reported to Kill At Least 6
abstract: A gas explosion ripped through a crowded meat market in a Warsaw suburb Saturday, killing at least six people and injuring about 30 others, official news organizations reported.   The explosion occurred in the suburb of Falenica, 12 miles east of Warsaw, according to the official Polish press agency, P.A.P.   Five women and a 7-year-old boy were known dead and some 30 others were injured in the explosion, P.A.P. said. Rescue workers searched for bodies believed to be buried in the rubble, Polish television said.

headline: PIZZA CHAINS' TOUGHEST TURF
abstract: New York City has long been a kind of paradise for pizzerias. Even allowing for high commercial rents, hundreds of independent pizza shops have been thriving here, with high sales volume in very little space and profits that can reach 80 percent a pie.    More important, the city's pizza entrepreneurs, unlike their counterparts almost everywhere else in the country, have not had to compete with the fast-growing, well-financed chains that have come to dominate the national pizza picture.    But now that part of the idyll seems to be over. The third largest of the national chains, Godfather's Pizza, has established a beachhead in Manhattan and is already planning to expand. The second largest, Domino's Pizza, is close behind, and Pizza Hut, the largest, may be heading to Manhattan as well.

headline: PARTNERS AT WORK
abstract: Paul A. Samuelson pondered letting the   book retire with him in May, when he turns 70   and completes his teaching career at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.  ''I'm not as hungry as I once was,'' said the   crew-cut father of six, the first American to   win the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic   Science. ''What I had to decide was whether   to let it gradually die,'' In the end, he said, ''I   felt I owed it to the book not to.'' Thus began the process that will prolong   the life and immediacy of ''Samuelson's 'Economics,'' which after more than 3 million   copies, has proved the most durable text ever   published on the subject. On Friday, McGraw-

headline: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 20, 1985   The Economy
abstract: The Ohio Legislature approved a measure to reopen some of the 70 state-insured savings and loans that were closed Friday. Governor Celeste was expected to sign the legislation immediately and a spokesman for the Governor said some of the institutions may be allowed to reopen as early as today. (Page A1.) Earlier, the Governor traveled to Washington to ask Ohio's Congressional delegation for help in his campaign to get Federal deposit insurance for the closed thrift institutions. (D9.) A number of analysts said the financial markets worldwide were displaying a new nervousness over the health of the American banking system. (D9.)    Housing construction declined a steep 11 percent in February, the biggest drop in almost a year. (D1.)

headline: Heileman Bid For Pabst Ends LA CROSSE, Wis., Feb. 8
abstract: (Reuters) - The G. Heileman   Brewing Company said today   that its $11-a-share tender offer   for the Pabst Brewing Company had expired and would not   be extended.

headline: IBM Credit In Offering In London, the IBM Credit
abstract: Corporation offered $300 million of four-year extendible   notes.  The notes, which are noncallable for three years, were   priced at par and carry a coupon of 10 3/8 percent.

headline: 'TAMED REBELS' MAKE GOOD MANAGERS
abstract: WHAT makes an effective corporate leader? Among other qualities, leaders have an overriding faith in themselves and their own ability to succeed - a faith that may defy the practical odds, in fact. And with this faith, leaders seem to be characterized by a higher degree of ego development than that of the average person. Yet, successful managers do not attain the highest order of ego development - which may be just as well for their corporations.    A recent study that I conducted illustrates these points. Despite the many demographic differences among the 70 managers that we studied, a striking 95 percent of them were in what we call the post-Conformist stage of ego development. In most social groups the majority, or a large minority, of people are at a less advanced level, the Conformist ego stage. But what does this finding mean in terms of how these leaders work and why they succeed?

headline: CONVERSION OF A HOSPITAL TO APARTMENTS
abstract: Change is nothing new for the large, ornate structure at Second Avenue and 18th Street that used to be a hospital. But never has it experienced the sweeping internal reordering that two housing developers are imposing upon it now.     The building went up in 1902 as the New York Lying-In Hospital, built with much philanthropic help to provide free maternity care to mothers from the ranks of the immigrant poor on the Lower East Side. The hospital replaced the Hamilton Fish mansion on the site.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Partnership Investment Registers a Decline
abstract: Investments in publicly registered limited partnerships declined 1.2 percent last year, to about $8.25 billion, the first drop in eight years, according to Robert A. Stanger & Company, a Shrewsbury, N.J., investment research firm.    Total investments of tax-shelter- oriented partnerships fell 10 percent, to nearly $3.9 billion, with oil and gas drilling partnerships losing the most ground, off more than 46 percent.

headline: Nipon Admits A Tax Bribe
abstract: Albert Nipon, head of an internationally known women's clothing company, pleaded guilty today to conspiracy and tax evasion in a scheme to bribe two Internal Revenue Service agents to overlook fraudulent tax returns.   Mr. Nipon, 57 years old, of suburban Gladwyne, entered his plea in Federal District Court before Judge Raymond Broderick, who set sentencing for March 27.

headline: Denmark to Sell Paper in U.S.
abstract: Denmark recently announced plans to become the first foreign government to borrow in the American commercial paper market, where it plans to raise up to $1 billion.    The $236 billion commercial paper market has grown rapidly and is an important source of funds for high- grade companies, including many foreign companies and authorities whose debt is guaranteed by a foreign government.

headline: Allis Set to Sell Agricultural Unit
abstract: The Allis- Chalmers Corporation said today that it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell its agricultural equipment operations and a financing unit, the Allis-Chalmers Credit Corporation, to a subsidiary of Kl"ockner- Humboldt-Deutz A.G. of West Germany for $100 million.   Allis said the transaction involves businesses with a book value of $260 million. Upon completion of the deal, it said, ''Allis-Chalmers will have an opportunity to participate in future profits of the new business.''

headline: People
abstract: * Richard Ferrante has joined Rumrill-Hoyt/New York as senior vice president, associate creative director.

headline: ADVERTISING;U.S. McCann Chairman Set
abstract: After a 22-year upwardly mobile career at Young & Rubicam, John J.  McNamara, a mechanical engineer by training, is moving over on March 1 to McCann-Erickson, the flagship of the Interpublic Group of Companies. He will be chairman of the domestic company and vice chairman of the worldwide company. He was president of Y.& R.'s U.S.A. division, which in billings is some three times larger than McCann domestically.  He is making the move at age 50 because of ''better opportunities,'' he said.  The announcement was made by Robert L. James, who becomes chief executive of McCann Worldwide March 1.  Mr. McNamara, called Jay,  worked for an engineering company after getting his degree from Yale, then switched to retail as a store manager of Grand Union. Then he saw the light and  got a job as an account executive at Ted Bates & Company. He's also an ex-Marine.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: The Nonunion Edge   This year should witness the end of a four-year-long slide in the rate of growth of nonfarm wages and salaries. But not every worker in the private sector will get a lift on payday. The biggest pay raises on average this year will go to nonunion labor, a trend that began in 1982.   B. K. Atrostic, an economist with Joel Popkin & Company, Washington-based economic consultants, expects nonunion wages and salaries this year to inch up 4.4 percent from 4.3 percent in 1984. But union workers' pay is expected to rise only 3.8 percent, compared with 3.9 percent in 1984. Neither group will receive wage increases that match the expected 4.8 percent inflation rate.  Miss Atrostic offered several reasons why nonunionized workers are expected to move ahead faster again this year.  ''The industries most severely affected by Government deregulation, such as the airlines, were heavily unionized,'' she noted. ''The strong dollar also cost unionized jobs and forced workers to accept wage freezes or pay cuts.''

headline: Italian Rail Notes
abstract: The Italian State Railways is issuing $460 million of floating-rate Euronotes due in 1995, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, to refund $225 million of floating-rate notes and to prepay a $230 million syndicated loan, both due in 1988. The notes, which are guaranteed by the Italian Government, pay interest semiannually. Interest will be adjusted monthly at the higher of the mean of bid and offered rates of six-month interbank deposits in London or the offered rate for one-month interbank deposits.

headline: Chip Protection
abstract: Gerald J. Mossinghoff, the Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, has expressed approval of the introduction in the Copyright Office this week of a system to protect designs of semiconductor chips. He headed a working group of Government officials who backed the project in Congress.

headline: Barbie Trial Scheduled For Later This Year
abstract: The Nazi war criminal Klaus Barbie will go on trial here sometime this year, probably in December, on charges of crimes against humanity, the chief prosecutor's office announced today.

headline: ITALIAN PREMIER URGES FRANCE TO EXTRADITE TERROR SUSPECTS
abstract: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi urged the French Government today to extradite Italian terrorist suspects, noting that some of them might have been involved in recent attacks elsewhere in Europe.     Mr. Craxi, in an address to Parliament, said terrorism against North Atlantic Treaty Organization targets in Europe had followed a pattern set by the Italian terrorist group known as the Red Brigades,    ''The anti-NATO themes inspiring the new terrorism were present in Italian terrorism in 1980 and 1981, when the Red Brigades singled out the men and structures of the Atlantic alliance as primary targets for their strategy,'' Mr. Craxi said.   He noted that when French authorities arrested members of the anti- NATO terror group Direct Action, seven of those picked up were Italians accused of terrorism - ''All fugtives and all dangerous,'' Mr. Craxi said.

headline: Murchison In Liquidation
abstract: Clint W. Murchison Jr., the ailing Texas oilman who once owned the Dallas Cowboys football team, has taken the first step toward liquidating most of his remaining empire. The Klimanorm Corporation, which is owned by Mr. Murchison, filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors on Monday, as the 25 wooded acres surrounding Mr. Murchison's Dallas mansion were about to be auctioned off.

headline: ENGINEERING;  OUTLOOK IS REWARDING FOR MOST SPECIALTIES
abstract: -technology sectors of the nation's economy, such as electronics, information processing and other science-related fields, continues to provide a plentiful supply of of job opportunities for engineers. But so intense is the interest in engineering that college and university faculties have failed to keep pace with the sharp increase in students, and some authorities fear this shortage of teachers may mean a decline in the quality of electrical and computer engineering and computer-science graduates.   An indicator of the strong demand for skilled technical graduates comes from the American Electronics Association, based in Palo Alto, Calif., which predicts an annual growth rate through 1987 of 10.6 percent for electrical engineers, 16.5 percent for computer engineers, and 15.2 percent for computer-science professionals.  Other groups make similar forecasts. The National Science Foundation, for instance, predicts a growth of 10 to 15 percent in jobs for electrical and computer engineers and a substantial shortage of computer-science professionals. A 1984 Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics report projects a shortage of 15 to 30 percent in jobs for computer engineers by 1987 and a job growth of 65 percent for electrical engineers between 1982 and 1995.

headline: ARMS NEGOTIATOR URGES PERSISTENCE
abstract: The Reagan Administration's new chief arms control negotiator said today that the United States and the Soviet Union ''must try to find a formula under which we can live together in dignity'' even though the negotiations were likely to be difficult.   In his first public comments since being named to head the Geneva bargaining team, the negotiator, Max M. Kampelman, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that although the Soviet Union was a ''repressive'' and ''aggressive'' society, the United States ''dares not and cannot blow the Soviet Union away.'' The negotiations resume in Geneva on March 12.    ''We cannot wish it away,'' he said, arguing for the necessity of pursuing negotiations. ''It is here and it is militarily powerful. We share the same globe. We must try to find a formula under which we can live together in dignity. We must engage in that pursuit of peace without illusion but with persistence regardless of provocation.''

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Hanover Bank Cuts Prime
abstract: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company yesterday announced a cut in its prime lending rate to 10 1/2 percent from 10 3/4 percent - a decline that reflected the steep drop in other interest rates during recent months. No other banks immediately matched the reduction.     The drop in the prime rate, which will benefit businesses and consumers whose loans are pegged to the bank rate, was the latest in a series of reductions that began in late September when the prime was 13 percent. The prime has fallen as the Federal Reserve eased monetary policy.

headline: ADVERTISING;Ohlmeyer Ad President
abstract: Dean J. Heitler, 44 years old, who was working at Parkson Advertising, the house agency of Nabisco Brands when it became part of the Ohlmeyer Communications Companies, has just been named president of Ohlmeyer Advertising, a subsidiary. A former executive vice president, he replaces Philip Howort, who  resigned earlier last week.

headline: Alaska Seeking Money Sources
abstract: Falling oil prices have led Alaskan officials to explore new ways of financing their state's operating and capital budget.    Don Bennett, president of the State Senate, has arranged for securities dealers to suggest new financing ideas on March 13, 14 and 26, Reuters news service reported yesterday.

headline: Syria Offering Amnesty To Underground Group
abstract: President Hafez al-Assad has declared an amnesty for some members of the outlawed Moslem Brotherhood organization who are imprisoned in Syria and has invited those in exile to return to the country, state-controlled newspapers reported today.   The report said Mr. Assad's decision had come after talks between Syrian officials and Moslem Brotherhood leaders abroad resulted in pledges from members of the group that their views had changed and that they would ''no longer be the tools of Syria's enemies.''

headline: A NEW ALLURE FOR FOREIGN STOCKS
abstract: After taking a drubbing in the currency markets last week the dollar now has some experts predicting that it finally has reached the top of its five-year climb. The American currency's value has risen almost 80 percent vis- a-vis other major currencies since 1980 and, according to some analysts, the only direction from here is down.   ''The dollar will decline, take my word for it,'' said Nicholas Bratt, portfolio manager of the $210 million Scudder International mutual fund.   Andre Sharon, partner in a newly formed international investment firm, Simms Capital Management, based in New York, agreed: ''Whether the dollar declines today, tomorrow, next month or next year, it's close to a peak. There's very little currency play left.''

headline: BANK IN BOSTON FINED ON SHIFTS IN CASH ABROAD
abstract: The First National Bank of Boston pleaded guilty in Federal District Court here today to failing to report $1.2 billion in cash transfers with Swiss banks and was fined $500,000.    Much of the cash, which was in denominations of $20 or less, had been put in ''satchels'' that were placed aboard airplanes and deposited in the accounts of the foreign banks at First National, according to the United States Attorney, William F. Weld.   In a similar manner, the bank transferred large sums of cash back to the foreign banks when withdrawals were requested, Mr. Weld said.        Largest Ever Imposed    The fine was the largest ever imposed on a bank for violating the Federal currency reporting law, a felony offense. It was also the first time an American bank has been prosecuted for illegal international interbank transfers.

headline: SALVADORAN ARMY IMPROVING, BUT REBELS ADJUST
abstract: A year ago, after a series of rebel successes, the spirit of Salvadoran Government troops seemed close to breaking. Today they appear more confident, willing to pursue rebel forces and to stand and fight when they clash.    But with the peace negotiations that opened last fall now at a standstill after only two sessions, there is no sign of an early end to the five-year-old war in the countryside.    Senior Reagan Administration officials have predicted that if present political and military trends continue the army could win the conflict within two years. At the same time, they have called for significant increases in military aid to El Salvador.

headline: STATE DEPT. OFFICIAL TO LET STAFF TALK TO TIMES CORRESPONDENT
abstract: The director of the State Department's Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs said today that he had decided to lift an order forbidding members of his bureau to talk to a correspondent for The New York Times.    The correspondent, Leslie H. Gelb, wrote an article concerning the disclosure in Canada, Iceland, Bermuda and Puerto Rico of American contingency plans for ''emergency'' deployment of nuclear depth charges in those locations. The article, saying the Governments that were to be hosts under the plan had not been informed, said that the plans had been divulged in press reports there and had become the subject of sharp public debate in Canada and Iceland.    After the article was published in The Times on Feb. 13, the bureau director, Lieut. Gen. John T. Chain Jr., ordered his staff not to speak to Mr. Gelb, asserting that the reporter had knowingly published classified information, the release of which was harmful to national security.

headline: People
abstract: *       Anthony I. Morgan, formerly of Backer & Spielvogel, is joining TBWA Advertising in the new position of executive vice president, director of marketing services.     *       Richard A. S'Dao, a management supervisor, has been promoted to senior vice president at Benton & Bowles.

headline: PRESIDENT CALLS CONTROL OF ARMS HIS MAJOR GOAL
abstract: President Reagan said today that he viewed the United States arms-control negotiating commitments made with the Soviet Union in Geneva ''with the utmost seriousness.''    In a statement issued after his first meeting with his new arms-control negotiating team, Mr. Reagan said he had ''no more important goal'' in his second term than in reducing and ultimately eliminating nuclear weapons.   ''I also want to emphasize that we are determined to achieve a good agreement - an agreement which meets the interests of both countries, which increases the security of our allies and which enhances international stability,'' Mr. Reagan said in the written statement.        Pledges 'Concrete Ideas'    He pledged that once the three-part negotiations begin, ''the United States will have concrete ideas to put on the negotiating table.'' He added that ''we hope the Soviet Union will follow a similar constructive approach.''

headline: Need for Electronic Banking Grows in Germany
abstract: The order for 1,000 leather jackets took about six minutes to clatter across the telex machine of Dae Woo Handels G.m.b.H., the $100 million-a-year West German trading arm of South Korea's big Dae Woo manufacturing concern.    It took less time for Alfred W. P"ohl, a financial officer in Dae Woo's cluttered headquarters here, to scan the Euromoney quotes in London on a desktop terminal and, by tapping a few keys, to open a 180-day credit line, until the customer paid.   ''I'm interested in dollar rates, in swaps, Eurodeposit interest rates, bid and offer rates, interbanking rates from one to six months,'' Mr. P"ohl said, spinning off a litany of the company's financial service needs.        The American Lead    To meet those needs and the requirements of other customers, European banks are rushing into electronic banking and trying to narrow the lead of the more technologically advanced American banks.

headline: PROSPECTS;  Then There's Granville
abstract: Not everyone expects equities to zoom.  Joseph E. Granville, the 61-year-old analyst whose market letter has a devoted, if nervous, following (his sell recommendations have been known to knock the wind out of the Dow) says predictions of the Dow hitting 1,400 to 1,500 are off by about 900 points.

headline: Combustion Inc. Receives Contract
abstract: Combustion Engineering Inc. said it had received a contract from the Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority valued at $154 million for the design and construction of a resource recovery plant. The project is subject to financing and approval from the 33 towns it will serve in the greater Hartford area, Combustion Engineering said. If approved on schedule, the plant would begin operating in 1988 and would generate 68.5 megawatts of electricity.

headline: Kindred Spirits
abstract: To the Editor:     Lee Iacocca ought to meet John Naisbitt (''The Importance of Being Iacocca,'' and ''Reinventing the American Corporation,'' Dec. 23). They are at opposite ends of the organizational universe regarding a philosophy of management.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW MOOD
abstract: The wheel, it almost seemed, had come full circle. On the 25th anniversary of the Sharpeville massacre of 1960, the police guns blazed again, this time in Langa township, near Uitenhage, just back from South Africa's southern coastline. At least 19 blacks died and 35 were hospitalized.     The temptation among commentators was to say things had not changed over the quarter-century. Yet, this time, there was a difference.

headline: FREED SOUTH AFRICAN EXPLAINS WHY HE TOOK BOTHA'S OFFER
abstract: A leader of the banned African National Congress who was released from prison in South Africa and allowed to fly to Israel said today that he might one day return to South Africa to continue his political struggle.    The freed man, Dennis Goldberg, said in an interview, ''Perhaps when I feel more recovered and a little more energetic, I might find that some fears may not be so important.''   The South African-born engineer accepted a conditional amnesty offered by President P. W. Botha on Jan. 31. Mr. Goldberg said of those, including Nelson Mandela, the head of the African National Congress, who declined the offer: ''I'm not as strong as they are. I ask for their understanding.''

headline: Bomb Kills 2, Wounds 7 In South-West Africa
abstract: -West Africa, Jan. 8 (Reuters) - Two men were killed and seven were wounded today when a nail bomb exploded in a shop in the town of Ondangwa, the territory's security police chief said.

headline: Arnell/Bickford Wins Neiman Marcus
abstract: Arnell/Bickford of New York is going to be doing the television advertising for the Neiman Marcus department store chain.

headline: Car Output Up 14%
abstract: The United States auto industry built more than 7.6 million cars in 1984, a gain of almost 14 percent from its 1983 output and the highest production volume since 1979, the companies reported today. General Motors, Ford and Chrysler each had their best annual car output since 1979.

headline: U.S. LOBBIES BRAZIL ON COPTER DEAL
abstract: The Reagan Administration is pressing Brazil to review its decision to purchase $140 million worth of military helicopters from France's Aerosp atiale Aircraft Company rather than from the United Technologies Corporation's Sikorsky Aircraft.    United States officials and company executives said Sikorsky's Blackhawk helicopter had been tested and approved by the Brazilian Air Force, but a last-minute offer by the French company was accepted in late January, reportedly on grounds of more favorable financing.   ''No one knows where we stand at the moment,'' said Joseph Cooper, Sikorsky's marketing director for Latin America, ''but we're guardedly optimistic, which means we hope that the contract has not been finally ratified by the central bank.''   Complicating lobbying efforts is that the decision was made during the final weeks of a military regime that leaves office on March 15, with local media reports reflecting confusion over who exactly opted for the French helicopters, why and under what circumstances.

headline: Anne Klein Chooses McCaffery & Ratner
abstract: McCaffery & Ratner has become agency for Anne Klein Fragrances, which are marketed in this country under a licensing agreement by Parlux Inc.    The products involved are Anne Klein Parfum, bath products and associated toiletries.

headline: MOSCOW CRITICIZES SENATE ON THE MX
abstract: The Soviet press today denounced the Senate vote to release $1.5 billion for 21 MX missiles, saying that President Reagan had twisted senators' arms to get his way.   Reports in Izvestia, the Government newspaper, and by Tass, the Government press agency, ridiculed the argument that the missiles were necessary to bolster the American bargaining position in Geneva.   ''The logic is striking,'' Tass said. ''Arms are to be amassed to achieve their reduction.''

headline: ASARCO HAS LOSS; TENNECO FALLS 46.1%
abstract: Citing a substantial write-down and weak prices for its major products, Asarco Inc. yesterday reported a loss of $236.3 million in the fourth quarter of 1984, contrasted to earnings of $11.7 million, or 27 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1983.     The company said last week that it would take an extraordinary charge of $216 million in the quarter, reflecting the suspension or permanent closing of some of its plants and mines.    Revenues in the quarter dropped 28.1 percent, to $282.2 million, from $392.5 million.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.         Monday    None      Tuesday    None      Wednesday    None      Thursday    None      Friday    None

headline: Market Place;   Taking a Look At Oil Stocks
abstract: -related stocks have benefited lately from takeover speculation and corporate restructuring plans, along with increases in the spot-market price for oil.   But Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. believes that ''caution is in order,'' and it warns that ''a sharp drop in the price of oil - perhaps to $20 a barrel or less - could occur.'' The warning is detailed in this week's issue of the Merrill Lynch Market Letter.   It follows a change in thinking by the firm's oil analysts, who said that ''we are no longer confident'' about prospects for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. This report was written by Constantine Fliakos, who follows the international oil companies, and Warren Shimmerlik, who watches the domestic oil scene.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM;  NOT ONLY FINANCIERS CAN GET CAUGHT
abstract: Money lenders and all of us who chance to deal with them were just handed this country's broadest and most potent financial bribery law ever.    It is broad because it reaches to all federally insured institutions, and for the first time exacts stiff punishment on tenderers as well as recipients of bribes.   And it is potent because the very definition of a bribe has been dramatically altered. On Oct. 12, a bribe was redefined so that if any employee of a bank, thrift institution or credit union accepts anything of worth - no matter how seemingly trivial - it can be treated as a big-time crime.

headline: RESERCH AND DEVELOPMENT: A RECORD PACE
abstract: WITH its space telescope, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration will search for planets beyond the solar system.  At its new biotechnology complex, the Monsanto Company is trying to develop seeds that will be resistant to drought. The Defense Department is looking into the Strategic Defense Initiative - commonly called Star Wars - that President Reagan says could render nuclear weapons obsolete.   These activities are part of a record-setting industrial and governmental research-and-development effort that saw $97 billion spent last year alone, according to the National Science Foundation. Just since 1980, spending to build the strength of the nation and to put it in a more competitive position in science and industry is up 55 percent. ''We are the strongest nation in all the leading (technological) areas,'' said Nam P. Suh, N.S.F.'s assistant director for engineering. ''We are the most innovative nation in the world. But being the front- runner you can never figure out how fast you ought to run to stay there.''

headline: Article 186488 -- No Title
abstract: The Irving Bank Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income would be reduced by about $4.5 million as the result of a loss by a Swiss affiliate.     Irving owns about 40 percent of the shares in the affiliate, the Banca della Svizzera Italiana, which is based in Lugano. The New York bank acquired the shares in January 1983.

headline: Canadian Wins Appeal on Anti-Jewish Book
abstract: A provincial court in Alberta ruled today that a small-town schoolteacher could keep a book that had been confiscated on the ground that it was anti-Semitic.    The successful appeal of the teacher, James Keegstra of Eckville, Alberta, was the latest development in a drive by the federal Government to crack down on dissemination of hate material aimed at Jews and other ethnic groups.    Next week, the Government plans to introduce tougher legislation on hate literature, according to Justice Minister John Crosbie.   A Toronto publisher, Ernst Zundel, was convicted last month of maliciously spreading false news, specifically that the Holocaust did not happen. On Monday, he was sentenced to 15 months in prison and 3 months' probation. He is appealing.

headline: Wells Fargo Callable Notes LONDON, March 11 (Reuters) - Wells Fargo & Company is issuing $200 million of
abstract: 15-year subordinated floating-   rate notes. The notes will pay 1/8 percent above the one-month   London interbank offered   rates.

headline: May-Metropolitan
abstract: The May Department Stores Company said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's 50 percent interest in Parklabrea Associates, a real estate partnership of May and Metropolitan.

headline: New Rule For Banks
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today adopted a long- awaited regulation setting a minimum capital standard for banks. Also the agency proposed to require more public disclosure of individual banks' financial problems.   The minimum capital figure (showing how much the owners have invested in a bank in relation to its outstanding assets, mainly loans) was set at 6 percent. This new requirement primarily affects a handful of the nation's largest banks.

headline: People
abstract: Kenneth Umansky has joined Ketchum Advertising/Pittsburgh as senior vice president, account group director.     *       John R. O'Reilly was appointed president and chief executive officer of Select Magazines Inc.     *       Ellen McVickar was named advertising director at Ski magazine.

headline: Briton Is Optimistic On Gorbachev Views
abstract: Neil Kinnock, the leader of the Labor opposition in Britain, met for more than three hours with Mikhail S. Gorbachev during the new Soviet leader's visit to Britain just before Christmas - perhaps the longest talk that any Western politician has had with the Russian.   Mr. Kinnock said today he was sure that Mr. Gorbachev would want to continue with the policies ''seeking progress towards the end of nuclear arms'' adopted by Konstantin U. Chernenko.

headline: Bhopal
abstract: To the Editor:     ''A Three Mile Island for Chemicals'' (Dec. 16) perpetuates public misperceptions about the testing and regulation of commercial chemicals.    The article implies that the Environmental Protection Agency is overwhelmed because new chemicals are introduced ''. . . at the astonishing rate of 70 an hour.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, JANUARY 18, 1985
abstract: Markets         Secretary Regan suggested that the U.S. may intervene more readily in currency markets. In the past the Administration said it would try to influence currency levels only when markets were ''disorderly,'' but after meeting with a group of finance ministers, Mr. Regan said a second guideline is to be ''helpful.'' A joint statement from the meeting reaffirmed that the leading industrial nations would ''undertake coordinated intervention in the markets as necessary.'' Treasury officials said this was more a warning that they would intervene if speculation continues than a threat of imminent action. (Page A1.) The dollar fell modestly before the statement was issued, on conjecture that the ministers would act to restrain its record-breaking climb. Gold rose $3.35, to $307.15, in late trading in New York. (D11.)         Stocks ended mixed again, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 1.99 points, to 1,228.69, but with more shares advancing than declining. Trading receded to 113.6 million shares. (D4.)

headline: BID TO ALTER ISRAELI LAW OF RETURN RENEWS DEBATE ON WHO IS A JEW
abstract: Israel appeared headed today for another major political debate over the question of who is a Jew.    In the midst of an economic crisis, the arrival of Ethiopian Jews and a national debate over the question of withdrawing troops from Lebanon, Israel's religious parties have again introduced a bill in Parliament that would amend Israel's Law of Return to redefine who is a Jew.   The proposal has prompted a storm of protests from American Jewish groups that oppose the amendment because it would invalidate the Jewishness of anyone who converted through a ceremony performed by a non-Orthodox rabbi - meaning rabbis of the Reform and Conservative Jewish movements.        Would Affect Some Decendents    The amendment would also bar recognition of those converted by Orthodox rabbis not recognized by the Israeli rabbinical authorities and would apply as well to the descendants of anyone who was converted by non-Orthodox rabbis.

headline: Unidynamics Gets Offer From Crane
abstract: The Crane Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Unidynamics Corporation for $29 a share, or a total of $199 million.     The agreement thwarts a hostile offer from Nortek Inc., which had bid $20 a share for Unidynamics on Jan. 8. Nortek said yesterday that in light of the deal with Crane it would terminate its tender offer for Unidynamics.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *       Crane Co. , with headquarters in New York City, said its Crane Acquisition Corp. subsidiary had extended its $196 million offer to buy all outstanding shares of Unidynamics Corp. at $29 a share until 5 P.M. today. The offer was to have expired Wednesday at midnight.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Impact on Jewelry Prices
abstract: It is too early to tell whether the recent drop in the price of gold will affect interest in owning the metal for investment. And retailers are not yet willing to predict when lower jewelry prices will reach consumers.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *       The American Stock Exchange announced that Porter P. Morgan, senior vice president for market development at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., had been named executive vice president, marketing.     *       American General Corp., Houston, a financial services company, said that Herschel C. Pittenger, William M. Stillman, Julia S. Tucker and James C. Whitley had been promoted to senior vice presidents.

headline: Briton Kidnapped
abstract: Gunmen kidnapped a British scientist today as he walked from his home to his office in West Beirut, the police said. The scientist, Geoffrey Vernon Nash, was stopped by three gunmen in the seaside residential area of Manara as he walked to work at a research institute, a police spokesman said.

headline: Confidence Index Is High By The Associated Press American consumers retained ''a relatively high level''
abstract: of confidence in the economy   during February, after showing a substantial increase during January, a business research organization said yesterday.

headline: Icahn Financing For Phillips Bid Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier attempting to take over the Phillips Petroleum Company, told 150 Wall Street professionals that he hoped to announce by today that he had raised ''between $1 billion and $2 billion'' of the $4.1 billion he would need to buy control.
abstract: In an unusual display of support, they applauded him enthusiastically after a short talk at the University Club, where he announced that, to indicate the seriousness of his bid, he intended to pay a $7.5 million fee to Drexel Burnham Lambert, his fund raisers, for lining up the funds.    Mr. Icahn, who owns 7.5 million shares of Phillips, is opposed to the company's recapitalization program and has offered, subject to several conditions including raising the money, $60 a share for enough stock to give him 50 percent.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: All of Sanyo Business Going to DYR Agency
abstract: Sanyo Electric of Compton, Calif., the Japanese manufacturer's marketing arm in the United States, has decided to consolidate all its advertising in DYR, Los Angeles, the joint venture of Dentsu, the giant Japanese ad agency, and Young & Rubicam, America's largest.

headline: U.S. Embassy in El Salvador Says Forces Are Within Limit
abstract: The United States routinely has about 120 soldiers in El Salvador but is not violating the 55-man limit that Congress imposed for military advisers, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.   Responding to allegations by three members of Congress that the Administration is deceiving Congress about the extent of American involvement in El Salvador, the embassy provided a breakdown of military personnel here.   The embassy spokesman said soldiers were here in addition to the 55 advisers but were handling other duties.

headline: Pan Am's Negotiator No Stranger to Strikes
abstract: C. Raymond Grebey Jr. is no stranger to tense labor negotiations. As head of major league baseball's Player Relations Committee, he represented team owners in the bitter 50- day strike in the summer of 1981.   Now, Mr. Grebey, a silver-haired, ruddy-faced man of 58, is in the news again - this time as chief negotiator for Pan American World Airways in its 22-day-old strike with 5,800 ground workers, including baggage handlers and food service personnel.

headline: Tax Rise
abstract: To the Editor:     Your article (''A Tax Rise Could Buoy the Recovery,'' Jan. 27) provided a useful perspective on reducing the deficit and simultaneously encouraging the current recovery. However, it misses the key point in the current debate on whether taxes should be increased or maintained.

headline: C.D.'s, Money Funds Show Decline in Yield
abstract: The yields on a variety of popular consumer investment vehicles declined a bit during the last week.   The Bank Rate Monitor's national index for bank six-month certificates of deposit dropped to 8.63 percent for the week ended yesterday, from 8.68 percent the week before. The index for money market deposit accounts slipped to 8.20 percent, from 8.26 percent. The Monitor's yield figures are based on minimum deposits available at institutions.

headline: 23 SECONDS IN '76, AND A CHINESE CITY STILL ACHES
abstract: At dawn each day, bands of peasants fan out across the acres of rubble that scar the heart of this city.    Although eight and a half years have passed since one of the century's most devastating earthquakes ravaged the city, scavenging continues in what were once Tangshan's most densely populated zones. For a levy of a few cents a pound, teams of men and teen- age boys scour the crumbled brick for twisted bicycles, enamelware basins and lead pipe.    Using donkey carts, the peasants contribute to an enterprise in urban recovery that matches the worst bombed cities of postwar Europe or Japan. After five years of intense reconstruction that has cost the equivalent of $1.4 billion, according to city officials, Tangshan is a bigger, more industrialized city now than it was when the upheaval struck.

headline: RESIGNATION AT F.T.C. COMES AS A SURPRISE
abstract: George W. Douglas, a Democratic member of the Federal Trade Commission who has been sympathetic to President Reagan's deregulation efforts, announced his resignation from the commission yesterday.    The resignation, effective in September, came as a surprise to other commissioners and staff members. Four years remain in his seven-year term.

headline: BIG BOARD PANEL URGES EASED LISTING STANDARD
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange, which has faced growing competitive pressure from other markets, should loosen its standards for the companies whose trading it supervises, a Big Board study group recommended yesterday.    Specifically, the panel proposed that the exchange reverse its decades-old policy and, as long as certain conditions were met, list companies that had two classes of common stock with unequal voting rights.   The most notable of the proposed conditions would require that owners of two-thirds of a company's common shares approve the creation of the second class of common stock.    ''If two-thirds of the shareholders vote for something, who are we to impose our judgment that they're not right?'' Andrew C. Sigler, co-chairman of the study group and chairman and chief executive of the Champion International Corporation, said at an exchange news conference.

headline: Pickens Raises Stake in Unocal LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19
abstract: An investor group led   by T. Boone Pickens, the Texas   oilman, said it had increased   its holdings in the Unocal Corporation to 8.5 percent.

headline: Futures Trading
abstract: To the Editor:     Your piece on Commodity exchanges and self governance (''Look Beyond the 'Pits' for Directors,'' Oct. 28) suggested that these exchanges are not receptive to outside involvement on their boards of directors.   A look at the four New York exchanges indicates that is incorrect.

headline: Bank of Boston to Keep HBM/Creamer
abstract: After reviewing agencies, the Bank of Boston, which admitted earlier this month that it had failed to file required reports on $1.22 billion in international cash shipments, has decided to stick with HBM/Creamer.   HBM said it won out over Needham Harper Worldwide, Ingalls Associates and Cabot Advertising. The account carries a 1985 budget of $8 million to $10 million.

headline: Michigan Bank's Plans
abstract: The Michigan National Corporation's new chairman and chief executive said the bank intends to remain independent, despite merger overtures from Comerica Inc. ''Just because we receive an offer doesn't mean we have to accept it,'' Robert J. Mylod said Wednesday during the company's annual economic outlook conference. Comerica, the state's second-largest bank holding company, sent a letter to directors before Mr. Mylod's appointment offering to open merger discussions. Michigan National is the state's third-largest banking company.

headline: WINANS SEES ETHICS VIOLATION
abstract: R. Foster Winans, the former Wall Street Journal reporter charged with conspiracy and securities fraud, admitted yesterday at his trial that he had violated his sense of journalistic ethics when he engaged in a stock trading scheme based on advance information of his columns.    ''I think it is wrong to own stock in a company you write about without disclosing that to your readers,'' Mr. Winans testified. He said he did not disclose to readers any of the financial interests he had in stocks that became the subject of his column, and assumed he would be dismissed from his job if his arrangement with a stockbroker were found out.   In its case against Mr. Winans, the Government has charged that he wrote in the ''Heard on the Street'' column about stocks owned by his roommate, David J. Carpenter, a co- defendant, and that he tipped others off with advance information about his columns so he could share in their stock trading profits. Mr. Winans testified on Monday that he did not believe he was committing a crime when he participated in that arrangement.

headline: ROUNDUP OF QUARTERLY PROFITS AND SALES AT 248 COMPANIES
abstract: Revenues

headline: Winans Case Defense Rests
abstract: With lawyers for two co-defendants in the trial of R. Foster Winans declining to call their clients to the witness stand, the defense rested yesterday and testimony in one of the most celebrated insider-trading cases came to an end.   Federal District Judge Charles E. Stewart then asked the defense and prosecution to present written summations of their positions by April 22.

headline: British Aerospace
abstract: British Aerospace P.L.C., one of Europe's largest aircraft and satellite makers, today set a May target for disposal of the Government's 48.43 percent stake in the company.

headline: Pepsico Studying Sale of Wilson Unit
abstract: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that it was studying the possibility of selling its Wilson Sporting Goods unit, which it acquired in 1970.   At the same time, Pepsico reported that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 16.1 percent on a revenue gain of barely four-tenths of 1 percent.   Pepsico, which is the second-largest soft-drink producer, after the Coca-Cola Company, said the sale of Wilson and the previously announced withdrawal from the transportation business would allow it to focus on its beverage, snack food and food services businesses, which have been profitable.

headline: Shultz and Mexican Discuss Border Concerns
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Bernardo Sepulveda Amor of Mexico met today. Both sides later indicated a desire to tone down their differences over drug trafficking and other issues.

headline: MADISON AVE. HOTEL RENOVATED WITH FOREIGN FUNDS
abstract: Four years ago, several major New York hotels passed into foreign ownership, and E. William Judson saw an opportunity to make a statement.     Mr. Judson, an Upper East Side commercial real estate broker then buying his first hotel - the Stanhope, on Fifth Avenue at 81st Street - renamed it the American Stanhope to assert the establishment's domestic ownership and management. ''We do not want to be a French hotel in New York, or an English Hotel in New York,'' he said.    With a similar strategy in mind, Mr. Judson subsequently lined up two American oil industry executives as joint venture partners on his next purchase, the old Hyde Park Hotel on Madison Avenue at 77th Street. But times and economics had changed: The oil industry had weakened; the partners wanted out, and Mr. Judson was left with a $10 million renovation project and a need for capital.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Second Fire Is Spotted On Galapagos Islands
abstract: Ecuadorean Air Force pilots said Friday that they had spotted another fire in the Galapagos Islands even as the blaze on Isabela Island continued to spread, officials said.    The pilots said that the fire on the second island, San Cristobal, was approaching the farmland of residents, but that it appeared easier to control than the wildfires on Isabela.

headline: Weinberger Is Distressed
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Reagan Administration was disappointed with New Zealand's decision.

headline: K Mart to Provide Financial Services
abstract: The K Mart Corporation said today that it had reached agreements to provide some banking, real estate brokerage, mortgage and consumer financing services at 31 stores nationwide in a test of what could be a multimillion- dollar market.   Under the agreements, K Mart will lease space in stores to various financial institutions, which will staff booths with their own employees.

headline: ISRAELIS SAY SYRIA DOESN'T SEEK DEAL
abstract: Israeli military officials say they are becoming increasingly convinced that Syria is no longer interested in an agreement for the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon.    Israel and Lebanon are scheduled to resume their United Nations-sponsored talks in Naqura, Lebanon, next Monday after a Christmas recess.    The Israeli officials say that if the Lebanese, whose position is being dictated by Damascus, do not show some sign of willingness to agree to certain basic Israeli security conditions at the next session, Israel will have no reason to continue with the talks and will have no choice but to act on its own.    The Israeli Army is already understood to have prepared a series of withdrawal options for Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin.

headline: PONTIFF BRINGS HOPE TO ECUADOR SLUM
abstract: At 6:30 this morning, the crowds had already started to gather in this slum neighborhood on the edge of the Ecuadorean city of Guayaquil.    Some of them passed by the two trucks bearing drinkable water, one of the few things the people of this neighborhood are asking for, along with police protection and, for the unemployed, a chance to work.   The people were coming to hear Pope John Paul II speak about Jesus and the poor, and these were John Paul's people: poor, devout, hardworking, believing that this Pope might really be able to change things.   ''This visit is very good for us,'' said Luis Ortiz, who was climbing up an unfinished cinderblock house with his wife and two children for a better view of the Pope.

headline: Canada's Defense Post Filled By Its Deputy Prime Minister
abstract: Deputy Prime Minister Erik Nielsen was named today as Canada's new Defense Minister, replacing Robert Coates, who resigned earlier this month after a furor erupted about a visit he had made to a West German striptease club.

headline: Botway And Libov Combine
abstract: CLIFFORD A. BOTWAY INC., which has specialized in buying TV network and radio advertising time for 15 years, has acquired Ed Libov Associates, specialists in buying spot TV, radio and print.    The resultant company, the Botway Group, says it is the largest media- buying company worldwide, with $400 million in billings.

headline: Mexican Drilling Plan
abstract: The state petroleum monopoly, Pemex, announced today that it would drill 1,000 new wells as part of a five-year program to increase Mexico's crude oil production by 1.6 million barrels a day, or 58 percent, to meet increased domestic consumption. Mexico currently produces 2.75 million barrels a day and exports an average of 1.4 million daily. It is the largest foreign supplier of oil to the United States.

headline: S.E.C. CHARGES 5 IN SCHEME TO DEFRAUD BROKERS
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged a group of investors with participating in a scheme to defraud some of the nation's largest brokerage firms, including E.F. Hutton & Company, Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. and Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. In a civil lawsuit, the S.E.C. said the five investors in the group bought $10 million of securities without intending to make payment.    Those charged with fraud by means of the illegal practice of ''free riding'' were Thomas W. Reid, a Texas businessman; Armond Zaccaria, a Manhasset, L.I., restaurateur and horse breeder; Maurice Rind, a Sherman Oaks, Calif., investor; Michael Joe Rogers, a Grandview, Tex., lawyer, and Peter Vito, of Corona, Queens, who is believed to be self-employed in the construction industry.   The S.E.C. said the five investors had caused several of the nine brokerage firms involved in the trading to lose a total of more than $500,000.

headline: HUNGARY APPOINTS DEPUTY TO KADAR
abstract: A four-day congress of the Hungarian Communist Party has ended here with the re-election of Janos Kadar and the selection, for the first time, of a designated deputy to the 72-year-old party leader.    Mr. Kadar first took power as Soviet troops quashed the uprising of 1956.    Though the choice of Karoly Nemeth, a 62-year-old national party secretary, to the new post of deputy chairman of the 13-member Politburo was a departure from previous practice, Hungarian commentators cautioned against any assumptions that Mr. Nemeth was being cast in a role of heir apparent.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *       Comarco Inc.  filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $10 million of convertible subordinated debentures, through underwriters led by Seidler Amdec Securities Inc.     *       Foxmeyer Corp. , a drug wholesale distributor, filed for an offering of $75 million of convertible debentures, due 2010, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.     *       Mattel Inc.  filed for an offering of $75 million of subordinated debentures, due 2000, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.     *       Great Western Financial Corp.  filed for an offering of $150 million of convertible subordinated debentures, due 2010, through Shearson Lehman Brothers.

headline: Roper Buys Back Shares Sears Held
abstract: The Roper Corporation announced the purchase of 815,000 shares of its common stock from the Sears, Roebuck & Company, reducing Sears's stake to 1.3 million shares, or 23 percent of Roper's common stock. Roper, based in Kankakee, Ill., produces outdoor power equipment, including lawn mowers and garden tractors; kitchen appliances, and coated metal products.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Rates Edge Up; 10-Year Notes at 11.36%
abstract: Yields rose slightly yesterday for Treasury notes and bonds, while rates for securities due in less than a year were little changed.     Trading in Treasury notes and bonds fluctuated during the day, according to securities dealers' assesments of demand for $6 billion of 11 1/4 percent Treasury notes due in 1995, which were auctioned at 1 P.M. at an average yield of 11.36 percent. Prices declined during morning trading, as dealers sought to raise yields to levels that would attract more investor demand for the new Treasury notes. But much of the decline was reversed late in the day, when results of the 10-year note auction showed that demand was stronger than expected.

headline: American Can Ends Sonoma Tie
abstract: The American Can Company sold its entire 9.8 percent stake in Williams-Sonoma Inc., American Can disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

headline: PLAY BALL! SANDINISTAS DELIVER SLIDERS AND SLOGANS
abstract: The national baseball stadium here reopened a few weeks ago, newly rebuilt after five years and with a new name. The former Anastasio Somoza Garcia Stadium is now called Rigoberto Lopez Perez Stadium, after the poet who assassinated the founder of the Somoza family dynasty in 1956.    Virtually every other aspect of Nicaragua's favorite sport is undergoing a similar transformation these days. Although fans here continue to follow the game with the same intensity and passion as ever, the Sandinista leadership is seeking to put its own distinctive stamp on Nicaraguan baseball.

headline: Rebels in Sri Lanka Shoot Four as 'Traitors'
abstract: Separatist guerrillas have killed four youths who they said betrayed the Tamil cause, the radio reported today.

headline: ANTI-SANDINISTAS' DIFFERENCES CLOUD TALKS ON UNITED FRONT
abstract: Unity among Nicaraguan rebel groups, which the Reagan Administration is reportedly considering encouraging, might be difficult to achieve because of persistent political differences and personal animosities, according to representatives of groups gathered in the Miami area.    Principal rebel leaders, in Miami for the last several days, are said to be making preliminary contacts to begin unity discussions, possibly next week. But according to one rebel source, many obstacles have to be overcome ''to be able to start seriously talking about unity talks.''

headline: Poland Bars Solidarity Exile
abstract: Poland today barred the return of Seweryn Blumsztajn, a former Solidarity official. He was told that his Polish passport was no longer valid and was put back on the Air France flight on which he had arrived. Mr. Blumsztajn was in Paris in late 1981, when martial law was declared in Poland, and has been an exile here since then.

headline: Turkey Recalls Its Envoy to Bulgaria
abstract: Turkey is recalling its ambassador from Sofia for consultations about Bulgaria's ethnic Turkish minority, the state radio said today.

headline: Orders Rise in Canada
abstract: Orders received by Canadian manufacturers rose 3.5 percent in November, to the equivalent of $14.7 billion in American money, from October's $14.2 billion, the Government said today.

headline: Toshiba's 2d U.S. Plant
abstract: The Toshiba Corporation plans to set up a second semiconductor factory in the United States in 1987 to produce microprocessors and advanced memories, the Japanese company said today. The site and other details will depend on the results of a current study.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Interest Rates Move Down;    Money Falls $2.1 Billion
abstract: Short- and long-term interest rates fell yesterday as traders were encouraged by signs of slower than expected growth in the economy and the nation's money supply.     Prices rose and yields fell in all sectors of the Treasury market early in the day after the Commerce Department estimated that the economy will expand, after inflation, at a 2.1 percent rate in the current quarter. Rates declined further late in the day after the Federal Reserve announced an unexpectedly large $2.1 billion decline in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended March 11.    By late in the day, rates on Treasury bills were down by an eighth of a percentage point and more, with the three-month issue bid at 8.43 percent, down from 8.55 percent and the one- year issue bid at 8.95 percent, down from 9.16 percent. Yields also declined in the note and bond market, with the bellwether 11 1/4 percent Treasury bonds due in 2015 offered late in the day at 96 1/8, up almost 3/4 point, to yield 11.71 percent, down from 11.81 percent.

headline: Article 020906 -- No Title
abstract: People Express Airlines yesterday reported a $9 million fourth-quarter loss that exceeded analysts' expectations and reflected the strain on the low-cost carrier of its rapid expansion.    The net loss was after a gain of $13.5 million from the sale of a Boeing 747 plane. In the fourth quarter of 1983, People Express had a net income of $1.3 million, or 7 cents a share.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Chief Financial Posts Filled by Convergent
abstract: Convergent Technologies Inc., the financially troubled computer company that replaced its chief executive two months ago, yesterday named John M. Russell as its chief financial officer.   Mr. Russell, 42, will also have the title of vice president-finance. He replaces E. Joseph Willits, 57, who had held the posts since July and is leaving ''to pursue other business interests,'' the company said.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Interest Rates Increase Again
abstract: Short- and long-term interest rates rose for the third consecutive day, as securities dealers prepared for next week's heavy supply of new Treasury issues and a Federal Reserve monetary policy that seems to be less generous than early last month.    Rates on Treasury bills and other securities due in less than a year, which have risen for the last five days, were up by as much as 1/8 percentage point. The three-month Treasury bill, for example, was bid at 8.21 percent, up from 8.09 percent a day earlier and 7.62 percent as recently as early Monday.

headline: ELECTION RESULTS SHOW WEAK SPOTS IN GANDHI PARTY'S ARMOR
abstract: For a few months, a glow of near-invincibility seemed to surround Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. His promises to revamp industry, eliminate corruption and forge a new national unity stirred hope even among the cynical in India.  But this week, the results of the latest parliamentary election brought India back to some familiar realities. Instead of the 80 percent electoral sweep he scored in December, Mr. Gandhi and the Congress (I) Party won 57 percent of the seats at stake in state legislative elections that were held in 11 of India's 21 states and one union territory.    More sobering was the fact that the party failed to make inroads in the opposition areas of Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh, where two charismatic Chief Ministers are now in an improved position to challenge Mr. Gandhi. The party also fell sharply behind its 1980 showing in the heavily industrial state of Maharashtra and even in Uttar Pradesh, in the Hindi- speaking heartland that has long been its power base.

headline: PATENTS;  Meat Calibrator
abstract: A device for the automatic calibration of meat, such as the proportion of fat it contains, is disclosed in patent 4,504,963, issued this week to Lloyd D. Johnson of Davenport, Iowa. The process described includes sending X-rays through two standard samples of meat and the unknown sample being calibrated, and examining the detected radiation. The weight proportion of fat in the sample is then calculated and displayed.

headline: THE DISASTER IN BHOPAL: WORKERS RECALL HORROR
abstract: About 12:40 A.M. on Dec. 3, a worker at the Union Carbide pesticide plant here went to investigate a growing leak of methyl isocyanate. As he stood on a concrete slab above three large, partly buried storage tanks holding the chemical, the slab suddenly began to shake beneath him.  ''There was a tremendous sound, a messy boiling sound, underneath the slab, like a caldron,'' the worker, Suman Dey, later recalled.  ''The whole slab was vibrating.'' He said he started to run away, heard a loud noise behind him, turned to look and saw 60 feet of concrete at least 6 inches thick crack. ''The heat was like a blast furnace,'' he said. ''I couldn't get within six feet of it.''

headline: Stock Proposal Study
abstract: The public policy committee of the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it was seeking public comment on a proposal to allow listed companies to create a second class of common stock with disproportionate voting rights. An exchange subcommittee made the proposal on Jan. 3. If the committee approves after receiving the public's comment, the proposal would still need the approval of the exchange's board and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: NEW A.T.&T. COMPUTER PUSH
abstract: After a rocky entry into the computer business last year, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is looking to a new organization, a new leader and - later this month - a distinctive new personal computer as it struggles to compete with the International Business Machines Corporation.     A.T.&T. has long been regarded as a major contender in the computer market, because of its unparalleled telecommunications experience, its innovative Bell Laboratories and its hefty wallet. But A.T.&T. executives interviewed last week conceded that in its first year, the drive to challenge I.B.M. on its own turf largely failed. Only now, they say, is the company overcoming the internal chaos caused by A.T.&T.'s split-up and misdirected marketing strategies.    ''I can't say that our execution last year met the expectations of outsiders, or even ourselves,'' said James D. Edwards, the energetic former I.B.M. strategist who was installed as president of the computer systems group last October as part of a broader effort to bring order to A.T.&T.'s twice-reorganized Informations Systems group. ''But I think that our product plans are finally coming together.''

headline: Sinclair Computer
abstract: Sinclair Research Ltd. said it planned to re-enter the North American market in May with mail-order sales of its QL microcomputer through its Boston- based subsidiary, Sinclair Research Inc. The QL will be offered at a basic price of $499. The company declined to say how many units it hoped to sell in a year. Sinclair ended an arrangement with Timex Inc. last February in which Timex marketed a repackaged version of Sinclair's Spectrum microcomputer in the United States.

headline: ATTRACTING THE RESEARCH DOLLAR
abstract: Hard-pressed for funds and eager to support more research, scores of universities around the country are developing corporate research parks in their backyards.    Yale, the University of Missouri at Kansas City and the Polytechnic Institute of New York are among those following the successful lead of Princeton University, with its Forrestal Center, and Stanford University, with its Research Park.   Douglas R. Porter, associate director for research at the Urban Land Institute, a private consulting group based in Washington, said 31 universities were now actively engaged in developing research parks. Fifteen or so more, he said, are in the ''initial investigation phase,'' while another dozen or two ''are being very quiet about their plans or thinking to themselves.''

headline: Briefcases
abstract: - William C. Triplett 2d, an expert on China and Japan, has left the Office of the United States Trade Representative to join the Senate Foreign Relations Committee as a Far Eastern specialist.      - Darwin G. Johnson has quit as chief of the fiscal analysis branch of the budget review division in the Office of Management and Budget to join De Seve Economics Associates as vice president.

headline: ARGENTINA DENIES POLICY SHIFT
abstract: The shake-up of Argentina's economic team this week does not signal a change in Argentina's approach to its economic troubles, according to President Raul Alfonsin.    After swearing in Juan Sourrouille as successor to Economics Minister Bernardo Grinspun Tuesday evening, Mr. Alfonsin told reporters that ''the economic conception of Sourrouille is the same as that of Grinspun.''   Mr. Sourrouille, a 44-year-old former Planning Secretary, immediately promised new measures to address the problem that has plagued the Alfonsin administration since it took office 14 months ago: how to recover economic growth at the same time as combating inflation.   But he added, ''There is only one economic plan, which is the Government's plan.''

headline: Workers Vote At Frontier Four of the unions at Frontier Airlines have agreed to let
abstract: their members vote on a tentative agreement to give the   money-losing carrier $30 million in concessions this year   and possibly buy the airline for  $220.4 million.  Brian Freeman, one of the   advisers to the unions in setting   up an employee stock ownership plan, said in an interview   yesterday that union leaders   and airline management had   agreed Saturday to submit the   plan to the workers.

headline: Rates Increase At Citicorp Sale
abstract: Interest rates rose at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper, the bank holding company announced yesterday.    For $100 million of 91-day paper, the average rate was 8.814 percent, up from 8.601 percent at last week's auction. For $50 million of 182-day paper, the average rate was 9.15 percent, up from 8.767 percent.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Pennsylvania Sells $102 Million in Bonds
abstract: The State of Pennsylvania yesterday sold $102 million worth of general obligation bonds at competitive bid.

headline: Frontier Backs Buyout Talks
abstract: The board of directors of Frontier Holdings Inc. yesterday authorized discussions that could lead to the acquisition of Frontier Airlines by Frontier employees and four investment groups.    Spokesmen for Frontier Holdings, which is the parent of the airline, and the investment group called the decision a significant advance.

headline: Harvester Reports Loss
abstract: The International Harvester Company, which ended more than 150 years of agricultural equipment manufacture last month, today reported a net loss of $534 million for the latest quarter. All the loss resulted from the discontinued operations.    Continuing businesses, primarily the manufacture of trucks and diesel engines, earned $42 million, after a $20 million tax benefit.

headline: JAPAN CALM ABOUT YEN'S FALL
abstract: Although the dollar's strength has caused widespread concern in the United States, inflaming protectionist sentiments and draining corporate profits, the reaction is very different on this side of the Pacific.    The dollar reached as high as 263.75 yen in trading last week. It closed today in Tokyo at 256.55, down from Friday's close of 259.20.    (The dollar opened higher in Tokyo Tuesday morning, at 260.45 yen, The Associated Press said.)

headline: Egyptians and Israelis Talk Again on Land Issue
abstract: The second day of Egyptian-Israeli talks about a disputed border ended without agreement today.   The parties, meeting in Beersheba, Israel, adjourned to draft new position papers defining areas of agreement and disagreement in preparation for the final round of talks on Tuesday.   Discussions centered on proposals to deploy the so-called ''multinational force and observers'' in the disputed 750-yard strip at Taba on the coast of the Gulf of Aqaba, where the Israelis remained when they withdrew from Sinai in l982.

headline: REAGAN NAMES THREE DELEGATES TO ARMS TALKS
abstract: President Reagan today named Max M. Kampelman, a Washington lawyer with political and diplomatic experience, to head the United States delegation to the new three-part arms-control talks with the Soviet Union.   In an announcement read at the White House by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, the President said that in addition to serving as the overall chairman of the delegation, Mr. Kampelman would also head the separate group discussing space weapons.   Under the agreement reached by Mr. Shultz with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko last week in Geneva, the two sides agreed to hold talks on space weapons, strategic arms and medium- range missiles.         Rowny Is Replaced      In a move that caught arms-control officials by surprise, Mr. Reagan named John G. Tower, the former Republican Senator from Texas, to replace Edward L. Rowny as head of the group dealing with strategic arms.

headline: U.S. AIDE TO VISIT MIDEAST FOR TALKS
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States would send the State Department's top Middle East official to the region later this month ''to maintain momentum toward peace in the Middle East.''    But in a news conference, Mr. Shultz again rebuffed the specific proposal made this week to President Reagan by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt that the United States invite a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation to Washington as a possible first step toward eventual negotiations with Israel.   ''Mr. Mubarak's suggestion is one suggestion,'' he said. ''There are others.'' The Reagan Administration has said it wants direct talks and is wary of such preliminary discussions getting in the way of actual negotiations.

headline: Gannett Profit Climbs 22.5%
abstract: The Gannett Company, which publishes 85 daily newspapers, said today that its profit rose 22.5 percent in the fourth quarter, to $74.5 million, or 93 cents a share, from $60.8 million, or 76 cents a share, a year earlier.   The company, which also owns 6 television and 16 radio stations, said revenue rose 19.5 percent, to $570.1 million, from $477.1 million a year earlier, Gannett said.

headline: BANKS REVIEW SECRECY COMPLIANCE
abstract: The First National Bank of Boston's guilty plea two weeks ago to charges that it did not properly report international currency transfers has spurred other major banks to scrutinize their procedures for complying with Federal bank secrecy regulations, officials said yesterday.     Compliance with the Bank Secrecy Act, enacted 15 years ago, is generally acknowledged to be spotty.    A Justice Department report in October 1983 said the law had failed to achieve its purpose. ''Reporting requirements were not fully implemented, and they were rarely invoked,'' the report said. ''Therefore, violations were seldom detected and much less often prosecuted.''

headline: Dexter Acquisition
abstract: The Dexter Corporation, a specialty chemicals concern, said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Permag Corporation for about 1.2 million common shares. Dexter stock closed at $20 today, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Permag fabricates and distributes magnetic materials and had 1984 sales of about $30 million.

headline: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ROBERTSHAW CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP (IBM)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **
