headline: MICOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FORMASTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Tribune Company
abstract: The Tribune Company, wary of unfriendly takeover attempts, is seeking permission from shareholders to triple the number of its authorized common shares, to 150 million. A proxy statement, to be voted on at the annual meeting in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on May 2, said the additional stock could be used to ''impede a takeover or to make a change in the control of the company more difficult.'' There have been no reports of attempts to take over the company, which owns The Chicago Tribune, The Daily News in New York, radio and television stations and the Chicago Cubs baseball team.

headline: 2d Southland Trial Opens The second trial in the Southland Corporation case opened yesterday, with two top executives of the company accused of conspiring to pay New York State tax officials to fix sales tax cases.
abstract: Defense lawyers told the jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn that their clients were victims of a ''litany of lies'' concocted by a former Southland vice president who had embezzled large sums.   In the first trial, Southland was convicted of having conspired to defraud the Internal Revenue Service by falsely claiming that $96,500 it paid in 1977 to facilitate the bribery scheme had been a deductible fee.

headline: 2 Southeast Banks In Merger Accord
abstract: In an action clouded by uncertainty over the legality of interstate banking mergers, the Citizens and Southern Georgia Corporation and Landmark Banking Corporation of Florida said yesterday that they had agreed to merge. However, the companies said that they had temporarily halted the transaction to resolve ''certain accounting issues.''     Citizens and Southern, the largest bank holding company in Georgia, said in a statement from its Atlanta headquarters that, ''except for the accounting issues, which C.&S. and its professional advisers continue to pursue, we emphasize that there is complete agreement on all issues between the two companies and their boards of directors.''

headline: POLISH SEEMINGLY IMPLIES A SOVIET LINK TO SLAYING OF PRIEST
abstract: A lawyer for the family of a slain pro-Solidarity priest seemed to imply today that Moscow had ''an interest'' in what he called the politically provocative murder.   ''Who could have had an interest?'' the lawyer, Jan Olszewski, said after depicting the slaying as a ''fuse'' intended to rekindle social unrest in Poland. ''I do not see in this any Polish interest since, if it suceeded, it would have made Poland a land of misery, despair and terror.   ''International relations tolerate no vacuums, and something that leads to weakness in one country is the strength of another. Every schoolchild with a thorough grounding in history knows who would profit from a weak Poland.''

headline: NEW BRANDS CITED
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company reported today that its earnings dropped 36 percent for the quarter ended Dec. 31, largely because of the cost of introducing new brands and of making improvements in its Pampers disposable diaper line.   The Cincinnati-based consumer products company announced that it earned $137 million for the quarter, down from $214 million in the comparable quarter of 1983. Earnings per share dropped to 81 cents, from $1.29.

headline: BONN TO CUT STAKE IN 10 COMPANIES
abstract: The West German Government today approved plans to cut the Government's stake in 10 state-controlled companies, including Lufthansa, the national airline, and Volkswagen, the country's largest auto maker.    While the Government would still have investments in nearly 900 companies, the move marks a drastic break with the traditional postwar German industrial policy of direct involvement in business. It is also the first time a European government, outside Britain, has embarked on such an undertaking.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 27, 1985        Companies         General Electric was indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges that it falsified claims and lied to the Federal Government about work done on a nuclear warhead system. A G.E. spokesman denied the company or any employees had committed any criminal wrongdoing. (Page A1.) Military contracts at G.E. represent nearly a fifth of its $28.9 billion in revenues for 1984. (D9.)         A.T.&T. introduced a personal computer relying on the company's expertise in communications. The machine joins the ranks of new computers competing with I.B.M.'s PC-AT. (D5.)

headline: BUNDLING THE MILITARY BUDGET
abstract: RARELY has any industry enjoyed a better operating environment than the nation's military contractors do today. Not since the Vietnam War has there been such heavy demand for weapons. The Reagan Adminstration has been progressively increasing budgets for military hardware since it arrived in Washington four years ago, and the Pentagon, for its part, has been working overtime to help contractors overcome their reputation for gross industrial backwardness and woefully inefficient production.     Yet, after four years of Pentagon nurturing and Reagan Administration budgetary largess, a dizzying procession of highly publicized cost and quality fiascos has left the industry's image more tarnished than ever. Why, critics ask, can't the industry find a way to remedy its mistakes and stop wasting billions of taxpayer dollars?    There is a litany of woes. The explosion earlier this month of a Pershing 2 missile in West Germany, which killed three American soldiers when its motor caught fire, shocked Europe. Eight governmental units are investigating the Navy's nuclear submarine building program, looking into allegations of multi-million dollar abuse. Other inquiries are focusing on possible illegal overcharges at Ford Aerospace and kickbacks at Hughes Aircraft. The armed services are rejecting shoddy products from military contractors at an unprecedented rate, including fighter jets from McDonnell Douglas, missiles from Hughes Aircraft and semiconductors from Texas Instruments. And cost increases and cost overruns persist, with inflation in the defense sector running 2 percentage points above the overall inflation rate.

headline: Market Place;   LIFO Index And Retailers
abstract: AFTER a tough year, America's retailers have finally got a break. The Government's recently released LIFO department-store price index, on which retailers base their year's inventory evaluation, has come in at the lowest level in at least six years.    This means that, since companies adjust the cost of their inventories based on the inflation rate reported by the Government at year-end, their earnings improve if the inflation rate is lower than expected. In the year just ended, the LIFO index for retailing came in much lower than generally expected. As a result, many retail companies in the next few weeks will report higher income in the final quarter than they expected and probably have to pay less taxes.

headline: NEW ZEALAND REBUFF: A BAFFLING FUROR
abstract: New Zealand's armed forces have fewer than 12,700 men; its navy consists of four frigates, six patrol boats and seven helicopters. Moreover, the Soviet Union has no vital interest in the Southwest Pacific and has paid little attention of any kind to the region.  Yet in the last few days United States officials have treated a refusal by New Zealand's Prime Minister, David Lange, to permit a port visit by an American destroyer as a major foreign policy crisis, as a matter of ''grave concern,'' and an event meriting possible economic retaliation against New Zealand's lamb, wool and butter exports.     The vehemence displayed by Reagan Administration officials has directed international attention to the issue just as Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia - the third partner in what is known as the Anzus alliance - arrived in Washington for a state visit.

headline: SELECTING ZERO-COUPON MUNICIPALS
abstract: Most of the zero-coupon bonds sold to individuals are backed by Treasury securities and their payoff is taxable, unless the bonds are used as investments in tax-exempt Individual Retirement Accounts, as many of them are.  Lately, however, zeros backed by tax-free municipal bonds are also gaining popularity, particularly among people in high-tax brackets.In fact tax-free municipals have become one of the hottest investments around as the prospect of tax simplification prompts the wealthy to replace the tax shelters they would ordinarily buy.   Some $1 billion face amount of zero coupon municipals has been sold in the last six months alone, said Stephen D. Leightman, national sales manager for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.  ''I would expect this year to be busier than last year,'' he added.

headline: Norfolk Rail Debt Ratings By Reuters Debt ratings for the Norfolk
abstract: Southern Corporation's subsidiary railroad companies   may be reduced if the company   buys Conrail, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday. Last Friday the United   States Department of Transportation said it had selected   Norfolk Southern as the buyer   of Conrail.

headline: Stock Rally Abates; Dow Off 9.05 Points
abstract: The stock market ended its winning streak yesterday, with prices falling across-the-board.   Analysts, while still bullish, blamed rising interest rates, some softness in the economy and profit taking after January's sharp run-up in stock prices.    The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks closed at 1,277.72, off 9.05 points for the day and up 1.66 points for the week. Last week, the Dow climbed 48.70 points.

headline: Finance Company Increases Offering
abstract: The International Lease Finance Corporation offered $75 million of four-year notes, an increase from $50 million.

headline: Deficit Up 14.4% in Quarter
abstract: The Federal Government spent $15.2 billion more than it collected in December, making the deficit for the first three months of the 1985 fiscal year 14.4 percent worse than a year earlier, the Treasury Department said today.   In the first quarter of the fiscal year, which began on Oct. 1, spending outpaced revenues by $72.4 billion.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: American Motors
abstract: The American Motors Corporation said it would lay off 4,500 hourly workers at its Kenosha, Wis., assembly plant for two weeks, effective Monday.

headline: A Stake in Scovill
abstract: A group of companies controlled by Ivan F. Boesky, the New York investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had bought 903,700 shares of Scovill Inc., or 7.4 percent of the total outstanding.

headline: SYRIANS WARN RIVALS OF GEMAYEL
abstract: Syria today warned Christian militiamen who are in revolt against President Amin Gemayel's pro-Damascus policies that it would not tolerate the rebellion.    At the same time, the rebels expanded their control over the main Christian areas of Lebanon.    Samir Geagea, the pro-Israeli commander of the major fighting units in the Lebanese Forces, the nation's largest Christian militia, seized control of major Christian communities north of Beirut in an overnight sweep Tuesday.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, MARCH 15, 1985        Companies         Coastal agreed to buy American Natural Resources and pledged not to break up the company or move its headquarters. The merger is valued at about $2.5 billion and will make Coastal one of the nation's largest gas distribution networks. (Page D1.)         The Washington Post Co. plans to buy 17 percent of Cowles Media of Minneapolis. Analysts said the Post might eventually take control of the newspaper company and its main asset, The Minneapolis Star and Tribune. Terms were not disclosed, but several analysts said the Post probably agreed to pay $53 million or more.  (D5.) The Minneapolis newspaper has endured a series of crises in the last three years. (D5.)

headline: REGULATION OF AUDITORS DEFENDED
abstract: John S. R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, defended the agency's oversight of the accounting profession today before members of a Congressional subcommittee who warned that S.E.C. actions to date were lax and invited legislative action.    Mr. Shad, testifying before the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, said alleged audit failures amounted to less than 1 percent of audits conducted each year on publicly held companies. He added that commission enforcement actions against auditors last year reached a record 18, with even more expected this year.

headline: IRAQ SAYS IT BOMBED TEHRAN
abstract: Iraq said today that its warplanes had bombed Teheran and several other Iranian cities, ''scoring crushing hits.''   At the same time both sides, in annnouncements monitored here, claimed victory in a battle for control of the highway linking Baghdad and Basra, the strategic southern Iraqi port.

headline: Tidewater Rejects Bid From Jacobs
abstract: The board of Tidewater Inc. has rejected a buyout offer of $415 million from an investment group headed by Irwin L. Jacobs of Minneapolis, saying the offer of $25 to $28 a share was too low.   Tidewater's three main businesses are all related to petroleum and have suffered in the slump of the offshore oil and gas industry.

headline: A Less Drastic Budget Cut
abstract: Soon after President Reagan appointed Terrence M. Scanlon to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission, the new chairman was able to get the Administration to back away from large cuts it planned in the commission's budget.    The elevation of Mr. Scanlon, a Democrat who has been a commissioner since March 1983, was not a surprise since he has more closely followed the Administration's deregulatory impulses than some commission Republicans.

headline: Conrail's Net Drops
abstract: The Consolidated Rail Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter net income fell 23.8 percent, to $89.6 million, from $117.5 million a year ago. Revenues dropped 2 percent, to $$791.9 million, from $808.1 million.

headline: TURNAROUND ARTIST ON THE LOOSE
abstract: LONDON MOVE quickly. That is the first commandment according to Sir Michael Edwardes, Britain's best-known doctor for ailing corporations. It is important to act before a situation ''solidifies around you,'' he explained in an interview last month. ''You really only have a matter of months to set the direction.''    But even for Sir Michael, the recent pace has been unusually rapid. He had scarcely settled in as chairman of International Computers Ltd., Britain's largest computer maker, when that company was taken over last summer. Sir Michael was soon appointed chairman of Dunlop, the troubled tire and sporting goods manufacturer, but by early this month he had received a takeover offer from BTR, a rapidly expanding industrial conglomerate, that was too good to refuse.   With Dunlop sold, no one expects the 54-year-old Sir Michael to continue nursing the company much longer, even though his employment contract has more than two years to run. Speculation is widespread that he will soon succeed Ian MacGregor as head of Britain's strike-weakened National Coal Board, despite Sir Michael's public denial of reports that he has discussed the job with Government representatives and Coal Board officials. Through his closest advisers he has let it be known that he would be more interested in private-sector employment.

headline: Saatchi-Infocom
abstract: Usually the acquisition of an audio- visual concern in England, even if it is the country's largest, would not rate coverage in these quarters. However, when the buyer is Saatchi & Saatchi, the great absorber, Madison Avenue is all ears. The acquired company is the Infocom Group, for which S.&S. said it is paying $1.3 million cash.

headline: Corporate Offerings Remain Scanty
abstract: The schedule of corporate debt offerings continues thin, in line with the fall-off in business at the turn of the year. But the flow of tax-exempt issues remains steady.

headline: AUSTRALIA BALKS ON ACCORD TO AID IN U.S. TEST OF MX
abstract: Australia's Prime Minister said today that he had told the United States that because of a revolt in his own party, he would probably have to renege on a pledge to allow American planes to use Australian bases to monitor an MX missile test.   As a result of this unexpected disclosure, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said this afternoon that the United States had decided to monitor the test of the latest American intercontinental ballistic missile ''without the use of Australian support arrangements.''        Split in Party Cited    Prime Minister Robert Hawke apparently startled American officials when he told them on his arrival here Tuesday night and again today that he would have to cancel the agreement to provide Australian base facilities for American surveillance planes because of a split within his governing Labor Party.   Australia, New Zealand and the United States are members of a 34-year old South Pacific alliance known as Anzus.    Australia's unwillingness to associate with the testing of the missile coin cided with a decision by New Zealand's Prime Minister, David Lange, not to permit an American warship to pay a port call to his country because of his Labor Party Government's antinu clear policy. As a result of that decision, the United States and Australia canceled naval exercises scheduled to take place with New Zealand next month off Australia.

headline: CONFESSIONS DENIED IN OSLO TRIAL
abstract: A former Norwegian diplomat accused of spying for the Soviet Union and Iraq asserted today that the confessions disclosed Monday by the State Prosecutor at the opening of his trial here were false.   Speaking for the first time in an outline of his view of the charges against him, the former diplomat, Arne Treholt, described the first days after his arrest 13 months ago as a ''Kafkaesque'' nightmare of endless questioning and isolation that led him to make up numerous responses.   ''I felt that the world had collapsed under me,'' Mr. Treholt told the seven judges. ''Sadness, desperation, pain and depression affected my condition during the first weeks of questioning at the Oslo police station.''

headline: QUARTERLY PROFITS HURT BY DOLLAR
abstract: Solid economic growth continued to bolster corporate profits in the fourth quarter, but the rising dollar on currency markets took a toll on profits in industries that depend on exports or compete significantly with imports.   Over all, after-tax earnings probably were about the same in the fourth quarter as in the third quarter, after adjusting for seasonal differences. But they were still high by historical levels, not much below the record set in the first quarter of 1984 when the economy was roaring at an annual growth rate of more than 10 percent.    According to a compilation by The New York Times of fourth-quarter earnings reports from 247 companies, 129 corporations showed improved profits compared with the same period the previous year (including 13 that were in the red in the 1983 period), 72 showed a decline in profits, 3 were unchanged and 35 posted a loss. No comparison could be made for 8 concerns.

headline: Mattel Weighs Bid for Parker The president of Mattel
abstract: U.S.A. said it was considering acquiring Parker Brothers, a move that would join two of the nation's biggest names in toymaking.  ''We are interested in Parker Brothers, and we are looking it over and studying it,'' said Thomas J. Kalinske, president of the domestic division of Mattel Inc., based in Hawthorne, Calif.

headline: Canada Opposes A-Arms
abstract: Canada has no plans to station nuclear weapons on its soil and will not let the United States do so without its prior approval, External Affairs Minister Joe Clark said today.

headline: Austrian Official Wins A No-Confidence Vote
abstract: Defense Minister Friedhelm Frischenschlager, who greeted a war criminal released by Italy with a handshake last week, survived a no-confidence vote in a special session of Parliament today.   The vote put an end to Government action, but it may not diminish the public unease over the case involving the Nazi war criminal Walter Reder, a former major in the SS.

headline: RUSSIANS SEEK TO HALT DECLINE IN OIL PRODUCTION
abstract: A potentially serious decline in Soviet oil production that began in 1983 has accelerated this year, causing concern in the Kremlin leadership.    The Minister of the Petroleum Industry has been dismissed and, according to Soviet press reports, a top member of the Soviet leadership has called for tighter organization and management in the distant West Siberian oilfields, which now yield more than 60 percent of Soviet oil.   The oil industry is a key sector of the Soviet economy. In addition to meeting domestic needs, it is the principal source of exports, earning the foreign exchange needed for Soviet purchases of Western grain and advanced industrial equipment.

headline: Budget Official Resigns
abstract: The Office of Management and Budget today announced the resignation of its chief economist, J. Gregory Ballentine, effective at the end of January. Mr. Ballentine joined the budget office in September 1983 after serving at the Treasury Department as a deputy assistant secretary for tax policy.

headline: A.N.R. QUESTIONS CONNALLY TRADING
abstract: The American Natural Resources Company of Detroit, the big gas pipeline operator, yesterday accused John B. Connally, a former Secretary of the Treasury, of buying stock in the company at a time a ''good friend'' was trying to take it over.     American further charged that the good friend, Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., and the Coastal Corporation, of which Mr. Wyatt is chairman, ''tipped'' Mr. Connally and others it did not identify to buy American shares before the takeover began.    By such tips, the suit maintained, Mr. Connally and others ''were put into the position of being able to make a profit by the use of such nonpublic information.''    On March 1, Mr. Wyatt offered to pay $60 a share for American, or $2.3 billion in cash.

headline: Stocks Are Mixed; Dow Falls 4.20
abstract: Wall Street stocks rallied yesterday morning after President Reagan delivered an optimistic speech to traders at the New York Stock Exchange, but the euphoria wore off by the close and prices finished the day mixed.    The Dow Jones industrial average, which was ahead 6 points after the first hour and by more than 5 points at noon, finished the session down 4.20 points, to 1,260.71.   Volume was again below 100 million shares, at 99.8 million, compared with Wednesday's 101 million.

headline: PROSPECTS;  Sluggish Retail Sales
abstract: On Friday, the Government will report the retail sales figures for February. At least one forecaster, Money Market Services Inc., of Belmont, Calif., expects only a one-tenth of 1 percent improvement from January.

headline: Time Goes Outside For Promotion Chief
abstract: For the first time, one of the magazines of Time Inc. has gone outside the corporation and hired a promotion director from the creative department of an ad agency.    The magazine is Time, and Katherine Erskine, 35 years old, is the choice as worldwide promotion director.

headline: People
abstract: *       Robert Lilley has been named senior vice president, director of media operations and network programming at SSC&B:Lintas USA.     *       Paul Carlucci has been appointed senior vice president for advertising at Bamberger's.

headline: E.D.S. to Set Up Network for G.M.
abstract: The General Motors Corporation's Electronic Data Systems subsidiary said it would set up a global telecommunication network in an effort to reduce G.M.'s communications costs and to give the automaker more control over its communications functions.   E.D.S. said it would operate a system incorporating the ''latest technological advances in digital switching systems and fiber optic cable'' with 14 G.M. sites in Flint, Mich., among the first to be connected by the end of March. An E.D.S. spokesman declined to give the cost of the project but said the system could eventually link 250,000 phones in the United States.

headline: Thrift Unit Recovery Plan
abstract: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it intended to cut its total assets by about $5.5 billion, to $24.5 billion, by the end of 1985 as part of a detailed plan to recover from its brush with failure last August.   William J. Popejoy, Financial's chairman, indicated that the disposal of the assets depended on interest rates remaining at levels where Financial can sell billions of dollars worth of mortgages and mortgage- backed certificates at a profit.

headline: Military Buildup
abstract: To the Editor:      In ''Bungling the Military Buildup'' (Jan. 27), you say that there is a quality problem with certain of Texas Instruments' military semiconductor components. This is incorrect.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, MARCH 22, 1985
abstract: The Economy         The economy is growing at a sluggish 2.1 percent annual rate in the first quarter, the Commerce Department said in its ''flash'' estimate. That is less than half the rate of the fourth quarter, which was revised downward to 4.3 percent, from the 4.9 percent reported earlier. Analysts said intense international competition hampered growth, as domestic demand was filled more and more by imports. They were particularly surprised by a sharp rise in a gauge of inflation. It spurted to an annual rate of 5.4 percent from the fourth quarter's 2.8 percent, but special factors magnified the change. (Page A1.)         President Reagan said he was willing to discuss a compromise on the budget with Senate Republican leaders. (A1.)

headline: ICAHN STILL WINNING
abstract: Carl C. Icahn once confided to an acquaintance: ''Chess was one thing I was really good at. I could have been a master or something, but there was no future in it.''     If the game failed him on that score, the predatory skills he honed over a chess board have served him well elsewhere. Mr. Icahn, who is 48 years old, has scored more corporate checkmates than just about any other takeover specialist. With his bid yesterday for Phillips Petroleum, he is now stalking his first multibillion-dollar prey.

headline: Levy Agency Sets Up Marketing Subsidiaries
abstract: Levy, Flaxman & Associates, billing not quite $20 million, is acting like an agency 10 times its size - establishing subsidiaries in other disciplines of the marketing game.

headline: Freeze Cost $253 Million
abstract: Florida citrus growers suffered almost $128 million in fruit losses and $125 million in costs of harvesting, hauling, packing and processing damaged fruit in the January freeze, a University of Florida researcher estimates. The $253 million figure compares with an estimated loss of $692 million that resulted from freezing weather in 1983, Evan Drummond of the university's food and resource economics department said Friday.

headline: SILICON VALLEY WAITS FOR RELIEF
abstract: The sales revival that Silicon Valley's chip makers have been waiting for appears to be several months away. As things are going, the computer chip manufacturers probably will do no better this year than match last year's production, industry analysts say.    The Intel Corporation, one of Silicon Valley's premier companies, underscored the seriousness of the industry's troubles when it announced today that its first-quarter sales are likely to run as much as 15 percent below the $431 million it registered in       the fourth quarter.    Gordon E. Moore, chairman and chief executive, said that even with recent cost-cutting moves, ''it appears first-quarter net income could be near break-even.'' He did say, though, that demand had nearly hit bottom, and ''some strengthening'' is likely next quarter.

headline: No Headline
abstract: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1985      The Economy      President Reagan offered an agenda of tax revision, economic growth and an elimination of the threat of nuclear war in a State of the Union Message marked by an evocation of hope and optimism. (Page A1.) He urged Congress to pass a tax simplification plan, calling it ''a giant step toward unleashing the tremendous pent-up power of our economy.'' (B9.)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Bank of America , San Francisco, said John A. Farnsworth had been appointed director of its nationwide private banking activities.     *       Cirrus Logic Inc. , Milpitas, Calif. a maker of integrated circuits, announced that Michael L. Hackworth had been named president and chief executive officer.

headline: TURNOUT IS MODERATE IN PAKISTAN'S ELECTIONS
abstract: Pakistanis voted in moderate numbers today in a parliamentary election that opposition leaders had hoped would produce a nationwide boycott.   Random checks of polling places by journalists indicated that the voting patterns varied, with some districts reporting a turnout below 20 percent and others well over 50 percent.    It thus appeared that the political opposition to President Zia ul-Haq had fallen short of its goal of keeping the turnout below 10 percent.    General Zia, who has said he would be satisfied with a turnout of 40 percent, has promised that, with the election of a National Assembly and of provincial assemblies, he would relinquish some of his powers and eventually lift martial law, which he imposed in 1977 when he took power in a coup.

headline: A Ford Merger In South Africa
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said that it agreed in principle to merge its South African operations with the Anglo American Corporation, the South African conglomerate, with Ford becoming the minority owner of a new company called the South African Motor Corporation. Both companies said the timetable for the merger had not been worked out.

headline: PRETORIA'S NEW TIES WITH BLACK NEIGHBORS SOUR
abstract: In marked contrast to a euphoric mood in this region less than a year ago, South Africa's relations with neighboring black-governed nations appears to have soured.     Its pacts with these ideological foes, hailed at the time as a breakthrough in regional diplomacy, seem to have brought few and ambiguous benefits to those nations with which South Africa concluded the accords.    In the last week, Angola, Botswana and Zambia have complained in varying degrees of what they say is South African aggressiveness, and South Africa has responded caustically to some of the complaints.   Reports from Mozambique, meanwhile, indicate there has been a widening of an insurgency that the Marxist authorities in Maputo hoped to end by signing a nonaggression pact with South Africa last March. On Tuesday, for the first time, a ranking Mozambican official directly accused South Africa of flouting the accord.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: March 13, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Special Committee on the Charter - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: PATENTS;  Rotary Turbo-Engine
abstract: A rotary turbo-engine with supercharger was patented this week by Joachim E. Lay of East Lansing, Mich., a professor of mechanical engineering at Michigan State University. He describes the invention covered by patent 4,504,196 as a simplification and streamlining of his three earlier rotary engine designs. Professor Lay explained that a supercharger makes sufficient use of the power left in the exhaust gases to force-feed the engine.

headline: WALL ST. WORRIES OVER INSIDER LEAKS
abstract: Some Wall Street executives are expressing a growing concern that the wave of corporate mergers in recent years has spawned a pattern of illegal insider trading in stocks of companies that receive takeover bids. Such trading, it is believed, has reached sizable proportions and, if allowed to continue, could tarnish the credibility of the securities markets.    Time after time when one company announces publicly that it wants to purchase another company at a premium over the current trading price, the stock of the target company already has been climbing for several days or several weeks.    ''It's to the point when as soon as investment bankers hold a private meeting, the stock of the company they are discussing goes up,'' said Peter J. Solomon, director of mergers and acquisitions for Shearson Lehman/American Express. ''Virtually all of the professionals in my business are upset.''

headline: THAILAND SAID TO USE FORCE TO REBUFF LAOTION REFUGEES
abstract: A United States Senator and refugee experts here expressed concern today over what appears to be a Thai Government decision to use force to turn back Laotian refugees - including many who once fought in the C.I.A.'s ''secret army.''    Reports in the Thai press in recent weeks have said that the Thai Government, in an effort to stem a rise in Laotian refugees, had refused since the beginning of the year to permit the Laotians to continue crossing the Mekong River into Thailand. There have been reports that Thai border troops have killed some of the Laotians.    Of prime concern to Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, and refugee specialists is the fate of the Hmong hill people, who were part of the clandestine army that fought the North Vietnamese for many years before the Central Intelligence Agency cut off funds between 1973 and 1975.

headline: NORWEGIAN DIPLOMAT FACES TRIAL TODAY IN SPYING CASE
abstract: The trial of Arne Treholt, a well-connected Norwegian diplomat accused of spying for the Soviet Union and Iraq, will begin here Monday.   The trial is expected to last at least five weeks and much of it will be held behind closed doors before seven judges.   The 42-year-old Mr. Treholt, who was head of the Foreign Ministry's press office at the time of his arrest 13 months ago, began his career as a journalist but later occupied a variety of positions that gave him access to secret information vital to both Norway and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.   He is accused of various lesser offenses in addition to spying and could be sentenced to as much as 20 years in prison. He has admitted breaches of confidence during questioning by the police but is expected to deny that he was involved in any continuing espionage arrangement and that any of the information passed to foreigners could have harmed Norway or its Western allies.

headline: TREASURY YIELDS EASE A BIT
abstract: Yields on Treasury securities were unchanged to slightly lower yesterday as traders and potential investors awaited monetary statistics to be issued by the Federal Reserve today.     While uncertainty about the future course of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy keeps interest rates slightly higher than their late January levels, participants in the credit markets said they were also feeling the effects of sharp increases in stock prices and in the value of the dollar.    Several analysts noted that rising stock prices were siphoning a noticeable amount of investors' funds from debt securities.   ''We are definitely seeing a shift of money away from bonds and into stocks,'' said Jay Goldinger, a Beverly Hills, Calif., broker who specializes in debt securities.

headline: FRONTIER ACTING TO SELL AIRLINE TO ITS 5 UNIONS
abstract: M. Gerald O'Neil, representing the largest stockholder in Frontier Holdings Inc., said yesterday that the board and management were giving priority to working out a sale of the subsidiary, Frontier Airlines, to the carrier's five unions.     Work on an agreement for a union buyout has been delayed primarily by differences over the value of productivity increases.   Under a preliminary agreement reached Dec. 21, the five unions agreed to buy the airline for $220.4 million, or $19 a share. The unions also agreed to concessions totaling $30 million a year, of which 40 percent would come from productivity increases and the rest from wage cuts. The final agreement is scheduled to be completed Jan. 31, with the concessions retroactive to Jan. 1.

headline: Solidarity Activists Call Off Planned Strike
abstract: Underground Solidarity leaders and the outlawed union's founder, Lech Walesa, called off a 15-minute national strike today after the Government's decision not to increase food prices.

headline: HUNTING FOR CREATIVE MINDS
abstract: LAST November, J. Walter Thompson ran a full-page newspaper ad asking would-be copywriters to mail in seven writing samples. The agency still is culling through the 800 replies it received, in hopes that maybe a dozen effective copywriters will surface.    Finding good creative people, managers say, is as difficult as keeping them happy. And companies will go to unusual lengths to do both.

headline: Engineer Pleads Guilty In Illegal-Export Case
abstract: A Maryland engineer pleaded guilty in Federal court today to charges he illegally exported $6.5 million worth of high-technology equipment to an Austrian firm that traded with Soviet bloc countries.   D. Frank Bazzarre, 45 years old, of Accokeek, Md., admitted in a plea statement in United States District Court that he shipped the products without obtaining licenses required by the Export Administration Act.

headline: U.S. CITES LAUNDERING PATTERNS
abstract: A senior Treasury Department official said today that the large flow of United States dollars in cash between Switzerland and the First National Bank of Boston resembled a classic money-laundering operation.   ''The patterns I am seeing in this case are consistent with laundering operations in Switzerland,'' said John M. Walker Jr., the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Enforcement and Operations.   The First National Bank, a unit of the Bank of Boston, pleaded guilty in Federal court Thursday to a felony charge of failing to report $1.22 billion in cash transactions with nine foreign banks, most of them in Switzerland. The bank was fined $500,000, the largest penalty ever imposed on a bank for violating the Federal currency reporting law, which requires banks to report transactions of more than $10,000.

headline: Doubt Voiced On Tax Plan
abstract: The long-term effect on the economy of the Treasury Department's plan to overhaul the Federal tax system would be ''ambivalent at best, and at worst highly unfavorable,'' according to a study released today by the National Association of Manufacturers.    The analysis, based on a computer model designed to simulate the workings of the economy, was challenged by Treasury tax officials.

headline: PHONE RATE IS TRIPLING FOR SOME
abstract: In what may be the largest such increase since the Bell System breakup, the New York Telephone Company is informing its 32,000 Connecticut customers that the price of their local phone service is more than tripling, to $14.65 a month for flat-rate service and to $10.03 for measured service, in which customers pay by the call after exceeding an allotted amount.     At the same time, the company's business customers in the two Connecticut communities it serves - Greenwich and Byram - have been told that the price of their local service will increase nearly sevenfold, to $18 a month for measured service, the only type available to businesses.   And to all of its customers in New York and Connecticut, New York Telephone has issued what amounts to a stern warning not to call the company for repairs if a problem lies with someone else's equipment, such as a privately bought telephone.

headline: CURBS SET BY AUSTRIA HELP U.S.
abstract: The Austrian Parliament has approved legislation enabling it to stop illegal shipments of United States technology to Soviet bloc countries.     The amendment to Austria's trade law, which unanimously passed the lower house in December, reflects Austria's concern that it might lose access to American technology if it failed to convince the Reagan Administration that it intended to prosecute violations of United States export law.    The move also appears to be the result of a conservative shift in the Government of Chancellor Fred Sinowatz after key Cabinet changes in September. Foreign Minister Leopold Gratz said in an interview that the main purpose of the new law was ''to assure Austrian industry unhindered access to high technology.''

headline: Continental Sets Challenge Continental Air Lines said yesterday that it would file a complaint with the Transportation
abstract: Department to prevent Southwest Airlines from going   through with its acquisition of   Muse Air unless Southwest allows its landing rights at airports in Houston and Dallas   to be made available   for sale to other carriers. Continental, which is based   in Houston, said Southwest and   Muse together operate all the   gates at Love Field in Dallas   and half the gates at Houston's   Hobby airport.

headline: Dow Falls 4.86 as Decline Continues
abstract: Stocks declined yesterday, for the third day in a row, as concern over the true course of interest rates, corporate earnings and the Federal deficit continued to worry traders, analysts said.    The Dow Jones industrial average lost 4.86 points, to 1,184.96. Over the first three trading days of 1985. the Dow has dropped a total of 26.61 points. The index had risen 7.40 points on Monday, Dec. 31, the last trading day of 1984.

headline: ENGLISH GAINS UNE PETITE NICHE ON QUEBEC'S SIGNS
abstract: A four-letter word hanging over her shop in Montreal's Pointe Claire suburb put Valery Ford in trouble with the Quebec authorities.    The offending word was ''wool.''    Quebec's Commission for the Protection of the French Language had no quarrel with the name of Mrs. Ford's shop, Les Lainages des Petits Moutons, which translates as ''Woolens From Little Sheep.''   But by making mention of wool in English for her English-speaking customers, Mrs. Ford had violated a law specifying that all commercial signs in Quebec must be in French only.

headline: A.T.&T. Computer Action
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation moved yesterday to regain some control over its popular UNIX operating system.    UNIX, designed by Bell Laboratories, is a basic set of computer instructions that has engendered a number of spinoff versions. A.T.&T. is stepping up its effort to establish a single UNIX standard that will run on a wide variety of personal computers.    Its primary competition is MS- DOS, the operating system used by the International Business Machines Corporation's line of Personal Computers and used widely in I.B.M.-compatible machines.

headline: Greenland Out of E.E.C.
abstract: Greenland has dropped its affiliation with the European Economic Community, becoming the first territory to leave the Common Market since the founding Treaty of Rome went into effect on Jan. 1, 1958.   Greenland voted against joining the community in 1972, but it reluctantly became bound by Common Market rules as part of Denmark's decision to join the community in 1973.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM;  TOO MUCH DEBT, NOT ENOUGH PROFIT
abstract: The citizenry of Bartlesville,   Okla., heaved a big sigh of relief  when Phillips Petroleum reached an agreement with Mesa Petroleum designed to insure that Phillips remains an independent company. But what's good for Bartlesville is not all that good for Phillips or for its stockholders.  Some arrangement surely had to be made to secure Phillips's freedom from a takeover. But now that freedom is accompanied by a huge increase in debt, with no improvement in - and even perhaps a weakening of - earning power. The recapitalized Phillips will be a less viable competitor in an oil industry weakened by surplus and declining prices.

headline: PINOCHET DISMISSES 2 IN POLICY DISPUTE
abstract: President Augusto Pinochet today dismissed the civilian chief of his Cabinet and another minister who had urged him not to renew the state of siege he has used to crack down on the political opposition.   The entire 16-member Cabinet resigned Monday at General Pinochet's request and he reappointed 14 members today, 10 days after the state of siege was renewed. He dismissed Sergio Onofre Jarpa, Interior Minister and chief of the Cabinet, and Finance Minister Luis Escobar, also a civilian. Four of the reappointed ministers are military officers.

headline: No Headline
abstract: In Energy Deal By The Associated Press W.R. Grace & Company, a   chemical concern with energy   holdings, said that it had   agreed in principle to sell several of its oil and gas interests   to the Exxon Corporation for   about $126.5 million in cash. Grace said Exxon had agreed to   buy the oil and gas interests   currently held by Grace's   wholly owned Grace Petroleum   Corporation unit.

headline: GERMAN TERRORISTS STEP UP ATTACKS
abstract: There has been a new wave of terrorist attacks by the so- called Red Army Faction against American military installations and other targets in West Germany.    The attacks, part of a so-called ''anti- imperialist offensive,'' have coincided with a hunger strike by a group of convicted West German terrorists.    At the same time, Western European police officials have been probing for evidence of coordination among West German, French and Belgian left-wing terrorist groups.    In Brussels today, a car bomb caused extensive damage to an American community center near NATO headquarters in Brussels and a note from a Belgian group said the attack was aimed at supporting the West German hunger strikers.

headline: Southmark Seeks Insurance Stake
abstract: The Southmark Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it intends to seek regulatory approval to buy at least 51 percent of the Western States Life Insurance Company.    Southmark, a Dallas-based company with interests in real estate and financial services, said it already held 330,306 Western States shares, or slightly less than 10 percent of the total outstanding, through a subsidiary, the Pacific Standard Life Company. It also holds options to buy an additional 332,743 shares.

headline: Bank, Fund Yields Fall
abstract: Yields on bank and money fund investments continued their decline for the week ended yesterday, the Donoghue Money Market Report and The Bank Rate Monitor reported.    In money markets, the seven-day compound average yield declined to 8.16 percent, from 8.25 percent, and the 30-day compound average yield fell to 8.37 percent, from 8.47 percent. Reporting on bank investments, The Bank Rate Monitor's national index of bank money market deposit accounts dropped to 8.07 percent, from 8.10 percent, while The Monitor's index for six-month C.D.'s decreased to 8.50 percent, from 8.55 percent. The Monitor's yield figures are based on minimum deposits available at institutions.

headline: TINDERBOX FOR TRADE;  THE LOOMING WORLDWIDE JOB SHORTAGE
abstract: UNLESS we start now to create new jobs by the millions in scores of countries, some of the most difficult years that man has ever known may be facing us. This is not opinion; it is simple arithmetic.   The numbers are going the wrong way. Every little sign of European recovery or easing of a Latin American debt crisis brings a sigh of relief. But it is unwarranted. The underlying global trend is for more and more persons to compete for a scanty supply of jobs. And no nation's policies even recognize how the jobless hordes are building to a ''critical mass'' that could be harder to control than any nuclear arsenal.

headline: Crane Picks President
abstract: The Crane Company yesterday named Edwin F. Phelps president and chief operating officer.

headline: STATISTICS SHOW RECOVERY IS BACK
abstract: After a four-month absence, the economic recovery reasserted itself strongly in the statistics. Housing starts showed a 2.1 percent gain in December, rounding out a year that was the best since 1979. Industrial production was up six-tenths of a percent, the biggest increase in five months; capacity use was up three-tenths of a percentage point, to 81.9 percent; and personal income rose five-tenths of a percent. And data from November showed a sharp, 1.1 percent rise in sales of manufactured goods.         There was one negative note - retail sales, which were down one-tenth of a percent in December. One factor in the decline was a drop in new-car sales, but that situation appears to have turned around. Auto makers reported a 12 percent gain in sales in the first 10 days of January - the best performance for the period since 1966.

headline: PAKISTANIS ADMIT GAINS IN URANIUM TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Pakistan has consistently maintained that it has no intention of developing a nuclear bomb and that all its nuclear work has gone into research and development of technology for peaceful purposes.    Nevertheless, a great deal of attention has been given here to assertions over the last few years that Pakistan is on the verge of making a bomb.    Pakistani officials, including President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, repeatedly deny the assertions. In the last year or so, however, officials have acknowledged that the Government has successfully developed the technology to make enriched uranium that could theoretically be used for a bomb.

headline: Terex Proposal Gains Ground
abstract: Creditors of the Terex Corporation have agreed to proceed with a reorganization plan that tentatively calls for a group of investors to acquire the company and merge it with its former operations in Scotland.   Terex officials said the company's creditors met Wednesday and agreed in principle to a plan to be developed with the First Boston Corporation, the investment banking company.

headline: View From Thailand
abstract: According to refugee and American Embassy officials in Bangkok, there have been persistent rumors for at least four months that Laotian refugees have been killed or shot at in attempts to turn back their boats on the Mekong River. Embassy officials say they have checked all such reports and found no evidence to substantiate them.

headline: Car Quotas
abstract: To the Editor:   There have been numerous claims that the Japanese voluntary export restraints raised car prices, inflated auto profits, and reduced the incentive of American auto makers to become competitive (''Economics of Car Quotas,'' Dec. 16). Let's look at the facts.    Government data show that the prices for all cars (including imports) rose only 4 percent a year during the restraint period, compared with a 5 percent rate of inflation. Prices of American small cars, which compete directly with 95 percent of the Japanese imports, have gone up only 2.4 percent a year. Ford's 1985 Escort is selling for less than the comparable 1982 model.

headline: French Trade Deficit
abstract: France's foreign trade deficit widened in January to a seasonally adjusted 3.8 billion francs, or $372.5 million, from 661 million francs in December, the Industry Ministry said today.

headline: Big Board Options on Stocks Set
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission, ending eight years of often contentious deliberations, voted today to let the New York Stock Exchange trade in options on individual stocks.    The Big Board's entry into such trading is expected to make this young and growing business more competitive.    Options, contracts to purchase or sell stocks in the future, are already traded on the American Stock Exchange, the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the Philadephia Stock Exchange and the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange.

headline: A MARSHY BATTLEFIELD IN THE GULF WAR FOUND STREWN WITH IRANIAN CORPSES
abstract: The thud of artillery filled the marshes and the firetrails of outgoing rockets lighted the twilight sky. Columns of Iraqi tanks clanked eastward through the wetlands on hastily built dirt roads.   A pair of legs in mud-covered boots protruded from a ditch beside one of the paths. The corpses of dozens of Iranian soldiers were strewn in the marshes beyond.

headline: ADVERTISING;Barneys on Its Own
abstract: Barneys New York, the 61-year-old clothing store, is starting its own advertising department and will therefore be splitting with Chiat/Day, New York, its agency since July. Neil Kraft is its advertising director, having come aboard from Epstein, Raboy Advertising, the Chiat/Day predecessor. Barneys spent about $3 million for advertising last year.

headline: TRADE ISSUES WORRY JAPANESE
abstract: Japanese officials have expressed strong concern in the last few days that relations with the United States are deteriorating as a result of stubborn two-way trade problems.    ''The sentiment in the United States is like that before the outbreak of a war,'' said Saburo Okita, head of a Government advisory committee on trade.   Mr. Okita, a former Foreign Minister, met with American officials in Washington and came home this week warning that they had grown increasingly impatient with what they viewed as Japan's reluctance to open its markets to imports.

headline: ETHIOPIAN JEWS SAID TO RESETTLE ON WEST BANK
abstract: The Reagan Administration has expressed its concern to Israel about reports that some Ethiopian Jewish refugees have been settled in the West Bank, State Department officials said today.    According to the officials, the United States Embassy in Tel Aviv was instructed to complain to the Israelis about reports that hundreds of the Ethiopian Jews - part of an airlift of some 10,000 - had been sent to the Kiryat Arba settlement outside Hebron in the West Bank.   The United States has given Israel some $12.5 million for the resettlement expenses of new immigrants this fiscal year and Washington wants to make sure that none of the money is spent on enlarging Jewish settlements in the West Bank.        Area Remains in Dispute      The West Bank of the Jordan River, populated mostly by Palestinian Arabs, has been under Israeli control since it was captured from Jordan in the June 1967 war. Jordan seized the West Bank in 1948, and the area's sovereignty remains in dispute.

headline: G.E. Information Unit Picks Waring Agency
abstract: Waring & LaRosa, of late a subsidiary of BBDO International, has been named agency for General Electric Information Services Company in Rockville, Md.

headline: OHIO LEGISLATURE PASSES SAVINGS UNIT FUND BILL
abstract: In the wake of the failure of the Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati, an emergency measure to shore up Ohio's 70 other state-chartered savings institutions has moved quickly through the State Legislature.   Late this afternoon, both houses of the Ohio Legislature passed a bill to set up a $90 million emergency insurance fund for the savings institutions.   Brian T. Usher, press secretary for Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio, said the Governor would sign the measure as soon as it could be brought before him.

headline: ITT PROFIT OFF 37.1%
abstract: The ITT Corporation, hurt by the strong dollar and a rise in insurance claims, yesterday reported a 37.1 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings, to $175 million, or $1.16 per share, from $278 million, or $1.86, in the comparable period of 1983.    Earnings for all of 1984 also declined, by 33.6 percent, to $448 million, or $2.97 a share, from $675 million, or $4.50, in 1983.   Sales for the year rose 5.4 percent, to $19.6 billion, while those for the quarter gained 3.8 percent, to $5.4 billion.

headline: TEXTRON STILL HAS TAKEOVER FEVER
abstract: PROVIDENCE, R.I.    IF the 1960's were the Age of the   Conglomerate, as the decade has   often been called, then the Textron Corporation was the father of an age. Throughout the 1950's, right through his retirement in 1965, Royal Little, Textron's now-legendary founder, bought and sold companies at a breakneck pace. He transformed Textron, once a textile manufacturer, into the nation's first and most widely emulated conglomerate, with businesses ranging from helicopters to lawn mowers to buzz saws.   ''I'd just get it in mind to do something,'' Mr. Little, now 89 years old, said the other day, ''and I'd go ahead and do it.''    But times have changed. Takeovers are difficult and costly - and often unnecessary, many believe. Analysts and academics no longer revere the Royal Littles, Harold Geneens and other conglomerateurs who bought and sold companies on a whim. Today, conglomerate stocks often sell below what their subsidiaries could command as stand-alone units. The 1980's have become the Era of Synergy, in which conventional wisdom dictates that corporations limit their acquisitions to companies that complement their core businesses.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, MARCH 7, 1985
abstract: The Economy         President Reagan vetoed emergency farm credit legislation, saying the measure was a ''massive new bailout that would add billions to the deficit.'' (Page A1.) The Senate Budget Committee, beginning voting on spending cuts on the non-military side of the budget, showed a reluctance to make deep reductions. (A21.)         Paul A. Volcker suggested that fresh, coordinated action by governments would be desirable to reduce gyrations in the currency markets. The Fed chairman was apparently referring to central bank intervention. But he cautioned that an agreement on exchange rate stabilization would be difficult to achieve. (D1.)

headline: SPAIN OUTS 2 U.S. DIPLOMATS AS SPYING SUSPECTS
abstract: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez said today that two American diplomats were asked to leave Spain 10 days ago because of suspicion of spying.   The Americans, identified as Dennis McMahan, a political officer, and John S. Massey, an official at the United States Air Force Base at nearby Torrejon, left the country immediately afterward, top Spanish officials said in interviews.   (In Washington, the State Department confirmed that the two Americans had been asked to leave Spain, but it declined further comment.)

headline: Haitian Official Disputes Human Rights Report
abstract: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 14 (AP) - A Government official today denounced an Amnesty International report of human rights abuses in Haiti as ''complete lies.''   The London-based organization's report, which was released Wednesday, said that although abuses have fallen sharply in Haiti since 1977, the authorities still single out political opponents, journalists and trade unionists for arbitrary detention, torture and execution.   The Government official, Information Minister Jean-Marie Chanoine, said in an interview: ''We have no political prisoners, and we have no selective repression.''

headline: Register to Sell Honolulu TV Unit
abstract: The Des Moines Register and Tribune Company has agreed to sell its Honolulu television station, NBC affiliate KHON, to the Burnham Broadcasting Company of Chicago. The sale of KHON is expected to be closed this summer as liquidation of the Register and Tribune Company continues.

headline: A WAVE OF EUPHORIA HITS WALL ST.
abstract: LAST week, the mood on Wall Street was a combination of wonder and well-being. For two   weeks, stocks of every shape and size had advanced. And even on those days when the Dow Jones industrial average declined, more issues rose in price than fell.    Many professionals are expressing optimism that the stock market is entering the much-ballyhooed second leg of the bull market that began in August 1982. And they predict that it will enjoy a sustained advance. In fact, many are now saying that the market could rise throughout much of 1985.

headline: SHULTZ, IN ICELAND, IS SAID TO DISCUSS ARMS DISPUTE
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz made an unscheduled stop here today for talks that were said to have included discussions of a controversy over reported American contingency plans to station nuclear arms in Iceland.    Mr. Shultz, in a brief statement to reporters, gave no details of his talks with Foreign Minister Geir Hallgrimsson, whom he praised as an effective spokesman for Iceland.   But Mr. Hallgrimsson said he had emphasized to Mr. Shultz that Iceland insisted on being informed about any military plans affecting the country. Iceland is a nonmilitary member of the North Atlantic Treaty Alliance.

headline: IRAN ASSERTS IT FAILED
abstract: Iraq and Iran gave conflicting reports today of a new Iraqi attack on the central war front, the second reported Iraqi drive in four days against Iranian positions.   An Iraqi field commander told the Baghdad radio that his troops seized several Iranian positions in two hours of fierce fighting.

headline: NEW PENSION RIGHTS FOR FORMER SPOUSES
abstract: Starting this year a new Federal law gives couples who are splitting up the go-ahead to put a new item on the bargaining table: the husband's pension. As a result of the Retirement Equity Act of 1984, an ex-wife can now be assured of collecting on her former husband's pension if a judge has awarded her that right. She can also start drawing the money before he retires. And even if her husband has remarried, she may still arrange to receive survivor's benefits if he dies before retirement.   Under the new law, a long-standing conflict between state law, which had been fairly liberal in permitting the award of all or part of a husband's pension to his ex-wife, and Federal law, which had been more restrictive and often prohibited such awards, has been cleared up. Now, as long as the divorce decree or separation agreement meets several key requirements, a woman can be awarded a claim against her ex-husband's pension.

headline: Western Casualty Offer The Lincoln National Corporation said that it
abstract: had agreed to buy the Western   Casualty and Surety Company   of Fort Scott, Kan., for $270   million.  However, a spokesman for   Saul P. Steinberg, a New York   financier, said he might make a   counteroffer for the company.

headline: Washington Watch;   Officials Battle For Trade Turf
abstract: WASHINGTON    THE scene: the Cabinet Room of the White   House. The time: last Thursday at 2 p.m.   Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to the President, and Joseph R. Wright Jr., deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget, made the presentation in favor of the plan to merge trade functions in a new Department of International Trade and Industry.    Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige looked on approvingly. Under the plan, his department would swallow the Office of the United States Trade Representative, which is headed by Bill Brock.

headline: WRISTON TRADE POST HELD LIKELY
abstract: Walter B. Wriston, retired chairman of Citicorp, has emerged as the leading candidate to succeed Bill Brock as United States trade representative, White House and other Government officials said today.    Mr. Brock was nominated as Labor Secretary Wednesday.    Mr. Wriston was described as the favorite of the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan. The two are former financial industry colleagues and competitors. Mr. Regan was chairman of Merrill Lynch before joining the Reagan Administration as Treasury Secretary in the first term.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM;  DESPITE FORECASTS, REVENUES ARE DOWN
abstract: A recent survey by the Internal Revenue Service seems to show that upper-income people are shouldering more of the tax load than they did before 1981, when tax rates were slashed across the board. In 1981, people with at least $100,000 of income paid 15.2 percent of the total tax take; the recent I.R.S. figures for 1983 show that people with incomes of at least $100,000 paid 20 percent - 4.8 percentage points more.  This news has been heralded by some as an indication that ''supply- side economics'' is working - that rich people are earning more money and, despite the lower tax rates, paying more in taxes. Perhaps we really can grow out of that budget deficit, as President Reagan once insisted. But don't count on it.

headline: Indian Elections End In a Burst of Violence
abstract: Mobs hurled explosives at voting booths and clashed with the police today during India's final round of state elections. The Congress Party of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi took the lead in three states.

headline: Armco Inc. to Cut 250 Jobs in Ohio
abstract: Armco Inc., the diversified steelmaker that has been struggling since 1982, said it would eliminate 250 jobs at its Middletown headquarters within the next week.

headline: Earnings Climb 30% At Ogilvy & Mather
abstract: Ogilvy & Mather International ended the year on an upbeat note as far as earnings went.    Revenues in the fourth quarter of 1984 were $131.2 million, up 20.5 percent from $108.9 million in the period in 1983. Net income did even better, increasing 30 percent, to $11.7 million, or $1.24 a share, from $9 million, or $1 a share.

headline: A WHITE HOUSE REPORT ARGUES FOR 'STAR WARS'
abstract: The White House issued its first public report today on President Reagan's proposal to develop a defense against nuclear missiles, arguing that the time had come to move away from reliance on weapons of mass destruction to deter a nuclear war.     While not departing from testimony given before Congress this year by an array of Pentagon officials, the report seemed clearly aimed at the general public rather than at expert audiences.   In the foreword, President Reagan wrote that ''we must seek another means of deterring war. It is both militarily and morally necessary.''

headline: Addendum
abstract: MCD Advertising Inc., Princeton, N.J., has changed its name to McDonald/Caskey/Gaffino Advertising and has named Barry Caskey president.

headline: ICAHN BIDS $8.1 BILLION FOR PHILLIPS
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier, offered yesterday to buy the Phillips Petroleum Company for $8.1 billion. He valued the leveraged buyout at $55 a share, half in cash and the other half in notes. He also threatened that, if Phillips turned that offer down, he would try to take over the company anyway.     Mr. Icahn, who already owns 7.5 million shares of the company, gave William C. Douce, Phillips's 65-year- old board chairman, until the close of business today to accept or reject his buyout, a plan using the company's own cash flow to pay off the debt incurred in the offer.

headline: BRAZIL TO RESUME TALKS ON RESTRUCTURING DEBT
abstract: Brazil resumes crucial debt talks with leading commercial banks Thursday, with both sides seemingly anxious to complete a major renegotiation package before this country holds indirect Presidential elections on Jan. 15.    Brazilian officials and foreign bankers said that considerable progress was made before Christmas on the broad lines of an agreement to postpone repayment of some $50 billion of Brazilian debt maturing through at least 1990.   They also expressed confidence that in the coming days the two sides would iron out their differences over grace periods for principal payments and the spread - the margin above prevailing interest rates - to be paid by Brazil on its rescheduled debt.

headline: Libya Calls It a Humiliation
abstract: Libya said today that Mr. Reagan's rejection of Egypt's Middle East initiative was a humiliation for Mr. Mubarak. The Libyan press agency said Mr. Reagan's remarks made him a ''judge of Egypt's policy.''

headline: SEOUL SAYS CHINESE CREW WANTS TO GO HOME
abstract: The South Korean Government said today that 13 surviving crew members of a disabled Chinese torpedo boat who are in its custody had expressed a desire to be sent back home.    A Government statement implied that the naval vessel and its crew would be returned, but a spokesman said in a telephone interview from Seoul that no decision had been made.   South Korea also said an investigation of a shooting incident aboard the boat, in which six crewmen were killed and two were wounded, had revealed no political motivation.        'Grievances' Against Officers    Over the weekend, foreign diplomats in Seoul said their information suggested that a mutiny or hostage-taking might have been attempted on Friday by would-be defectors while the boat was taking part in maneuvers in the Yellow Sea. But the South Korean announcement today said the shooting had been started by two sailors with ''grievances'' against senior officers.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD;Swedish Fighter Jets Grounded After Crash
abstract: Sweden has grounded most of its fighter planes because it suspects a recent  crash may have been caused by sabotage, the daily Svenska Dagbladet reported today.         The paper quoted an air force spokesman as saying that all Viggen aircraft had been grounded after technicians found that a crash last week was caused by loose screws and other metal objects in the plane's guidance system. The spokesman said the same problem had been found in four other planes, adding, ''We cannot rule out that the screws were placed by saboteurs.'' He did not elaborate.

headline: A TRUSTEE TAKES ON THE GREENMAILERS
abstract: LAST June, when Walt Disney Productions paid a hefty premium to buy back Saul P. Steinberg's 11.1 percent equity stake, Jesse Unruh, the treasurer for the State of California, was outraged. In previous months, half a dozen big companies had paid ''greenmail'' to get potential corporate raiders off their backs and, now, he had seen enough.    ''There must be a better way,'' he recalls saying to himself, ''than sitting by and getting ripped off.''   Mr. Unruh, one of the trustees for his state government's huge pension funds, said he ''inquired around among other pension fund trustees, and found out they didn't know any more than I did about what was going on. All we knew was what we saw in newspapers. There also was no way to trade information about situations like this.''

headline: COKE TO OFFER DRINK FOR EXERCISERS
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company, continuing an aggressive series of new-product introductions, will begin to test-market next month a beverage designed for heavy exercisers.    The company hopes that the glucose-based drink, called Max, will appeal to the estimated 20 million Americans who exercise for five or more hours a week. Max will be tested in Houston and parts of Colorado by its Coca-Cola Food Company division.

headline: TOWER, NEW TO ARMS TEAM, HAS WARNED OF SOVIET MIGHT
abstract: Former Senator John G. Tower, the Texas conservative who will head the negotiating team in the talks on strategic arms, comes to the job with a long history of concern over the Soviet military buildup.    He has an outspoken determination to increase American military might and a reputation as a forceful debater.    His chief qualifications for the job, he said at a news conference at the State Department on Friday, are his academic background in foreign policy issues - he was an assistant professor of political science at Midwestern State University in Wichita Falls, Tex., before winning his Senate seat in 1961 - and his familiarity with modern weapons systems gained as chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. That, he said, ''gives me a pretty good foundation,'' although he acknowledged he had ''a good deal of homework to do.''

headline: Money Fund Assets Drop
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $824.9 million, to $218.48 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

headline: GREEK PARTY BOYCOTTS PRESIDENT'S INSTALLATION
abstract: Christos Sartzetakis was sworn in tonight as President of Greece. He was elected Friday in a tumultuous special session of Parliament.    The opposition benches were empty as the new President, a 56-year-old Supreme Court justice, recited the oath read to him by the Greek Orthodox Primate, Archbishop Seraphim.   Constantine Mitsotakis, the opposition leader, announced after the voting that his New Democracy Party considered Mr. Sartzetakis's election invalid. He challenged the constitutionality of the deciding vote of the interim President, Yannis Alevras, and accused the governing Socialist Party of violating the secrecy of the ballot.

headline: GENERAL TO LEAVE TOP LATIN POSITION
abstract: Gen. Paul F. Gorman, the commander of United States forces in Latin America and a major strategist of the Administration's military activities in Central America, will retire this year, the Defense Department said today.     As chief of the Army's Southern Command, with headquarters in Panama, General Gorman has promoted an activist United States role in Central America, stirring controversy both in Congress and in the region.    A Defense Department official said a successor would be named Friday.

headline: Regent Air Extension
abstract: The Transportation Department said today that it had told Regent Air it could fly for another 90 days, but that the airline would then be grounded unless it comes up with a better plan to put distance between itself and its founders, Clifford and Stuart Perlman.

headline: Greyhound Net Climbs 51.2% PHOENIX, Feb. 4
abstract: The Greyhound Corporation said today that its   fourth-quarter profit rose 51.2   percent on a 23 percent revenue   gain. The company said its profit   for the quarter rose to $36.6   million, or 75 cents a share,   compared with $24.2 million, or   49 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: 2 AGENCIES REPORT SOVIET ARMS SPURT
abstract: Analysts for the Central Intelligence Agency and the Pentagon said today that there was evidence of a sudden spurt in Soviet spending on weapons procurement for the first time since the mid-1970's. But the agencies differed sharply on the pace of this latest buildup and what it meant.     The Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency estimated that the weapons part of the Soviet military budget had increased by 5 to 8 percent from 1982 to 1983, the last year studied, and said preliminary signs pointed to another increase in 1984.    The C.I.A., basing its estimate on what one official called ''a little more cautious'' forecast of how fast the new weapons would roll off the assembly lines, said that Soviet weapons spending rose between 1 and 2 percent in 1983 and that it was too early to tell about 1984.

headline: CHINA PROMISES CREATIVE FREEDOM TO WRITERS
abstract: China's writers were given a new constitution today that spoke of their right to ''democracy and freedom'' in developing a literature that served a readership beyond workers, peasants and soldiers.     The development followed an eight- day congress of the Chinese Writers' Association that was dominated by calls for new creative freedoms and by a keynote speech from a top Communist Party figure, Hu Qili, promising that they would have it. Some writers hailed the speech as heralding a new golden age for Chinese literature.    But a description of the new charter that was issued today by the official New China News Agency indicated that it retains strictures about writers remaining faithful to the party and to Marxism-Leninism. In effect, the party seemed to have loosened its controls as it has on earlier occasions, but to have retained broad ideological constraints that could be invoked against any writer venturing too far.

headline: EDITOR DESCRIBES GUIDELINES GIVEN TO WINANS
abstract: A third Wall Street Journal editor, Richard E. Rustin, was questioned yesterday about the newspaper's conflict-of-interest policy and about the work of R. Foster Winans, the former reporter who is on trial with two others in Federal District Court in Manhattan on charges of conspiring to trade on advance information about what would appear in The Journal's ''Heard on the Street'' column.     Mr. Rustin, a news editor who was Mr. Winans's supervisor, testified that he had told the reporter about the paper's conflict-of-interest policy several times.    ''I told him that we don't invest in stocks we write about,'' he said. ''I told him it was probably best to be out of stocks. The only stock I own is Dow Jones.''

headline: Allnet Layoffs
abstract: Allnet Communication Services Inc. said that it had laid off about 260 workers or roughly 15 percent of its work force. Allnet, a Chicago-based provider of discount long-distance telephone service, said it had reduced its work force because regulatory decisions had reduced its profitability. It cited higher access charges to connect to local customers.

headline: WILL ABC BOUNCE BACK?
abstract: Until recently, a change in the overall alignment of the commercial broadcasting industry was unthinkable. ABC, CBS and NBC were perceived as monolithic entities, beyond the ordinary tides of business. But since early this year - when assorted interests cast acquisitive eyes on CBS - a sense of impending upheaval has been growing in the industry. And yesterday, when Capital Cities Communications Inc. moved to take control of ABC, the unthinkable happened.     The question now confronting ABC executives is whether the surprising new arrangement with Capital Cities will signal a dramatic change. The role of momentum in the fortunes of a network is crucial. When things are moving forward and up, they tend to stay that way for a while, sometimes for years. The problem that has to be faced is whether ABC's recent slide in audience ratings will be temporary or sustained. Has success during the last eight years made the network sluggish? Can it bounce back?    Network spokesmen say that it can. They point to new series such as ''Eye to Eye,'' which has its premiere Thursday, and several multimillion-dollar mini-series, including a drama special dealing with the Vietnam War years in this country, which are well along in the planning stage.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *       American Hospital Supply Corp., Evanston, Ill., said it had received Food and Drug Administration approval to market its Homepro Intravenous Infusion Pump. The pump is designed for patients who need intravenous nutrition or drug therapy at home.

headline: LOOKING AT RECENT TAX RULE CHANGES
abstract: THE Internal Revenue Service started off the   new year with fireworks when it issued new   rules for taxing employees' personal use of company cars. Released on Jan. 2, the proposed regulations provide some needed guidance on how to value this popular executive perk - but they are also more onerous than many people had expected. Following is an analysis of the new rules, as well as a summary of other recent developments of interest to individual taxpayers.  Using the Company Car NEW tables furnished by the I.R.S. give an annual ''lease value'' of company cars, based on the vehicles' fair market value. The lease value is then used to determine the amount of ''income'' benefit that the executive derives from personal use of the car. The executive must include the value of that benefit in his or her taxable income, and the company must withhold a flat 20 percent of that value each quarter.

headline: Times to Print In Tacoma
abstract: The New York Times will start satellite production in the fall of its national edition at a seventh site, The Tacoma News Tribune in Washington State.    The announcement was made yesterday by William L. Honeysett, president and chief executive of the Tribune Publishing Company, and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman of The New York Times Company and publisher of The New York Times.

headline: Marcos Orders Release Of Filipino Film Makers
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today ordered the release of two movie directors and 39 other people jailed on his orders for 16 days.   Justice Minister Estelito Mendoza announced the action a day after the moviemakers, Lino Brocka and Behn Cervantes, filed a petition with the Supreme Court contending that the detention was unlawful.

headline: 21 Dead in Honduras Crash
abstract: There were no survivors among the 21 American servicemen who were aboard a military cargo plane that crashed on Tuesday off Puerto Castilla, Honduras, the United States Embassy here said today.
