The Air Force Reserve plane was based at Billy Mitchell Field in Milwaukee. It had been carrying the soldiers on a flight from Howard Air Force base in Panama to Trujillo, on the northern Honduras coast.

headline: U.S. PLANS TO AID MOZAMBIQUE ARMY
abstract: State Department officials said today that the Reagan Administration would try to open a ''limited military assistance relationship'' with the Marxist Government of Mozambique as a result of recent changes in that southeast African nation's attitude toward the United States.    The officials, who attributed the changes to economic and military pressure on the Mozambique Government, said the Administration notified Congress several weeks ago that it wanted to give Mozambique's armed forces $1 million in ''nonlethal'' military equipment, such as uniforms, vehicles and communications equipment. In addition, $150,000 would be spent to train Mozambican military personnel, some of them in the United States.

headline: TALKS BREAK DOWN IN SENATE ON LOANS TO ASSIST FARMERS
abstract: In an outburst of partisan rancor, negotiations to seal a compromise on farm credit legislation collapsed in the Senate early this morning, and the filibuster blocking a vote on the confirmation of Edwin Meese 3d as Attorney General is to continue.   Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, threatened all-night sessions in the Senate next week in order to face down the Democrats who have blocked the compromise and to force a vote on the Meese nomination.   He ordered the Senate to reconvene this morning.    Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Democrats' leader, said the Republicans were putting the confirmation of Mr. Meese over the welfare of the nation's farmers. He said the Republicans' message was, ''Let the farmers go to hell.''

headline: SOWETO PROTEST BLOCKS KENNEDY SPEECH
abstract: Black demonstrators forced Senator Edward M. Kennedy to cancel plans for a major speech today that was to have been the climax of a one-week visit to South Africa.     The Massachusetts Democrat was to have addressed a meeting at Regina Mundi Cathedral in Soweto, South Africa's biggest black township, just outside Johannesburg.    Between 3,000 and 4,000 people assembled to hear the Senator but in their midst around 100 demonstrators from the radical Azanian People's Organization marched toward the altar shouting ''No more Kennedy!'' and bearing placards that described him as an imperialist. Bishop Desmond Tutu, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize and one of the Senator's hosts, announced after emotional pleas for calm that the Senator's speech had been canceled.

headline: Trial of Lambsdorff Is Postponed Indefinitely
abstract: The trial of former Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff on corruption charges, which was scheduled to begin Jan. 10, has been postponed indefinitely on legal grounds, the Bonn district court said today.   A court spokesman attributed the delay to plans to add tax evasion to the list of charges being brought against Mr. Lambsdorff and a second defendant, Eberhard von Brauchitsch, a businessman.   The two men, and a third defendant, Hans Friderichs, a banker, have been accused in connection with payments to Mr. Lambsorff's Free Democratic Party between 1975 and 1980 from the Flick industrial concern in exchange for tax breaks on the proceeds of a sale of Flick holdings in the Daimler-Benz automobile company.

headline: DENTISTS MAY ENDORSE ANTI-PLAQUE INGREDIENT
abstract: The American Dental Association's Council on Dental Therapeutics will probably grant its seal of approval in the ''near future'' to several proposed agents for toothpastes or mouthwashes that fight plaque and gum disease, an official said today.   Several Wall Street analysts and dental experts said the new products would be the largest scientific breakthrough in the toothpaste industry in decades, with substantial profits at stake in the high margin business.    Hercules Segalas, a senior vice president with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said the anticipated action would greatly help the Procter & Gamble Company, which he said was poised to bring to market a prescription mouthwash that would fight gum disease and a toothpaste that would fight accumulations of tartar.   ''The potential to oral health of some of these chemical agents would be very significant,'' said Edgar W. Mitchell, secretary of the A.D.A.'s Council on Dental Therapeutics. ''The dental profession is almost eager to have some of these products on the marketplace.''

headline: Order for Pneumo
abstract: IC Industries' Pneumo Corporation subsidiary said that it had received a $162 million order from the General Dynamics Corporation for production of flight control actuators for the F-16 fighter aircraft. The company said deliveries would start in the 1986 fiscal year and continue through 1990, with 70 percent of production going to planes made for the United States Air Force and the rest for planes to be sold internationally.

headline: Italian Chamber of Deputies Ratifies Accord With Church
abstract: The Italian Chamber of Deputies ratified a revised concordat tonight regulating church-state relations that ends Roman Catholicism's status as the state religion.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN COMPUTER PSYCHOLOGY;  A STAMP OF APPROVAL FROM ACADEMIA
abstract: TEN years ago, Marilyn Mantei,  then a recent college graduate,  wanted to take a graduate program in human-computer interaction. She looked through countless university catalogues, yet could not find one that offered such a course of study.  Today Miss Mantei, who is an assistant professor of computer and information systems at the University of Michigan's Graduate School of Business Administration, counts more than 50 schools offering doctorates in psychology, computer science or business, with an emphasis on human-computer interaction, as tech psych is formally called. What is more, she claims that the computer industry snaps the graduates up as quickly as the schools spew them out. ''The demand for Ph.D.'s with psychology research skills who understand how computer systems are designed is enormous,'' she said.

headline: STATUE'S REPAIR AIDS RESEARCH
abstract: ELECTRIC power was new and computers nonexistent when the Statue of Liberty was dedicated in 1886. But a century later the repair of the nation's most famous statue is being accomplished with electricity, computers and other innovations developed while the copper lady weathered the storms of time.   And she is yielding new research as well.   ''There will be fallout through all of industry from this project,'' said Lawrence Bellante, a partner of GSGSB, a New York architect-engineering firm aiding in the restoration      .

headline: BIG BOARD, PACIFIC TIE PROGRESSES
abstract: The Pacific Stock Exchange would become a wholly owned subsidiary of the New York Stock Exchange under a proposal that members of both exchanges are being asked to consider. The link could be the first step toward establishing the Big Board as the driving force behind eventual round-the-clock trading in the stocks of American corporations.     Talks between officials of both exchanges have been under way since last fall, and an outline of the status of those discussions was expected to be delivered to members today.   Although neither exchange is yet asking for a vote from its board or its members, the outline, entitled ''Suggestions for proposed NYSE/PSE affiliation,'' shows clearly that the staffs of the exchanges have worked out many key details. The merger is likely to be the main topic at the Big Board's monthly membership meeting on Wednesday.

headline: Advertising;   Screened Ads for Parents
abstract: -free since its founding 15 years ago, will open up its pages next September. It will be offering advertisers the minds and hearts not of the preschool, nonreading audience but of their parents.   Additionally, the Children's Television Workshop, which publishes it, will also offer advertising space in its Electric Company magazine for the 6-to-10 set. A third magazine, 1-2-3 Contact, for the budding of scientific knowledge, will merge in June with Enter magazine, which has been taking advertising since it started.

headline: MOTHER PLANS TO VISIT SHCHARANSKY IN CAMP
abstract: The mother of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, who is serving a sentence for espionage, said today that she had received permission to visit him at a labor camp to which he has been transferred from prison.    She said it was the first confirmation that he had arrived at the camp, near Perm in the Urals, since he completed a prison term at Chistopol on Oct. 22. The Soviet penal system considers work camp a more lenient form of confinement than prison.

headline: JACKSON BIDS POPE VISIT SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: The Rev. Jesse Jackson urged Pope John Paul II today to visit South Africa and speak out against apartheid.     Mr. Jackson, the 43-year-old Baptist minister who was a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination last year, said such a mission by the Pope could ''have a profound impact in mobilizing the moral forces of the world.''    Mr. Jackson spoke at a news conference here after a half-hour audience with the Pope, whom Mr. Jackson praised repeatedly for his work for human rights.   Mr. Jackson said he had asked the Pope to focus the world's attention on the problems of blacks in South Africa, much as he had mobilized world opinion on behalf of Solidarity, the banned trade union movement in Poland.

headline: TEACHING ARTS INSTEAD OF ACCOUNTING
abstract: JOSEPH J. LAVIN, vice president   of Sandoz Inc., the pharmaceuticals company, and general manager of its Dorsey Laboratories unit, is planning to tackle subjects this summer that he hasn't studied in years. The idea, he says, is to ''clear out some of the cobwebs'' in his mind.    Sandoz will hand over nearly $10,000 to Dartmouth College to make sure that the process takes place. Mr. Lavin and his wife are joining 100 or so executives from companies across the country for a four-week program in Hanover, N.H., where they will discuss Plato, explore DeTocqueville's observations on American democracy and argue about Horatio Alger's thoughts on the American dream.   ''The topics are very pertinent,'' said Mr. Lavin, 42 years old and a 17- year Sandoz veteran. ''They will help me see what we are doing and how it will fit in better to the marketplace.''

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Moody's Sees Losses For Mortgage Insurers
abstract: The mortgage insurance industry, plagued by rising foreclosures and low premiums on many outstanding policies, may face another four years of heavy underwriting losses, according to a report published yesterday by Moody's Investors Service.    As a whole, ''the majority of firms at this time would not survive'' an economic downturn as severe as the Depression, according to Michael F. Molesky, an analyst at Moody's. ''In a few years conditions might be better, but right now most of these companies have low net equity and a tremendous amount of risk exposure from their activities in 1983 and 1984,'' he said.

headline: A STORMY HALT FOR WORLD CHESS MATCH
abstract: The president of the International Chess Federation halted the five-month-old championship match between Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov today and ordered that a new one begin in September.    The action was taken despite protests by both players that they wanted to continue.    The competition, which after 48 contests stands at 5-3 in favor of Mr. Karpov, with 40 draws, has broken countless records.  The federation president, Florencio Campomanes, said his decision was prompted by his conclusion that the match ''has exhausted the physical if not the psychological resources'' of the participants and others connected with the match.

headline: CLAMOR OVER CAMBODIA
abstract: The non-Communist nations of Southeast Asia took their strongest united stand against Vietnam this week, condemning it for ignoring ''the established rules of orderly and peaceful conduct of relations between states.'' The statement by Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Brunei and the Philippines came amid growing regional alarm over Vietnamese attacks on rebels that have begun to spill into Thailand and frustration over repeated failures to bring Hanoi to the negotiating table.    35,000 Said to Flee Fighting    Today, 10,000 Vietnamese troops were reported to have surrounded rebel strongholds in western Cambodia, and the guerrillas were said to be fighting back with mortar and cannon fire. An estimated 35,000 civilians are believed to have fled across the Thai border since the Vietnamese push began on Tuesday.  Regional officials and diplomats regard the statement by the six-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, which took the form of an international plea for military aid for the Cambodian guerrillas, as significant for several reasons.

headline: Washington Watch;   A Hard Line Against Japan
abstract: WASHINGTON THE Reagan Cabinet has rejected as inadequate moves taken so far by Japan to reduce   barriers to telecommunications imports.    Bill Brock, still wearing his hat as United States Trade Representative, took the hard line in Cabinet trade discussions Friday against a package of concessions just brought back from Tokyo by Lionel H. Olmer, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade Administration.

headline: AN OPPOSITION PARTY GETS STRONG SUPPORT IN SOUTH KOREA VOTE
abstract: A new party of anti-Government politicians picked up surprisingly strong support and emerged today from general elections as South Korea's leading opposition group.    The ruling Democratic Justice Party, as expected, retained its majority in the National Assembly. But potentially the most significant result of Tuesday's legislative elections was the success of the New Korea Democratic Party, formed by opposition figures who only three months ago were banned from political life by President Chun Doo Hwan.    The new party's strong showing created a possibility that the fundamentally weak legislature could become a more vigorous political forum.

headline: BAR TO DEPORTING OF CUBANS STAYED
abstract: A Federal appeals court said today that the Government could send back to Cuba hundreds of Cubans being held in the Atlanta Penitentiary.   The court's action stayed a Federal district judge's ruling that forbade the Government to deport any Cubans who were now or ever had been in the Atlanta penitentiary, until their appeals for asylum were decided by Federal immigration officials.     Earlier today, however, the judge whose ruling was stayed ordered 34 of the Cubans released from the Atlanta penitentiary and perhaps from the threat of deportation. The judge, Marvin Shoob, said the Government had found that the Cubans had committed no crime and posed no danger to American society.

headline: FLORIDA'S BATTERED CITRUS BELT
abstract: For the fourth time in five years, a severe freeze has devastated Florida orange groves, raising questions about the state's future as a dominant orange producer.     ''Coming after the last few years, this has to make producers wonder about Florida's citrus potential,'' said Robert W. Back, a food industry analyst with Rodman & Renshaw Inc. of Chicago. ''Is it becoming so unstable weather-wise as to be an undependable supplier?''    Florida officials and others were emphatic in asserting that the $3 billion industry, which employs more than 100,000 people and generates $7 billion for the state's economy, was not on the verge of decline.

headline: Ayer Develops Formula To Gauge Acceptability
abstract: Ayerwaves, the newsletter of the N.W. Ayer media department, has come up with a dandy yardstick for measuring the acceptability of advertising in a medium.

headline: KOREANS PLAN U.S. CAR SALES
abstract: The Hyundai Motor Company of Korea will begin selling cars in the United States later this year when it introduces a new, front-wheel-drive subcompact as a 1986 model. The company said its initial plans are to build an additional 100,000 cars a year for sale in the United States.          The formal announcement of the move, the first of its kind by a Korean automobile company, is expected on Monday. Company officials made it clear over  the weekend that their strategy is to concentrate on the market for small, relatively inexpensive cars that the Japanese auto makers have largely abandoned in favor of more elaborate and expensive models.

headline: WASHINGTON'S GENEVA GOAL: A FORMULA FOR WIDER TALKS
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz was scheduled to arrive in this snow-covered city Sunday to open the first significant Soviet- American arms control talks in 13 months.   He and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko are scheduled to hold at least four rounds of talks over the next two days.    The purpose of the renewed Soviet- American talks is to find a formula for resuming formal negotiations covering both offensive and defensive weapons. But even in advance of the opening session on Monday morning at the Soviet Mission here, there are wide disagreements between the two sides on the scope of the talks that could make progress difficult, American officials warned.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: March 4, 1985

headline: Storage Head Resigns
abstract: The financially troubled Storage Technology Corporation said yesterday that Jesse I. Aweida had resigned as chairman. The resignation, which had been widely expected, is effective Saturday. Mr. Aweida, 53 years old, is the company's founder and major stockholder. He will remain a director, Storage Technology said. Mr. Aweida stepped down as chief executive officer on Nov. 19.

headline: Philippine Battles Kill 15
abstract: At least 15 people have been killed in a continuing battle between Government troops and Communist rebels in the northern province of Cagayan, the military authorities said today.

headline: ANOTHER INDECISIVE DECISION ON OIL PRICES
abstract: OPEC ministers gathered in Geneva this week needing to make a bold stroke that would change the psychology of an oil market so weak that buyers have nothing to lose by continung to defer purchases in the expectation of still lower prices.  What they produced instead was more evidence of a lack of cohesion that could make inevitable the very price declines the group sought to arrest.    ''If anything,'' commented Constantine D. Fliakos of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., ''they made the outlook even more uncertain.''   By itself, the decision for a small price cut, OPEC's latest bow to the realities of the depressed market, is unlikely to have any immediate noticeable effect on what consumers pay for gasoline or heating oil. Actual prices are already below the new official levels, just as they were in early 1983 when the would-be cartel was forced to make a $5 cut, to $29 a barrel, the first since its founding in 1960.

headline: MOSCOW PORTRAYS TALKS AS SUCCESS
abstract: The Soviet press today portrayed the agreement between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko as a success, describing the accord to open new arms talks as a victory for Moscow.    The Government newspaper Izvestia even allowed itself a moment of jubilation, exclaiming, ''The talks are on!''    Six months ago Western diplomats were writing off the possibility that the Kremlin might return to arms negotiations. They said the Soviet Union's aging leaders were too insecure, too set in their ways, to take initiatives.

headline: Vornado Shares
abstract: Vornado Inc. said it had repurchased 187,800 of its common shares in unsolicited broker transactions and that its board had authorized the purchase of up to an additional 500,000 shares when market conditions deem it advisable. Before today's transaction there were 3,567,090 shares outstanding. The shares of Vornado, a real estate leasing concern, closed at $40.125 today, down 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 2, 1985        The Economy         The Treasury's tax plan is having a chilling effect on some real estate investments. Investors, developers and prospective buyers of vacation homes worry that if the plan is approved, the loss of tax breaks will depress property values. (Page A1.)

headline: SANDINISTA IS PRESSING PEACE PLAN
abstract: No sooner had Daniel Ortega Saavedra finished attending funeral services for Konstantin U. Chernenko in Moscow last week than the Nicargauan President was back on an airplane. But instead of heading home, he was winging his way to Brasilia for the inauguration of Brazil's new civilian Government and the start of a weeklong visit.    Mr. Ortega's current Brazilian tour is his second trip to South America this month and, like the first, it involves far more than a mere exercise in diplomatic protocol. His sudden burst of globetrotting, diplomats here say, is part of a drive to drum up support for the peace proposal he first made public late last month.

headline: President Is Retiring At GTE Florida Unit
abstract: The General Telephone Company of Florida announced yesterday that George H. Gage Jr., its president for 15 years, will retire at the end of June, when he reaches the age of 60.    The company, a subsidiary of the GTE Corporation, said that William E. Starkey, 49, would succeed Mr. Gage. For the last two years Mr. Starkey has served as group vice president of GTE's telephone operating group at the company's Stamford, Conn., headquarters.

headline: OPPOSITION LEADER WINS BRAZIL VOTE
abstract: An electoral college chose Brazil's first civilian President in 21 years today, overwhelmingly electing the opposition candidate, Tancredo Neves.     Mr. Neves, a 74-year-old centrist whose victory had been widely forecast, defeated the governing party's candidate, Paulo Salim Maluf, 480 votes to 180 votes, with 17 College delegates abstaining and 9 absent. Mr. Neves is to take office in two months.    As Mr. Neves won a clear majority with the 344th vote cast in his favor shortly before noon, a loud cheer went up across Brazil. Crowds who had gathered in towns and cities to follow the vote count immediately began celebrating.

headline: 13 DONOR NATIONS FORM AFRICA FUND WITH WORLD BANK
abstract: A group of 13 industrialized nations and the World Bank today pledged more than a billion dollars to establish a new fund for long-term economic help to African nations suffering from famine and economic collapse.     Officials here said the purpose of the fund, the Special Facility for Sub-Saharan Africa, is to make famines in Africa less likely. The fund is distinct from the emergency food supplies that Western nations are now sending to famine-stricken parts of the continent.         All Technically Eligible    Under the terms of the fund, all African countries are technically eligible for assistance, including those, like Ethiopia and the Sudan, that have been receiving substantial famine-relief supplies from the West.

headline: ALCOA SHOWS LOSS
abstract: Walt Disney Productions reported today that profits in its first fiscal quarter rose by nearly four times the total a year ago, to $32.2 million, or 95 cents a share. Revenues were up by 41 percent.   Much of the profit increase was attributed to the addition of the Arvida Corporation, a real estate development company, which contributed $28.3 million in pretax profits on revenue of $84.2 million. Disney acquired Arvida last June as part of its defense against a takeover attempt led by Saul Steinberg, the New York financier.

headline: EGYPT AND ISRAEL TACKLE BEACH ISSUE
abstract: Egyptian and Israeli officials began trying to work out a solution today to  the long-festering dispute over Taba, a 750-yard stretch of desert, but the two  sides still appeared to be far apart.         Conference sources said that Egyptian and Israeli delegates at the two- hour  session at the Beersheba Desert Inn presented their countries' longstanding positions about the beachfront desert strip, situated on the Gulf of Aqaba just  south of Eilat. Both countries claim it as their own.

headline: Money Market Rates Dip
abstract: The Dime Savings Bank continues to offer the highest yield on money market accounts among a group of 17 banks and savings institutions in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, according to figures compiled by The Bank Rate Monitor of Florida. But yields nationwide eased.   And, after a sharp rise of $8.3 billion in the first two weeks of January, assets of the nation's 255 taxable money market funds decreased by $429 million, to $207.5 billion, in the week ended Tuesday, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report. William E. Donoghue, publisher of the report, attributed the drop to the fact that, for the first time since June 15, 1983, the seven-day average yield dropped below 8 percent, to 7.93 percent, from 8.14 percent. The taxable funds' 30-day average yield dipped to 8.14 percent from 8.26 percent.

headline: Gunman in Ulster Kills A Catholic Policeman
abstract: A Roman Catholic police sergeant was shot and killed today as he prepared to go to mass with his family at Enniskillen, near the border with the Irish Republic, officials reported. The killing was the 10th police death in four days to be blamed on the Irish Republican Army.

headline: Part of Jack Eckerd
abstract: Moves to Thompson      After an agency competition, J. Walter Thompson/New York has been assigned the TV advertising for the pharmacy sections of the 1,500 drugstores operated by the Jack Eckerd Drug Company of Clearwater, Fla.

headline: CHINESE, MODERNIZING ARMY, RETIRE OFFICERS
abstract: The drive to professionalize China's armed forces took a step forward today with the announcement that 47,000 officers, about a tenth of the officer corps, will be retired before the end of 1986.     The announcement had political ramifications since the officers involved are mostly men who joined Mao Zedong's guerrilla forces before the Communists seized power in China in 1949. Although there has been an official retirement policy for 25 years, the practice had been to allow those who took part in the guerrilla struggle to remain in uniform until they died or voluntarily stepped aside.    Deng Xiaoping, the 80-year-old army veteran who holds pre-eminent political power, has made the remaking of the army one of his priorities. He wants to replace the poorly educated peasant boys who made the revolution by younger, better-trained men.

headline: Peruvian Rebels Wreck Dam
abstract: Maoist guerrillas have bombed a hydroelectric dam, cutting off power to the town of Churcampa, only 30 miles from Ayacucho, where Pope John Paul is to visit Sunday, officials said today.

headline: TREASURY ISSUE RATES MIXED
abstract: After a day of erratic trading, interest rates on Treasury issues were mixed yesterday, with short-term rates falling modestly while note and bond yields rose slightly.     The decline in short-term rates was linked to the lower than expected rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market. Federal funds traded below 8 percent most of the day, and the rate for six-month bills were down to 8.74 percent, from 8.80 percent. Although many economists still expect the funds rate to average about 8 1/2 percent or 8 3/4 percent, traders noted that the decline had reduced their fears that the Fed might soon decide to encourage higher interest rates.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: TUESDAY, MARCH 19, 1985        Companies         ABC agreed to be acquired by Capital Cities Communications for more than $3.5 billion. The deal would mark the first time a major television network has changed hands and would be the biggest non-oil acquisition in corporate history. The acquisition is subject to F.C.C. approval. (Page A1.) Analysts said ABC was able to negotiate the deal from a strong financial position. (D1.) The acquisition is a coup for Capital Cities, which would get a company four times its size. (D1.) Executives moved quickly to assure employees of the network that there would be few changes. (D24.)        Texas Commerce Bancshares stock continued to fall after the company announced that it expected lower earnings in the first quarter, for the first time in 16 years. The bank holding company cited problem loans to the energy industry. (D1.)

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: Central Louisiana Electric Co. , Alexandria, La., has appointed William F. Terbot president and chief operating officer.     *       First Pennsylvania Corp. , Philadelphia, has elected Nelson G. Harris, president and chief executive officer of Tasty Baking Co., to its board of directors and the board of its principal subsidiary, First Pennsylvania Bank N.A.     *       Helionetics Inc., Irvine, Calif., a manufacturer of power conversion equipment, lasers and computers, has named Wilson K. Talley chairman and Michael M. Mann president, chief executive and a director.

headline: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1985
abstract: The Economy         The economy grew at a 4.9 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, a faster rebound from its summer slowdown than previously estimated, the Commerce Department said. A month ago the department put the growth at 3.9 percent, and in December it estimated 2.8 percent. Economists said the inflation outlook remains good, but bond yields rose on an expectation that a stronger economy would lead to higher interest rates. (Page A1.)         Beryl W. Sprinkel was nominated to head the Council of Economic Advisers. The monetarist, who is Treasury Under Secretary for Monetary Affairs, is known as an Administration loyalist. (D1.)

headline: No Headline
abstract: Kenneth F. Hartman, associate counsel of the New York State Comptroller's office, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami, where he had gone for tests. The cause of death has not been established.

headline: CHRYSLER PLANS TO SELL MORE CARS FROM JAPAN
abstract: A Chrysler Corporation executive said today that his company was planning to import 200,000 more cars a year from its Japanese affiliate, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, to sell in this country.     Testifying before the House Ways and Means Committee in Washington, Robert S. Miller, Chrysler's executive vice president for finance, said the company would place the order in a few days, even though the White House has not decided whether to extend the restraints on imports of cars from Japan.    ''In our estimation, the restraints are coming off,'' Baron Bates, a Chrysler spokesman, said. ''Even if they are extended, there will be an increase in the number of cars allowed, so we decided not to wait any longer.'' If the restraints do continue, Chrysler would not be able to import as many extra cars as it plans.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *       Advanced Resource Development Corp., Columbia, Md., a technology and management consulting company, has named Eugene P. Wilkinson, president emeritus of the Institute of Nuclear Power Operations, to its board.     *       American Independent Reinsurance Co., Stamford, Conn., has named Raymond L. Osterhout president and chief executive officer.

headline: U.S. AMBIVALENCE ON DOLLAR'S RISE
abstract: The finance ministers of the most powerful industrial nations gathered here for dinner tonight and a daylong meeting Thursday at a time of increased concern about the implications of the extraordinary rise of the American dollar.    The prolonged ascent of the dollar has baffled even the members of the Reagan Administration and has aroused a new ambivalence about how to deal with it.    The dollar's long climb from its depths of 1980 confirms the validity of the Administration's economic policies, they say, but it is causing immense dislocations in the politically important sectors of the economy most affected by it, especially exporters, and undermines the ability of developing countries, such as Argentina, Brazil and Mexico, to make payments on their dollar loans.    For Europeans, as for the Japanese, the strong dollar has brought a boom to exporters, but in pushing up the cost of the goods they import from the United States and other imports that are priced in dollars, especially oil, they fear that the dollar will push up the inflation rates, undoing years of austerity meant to bring them down.

headline: 5 PEACE PRINCIPLES LISTED BY JORDAN IN ITS P.L.O. PACT
abstract: Jordan today made public the text of its agreement with the Palestine Liberation Organization that outlines a framework for a joint approach to peace in the Middle East.     The agreement was signed in Amman on Feb. 11 by King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the P.L.O.   The text of the accord, distributed in English and Arabic in the Jordanian capital, specifies five principles upon which their ''bid for joint action'' should be based. A key provision includes ''total withdrawal'' by Israel from ''the territories occupied in 1967 for comprehensive peace as established in United Nations and Security Council resolutions.''   Jordan's Acting Information Minister, Taher Hikmat, said at a news conference in Amman today that this meant the P.L.O. had accepted United Nations Resolution 242, which calls for recognition of Israel's sovereignty and borders in exchange for the return of occupied Arab lands.

headline: Denver Sewer Authority
abstract: A syndicate led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company purchased $28.8 million of Metropolitan Denver Sewer Authority bonds yesterday at competitive bid.

headline: COMPUTER GIANT FINDS PROBLEMS IN SUCCESS
abstract: Most of the mobile robots at I.B.M.'s sprawling personal computer plant here really earn their keep. The ones that pluck up just-completed PC's and PC-XT's work so fast they turn their six production lines into a blur of fast-moving gray boxes.    Life is easier for the robots on the single production line dedicated to I.B.M.'s newest, most sophisticated personal computer, the PC-AT. They can take their time, and the finished computers pass by slowly enough so that even humans can read their serial numbers.    But what is good news for these robots is not necessarily good news for the International Business Machines Corporation. While nearly every major corporation in America is clamoring for the new PC-AT - a much faster, more capable machine, whose initials stand for ''Advanced Technology'' - I.B.M. has discovered, to its surprise and chagrin, that it cannot make the new computers fast enough. So far advanced is the AT technology, in fact, that some of I.B.M.'s eager bevy of suppliers cannot keep up.

headline: Farm Prices Are Steady
abstract: The prices that farmers receive for raw products held steady in February but still averaged 6.2 percent below the levels of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.   The price index had been above marks a year earlier for almost a year and a half before edging lower in December, January and February.   The department's report also included revised figures, however, that showed prices in January also held steady instead of declining, as a preliminary report showed a month ago.

headline: California Bill Aids Savers
abstract: The California Senate will consider a bill on Thursday that would use state funds, at least temporarily, to repay depositors in a privately insured thrift and loan association that closed last April.   The 12,500 depositors in the Western Community Money Center have so far received only 24 percent of the funds they had on deposit at the time. They have been told by the state that they may have to wait as long as five years while the state sells off the institution's assets.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: American Software Inc., Atlanta, said Prutech Research and Development Partnership had agreed to provide about $1.2 million in financing for American Software's development of manufacturing and inventory control software.     *       Calmar Inc., Watchung, N.J., and Realex Corp. said they had extended their merger agreement until March 1.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Bond Prices Rise Modestly
abstract: Treasury bond prices rose modestly yesterday after six consecutive trading days of falling prices that increased yields about half a percentage point.     The rebound was a continuation of the better conditions that became apparent Monday afternoon when prices rose enough to end the day unchanged to slightly lower.    Government securities dealers said investor demand was fair to good for the $7 billion of new five-year notes auctioned yesterday by the Treasury, but said demand for longer-term issues remained weak as many investors remain convinced that interest rates will trend higher this year.    At the 1 P.M. auction, the new 11 3/8 percent Treasury notes due May 15, 1990, sold at an average yield of 11.43 percent. Several participants said demand for the new notes was very strong at a yield of 11.43 percent or higher. By late in the day, prices had improved enough so that the new notes were offered with a yield of 11.37 percent, down from 11.40 percent a day earlier. The 11.43 percent average yield was higher than the 11.02 percent average for similar notes sold last November, but well below the 13.93 percent yield for five- year notes sold in May 1984.

headline: Insurer Loss Seen
abstract: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. said that it expects to report a ''significant fourth-quarter loss'' and that it intends to sell the underwriting companies acquired as part of the Alexander Howden Group.

headline: VERY HIGH LEVELS OF TOXIC MATERIAL ARE FOUND IN AIR
abstract: The first systematic survey of toxic chemicals being emitted into the nation's air has found hazardous materials at far higher levels and at many more locations than suspected, according to a Congressional survey to be released today.    The survey of 80 large chemical companies found that thousands of tons of cancer-causing agents and other very hazardous materials are being released into the atmosphere from hundreds of factories. There are no uniform standards to control the emissions of most of the substances, the study's directors said, and some of the materials are subject to no regulations.   ''No government agency has ever attempted to gather this information, and the information we received is not reassuring,'' said Henry A. Waxman, a Califonia Democrat who ordered the survey as chairman of the House Subcommittee on Health and the Environment.   High Rates of Release    ''Almost every chemical plant we received information about is releasing staggeringly high rates of hazardous chemicals, even in routine releases,'' he said.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   A Rush in Texas to Sell Mortgage-Backed Bonds
abstract: Local governments in Texas are scrambling to sell tax-exempt bonds backed by single-family mortgages before a state-imposed deadline of April 12. In the last two weeks, 10 local housing finance corporations have sold or are expected to sell more than $334 million of bonds to finance single-family home mortgages at interest rates between about 10 1/2 percent and 11 percent.    Although Texas is far from exhausting its Federal ceiling on sales of housing bonds, local governments have been pressing to complete their financings before their allocation expires next month.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
abstract: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1985        The Economy         President Reagan urged Congress to press on toward sustained growth and less government by enacting his new budget. He faulted the Federal Reserve, saying it contributed to the severity of the 1981-82 recession and the recent slowdown in the economy. The President also espoused the further deregulation of industry. (Page D1.) David A. Stockman, the budget director, told Congress that military pensions, not military programs, should be curbed. Mr. Reagan, in today's State of the Union message, is expected to emphasize deficit reduction and tax simplification. (A1.)

headline: Bolivian Workers Free 200 Hostages
abstract: Workers at 34 factories freed about 200 executives and technicians today who had been held hostage for three days, but kept to their demand for pay raises and went ahead with a nationwide general strike.   The hostages were released at the urging of President Hernan Siles Zuazo, who had negotiated for hours with management and the protesters.

headline: Daylong Salvador Truce Allows Inoculation Drive
abstract: Fighting stopped in El Salvador for a day today as health officials began an effort to vaccinate 400,000 children against diphtheria, tetanus, whooping cough, measles and polio, the authorities said.   The three-stage vaccination program began today and is to continue March 3 and April 21, according to officials of the United Nations Children's Fund.   Radio Venceremos, the rebel radio station, told guerrillas not to interfere with the program, and Health Minister Benjamin Valdez said the army would not initiate ''belligerent actions.''

headline: SUPERCOMPUTERS: SUPER-SHORTAGE OF EXPERTS
abstract: THEY are the biggest, the fastest, the most unconventional. They are easily the most complex machines coming out of major computer manufacturers, university laboratories and now even Silicon Valley start-up companies.  They are supercomputers, machines that can run circles around the quickest mainframes now made.   But supercomputers are in short supply, and so is the highly specialized talent used to design and operate them. ''The best number I've heard is that there are about 250 people in the United States who really understand the monsters,'' an executive of one of the nation's largest mainframe manufacturers said recently. ''And there's probably about an equal number of companies bidding for them.''   So acute is the shortage, in fact, that the Federal Government has stepped in. Last month the National Science Foundation said it would provide at least $200 million to create four supercomputer centers around the country, each equipped with a different kind of machine. The stated goal is to make the computers available to researchers for everything from designing airplane wings to simulating what happens to an automobile as it crashes.

headline: U.S. Condemns Private Raids Into Laos for Missing G.I.'s
abstract: The United States Government said today that it strongly opposed private raids into Laos in search of Americans still missing from the Indochina war.

headline: Bonn and Paris Plan Antiterrorist Hot Line
abstract: West Germany and France agreed today to set up an antiterrorist hot line to help combat an increase in urban guerrilla violence.

headline: Borg-Warner Filling Vice Chairman Vacancy
abstract: James J. Gavin Jr. has been named vice chairman of the Borg-Warner Corporation. But the 62-year-old executive, who has been senior vice president for finance since 1975, is not expected to succeed James F. Bere as chairman.    ''Jim Bere and I are almost exactly the same age,'' said Mr. Gavin, in explaining why his elevation is less a grooming for the top and more an opportunity ''to position my replacement in the financial post for several years before I retire.''

headline: EUROPEANS EXPLORING POTENTIAL ROLE IN 'STAR WARS' RESEARCH
abstract: Western European governments have begun identifying areas of possible European participation in high-technology research involving the multibillion-dollar Strategic Defense Initiative.    A confidential West German report, prepared by the Defense Ministry for Government planners and made available to reporters Wednesday, identifies five major areas in which German industry could offer cooperation.   The report also listed six other fields of high technology, in which it said West Germany was ''more or less backward,'' that might be relevant to space-based defense systems.    After a meeting Wednesday of NATO defense ministers in Luxembourg, Michael Heseltine, the British Defense Minister, told reporters that his department was drawing up a similar list for British industry.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Long-Term Yields Move Up Slightly
abstract: Treasury note and bond yields rose slightly yesterday, as traders were willing to sell securities and take profits earned last week when bond prices rose sharply.     In the wake of last week's sharp rise of about three points, or $30 per $1,000 bond, in long-term Treasury bond prices, analysts said price weakness was to be expected.   ''The general attitude is still one of optimism that bond yields can come down, but everybody is a little more cautious after last week's big run- up,'' said Albert Gross, senior vice president at Refco Inc., a securities firm. He added that the heavy supply of new Treasury issues to be auctioned next week may have encouraged some participants to stay on the sidelines.

headline: Venezuela Bank Action
abstract: The Venezuelan Government said it would liquidate Banco Nacional de Descuento, one of the nation's biggest banks, which has been closed since June.

headline: Columbus Circle To Be Acquired
abstract: Thomson McKinnon Inc. said it would buy Columbus Circle Investors, the unit of Gulf and Western Industries that acts as the asset manager for the company's pension and employee benefit plans. Columbus Circle would continue as principal manager for the Gulf and Western benefit plans and would seek other tax-advantaged asset management accounts, the company said.   Thomson McKinnon Asset Management Inc. now offers a group of mutual funds, manages individual accounts through its Foxhall Investment Management division and provides cash management for accounts at Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 11, 1985:                       MONDAY Amer Broadcasting   Minnesota Mng&Mfg

headline: 'MOUSSE MANIA' IN HAIR CARE
abstract: Chocolate mousse has been joined by strawberry, lemon and blueberry, on a menu that features hair products, not desserts.   This type of mousse - a hair-care product with the consistency of whipped cream - not only keeps stray strands in place, but can also keep hair literally standing on end. Analysts call it the hottest new product in the $2.5 billion hair-care industry in 25 years. Sales for 1984 were in the $250 million range in the United States alone.

headline: People
abstract: *       Rosalyn Dunham is joining MCA Advertising as senior vice president- creative director.

headline: ANOTHER DISSIDENT SENTENCED IN YUGOSLAVIA
abstract: Another dissident, Milan Mladenovic, was convicted Monday of antistate activity and sentenced to 18 months in prison, the newspaper Politika said today.

headline: Kim Dae Jung Takes Post in Seoul Opposition
abstract: Kim Dae Jung joined a fellow dissident, Kim Young Sam, today as joint leaders of the group behind a new opposition faction that finished a strong second to the Government party in parliamentary elections last month.   Kim Young Sam was a leader in founding the Council for the Promotion of Democracy last May.

headline: ARMY GAMES DUE WITH HONDURANS
abstract: About 7,000 G.I.'s will begin two large-scale military exercises in Honduras over the next two months, a United States military spokesman here says.    The maneuvers are to include the use of pilotless aircraft for reconnaissance missions over suspected guerrilla positions in northern El Salvador, said a Western diplomatic official here.    The new exercises are part of a two- year buildup of the American military presence in Honduras. The presence is part of the Reagan Administration's policy of maintaining pressure on Nicaragua's Sandinista Government across the border.

headline: Bell Resources
abstract: Bell Resources Ltd. said it had exercised an option to acquire UB Minerals Inc. from the General Electric Company's General Electric Holdings subsidiary for $118.8 million, in addition to the $6.3 million option fee paid last April.

headline: ZIMBABWE TROOPS SEAL TOWNSHIPS IN A HUNT FOR ARMS AND DISSIDENTS
abstract: Thousands of soldiers and policemen cordoned off townships on the western outskirts of Bulawayo early today in a wide search for arms and anti-Government dissidents.    According to residents, the security forces encircled the densely populated townships in a predawn operation, putting up roadblocks on all roads and carrying out random searches.    Helicopters and light planes equipped with loudspeakers began patrolling overhead at dawn, telling people that movement in and out of the townships was controlled and advising them to stay at home. About 400,000 people live in the suburbs.

headline: NORFOLK SELECTED BY ADMINISTRATION AS CONRAIL BUYER
abstract: The Secretary of Transportation announced today that she had selected the Norfolk Southern Corporation, a huge railroad holding company, as the purchaser of Conrail, the Government-controlled railroad.    The sale, which still requires Congressional approval, would create the country's largest rail system, stretching from Boston to New Orleans and as far west as Kansas City, Mo. Norfolk has 18,000 route miles of track at present while Conrail has 13,500 miles.   The Norfolk-Conrail combination has been strongly opposed by labor, other carriers and several legislators, however, and its approval is far from assured.

headline: Goldsmith's Zellerbach Buy Sir James Goldsmith, the
abstract: British industrialist, yesterday   disclosed that he owned 8.6 percent of the outstanding stock of   the Crown Zellerbach Corporation and said he might seek control of the San Francisco-based   forest products company. Sir James, who in the last   four years has pursued three   other natural resource companies, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that his   company, General Oriental Investments Ltd., had spent $78.3   million buying 2,375,000 Zellerbach shares, an average of $33   a share.

headline: WORLD FINANCIAL CURBS EASED BY TECHNOLOGY AND IDEOLOGY
abstract: From Tokyo's gleaming busine en place in the central assumptions which underlay the ABM treaty,'' he said. ''The underpinnings of that are less strong than when we went into the ABM Treaty and that troubles us.''   Soviet leaders have also said the President's space- based defense plan is undermining Moscow's confidence in existing arms accords.

headline: NASTY MERGER FIGHT IN CANADA
abstract: The Unicorp Canada Corporation's bid to take over Union Enterprises Ltd. is a battle that business observers are calling one of the nastiest ever in Canada.    ''It's the kind of thing that brings the whole business community into disrepute,'' Henry Knowles, a lawyer and former chairman of the Ontario Securities Commission, said.   The battle has seen the authorities decline to prosecute Unicorp for seemingly offering some Union shareholders a lower price than others; Union, as a possible takeover foil, buying a Calgary, Alberta, meatpacker last Thursday at a price far in excess of what Unicorp says it is worth, and relations between the two companies' investment bankers becoming so strained that their heads, half humorously, exchanged presents: a live turkey and a dead duck.        Offer Made Feb. 1    Unicorp, an investment concern with interests in real estate and oil, made its offer for Union, which owns a natural gas utility in southern Ontario and oil interests, on Feb. 1. The results of the tender offer will be known Tuesday. Unicorp offered a package consisting of a share of preferred stock and one-half of a nonvoting warrant for common shares.

headline: Gandhi to Visit U.S.
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India has accepted an invitation from President Reagan to pay an official visit to the United States and will meet with the President on June 12, the White House announced today.

headline: Income and Spending Rise a Bit
abstract: Personal income and consumer spending both climbed a notch last month in modest rises that analysts said were in line with an emerging picture of steady economic growth and low inflation.   An income rise of five-tenths of 1 percent was primarily accounted for by a Federal pay increase. On the spending side, January's unusually cold weather showed up in higher outlays for utility bills and gave impetus to a rise of six-tenths of 1 percent. Spending had risen three-tenths of 1 percent in December

headline: Approval in Japan
abstract: Japanese Government officials and automobile manufacturers today applauded the United States decision not to press for extension of Japan's export quotas, saying that the American consumer would benefit from resulting lower prices and greater selection.   At the same time, they sought to reassure the United States that the end of ''voluntary restraints'' would not mean the beginning of a Japanese invasion of the American auto market.

headline: BETTER OUTLOOK FOR CATERPILLAR
abstract: THE Caterpillar Tractor Company, the   world's largest producer of earthmoving machinery and equipment, has not enjoyed a profitable year since 1981, and last December its stock sold at a 10-year low of 28 3/8. For all of 1984, its shares plunged 34.4 percent.   So far, any price recovery in Caterpillar has been meager. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the shares rose 1/8, to 31 7/8.

headline: PHILLIPS OPPOSED BY JACOBS
abstract: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis businessman, said yesterday that he had been buying up stock in the Phillips Petroleum Company and would vote against its proposed refinancing plan.     Phillips, meanwhile, is understood to have raised $1.5 billion from major American insurance companies to finance the plan.    Subject to shareholder approval, the money would be used to buy back $1 billion of company stock to help buoy the market price. Phillips yesterday called a meeting for Feb. 22 for shareholders to vote on the plan.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: WHITE HOUSE REJECTS INDIRECT ASSISTANCE TO NICARAGUA REBELS
abstract: The White House has rejected a series of proposals for indirect financing of the Nicaraguan rebels and intends to continue to put pressure on Congress to renew direct covert aid, senior Reagan Administation officials said today.    The maximum amount it is seeking at this time is $14 million.    A senior State Department official said, ''Our fundamental approach is going to be to hype this issue as much as we can to make Congress accountable for their votes.''

headline: Alleghany Bid Backing Delays Conrail Decision
abstract: The surprise unanimous endorsement by railway labor of the Alleghany Corporation's bid to buy the Consolidated Rail Corporation was significantly influenced by a warning from Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole that there was no way she would support a public sale of the railroad, several union leaders said.    Department of Transportation and legislative sources said that the labor decision had forced Mrs. Dole to delay her choice among three final- round bidders for Conrail with whom she has been negotiating, while she assessed the political implication's of labor's endorsement. She had been expected to announce a recommendation to Congress Thursday and it was widely expected to be the Norfolk Southern Corporation. The other finalist is an investor group led by J. Willard Marriott Jr.

headline: Data Bank;   March 3, 1985
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: MCI Earnings Slide by 69.7% The MCI Communications
abstract: Corporation, as expected, yesterday reported a 69.7 percent   drop in fourth-quarter earnings, to $13.2 million, or 6 cents   a share, from $43.6 million, or   19 cents a share, in the comparable   period of 1983. Revenues rose   21.3 percent, to $521.5 million,   from $430.1 million.

headline: Grumman Order
abstract: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation, a subsidiary of the Grumman Corporation, won a $109.1 million Navy contract for full-scale development of F-14A aircraft avionics and radar, and the reconfiguring of F-14A engines to other specifications, the Defense Department said.

headline: 3 Eritrea Rebel Groups Merge But Largest Force Stays Out
abstract: Three rival guerrilla groups seeking to free Eritrea from Ethiopia announced today that they were joining forces in their 22- year-old struggle.   By uniting, the three groups claim to be equal in military strength to the largest rebel band, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front.

headline: CANADIANS REPORT AIR DEFENSE PACT
abstract: Canada announced details today of an agreement that it has reached with the United States to modernize North America's obsolete air defenses.    The agreement will be signed by President Reagan and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney next Monday at the end of their working meeting in Quebec City.   The modernization, which is expected to cost about $5 billion, will include the replacement of the Distant Early Warning Line with a more sophisticated new chain of 52 ground radar stations, to be called the North Warning System, across Labrador, the Canadian Arctic and Northern Alaska.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: PRETORIA PROMISES CITY BLACKS 'A SAY'
abstract: The State President of South Africa promised blacks living outside the country's tribal homelands a greater political voice today. But he made it clear that his Government had no plans to dilute the white Afrikaner power that has prevailed since 1948.    The President, P. W. Botha, said, ''It remains the Government's point of departure that because of the diversity of South African society, it is neither desirable nor practicable to accommodate all communities in the same way.''    His comments came at the opening in Cape Town of South Africa's new three- house Parliament, based on racial segregation and made up of separate chambers for whites, ''colored'' or mixed-race deputies, and Indians.

headline: Municipalities In E.S.M. Suit
abstract: Four municipal governments that were customers of the failed E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. intervened today in the Securities and Exchange Commission's suit against the securities firm, but their position was limited by a judge.    Federal District Judge Jose A. Gonzalez agreed with lawyers for the S.E.C. and E.S.M.'s receiver that direct intervention could encumber the litigants, the lawyers said.

headline: Chinese Stock Market
abstract: China's Communist rulers are considering opening a stock market in Shanghai, a senior financial official said today. Sheng Baizhang, vice president of the Shanghai Investment and Trust Corporation, added, ''I would say we could have a stock market in Shanghai within two years.''

headline: The CBS Protest
abstract: Officials of CBS News underscored their protest of the killing of two free- lance television crewmen yesterday by canceling plans for weeklong television programming from Israel before Easter.     In a telex to Prime Minister Peres, Mr. Joyce, the CBS News president, urged ''immediate and energetic action by your Government to investigate the responsibility of this tragic and shameful occurrence, and once the facts are clear, to take rigorous and appropriate action to prevent the recurrence of such outrageous behavior by Israeli forces.''   Mr. Joyce said two witnesses, Miss Jacquemin, of French TV, and Alain Meargues of French National Radio, had described the killings and the wounding of the crew's driver as ''an unprovoked and deliberate attack by Israeli forces.''

headline: U.S. WAS WILLING TO MERGE PARLEYS
abstract: President Reagan recently authorized a merger of talks on reducing medium-range and intercontinental-range nuclear weapons if such an arrangement was proposed by the Soviet Union, according to Administration officials.     The officials said Secretary of State George P. Shultz was given this option as a ''fallback position'' for his meeting with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko in Geneva three weeks ago.    Instead, and to the relief of the American team, the officials said, Mr. Gromyko proposed and the two sides agreed on three separate working groups - defensive systems, strategic or intercontinental-range weapons and medium-range weapons - as part of one overall negotiation.    But there have been indications recently that Moscow may be reconsidering the merger idea in some form.

headline: A Top Sikh Priest Is Shot in Punjab
abstract: Two young Sikhs shot and wounded a leading Sikh priest and two aides today as they left their car in the Ludhiana district of the Punjab, a district official said today.    The official said the two men had been on a motorcycle pursuing the priest, Kirpal Singh, who is head of the Akal Takht shrine at the Golden Temple in Amritsar, District Magistrate N. K. Lakhanpal said.

headline: OHIO BANKS URGED TO TAKE OVER UNITS
abstract: Representatives of Ohio's major commercial banks were asked at a meeting yesterday to take over the 71 state-chartered savings and loan associations that were ordered closed for three days because of a collapse of depositor confidence, according to officials who attended.    The suggestion was made at the meeting that was called by the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland and attended by Fed officials, Gov. Richard Celeste, state legislative leaders and about 40 bankers.    Under the takeover proposal, the state's commercial banks would jointly establish a corporation that would take over the thrift institutions. The proposal was put forward by an unidentified ''consultant,'' but the idea seemed to have the strong support of state officials as well as representatives of the Federal Reserve, according to individuals at the meeting.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Paraguay Judge Orders Destruction of Chemicals
abstract: A Paraguayan judge ordered today that the authorities destroy 141 tons of impounded chemicals that could be used to process eight tons of cocaine. The United States has been seeking such a decision for seven months in an effort to combat international drug traffickers.

headline: MERRILL LYNCH REPORTS A GAIN
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday reported improvements in fourth-quarter results compared with the 1983 quarter. But some analysts said they were with disappointed with giant Wall Street brokerage's results compared with the third quarter.    ''It was a major disappointment,'' said Perrin Long of Lipper Analytical Services.    The firm's fourth-quarter pretax income was $7.9 million, but a $21.7 million tax credit increased the fourth quarter's profits to $29.6 million, Mr. Long said. Third-quarter pretax income was $23.3 million and its net income was $24.5 million, before an extraordinary gain.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1985        The Economy         Senate Republican leaders would eliminate a cost-of-living increase for Social Security pensioners for one year as part of a package to reduce Government spending by at least $50 billion in 1986. (Page A1.) It may be April or May before the White House is ready to send tax recommendations to Congress, officials said. (A21.)

headline: NEW ZEALANDERS TO THE RAMPARTS (IT'S FOR RUGBY)
abstract: Earlier this month, the Government decided to refuse to give an American destroyer access to the country's ports because of the possibiltity that the warship might be carrying nuclear weapons. The action angered the Reagan Administration and raised doubts about the future of New Zealand's military alliance with Australia and the United States.     In New Zealand, the furor was notable chiefly because it diverted public attention from what Prime Minister David Lange has called ''perhaps the most contentious issue of the coming year.''    The issue: whether New Zealand's national rugby team will go ahead with a scheduled tour of South Africa.

headline: COLOMBIA TURNS OVER TO U.S. 4 FACING DRUG TRIAL
abstract: The Government of Colombia today turned over to the United States four men who face Federal charges for drug trafficking and money laundering, the Justice Department said.   American officials hailed the action, saying the extraditions marked a significant step toward halting the flood of drugs from South America.    Colombia, producer of more marijuana and cocaine than any other nation in the world, has until recently been a ''safe haven'' for drug traffickers fleeing the authorities, the officials said.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: March 15, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: FOLLOW TREATIES, DEMOCRATS URGE GORBACHEV
abstract: A group of powerful liberal and centrist Democrats in the House of Representatives have sent a private letter to Mikhail S. Gorbachev warning that the Soviet Union must comply with existing arms control treaties or risk the most ''serious consequences for the future of arms control.''     The main purpose of the letter to the Soviet leader, several of the signers said, was to send a message to Moscow that arms control advocates as well as critics will insist that existing arms limitation pacts be honored before future ones can be negotiated.    The highly unusual form of communication specifically stated that prospects for a limit on space-based defenses, which is widely seen as Moscow's major goal in the arms control talks in Geneva, ''would become much more difficult'' without strict treaty compliance.    Twenty-three Representatives signed the letter, including three powerful House members who will deal with future arms treaties: Dante B. Fascell of Florida, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee; Joseph P. Addabbo of Queens, chairman of the Appropriations Committee's subcommittee on defense; and Les Aspin of Wisconsin, chairman of the Armed Services Committee.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: AS SICILY GROWS UP, IN PART WITH MAFIA MONEY, IT TURNS AGAINST GODFATHER
abstract: The Mafia has come under strong attack here as a result of far-reaching changes in Sicilian political and social life, many Sicilians say.     The stepped-up assault on organized crime, many believe, has permanently altered the relationship between the Mafia and the people of this Mediterranean island at the southern edge of Italy.    Magistrates, politicians, church leaders and ordinary Sicilians who express this view do not play down the importance of recent police breakthroughs, notably the confessions of a former Mafia leader, Tomasso Buscetta.   Nor do they argue that the war on the Mafia has been won. Indeed, some Sicilian authorities contend that in certain respects, the Sicilian Mafia is more powerful than it was a decade ago.

headline: Companies
abstract: ected an I.B.M. proposal for a wholly I.B.M.-owned plant to produce microcomputers. A commission turned down the plan saying ''there are already companies in existence that manufacture them with a majority of national capital.'' The proposal was looked on as a key test of Mexican foreign investment policies, and it was unclear whether the plan could be revived. (Page 1.) I.B.M. restructured its personal computer division, transferring responsibility for its 2,000 computer dealers out of the division. Development efforts are also being changed to respond to the wide uses to which customers put I.B.M. PC's. (33.)         Eastern Air Lines backed off on its extension of wage concessions with its machinists union, and said it would restore pay withheld since Dec. 31. Both sides also agreed to try to reach a labor contract by Feb. 1, and talks will proceed with other unions. An airline negotiator indicated that lending institutions would have to make new financial sacrifices. (31.)

headline: CHARITY AND MEDICAL ITEMS CHANGED
abstract: The income tax code has long provided incentives for certain activities, such as contributing to charity and political campaigns, as well as tax benefits to alleviate some personal hardships, such as large medical bills or property that is stolen or destroyed. A variety of changes has been made in all of these areas for 1984 tax returns.    Taxpayers who do not itemize deductions, for example, will find generosity rewarded with a bigger deduction for charitable giving.    Changes were also made in itemizing deductions for medical expenses. These changes will disappoint people who spent large amounts on over-the- counter drugs but will benefit those who traveled to a far-off medical clinic for treatment. A recent court decision also should help some taxpayers who do not want to file an insurance claim but still want to claim a medical expense deduction.

headline: PATENTS;  Putting Food Samples On a Magazine Page
abstract: A magazine page containing dehydrated foods in plastic bags was patented this week by Penny Stone Cooper of New York and Richard L. Miller of Dix Hills, L.I., the patent attorney who handled the case.

headline: Husband-Wife TeamAt Success Magazine
abstract: Won't it be nice to be able to point to a magazine where the publisher and ad director are very much in love.    The magazine is Success! and the people involved are Henry W. Marks, new publisher, and Barbara Hannah Marks, ad director.

headline: CBS Magazine
abstract: CBS Inc. said it had sold World Tennis Magazine to Family Media Inc., a closely held publisher, for undisclosed terms. World Tennis, the official magazine of the United States Tennis Association, had a circulation of 386,000 and had been owned by CBS since 1972. Family Media publishes The Ladies' Home Journal, 1001 Home Ideas, Health and The Home Owner.

headline: Big Board, Comex In Impasse Talks End on Futures Link
abstract: Alan J. Brody, chairman of the Commodity Exchange Inc., said yesterday that he had ended talks with the New York Stock Exchange about the possible joint operation and ownership of the stock exchange's ailing subsidiary, the New York Futures Exchange.   He added that the talks, which began early in 1984, had reached ''an impasse'' and said that the Comex would now turn its attention to ''more fruitful endeavors.''   For its part, the Big Board said only that ''discussions have been terminated.'' However, a spokesman added that ''our goal is for the continued strength of N.Y.F.E., and we are continuing discussions with other exchanges for a possible joint venture.''

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: March 29, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Outer Space Legal Subcommittee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad hoc committee on Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Committee on United Nations Charter - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: U.S. EXPERTS NOTE GROMYKO'S ASCENT
abstract: American specialists are struck by the unusually prominent role of Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko in the shift of the Soviet Communist Party leadership, and some say they now regard him as the second most powerful figure in the Soviet hierarchy.    The 75-year-old Soviet diplomat was given the politically significant and prestigious assignment of nominating Mikhail S. Gorbachev as the new Soviet leader Monday. Normally that task goes to a defeated rival for the party leadership or to the second-ranking figure in the Soviet hierarchy. In other ways, too, Mr. Gromyko has ranked high in Kremlin protocol lately.

headline: Merrill Lynch Has Datacast Stake By Reuters
abstract: The Financial News Network said Merrill Lynch & Company had invested $4 million for the purchase of a major position in Datacast Inc., a company formed to carry financial information within the network's television signal to 18 million cable viewers.

headline: GANDHI STARTS TO USE HIS NEW BROOM
abstract: By the tens of thousands, politicians from across India arrived here earlier this month, resumes in hand. But for many of these aspirants for new terms in public office, a surprise was waiting.    Mr. Gandhi, who had already removed numerous longtime office holders, this time denied no fewer than 40 percent of his party's incumbents a chance to run in state elections in March. Many of those ousted were veterans of years of legislative service.    After little more than 100 days in office, Mr. Gandhi is still jolting the expectations of many supporters and critics with a series of changes in the Government that he inherited when his mother, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, was assassinated on Oct. 31.

headline: Business Week's Pierce Leaving to Join Lotus
abstract: James R. Pierce, publisher since mid-1982 of Business Week magazine, surprised his fellow workers last week by turning in his resignation.

headline: SHULTZ SAYS PLAN FOR SPACE DEFENSE IS GAINING SUPPORT
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that there was growing national support for the Administration's plan to develop a space-based defense system.   At the opening of a Senate hearing on foreign policy, Mr. Shultz and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, who appeared later, said the plan, known as the Strategic Defense Initiative, was crucial to the stability of the strategic relationship with the Soviet Union and could reduce the threat of nuclear war.   The plan, for which the Government wants to spend $26 billion in preliminary research, has attracted both increasing support and increasing opposition since it was formulated two years ago. (Page A5.)

headline: BTR MAKES A BID FOR DUNLOP, WHICH CALLS IT 'OPPORTUNISTIC'
abstract: BTR stepped in today with an offer to buy Dunlop Holdings, which only last Tuesday proposed terms of a financial restructuring after almost a year of painstaking negotiations guided by the Bank of England.   The offer was denounced by Dunlop's chairman, Sir Michael Edwardes, as ''grossly inadequate and opportunistic.''    Market analysts said the stage was now set for a battle between two powerhouses of British industry, Sir Michael and Sir Owen Green, who has presided over a profit growth at BTR that has outpaced all other major British manufacturers. Sir Michael recently came to Dunlop after being chief executive of BL, formerly British Leyland, and ICL, the British computer manufacturer.

headline: Stocks Advance in Heavy Volume
abstract: The stock market ended generally higher yesterday in continued heavy trading.    Although the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.11 point, to 1,230.68, there were 1,092 advancing issues on The New York Stock Exchange, twice as many as the 541 that declined.    Analysts said this reinforced the broad resurgence of secondary issues and the involvement of individual investors as well as institutions.

headline: Adjustable Stock From U.S. Steel
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation has offered two issues of money market preferred stock totaling $125 million, with an initial dividend yield of 6 1/2 percent, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman/American Express.

headline: Consumer Banks Delayed
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board, citing a Federal court ruling against the Comptroller of the Currency, announced Friday that it was suspending the processing of pending applications from bank holding companies to acquire or establish limited-service, or nonbank, banks.   The board said in a statement that such applications were being returned.

headline: Market Place;   Bullish On Foreign Stocks
abstract: BAILARD, BIEHL & KAISER INC. of San Mateo, Calif., takes a positive view of investment opportunities in foreign securities markets. ''Our asset allocation in that sector is now 15 percent for individual accounts and we plan to increase that to 20 percent within the next several months,'' Ronald W. Kaiser, a senior vice president, said Friday. ''About one-half of our foreign stocks are Japanese companies, with the remainder concentrated in Europe.''    Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser provides investment advisory and financial planning services. Its investment counseling arm has $375 million under management, mainly for wealthy individuals.

headline: Salvador Helicopter Crash
abstract: A Salvadoran Air Force UH-1 helicopter carrying an American military adviser crashed today during a routine training mission, according to spokesmen for the United States Embassy and the Salvadoran Army. The adviser and two Salvadoran pilots were not hurt.

headline: Provincetown International
abstract: Provincetown International Ltd., a New York-based financial services holding company, sold shares of two insurance brokerages, Frank B. Hall & Company and Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., on the open market for $35.6 million.   In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Provincetown said it and its subsidiaries had sold 781,400 Alexander common shares in two transactions for prices of $25.35 and $25.50 a share, for a total of $19.8 million.

headline: Chinese Oil Exploration
abstract: China said today that it was opening 18 more offshore oil exploration blocks to bids from international companies.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: SATURDAY, MARCH 16, 1985        The Ohio Bank Crisis         Governor Celeste of Ohio ordered 71 thrift institutions closed for three days after efforts to stem a run on deposits at several of them failed. The emergency action is believed to be the most extensive closing of financial institutions in the United States since the Depression. The run on deposits followed the collapse of one of the state's largest thrift institutions last week; that threatened to wipe out Ohio's private deposit insurance fund covering state-chartered thrift institutions. Commercial banks and federally chartered savings and loan institutions were not affected. (Page 1.)

headline: Taiwan Admiral Named At Murder Trial
abstract: A reputed gang leader testified today that the chief of Taiwan's military intelligence had ordered him to murder a Chinese-American journalist on the ground that the journalist had been a ''double agent'' who had spied for both Taiwan and China.    Chen Chi-li, who is charged with the murder on Oct. 15 of Henry Liu in Daly City, Calif., told a pretrial hearing that he had decided to disobey the order from the military intelligence chief, Vice Adm.

headline: NEW COMPETITION HURTS THE RETAIL
abstract: THE changes that are forecast for the retail securities business may fundamentally change the nature of the industry. The traditional revenue base of the retail brokerage firm is in jeopardy. But that is not the only threat to our future. More important, our relationships with our clients are going to be severely challenged, according to a recent study by the Securities Industry Association. The products and services offered by competitors of brokerage firms will continue to evolve. The dollars and resources that we must commit to new technologies will continue to rise.   The upshot of these changes is that future growth of retail revenues most likely will not sustain the profit margins we have traditionally enjoyed, and the expenses of competing are going to expand dramatically. All in all, we have before us a harsher competitive environment.

headline: D'Amato to Head Unit On Soviet-Bloc Rights
abstract: Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, was named today to head the Helsinki Commission, a group of senators and congressmen that monitors human rights abuses in the Soviet bloc.    Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, announced that Mr. D'Amato would replace Representative Dante Fascell, Democrat of Florida, as chairman.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Apple Co-founder Leaving Company
abstract: Stephen Wozniak, the brilliant and erratic computer whiz who with Steven P. Jobs founded Apple Computer Inc. in a garage in 1976, announced yesterday that he intends to leave Apple to start up a home video products company.
