''I've been really into computers for 10 years, and that's a long time,'' Mr. Wozniak said in an interview. ''I don't know many people who stay with the same thing that long.''

headline: Smith Barney Is Censured
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had censured Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company for failing to properly supervise one of its brokers. The action stemmed from $780,000 in losses suffered by customers of the firm's Rhinelander, Wis., office after they sold uncovered options of the Cities Service Company in June 1982.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 18, 1985:

headline: Financial Corp. Sets New Layoffs
abstract: The Financial Corporation of America, which just completed cutbacks aimed at saving about $35 million a year, plans more layoffs before the end of March, the company said.   A company spokesman, Layna Browdy, declined, however, to say how large the layoffs would be except that they would be sizable. She added that they would come from the lending, administrative and personnel operations of the troubled company and its chief subsidiary, the American Savings and Loan Association.

headline: 4 REFUSE TO TESTIFY ON AQUINO
abstract: Four witnesses failed to appear today in the trial of 25 military men and a civilian in the killing of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.    The four witnesses were relatives of Rolando Galman, the man originally identified by Philippine authorities as Mr. Aquino's assassin.    The prosecutor, Manuel Herrera, noted that the four had told a local newspaper that they would not cooperate with the court as long as the accused enjoyed special conditions in jail.

headline: GIBSON STOCK OFFERED FOR SALE
abstract: Senior management at Gibson Greetings Inc. and Wesray, a partnership, are selling 3.5 million share of the greeting card company in a public offering through Shearson Lehman Brothers.   The stoick was offered yesterday at $19.95 a share and Gibson closed at $19.875 in over-the-counter trading.  After the sale, management and Wesray wil own 50.2 percent of the company's stock , down from 64 percent.  Wesray's two major sellers of stock are William E. Simon, a former Treasury Secretary, who will sell 790,000 shares to reduce his ownership in the company to 17.4 percent, from 22.5 percent, and his equal partner in Wesray, Raymond A Chambers, who is selling about 727,000 shares

headline: The Check Isn't in the Mail
abstract: Computer problems at the Internal Revenue Service have slowed the mailing of tax refunds. The delay has frustrated the I.R.S., annoyed taxpayers and bothered some not directly affected - particularly those who track the nation's money supply.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THURSDAY, MARCH 21, 1985        International         Union Carbide traced the plant disaster in India to operating errors and procedural violations that it said are never tolerated at a similar plant in West Virginia. The company said the deadly reaction apparently occurred when a large amount of water entered a storage tank containing methyl isocyanate, but it said the entry would not have had so drastic a result without the six or more errors and violations involved. (Page A1.) Carbide provided highly technical information but was unable to answer some important questions about the disaster, including who was to blame. (Page A1.)         The President of Argentina told Congress that the debt crisis threatens peace in the Western Hemisphere. Argentine has recently fallen out of compliance with an I.M.F. loan agreement. (A5.)

headline: COMPTROLLER EXPECTED TO APPEAL BANKING RULING
abstract: Banking officials said today that the Comptroller of the Currency would almost certainly appeal a Federal judge's halt to further expansion of interstate banking through the chartering of limited-service banks.    A spokesman for C. Todd Conover, the Comptroller, said he had not decided how to respond to a Federal District Court order that he stop issuing final charters for limited-service banks. However, the spokesman, Ellen Stockdale, said that an appeal was the most likely course.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Computer Leases Back Financing by Sperry
abstract: The move to repackage loans and other assets into securities took a large step forward yesterday when the Sperry Corporation announced plans to sell $200 million of notes backed by computer leases, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.    The financing, which is the first of its kind, was registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and is expected to be rated AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The notes are backed by a pool of about 75 leases on computer equipment, with Sperry and its newly formed Sperry Lease Finance subsidary guaranteeing up to 20 percent of the pool against default. Defaults on the notes have been less than one-half of 1 percent in the past. The ability of Sperry and its subsidiary to pay is supported by an irrevocable bank letter of credit.

headline: Marcos Appears in Public
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, making his first appearance outside the presidential palace in four months, saw his wife off to Moscow today for the funeral of Konstantin U. Chernenko.

headline: GREEK PUBLISHER IS SLAIN IN HIS CAR
abstract: The publisher of a conservative newspaper was shot dead tonight as he was being driven to his office here, and a leftist organization called the November 17th Group claimed responsibility.    The publisher's chauffeur was seriously wounded.   The slain man, Nikos Momferatos, 62 years old, was publisher of the mass circulation conservative daily, Apogevmatini - The Afternoon - and president of the Athens Publishers' Union.

headline: Altschiller Reitzfeld, WABC-TV Part Ways
abstract: Although it was announced last August that Altschiller Reitzfeld Solin had become agency for WABC-TV, Channel 7, and even though it went right to work to produce advertising, the agency and the client never did reach an agreement on compensation. And their inability to do that led to an announcement yesterday by the station that negotiations had been called off and the relationship had been ended.

headline: FEARFUL CITY IN SOUTHERN SUDAN EXPECTS REBEL ATTACK
abstract: The American compound is almost deserted. So is the United Nations enclave. Norwegian Church Aid, a mainstay of the regional aid and relief effort, has evacuated about 150 of its staff and dependents to Nairobi, Kenya.    Ninety percent of the foreign relief workers have left Juba and nearby towns in the last two weeks. Today, the Sudanese insurgents who have been fighting since 1983, warned foreigners to leave to avoid being killed, according to a rebel broadcast from Ethiopia.

headline: French Output Down
abstract: Industrial production in France fell 1.6 percent in January from the month before, the National Statistics Institute said today. In a separate report, the Labor Ministry said the unemployment rate fell to 10.9 percent in February from 11.4 percent in January.

headline: AMERICAN AND COASTAL DISCUSS BID
abstract: In a sign that a hostile takeover bid may turn friendly, the American Natural Resources Company of Detroit said that its chairman and chief executive, Arthur R. Seder Jr., had met yesterday with Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., head of the Coastal Corporation of Houston.     Both are major pipeline companies. Up to now Mr. Seder had refused to even meet with the Houston oilman and American has been vigorously opposing his unwanted advances.    Whether the meeting meant that Mr. Seder had now decided to negotiate a deal with Mr. Wyatt, possibly based on a price acceptable to both sides, could not be determined.

headline: CITY OF MADAME BUTTERFLY LOOKS TO THE NEXT ACT
abstract: The Mayor was not in. He was attending a peace conference in West Berlin, a fact that had a certain symmetry to it.   Nagasaki, as every Japanese knows, was the second city to have an atomic bomb dropped on it, and so its leaders get called upon to talk about war and peace more than most municipal officals.  Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima, in office for six years, preaches good will more fervently than most of his predecessors. Recently, for example, he stood on a downtown street corner, collecting money to help famine victims in Africa.

headline: MADRID IN BASQUE PACT AIMED AT THE TERRORISTS
abstract: Spain's governing Socialist Party and the Basque region's governing party have signed a legislative pact designed in part to politically isolate separatist Basque terrorists.   Jubilant officials in the Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez said that the pact, signed Wednesday, was the most significant development in the troubled relations between Madrid and the Basque region since the signing of the Statute of Guernica five years ago giving the region limited autonomy.   Fulfillment of that statute has been mired in political bitterness, personal jealousies and regional passions, involving hundreds of kidnappings and assassinations by Basque terrorists demanding complete independence.   The new pact calls for the two governing parties to cooperate in carrying out the Guernica statute and ''to work together, within the demands of a state of law, in the fight against violence and terrorism.''

headline: Taiwan Inquiry Extended
abstract: Military prosecutors extended for two months today an investigative period to determine if three military intelligence officers were involved in the slaying of a Chinese-American writer, Henry Liu, who was shot dead at his home in Daly City, Calif., last Oct. 15, official sources said. The three officers were implicated by an informer.

headline: ETHIOPIA WILL REPORTEDLY ARM FOOD CONVOYS
abstract: Ethiopia plans to use armed convoys to transport famine-relief supplies into its northern provinces, where guerrillas have been active, a high-ranking United Nations official said here today.     The official, Kurt Jansson, an Assistant Secretary General in charge of emergency operations in Ethiopia, said he ''raised the issue of food distribution in areas of Tigre and Eritrea where security is a problem'' in a meeting this week with the Ethiopian head of state, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam.    The conflict between the rebels and Government troops has continued for years in the provinces of Eritrea and Tigre, and there has been international concern that little food has been reaching the starving people of these regions.

headline: Utility Board Election Set CONCORD, N.H., March 18
abstract: The Public Service Company   of New Hampshire has successfully concluded a hurried effort   to re-elect the company's board   of directors at an unusual annual meeting later this week.  Proxies received by management call for the preferred   shareholders to re-elect seven   members of the board, and for   the common shareholders to   elect the other six.

headline: Hunt Sugar Unit In Chapter 11
abstract: The Great Western Sugar Company, one of the last assets of the Hunt International Resources Company, has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The Denver-based company had been shut down last week by its parent company, which is owned by Nelson Bunker Hunt and W. Herbert Hunt of Dallas.

headline: COLECO POSTS LOSS IN QUARTER
abstract: Buffeted by its withdrawal of the Adam home computer from the market, Coleco Industries today reported a $93.2 million loss in the fourth quarter of 1984, compared with a $35 million loss in the 1983 period.   For all of 1984, the company lost $79.8 million, compared with a $7.4 million loss for 1983, Coleco's president, Arnold C. Greenberg, said in a letter to stockholders.   Last year's operating profit of $208.6 million from the company's toy segment was more than offset by an operating loss of $140 million in the consumer electronics segment and a loss of $118.6 million associated with the disposition of the Adam computer system, Mr. Greenberg said.

headline: FEBRUARY TOOL ORDERS ROSE 12.4%
abstract: Orders for American-made machine tools rose 12.4 percent in February from the month before and 17.1 percent from February 1984, the industry's trade association said in a report to be released today.     The National Machine Tool Builders' Association described the mood of the industry as one of ''cautious optimism,'' as manufacturers of machine tools continued their gradual recovery from two years of huge losses.        Industry 'Smaller'    James A. Gray, president of the association, said the industry had become ''significantly smaller, with a smaller share of the domestic market. In an effort to reverse this trend, our companies are streamlining operations, applying new technologies and, in many cases, forming joint ventures with foreign manufacturers.''

headline: Anti-Communist Group Raided by Polish Police
abstract: The police raided a meeting of an outlawed anti-Communist group in Warsaw and arrested at least five members, the wife of the group's leader said today.    The official Polish press agency said the security police broke up a meeting of the group, the Confederation of Independent Poland, on Saturday.

headline: A.T.&T. Consolidates Accounts Under Ayer
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it had decided to consolidate its consumer products advertising under one agency, N W Ayer.

headline: U.S. and Southland At Odds on Obstruction
abstract: The Justice Department official whose office gained a criminal conspiracy conviction against the Southland Corporation has charged that in investigating the case, ''the Government encountered a code of silence that rivaled anything seen in its experience with organized crime.''    Southland's chief attorney in the case has replied that the official was making ''shrill and irresponsible charges,'' and that the company cooperated with the investigation and did not seek to delay it.   The exchange, which became public yesterday, was touched off last week when Raymond J. Dearie, United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, sent a letter to Judge Charles P. Sifton of Federal District Court in Brooklyn. In the letter, Mr. Dearie urged the judge not to impose a jail sentence on a former Southland vice president, Eugene DeFalco.

headline: WASHINGTON WATCH;Questions for Hodel
abstract: Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel is expected to be closely questioned at a Senate confirmation hearing Friday on his shift to the Department of the Interior.         Some staff members, spurred by an independent analyst, Loren R. Needles, think the United States has been overstating the size of energy-efficiency gains. The Energy Department has been using a ''rubber yardstick,'' they say, because it does not remove the energy component from gross national product before looking at the relationship between the two.

headline: CHEMICAL UP 19.8% IN FOURTH QUARTER
abstract: The Chemical New York Corporation, the first of the major banking companies to report its fourth-quarter results, yesterday announced a 19.8 percent gain in net income, to $105.5 million, from $88.1 million in the comparable period of 1983. On a per-share basis, net income climbed 16 percent, to $2.03, from $1.75.     ''Real solid performance,'' said James J. McDermott Jr., senior vice president of Keefe, Bruyete & Woods, a securities firm that specializes in bank stocks. ''It's a precursor of what investors can expect from the big banks in the fourth quarter,''    Declining interest rates, heavy loan demand, lower provisions for loan losses and $6.5 million in past-due interest payments from Argentina contributed to Chemical's strong fourth quarter.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;    Phibro Names a Panel For Non-Oil Business
abstract: In a move intended to bolster bottom line performance, Phibro-Salomon Inc. said yesterday that a nine- member executive committee had been appointed to oversee the non-oil business at Phillipp Brothers Inc., its commodities marketing subsidiary.    The company said that Alan Flacks, the 54-year-old chairman and chief executive of Phillipp Brothers, would head the committee. Other members include Walter E. Baker, 48, Phibro-Salomon's chief financial officer and a number of commodity specialists based in New York, Europe and Japan. Included in this group are Ernst Fraenkel, 61, who is based in Zug, Switzerland; Martin M. Kaufman, 31, based in London; Nobuo Kohyama, 45, based in Tokyo; and Henry Schacher, 31, who is based in New York. Ludwig Jesselson, 74, former president and chief executive of Phillipp Brothers, will serve as an adviser, Phibro-Salomon said.

headline: U.S.-GREEK STRAINS TURN SMALL ISSUES INTO BIG ONES
abstract: For many months, senior Greek and American officials have been preoccupied with such matters as labor-management relations at United States military bases and the renewal of a civil aviation agreement.    It is rare for such routine business to reach the higher levels of Government between friendly nations. But in the case of Greece and the United States, the bitterness engendered by these issues and the amount of time both sides have devoted to them is viewed by diplomats here as a reflection of the greater controversies dividing the countries - nuclear weapons, the Atlantic alliance and the confrontation between the Soviet bloc and the West.   Senior officials of the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou say the objective of their stands on relatively minor issues as well as on major policy is to use the limited powers of a small nation to reprimand its allies, principally the United States, for what Greece considers favoritism toward Turkey.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Buffalo and Erie County Plan Major Bond Sales
abstract: The City of Buffalo and Erie County, recovering from the closing of major steel plants in recent years, are in the midst of several major bond financings.    Buffalo, which turned a $5.3 million budget deficit in 1982 into a $7 million surplus at the end of last year, was regarded so highly that its bonds were insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurace Corporation. ''Buffalo has turned the corner with its finances,'' said Roger K. Taylor, executive vice president at Financial Guaranty. ''We normally don't insure bonds rated Baa, but exceptions are made for cases like Buffalo where the credit quality is stable to improving.''

headline: Elias Eliou, 81, Former Head Of Left-Wing Party in Greece
abstract: Elias Eliou, former leader of a political party that served as a front for Greek Communists before the Communist Party was legalized in 1974, died today of kidney failure, his family said. He was 81 years old.

headline: Economic Scene ;   Reagan's Revolution
abstract: President Reagan's State of the Union Message may not have made a lot of fresh news. But it was, as Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin put it, a remarkable piece of ''show biz,'' from the President's call for a Second American Revolution, his modest bid for a place in the history books next to George Washington, to his shy enjoyment of a Congressional first, the enthusiastic singing of ''Happy Birthday, Mr. President'' by Republicans and Democrats alike.    Yet the occasion was not utterly devoid of news. For one thing, Mr. Reagan increased his commitment to what he called a ''historic reform of tax simplification for fairness and growth.'' Skeptics may still wait to see how hard the President fights to overcome the opposition of the ''special interests,'' some of them commercial, some eleemosynary and some personal, but Mr. Reagan gave every sign of meaning business.

headline: Buick Skylark
abstract: The General Motors Corporation will keep a Buick Skylark in its car lineup despite plans to stop building the current X-car version, the company's Buick division said. The company confirmed last week that the X-cars would be discontinued in May because of slumping sales and a controversy over purported brake problems. Buick said it would introduce a new four-door, front-wheel-drive compact Skylark in the 1986 model year as a companion to its two-door Somerset compact that was brought to market last fall.

headline: Embryo Research Ban Supported in Britain
abstract: A bill that would ban experiments on human embryos has cleared a parliamentary hurdle, but the Government is expected to prevent it from becoming law.   The bill, introduced by Enoch Powell, an Ulster Unionist and former Health Minister, passed a second reading, or debate, in the House of Commons on Friday.

headline: SALVADOR GUERRILLAS CLASH WITH MILITARY JUST OUTSIDE CAPITAL
abstract: Leftist guerrillas attacked a key communications complex on a volcano overlooking San Salvador today, setting off the heaviest fighting in the capital area in more than three years, military officials said.   A rebel force of about 400 was repulsed by a 52-man National Guard unit backed by army reinforcements and air force gunships after four hours of fighting, the army chief of staff, Gen. Adolfo Blandon, told reporters.   Several helicopters and a C-47 flying gun platform circled the 5,400-foot San Salvador volcano during the predawn battle, strafing and pounding steep ravines just above the capital's most exclusive suburbs.

headline: Auto Quota Costs Weighed WASHINGTON, Feb. 14
abstract: (Reuters) - Limits on Japanese car imports have cost   American consumers $15.7 billion in higher prices on domestic and foreign cars since 1981,   according to a Government   study released today. The International Trade   Commission study comes as   the Reagan Administration   weighs its position on the car   trade agreement with Japan   that expires at the end of   March.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Knapp's Empire Crumbles
abstract: Charles W. Knapp, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Financial Corporation of America, had long been lauded as one of the most innovative savings and loan executives. That praise, however, disappeared last summer, as his company, which had moved too far, too fast, started crumbling around him.

headline: Doctors for Brazilian Leader Report Intestinal 'Alterations'
abstract: Doctors attending Brazil's President-elect, Tancredo Neves, said today that he is suffering from ''alterations'' in his intestinal movements following the emergency surgery that prevented him from assuming office last Friday.   With rumors sweeping the country that his condition had deteriorated, specialists as well as senior political figures were summoned this morning to the Hospital de Base in Brasilia where the 75-year-old Mr. Neves is still under intensive care.

headline: Money Fund Assets Down Assets of the nation's money
abstract: market mutual funds fell $1.04   billion, to $211.97 billion, for the   week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute   reported yesterday.

headline: C.I.A. Chief Says Tide Is Now Against Soviet
abstract: The Director of Central Intelligence said yesterday that resistance to Soviet military aggression imposed directly or by proxy was growing and offered the Western countries an opportunity that must not be ignored.

headline: U.N. Expects 19 Relief Ships To Reach Ethiopia This Month
abstract: Nineteen ships carrying 133,000 metric tons of food aid, one-tenth of Ethiopia's total estimated relief needs for 1985, are expected to arrive by the end of this month, a United Nations official said today.    ''The flow of food aid from abroad this year looks assured,'' said Desmond Taylor, the officer in charge of the United Nations emergency operation in Ethiopia.

headline: Philadelphia Shop Gets Silo Inc. Assignment
abstract: Lewis, Gilman & Kynett, a Philadelphia subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding, has become the ad agency for Silo Inc., a retail discount appliance chain that is a division of the Universal-Cyclops Corporation of Pittsburgh.

headline: HIGH PLACE OF PATIENCE
abstract: LAST June, when most investors were worrying   over the stock market, Charles Allmon made   his move. In the accounts that he manages for clients, he went from a big cash position to 75 percent invested.    ''Right now we are about 95 percent invested,'' Mr. Allmon said this week in Chevy Chase, Md., where he tends $165 million in managed accounts, divided about equally between individual and institutional clients. He also publishes two well-known investment advisory reports - Growth Stock Outlook and Junior Growth Stocks.

headline: A PERILOUS DIP IN BRAZIL'S EXPORTS
abstract: RIO DE JANEIRO      Selling commuter planes to   the United States, oil rigs to the   Soviet Union and myriad other products to all points in between, Brazil's exporters last year became the toast of the International Monetary Fund and the foreign banking community.   The exporters demonstrated, after all, that the country's worst economic crisis in decades could be overcome with good, salable products and hard work. As a result, the Brazilians were held up as models to other Latin American nations being urged to cover their huge foreign debt payments by earning more from exports.   Brazil's achievement was impressive. A record $13.1 billion trade surplus fueled a 4.4 percent growth rate last year - the first expansion of the economy since 1980 - and supplied the dollars necessary to meet interest payments on the country's $102 billion foreign debt. It seemed the worst was over for Brazil.

headline: U.S. EMBASSY EVACUATES CHILDREN AFTER REPORTING THREATS IN BOGOTA
abstract: The United States has begun evacuating the children of American Embassy personnel from Colombia because of reported threats to the children's lives from Colombian drug traffickers, State Department officials said today.   In the latest development in what one official called an ''undeclared war'' between the United States and the drug traffickers in Colombia, the United States Embassy in Bogota received intelligence reports in recent days that Colombian criminals were plotting to kill or kidnap children of American diplomats, department officials said.   Last November, the United States evacuated about 10 diplomats and their families after the embassy received threats of retaliation by drug traffickers for stepped-up efforts to try to block the export of marijuana and cocaine to the United States. On Nov. 26, a bomb exploded under a car near the embassy, killing a Colombian woman but not harming any Americans.

headline: Reagan Gives Hint on G.N.P. WASHINGTON, Jan. 21
abstract: President Reagan announced at an inaugural ball tonight that two economic figures   to be released by the Commerce Department this week   will show the most dramatic   improvement in the economy   in more than 30 years. ''I'm not going to give you all   the facts,'' Mr. Reagan said at   the ball at the Pension Building.

headline: MANILA EXPECTING AQUINO CASE TRIAL
abstract: A Philippine opposition newspaper reported today that an inquiry board would recommend the indictment of Gen. Fabian C. Ver, the suspended Chief of Staff, and 25 others for the 1983 slaying of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the opposition leader.    The report, in the daily Malaya, followed recent indications that the Government panel would agree with the majority ruling of a citizens board in October finding the 26 men indictable.   ''I know that is what people expect,'' a member of the Government panel said. ''But I will not confirm or deny the Malaya story.''

headline: Canon Will Build 2 Kodak Copiers
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced two new copying machines that will be made by Canon Inc. of Japan but sold exclusively by Kodak.

headline: G.O.P. LEADERSHIP SEEKING A FREEZE IN SOCIAL SECURITY
abstract: Business leaders said the President's budget should have done more to narrow the deficit. Page D1.       WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 - Senate Republican leaders said today that they would propose a one-year elimination of the cost-of-living increase for Social Security pensioners as part of a package aimed at reducing Government spending by at least $50 billion in 1986.   The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, stressed that the Republicans would support the elimination, beginning next January, only as part of a larger package that included cuts in other domestic programs and in the military budget.   Meanwhile, Republican and Democratic members of the Senate Budget Committee bluntly told Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that he should expect President Reagan's military budget request to be reduced.

headline: Skybus Relocation Plan
abstract: Skybus Inc., which recently bought Denver- based Frontier Horizon Airlines, has proposed to move its headquarters to Atlanta and to offer nonstop service from Atlanta to six cities.

headline: COMPUTERS CAN EASE PREPARATION
abstract: THERE is really only one reason to use a personal computer and specialized software to prepare a tax return and that is to ease an altogether burdensome chore. A personal computer cannot interpret tax law, nor can it supply records of deductible expenses that its owner neglected to keep. Most software programs can assist only with Federal, not state, taxes. But a personal computer can ease the task of preparing taxes to the extent that the taxpayers using it understand how the tax laws apply to their particular returns.   ''A computer isn't an electronic accountant,'' said Norman D. Nicholson, editor of Computerized Investing magazine. ''It's only really going to help people who understand what goes into their return - and for some of them, a computer is overkill.''

headline: Tull Industries Rejects Inland Bid
abstract: J.M. Tull Industries said that its board recommended that shareholders reject the Inland Steel Company's $19 dollar-a-share tender offer. Tull said that, after consulting with its investment advisers, Kidder, Peabody & Company, it decided to write a letter to shareholders saying the offer was inadequate and not in their best interests.

headline: COMPUTER IMPORTS SOUGHT BY SOVIETS
abstract: The Soviet Union is negotiating to buy large numbers of Western-made personal computers, including Apple and I.B.M. models, according to industry sources.    The computers are apparently for use in scientific institutes and schools.    The move marks the first time the Russians have sought personal computers from Western nations and Japan in the open market. It is possible because of recently liberalized high-technology trade rules that went into effect five weeks ago.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: American Express International Banking Corp. , the international banking arm of American Express Co., has elected Amos Bergner, J. Barry Brokaw, Sem Almaleh and Michel Cartillier executive vice presidents.     *       BancOhio National Bank, Columbus, has elected David A. Daberko president.     *       Canadian Pacific Air Lines Ltd. , Vancouver, British Columbia, has appointed Donald Carty president and chief executive officer.

headline: THE MARKET
abstract: To the Editor:     The problem of institutionalization of the system is present in all aspects of our economic system.

headline: Top Editor of Pravda Says Chernenko Is Ill
abstract: The editor in chief of the Soviet party daily Pravda confirmed tonight that Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, is ill, but said he remains in charge of the country and the Communist Party.    ''I have to tell you that Comrade Chernenko is ill,'' the editor, Viktor G. Afanasyev, told an Italian journalist, Enzo Biagi, in an interview over a telecommunications link between Rome and Moscow that was broadcast on Italian state television.

headline: BRAZILIAN COMPLAINT: HIGH INTEREST
abstract: Brazil's President-elect, Tancredo Neves, today called on the United States to reduce its ''very cruel'' interest rates.     But Mr. Neves, speaking to the National Press Club near the end of his three-day courtesy visit to Washington, said his central message was that ''Brazil is the friendliest nation the United States has in this hemisphere.'' He added, ''Relations between Brazil and the United States are remarkably lacking in problems of a political nature.''

headline: ADVERTISING;2 Agencies GetNew Assignments
abstract: Two agencies picked up big creative-only assignments on Friday. Cunningham &  Walsh got its from Aamco Transmissions. And Benton & Bowles was tapped by Jeffrey Martin Inc., the health care and beauty products marketer.         Aamco, with headquarters in Bala- Cynwyd, Pa., has almost 1,000 franchise locations throughout the country. Its advertising is bought and placed locally and there was about $11 million of it last year. The former agency was Calet, Hirsch & Spector.

headline: IN U.S., DIFFICULT NEGOTIATIONS ARE FORESEEN
abstract: Former United States Government negotiators and academic specialists in Soviet affairs yesterday greeted the agreement in Geneva to resume arms talks as an encouraging first step. But they also cautioned that agreement on the substantive issues dividing the two superpowers would be slower and much more difficult to achieve.     ''I am glad to see that a preliminary agreement has been reached,'' said former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance. ''It means that we will be moving on to serious negotiations, but it is going to require some hard slogging to reach a substantive agreement.''

headline: Archbishop Dermot J. Ryan; Ex-Head of Church in Dublin
abstract: Archbishop Dermot J. Ryan, a former head of the Dublin archdiocese who had been serving in a high Vatican post, died of a heart attack today, church officials said. He was 60 years old.

headline: AUSTRIAN APOLOGIZES FOR MEETING A WAR CRIMINAL
abstract: The Austrian Defense Minister publicly apologized today for having met with an Austrian Nazi war criminal who was released from an Italian prison last week.   The Defense Minister, Friedhelm Frischenschlager, who is a member of the right-wing Freedom Party, met with the man, Walter Reder, a former major in the SS, in Graz, where Mr. Reder was flown after being freed by the Italians on Thursday.   Mr. Reder was convicted in 1951 of responsibility in the deaths of 600 people in the mouintain village of Marzabotto, near Bologna, in September 1944.

headline: CHERNENKO WARNS AGAINST DECEPTION AT GENEVA PARLEY
abstract: Konstantin U. Chernenko said today that the Geneva arms-control talks with the United States must be ''honest and businesslike'' and that the Soviet Union would brook no attempts at deception.    Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko are due to arrive in Geneva on Sunday for a two-day meeting aimed at preparing the ground for a new set of arms negotiations. (Page 10.)    Mr. Chernenko stressed the Kremlin's desire to block an arms race in outer space, saying the militarization of space would be irreversible.

headline: Thais Say Cambodians Fended Off Vietnamese
abstract: Khmer Rouge guerrillas repulsed a Vietnamese attack on their mountain strongholds in western Cambodia today, Thai officers said.

headline: Steel Accord Completed
abstract: An accord to limit European steel pipe and tube exports to the United States has been completed, and letters of agreement will be exchanged Friday, United States trade officials said today. Reports last week said the exports would probably be limited to about 700,000 tons a year.

headline: Money Supply
abstract: To the Editor:     If the plans proposed in ''Open Up the Money Supply Spigot'' (Dec. 23) were feasible, the third world or lesser developed countries would not have their present serious financial problems. Most of the LDC's are masters of printing semi-worthless paper money, which is what your article was really all about.    Mexico has devalued the peso from 50 cents to less than 1/2 cent without having reached a bottom! The same generally holds true for Brazil, Argentina, et al. The excessive printing of money has increased poverty.

headline: WINANS DENIES SCHEME WAS DEVISED BY HIM
abstract: R. Foster Winans, the former Wall Street Journal reporter on trial for conspiracy and securities fraud, testified yesterday that at the time he gave out advance information about stock market columns he did not believe that he was committing a crime. He also contended that the plan to share that information with others was not his idea.    ''It was suggested on Oct. 12, 1983, by Peter Brant in the lounge of the Racquet and Tennis Club'' in Manhattan, Mr. Winans said in reply to the first question asked by his lawyer. Mr. Brant is a former broker for Kidder, Peabody & Company who has pleaded guilty to charges involving his dealings with Mr. Winans. Mr. Brant has testified for the prosecution that David J. Carpenter, Mr. Winans's roommate, came to him with a plan to share profits made from trading securities based on advance information.   While at The Journal, Mr. Winans wrote the ''Heard on the Street'' stock market column, which often has an impact on the prices of the securities it mentions.

headline: CONVERTING WASTE TO ENERGY
abstract: When the breeze wafts across the crowded landfills of 100 American cities, keen business noses recognize a familiar scent: money.     New York City, which has turned its last 20 years of garbage into the highest peak on the Eastern Seaboard, in a Staten Island landfill that will soon run out of space, is preparing to spend $2.5 billion on the construction of eight trash-to-energy plants, and billions more to operate them.   San Francisco and neighboring municipalities recently agreed to the construction of a $200 million plant that will burn hundreds of tons of garbage a day and produce 40 megawatts of electricity. In the meantime, since they have filled nearby landfills, they haul their refuse 57 miles.    From the burgeoning population centers of Florida to the sparsely settled reaches of Alaska, North American cities are finding that burning their wastes and selling the energy as electricity or steam is cheaper or healthier than operating dumps. Few municipal governments are equipped to build and run the plants, leaving private industry lots of room for profit.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;  $4.3 Billion Financing Heads New State Issues
abstract: Various authorities and local governments in New York State expect to sell nearly $6.3 billion of new securities in the quarter beginning in April, according to the State Securities Coordinating Committee.    The largest sale, estimated at $4.3 billion, will be the state's annual spring borrowing, where it finances its accumulated budget deficit and raises funds needed to make aid payments to local governments.

headline: GREEK CYPRIOTS FIGHT OVER PEACE AGREEMENT
abstract: Parliament demanded Friday night that President Spyros Kyprianou either accept a United Nations-sponsored draft agreement with Turkish Cypriots or order new presidential elections. The President refused today to do either.     In Parliament Friday night, the two leading parties, the conservative Democratic Rally and the Communists, combined to censure Mr. Kyprianou by a vote of 23 to 12.   They demanded that the President accept the draft agreement for a settlement of the Cyprus dispute prepared by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations. This would reverse his rejection of the document last month, when he met in New York with Rauf Denktash, leader of the Turkish Cypriots, and the Secretary General.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Centronics Data Computer Corp., Hudson, N.H., said it had agreed to acquire the operating assets of Trilog Inc. for about 170,000 common shares. The transaction is subject to approval by Trilog shareholders.

headline: U.N. AT 40: TALK OF A WAYWARD CHILD
abstract: Like so many disappointed parents, many of the participants at a two-day conference on the ''United Nations at 40'' expressed disillusionment, anger and resentment that the child they had conceived did not turn out the way they wanted.     The conference, sponsored by the Center for International Studies at New York University, served as a sort of unofficial kickoff to a flurry of festivities, speeches, articles, seminars and conferences scheduled over the next several months to mark the 40th birthday of the world organization.    Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar hopes to assemble ''dozens'' of heads of state to re-examine the United Nations and express a ''recommitment'' to the Charter. Already many heads of state have indicated that they intend to come and more than 100 nations are taking part in a preparatory committee.

headline: SANDINISTA GOVERNMENT VIEWED AS LEFTIST HYBRID
abstract: When Konstantin U. Chernenko died last week, the Nicaraguan Government declared three days of national mourning for the Soviet leader. To sorrowful strains of Chopin and Tchaikovsky, nightly news broadcasts praised ''Comrade Chernenko'' as a ''great statesman and untiring fighter for the cause of world peace and solidarity.''     For some Nicaraguans and many foreigners, the tributes to the Soviet leader were one more sign of the Government's eagerness to align itself with the practices and the values of the Eastern bloc. ''It was just the sort of thing you would see in Moscow,'' said a diplomat with experience in Communist capitals.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Stocks Up at Close; Dow Slips Again
abstract: Stock prices, in retreat most of the day, made a last-minute comeback and edged ahead yesterday. Broad market indexes again reached new highs, although the closely followed Dow Jones industrial average slipped.   At the close, the Dow average of 30 stocks was down 1.11 points, to 1,286.77, having recovered smartly from its 10-point deficit in midafternoon but still off from Tuesday's record close of 1,292.62.    Nevertheless, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 0.24, to close at a record 179.63. The New York Stock Exchange composite of more than 1,500 stocks also finished at a new high, climbing 0.10, to 103.75.

headline: 21 JEWISH GROUPS DEPLORE ISRAELI BILL
abstract: A coalition of 21 major American Jewish groups said yesterday that a proposal before the Israeli Parliament that would alter the definition of who is a Jew was ''morally and religiously offensive to us.''    ''The proposed change in the Law of Return would do violence to the principle of Jewish unity and jeopardize the sense of solidarity that binds the Jewish people everywhere to the state of Israel,'' the organizations said in a joint statement.   Under the legislation introduced by the religious parties in Israel and expected to be debated in Parliament tomorrow, only Orthodox conversions would be valid for those who want to enter Israel with the privileges of Jews.    The American protest was signed by Reform and Conservative groups as well as community service agencies, including the American Jewish Congress, the American Jewish Committee and B'nai B'rith.

headline: POPE BEGS REBELS TO END PERU WAR
abstract: Pope John Paul II issued a dramatic plea today to guerrilla fighters in this rugged Andean mountain province to lay down their arms and ''seek the roads of dialogue and not those of violence.''   Speaking in the heart of an area where guerrillas of the Shining Path movement have waged a war that has taken some 4,000 lives, the Pope declared, ''I beg you, with pain in my heart, and at the same time with firmness and hope, that you reflect on the roads you have taken.''   ''In the name of God, change roads!'' he shouted in his address to an airport crowd of about 15,000. ''You still have time. The many tears of innocent victims await your responses.''

headline: Shocks Still Shake Chile
abstract: Aftershocks of Chile's worst earthquake in 25 years sent shudders through the devastated countryside at four-minute intervals today as thousands of people camped in the streets. Rescue teams ended the search for people trapped in collapsed houses and the death toll from Sunday's quake stood at 151.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, JANUARY 11, 1985
abstract: Markets         Stocks soared, with the Dow Jones industrial average jumping 20.76 points, to 1,223.50. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange surged to 124.7 million shares, from 99.2 million. The rally, extending Wednesday's gains, was reinforced by comments from Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. (D1.) Mr. Volcker said the Fed has more flexibility in managing credit now that inflation appears under control. (D4.)         The basic money supply fell $500 million in the latest week.  The drop was much less than expected and bond prices fell. (D10.)

headline: European Farmers Protest
abstract: More than 10,000 French and West German farmers marched here today in protest against a Common Market proposal to impose a virtual freeze on farm prices for the 1985-86 season and set quotas on production.

headline: Xerox China Plans
abstract: The Xerox Corporation has taken the first step toward forming a joint venture later this year for the production of copiers in China, Xerox said.

headline: UNIONS SET TO MEET ON CONRAIL BIDS
abstract: A divided group of negotiators for the Consolidated Rail Corporation's labor unions begins a crucial set of bargaining meetings here Tuesday to try to extract from potential buyers of the carrier the best offer for Conrail's 35,000 workers.   In talking to the three remaining bidders, rail labor leaders will be balancing what may be conflicting goals - protecting jobs and recovering some of the wage concessions made to keep the railroad in business. The concessions, some analysts say, are responsible for Conrail's return to prosperity and accumulation of $800 million in cash.

headline: Article 224054 -- No Title
abstract: Gearing up for the $20 billion- a-year market for factory automation equipment envisioned in just five years, the Rockwell International Corporation announced yesterday that it had won an auction sale to buy the Allen-Bradley Company of Milwaukee with a sealed bid of $1.65 billion in cash.     Allen-Bradley, a private company, is one of the world's leading manufacturers of industrial computers used to run production equipment and of computerized devices to operate machine tools. Almost 40 percent of its business comes from the automotive industry.    As part of the deal, Claude R. Whitney, the 61-year-old chairman and chief executive of Allen-Bradley, and J. Tracy O'Rourke, 49, its president, would continue in those posts.

headline: 100 Policemen Surround Seoul Dissident's House
abstract: More than 100 police officers surrounded the home of a leading South Korean dissident for three hours today but withdrew, his aides said.

headline: Iraq Says Its Jets Strike 2 Targets in Gulf
abstract: Iraq said its warplanes attacked two ''naval targets'' today in the Persian Gulf near the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island. There was no immediate word from shipping sources in the gulf of any ships in difficulties today.

headline: PENTAGON STUDY EXPLORES PROFITS FOR CONTRACTORS
abstract: With Congress hungry for painless ways to cut military spending, the Pentagon is examining whether defense contractors make too much profit or not enough.     It hopes to find out whether its pricing rules encourage companies to cut costs or - as many critics charge - perversely reward inefficiency because, under the rules, higher costs generally yield greater profits.    This spring the Defense Department will complete its first comprehensive review of profits and accounting practices in a decade. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, is monitoring the Pentagon study and will issue its own evaluation.           Debate on Defense Budget    These two studies of procurement and profits are likely to figure prominently in the coming debate over the defense budget and may leave a lasting impact on one of the nation's largest industries - defense and aerospace.

headline: Imports . . . and Imports
abstract: After drawing down swollen inventories of foreign goods last summer and fall, American importers, loaded with even stronger dollars in the final quarter of 1984, went on another buying spree in abroad.    ''With the dollar and economy strengthening, we expect the merchandise trade deficit to continue to soar in 1985,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.  ''For example, we expect the Government to report this Thursday that the January deficit rose to $10.2 billion from $8.2 billion in December.''

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Fed's Policy Report Awaited
abstract: Although many economists are predicting higher interst rates by summer or year-end, fears that the Federal Reserve was encouraging a quick rise in rates have subsided.     When Federal Reserve Chairman Paul A. Volcker delivers the Fed's semi-annual report on monetary policy to the Senate Banking Committee today, credit market participants will of course be listening for clues to monetary policy decided at last week's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee.   But the Fed's willingness to provide funds to the banking system through temporary purchases of securities last Thursday and Friday convinced many specialists in the money markets that the central bank is holding policy stable.    ''The real issue is not so much what the Fed decided in February - I think everyone assumes that no real move to a tighter policy was made because that would make the dollar even stronger,'' said one Government securities trader. ''We will be listening to learn how willing the Fed is to bring the dollar down, how tolerant it will be if money supply growth remains above target and their outlook for the economy and inflation.''

headline: SOLDIERS PROTECT A WHITE TOWN IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Army and police units threw a protective ring around white residential areas near this troubled black township today, where five black people were hacked and burned to death by blacks in revenge killings Saturday.     The measure seem designed, white liberal politicians said, to assure the whites that any effort by blacks to carry protests outside the township in the restive Eastern Cape region would be forestalled. No such attempts have been reported.   A police spokesman, meanwhile, said three more blacks died here overnight after a police patrol opened fire on people setting fire to a liquor store. One person died immediately, the spokesman said; a second died later of wounds, and a third body was discovered at 5:30 A.M. today.

headline: 2 U.S. Envoys Nominated
abstract: President Reagan today nominated Faith Whittlesey, a White House public affairs aide, to serve as ambassador to Switzerland, where she served once before, from 1981 to 1983. Another ambassador, Fernando Rondon, now serving in Madagascar, is to be sent to Ecuador.

headline: U.S. AIDE WARNS BANKS ON TAKING CRIME FUNDS
abstract: Amid continuing reverberations about the Bank of Boston, which is under investigation by a Federal grand jury looking into money-laundering, the chief counsel of the President's Commission on Organized Crime came here today to deliver a lecture on the responsibilities of a bank in a nation at war with organized crime.   ''The attention being placed on financial institutions is unparalleled, and is absolutely essential in the fight against organized crime,'' James D. Harmon told 250 law enforcement officials assembled here for a meeting of the New England Organized Crime Drug Enforcement Task Force.   The attention given the Bank of Boston, which has grown intense this last week, has already begun to result in the withdrawal of some nominal deposits by small cities in the area, and in expressions of concern by the City of Boston, which has $44 million placed with the bank. As a result, bank officials today asked for a meeting with Mayor Raymond L. Flynn to discuss reports of a customer relationship with organized crime.

headline: Polaroid Net Slides 59.3% CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb.
abstract: 12 (AP) - The Polaroid Corporation said today that its profits   plummeted 59.3 percent in the   fourth quarter from a year   earlier, as the growing   strength of the dollar cut   sharply into overseas sales. The manufacturer of instant   cameras and films said its   profits fell to $10.3 million, or 33   cents a share, in the fourth   quarter, from $25.3 million, or   82 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Arco Chemical Europe Inc., a subsidiary of Atlantic Richfield Co., said it plans to build a new plant to produce Poly BD liquid resins at its existing petrochemical complex in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.     *       Avon Products Inc., a cosmetics concern, said its beauty products division would cut 150 of the 1,150-member staff at its Cincinatti facility and hopes to accomplish most of the reductions through a new early retirement program, for which more than 140 employees are eligible.

headline: CANADA ANNOUNCES PLAN TO REDUCE ITS ACID RAIN
abstract: The Canadian Government announced a major environmental plan today to reduce airborne emissions of sulfur and nitrogen oxides, better known as acid rain, by 50 percent in eastern Canada over the next nine years.   The program, which was announced by the Environment Minister, Suzanne Blais-Grenier, includes contributions totaling $109 million by 1994 to clean up Canadian smelters and the adoption in 1987 of tougher vehicle emission standards like those in the United States.    The announcement at a news conference, coming just 11 days before Prime Minister Brian Mulroney meets with President Reagan in Quebec, seemed timed to strengthen Canada's case for more joint action. Mr. Mulroney said last December that acid rain would be at the top of his agenda with Mr. Reagan.   However, Mrs. Blais-Grenier carefully avoided linking today's announcement to the Quebec meeting. She insisted that the program resulted from six months of work since the Mulroney Government came into office last September.

headline: Key Computer Editor In Ziff-Davis Talks
abstract: In the computer industry, Esther Dyson holds something of a charmed post: part newsletter publisher, part influential critic, part advocate for new technologies. Now, Miss Dyson, 33, appears ready to sell her rights to RELease 1.0, her erratically published and sometimes irreverent newsletter, to the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company and head up a new daily newspaper there covering the computer business.    Neither Miss Dyson nor Ziff-Davis officials would discuss details of the proposed new publication yesterday, but they said that a joint news conference was scheduled for March 29. Industry sources, however, said that the new publication would run more than four pages a day and replace Miss Dyson's current newsletter. Unlike Ziff's other computer magazines, the publication would carry no advertising, the sources said, but would charge a stiff subscription fee to its target audience: industry professionals, financial analysts, investors and journalists.

headline: CONGRESS IS URGED TO RESUME ANTI-SANDINISTA AID
abstract: A high- ranking Administration spokesman on Latin America engaged in a sharp debate today with Congressional critics over covert United States aid to rebels fighting the Government of Nicaragua.   Langhorne A. Motley, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, told a House hearing that it would be a ''serious mistake'' for Congress to continue its ban on aid to the rebels, known as ''contras.''    Without the pressure of armed rebellion, Mr. Motley argued, the Sandinistas would ''have no reason to compromise'' in any negotiations over Nicaragua's foreign or domestic policies.

headline: CONDITIONS FAVOR BOND RETIREMENT
abstract: The sharp drop in bond yields and rise in bond prices in recent months is a tremendous benefit to many local governments and corporations that are using the opportunity to refinance outstanding bonds sold when interest rates were much higher.     Billions of dollars worth of old bonds are candidates for refinancing, and investors should not expect to hold until maturity bonds with a coupon, or stated interest rate, two percentage points or more above current interest rates for similar issues.    ''We expect one of the major 1985 developments to be companies redeeming high-coupon issues and either retiring them or, more likely, refinancing,'' said James R. Stork, an analyst at Duff & Phelps, a Chicago-based subsidiary of the Security Pacific Corporation that specializes in credit analysis.    Techniques of refinancing vary from issue to issue, but the aim is usually the same - reduce interest expenses by replacing high-interest bonds with low-interest bonds. Corporations benefit because reduced interest expenses mean higher profits, and local governments and agencies benefit because lower interest costs mean more money for other uses or maybe even lower taxes.

headline: ITT Awaits S.E.C. Ruling
abstract: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission would soon decide whether to permit a proposal to liquidate the company to be included in the proxy material for its annual meeting.   The telecommunications company, which recently disclosed that it is trying to dispose of $1.7 billion worth of its businesses, said the liquidation proposal had been made by a single stockholder who owns about 700 shares.

headline: HELP IN MANAGING THE ELECTRONIC DESK
abstract: ABOUT the time that the Osborne Computer Corporation was making its big splash with the first   portable computer, another small machine by the name of Otrona was also struggling to nudge its way into the marketplace. Although the company failed to capture the hearts, minds and wallets of the computer-buying public, the Otrona did deliver some unique software.   An accessory program called Valet allowed you to call up an appointment calendar, telephone directory and other on-screen aids without having to switch out of the main program, say word processing, that you happened to be using at the time.   Valet vanished, ahead of its time, but now programs reminiscent of it are all the rage - so much so that 1985 is apt to go down in microcomputer history as the year of desk management software.   Sidekick, from Borland International, started the trend last year, and at $49.95 it is still a bargain, even though one of its constituents, the ASCII (for American Standard Code for Information Interchange, and pronounced as-kee) table, is something only a programmer would ever want. Popular though Sidekick remains, it no longer has the marketplace to itself. New and different features are being introduced by new and different manufacturers - although at a price.

headline: Installment Debt Up in November
abstract: Americans took on $7.95 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in November in yet another sign, analysts said, that economic activity rebounded late last year.   The November increase followed a $6.28 billion October increase.

headline: Bangladesh Lawyers Are Boycotting Courts
abstract: Lawyers in Bangladesh began an indefinite boycott of courts today in a bid to force President H. M. Ershad to restore democracy and the powers of the judiciary.   They said in a statement that the boycott was designed to back demands by opposition political parties for an end to nearly three years of military rule and establishment of a civil government through free parliamentary elections next April.

headline: PROFIT RISES 38.9% AT BIG COAST BANK
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation yesterday reported a 38.9 percent increase in fourth-quarter net income, to $72.9 million, from $52.5 million. Per-share net income rose 59.1 percent, to 35 cents, from 22 cents.     The discrepancy between the percentage gain in aggregate and per- share income reflected preferred stock dividends, which are deducted from net income in calculating per- share earnings. In both fourth quarters, preferred dividends amounted to $19 million, a bank spokesman said.

headline: Boise Cascade's European Sale
abstract: The Boise Cascade Corporation issued $50 million of seven-year callable Eurobonds in London yesterday.    The bonds, which are callable in the sixth year at 101, carry a 12 percent coupon and were priced at par. Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. was lead manager for the underwriting. The issue has not yet been rated by Moody's or S.&P.

headline: HUSSEIN AND MUBARAK CONFER IN JORDAN
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Hussein of Jordan discussed the Palestinian problem today at an unexpected meeting in Jordan.    The two leaders met for three hours during Mr. Mubarak's four-hour visit to the Red Sea port of Aqaba.   ''We discussed the Palestinian issue at present and how we plan to move in the future,'' Mr. Mubarak told reporters after his return to Cairo. ''There must be movement on the Palestinian issue or else it will die.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *       Beverly Enterprises, a health care company based in Pasadena, Calif., said it had agreed to acquire the closely held Home Medical Systems Inc., Philadelphia, a provider of durable medical equipment. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Head for Economic Committee
abstract: Representative Gillis W. Long, a Louisiana Democrat, has taken over as chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, replacing Senator Roger W. Jepsen.

headline: THE COMPUTER ;  TELECOMMUTERS SAY THERE'S NO WORKPLACE LIKE HOME
abstract: Rising Star Industries Inc. is the kind of company in which no one worries about getting to the office on time. For most employees, there is no traditional office.   Based in Torrance, Calif., with annual sales of approximately $6 million, this computer-software company employs about 100 people, many of whom live and work all over the map - Peekskill, N.Y., Portland, Ore., and Peterborough, N.H., are just a few locations. The vice president is based in Trenton, New Jersey, while the president can often be found working in his home in Palos Verdes, California.   ''Software can be done anywhere, wherever you have a computer hooked up to a phone,'' explained Roger Amidon, executive vice president for Rising Star. ''A good creative programmer works best in an environment that he prefers, and for many programmers, that place is the home.'' Computer programmers link their terminals to the main office by telephone lines. Whenever an assignment is completed or finished in part, the information that needs to be reviewed is transmitted by phone to the appropriate person. Employees may keep in touch by talking on the telephone or by sending messages via computer.

headline: Peru Rebels Attack Capital
abstract: The police shot and killed two Maoist guerrillas and detained more than 1,000 people Thursday night after rebels carried out their biggest assault on the Peruvian capital this year.

headline: Business Digest;   FRIDAY, MARCH 8, 1985
abstract: Companies    Apple Computer plans to close its four factories for one week because of an oversupply. Sales have been slow for all the industry, but Apple seems to be hit worse than others, analysts said. A spokesman said the glut affects all of Apple's products. It is the first time the company has suspended production. (Page D1.)    Agents that fight plaque and gum disease will soon get a seal of approval from the American Dental Association's Council on Dental Therapeutics, an official said. The agents, to be added to mouthwashes and toothpastes, would be a breakthrough for the toothpaste industry, analysts said, and could help Procter & Gamble in particular, whose toothpaste sales have been lagging. (D1.)

headline: DOW CHEMICAL NET UP 9.7%
abstract: The Dow Chemical Company, experiencing a sharp slowdown in earnings growth from the first three quarters of 1984, reported yesterday that earnings increased 9.7 percent in the fourth quarter.    Dow, the country's second-largest chemical producer, after E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said that net income in the latest three months rose to $79 million, or 42 cents a share, from $72 million, or 37 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales declined 7.9 percent, to $2.69 billion, from $2.92 billion.

headline: Washington Wtch;   Monetarists Gain Influence
abstract: WASHINGTON    BERYL W. SPRINKEL, whom President Reagan named last week to the chairmanship of the Council of Economic Advisers, is a diehard monetarist. As he was heard telling an associate last week, ''I've believed in money all my life'' - not so much in having it, in this context, as in believing that erratic behavior of the money supply causes inflation, deflation and economic ruin.    Mr. Sprinkel's appointment may enhance a renaissance of monetarism that is already apparent at the Federal Reserve Board. Monetarism is about all that is left to the Administration following the failure of the supply-side economists to show that large tax cuts would eat away the budget deficits and the subsequent failure of more conventional conservatives to show that the deficits portended soaring interest rates and another recession.

headline: Rath Shuts Down In Temporary Step
abstract: The Rath Packing Company said it had stopped processing meat temporarily and would sell the remaining inventory.

headline: WHO AUDITS THE AUDITORS?;  CONGRESS SHOULD BE THE WATCHDOG
abstract: AS it burgeons into an intensely   competitive and diversified  business dominated by multi- billion dollar companies, accounting is increasingly implicated in stock manipulations, bank failures and instances of illegal corporate conduct. In this new climate, Congress - in keeping with its concern for the independence of auditors that goes back to the 1920's and the great stock frauds of that era - needs to establish rules that will insure that the profession's traditional high standards of reliability are upheld.   Generally, the accounting profession has performed to its own credit and the nation's benefit. Often severely tested, the industry nevertheless has demonstrated a high degree of competence and integrity. The investigation my subcommittee is undertaking this spring is designed to insure that this record continues.

headline: POLISH LEADER SAYS JUSTICE WAS SERVED IN THE MURDER TRIAL
abstract: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, expressed confidence today that all those responsible for the slaying of a pro-Solidarity priest last fall had been brought to justice by his Government.    It was his first public comment on the case since four security officers were convicted in the death of the priest, the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, in a trial in Torun, Poland, last week. Mr. Jaruzelski said it was ''so far not possible'' to say that the murder conspiracy had gone beyond the four men.   ''Should we find in the future any other traces of instigation,'' said General Jaruzelski, ''I wish to assure you that it will be in the best conceived interest of the Government of Poland to draw all the possible and the severest conclusions from that fact. For the time being, there are no such traces.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Artel Communications Corp., Worcester, Mass., which makes fiber optic systems, announced that its president and chief executive officer, Tadeusz Witkwicz, had been named to the additional post of chairman, succeeding Richard A. Cerny, who has resigned.     *       Farm House Foods Corp.  of Milwaukee, said Donald E. Runge had been named chairman and president.

headline: Domino's Credit
abstract: Domino's Pizza Inc. said it had secured a $102 million revolving line of credit from a group of nine banks that would allow it to proceed with a major expansion of company- owned stores. Domino's, the largest pizza-delivery chain, with more than 1,900 outlets in the United States, Canada and Australia, plans to double the number of company-owned stores to 1,200 over the next three years, according to its chairman, Thomas Monaghan.

headline: REAGAN'S HIGH RISK GROWTH GAME
abstract: ALL last week, in his budget message, annual economic report and State of the Union address, President Reagan laid out the game plan for his second term. He means to consolidate the conservative revolution in public policy - he calls it a Second American Revolution - that he began four years ago.    In fact, the Reagan revolution, which he suggests is a reprise of George Washington's, is meant to be the counterstroke of the Roosevelt revolution of the 1930's. Where Franklin Roosevelt sought to overcome the problems of the Depression by increasing the economic and social role of the Federal Government, Ronald Reagan has attacked ''stagflation'' - that combination of stagnation and inflation that dogged the economy in the 1970's - by cutting the role of Government and by relying increasingly on what he calls ''the magic of the market'' to generate strong economic growth.    To date, Mr. Reagan's economic policies look like a striking success. The economy's performance was a major - perhaps the major - factor in the President's landslide re-election, and that victory has emboldened him to stay the course he began in 1981. As he envisions that course, a free-market economy, with steady growth and low inflation, will emerge from the changing tax system, from the deregulation of major industries and from cuts in long-standing Federal subsidies in many areas, including agriculture, housing and medical care.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Pervious   Year

headline: No Headline
abstract: Rebel Dismisses Unity Bid        MIAMI, Feb. 6 - A Nicaraguan rebel leader, Eden Pastora Gomez, said today that efforts by rival anti- Sandinista groups to form a united opposition front were ''meaningless'' and ''not serious.''    Mr. Pastora, head of the Nicaraguan Democratic Revolutionary Alliance, said that he met Monday with Adolfo Calero, head of the largest guerrilla organization, the Nicaraguan Democratic Front, and Arturo Jose Cruz, leader of a civilian anti-Sandinista group, and that the discussion was ''disappointing and fruitless.''

headline: CHRISTIAN FORCES IN LEBANON RISE AGAINST LEADER
abstract: Christian militia leaders revolted today against Lebanon's President, a Maronite Catholic who is their ostensible leader.    The uprising against President Amin Gemayel, which involved members of the private Christian army known as the Lebanese Forces, posed a new threat to the stability of the Government and added another element to the spiral of violent disintegration here.   (In Washington, State Department officials said the Administration was close to a decision on whether to withdraw the remaining United States Embassy personnel in Beirut or to reduce the already small staff to a caretaker status. Page A3.)

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Feb. 13, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on Non-Use of Force - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: Aeroflex Laboratories Inc., a manufacturer of military and industrial products, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $25 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2005, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.     *       Bankers Trust Co.  filed for an offering of $500 million of debentures.     *       Brooks Satellite Inc.  filed for an initial public offering of 500,000 units, through Eastlake Securities Inc. Each unit consist of two common shares and one common stock purchase warrant.     *       Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce is issuing $250 million, up from $200 million, of 20-year floating-rate notes through underwriters led by Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd., with interest set monthly at the mean level between the bid and asked rates for six-month London interbank loans.

headline: Advertsing;   Hardee's Account to Ogilvy
abstract: THERE were the usual number of   breathless new-business annoucements on Friday. But, for a change, there was at least one that deserved getting breathless about. It was from Ogilvy & Mather, which has won the competition for the $35 million Hardee's fast-food chain account.

headline: ALL SHAREHOLDERS TO GET MORE
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the multimillionaire New Yorker, called off an $8.1 billion takeover bid for the Phillips Petroleum Company yesterday.    The move came one day after Phillips, the nation's 11th-largest oil company, sharply improved the terms of a defensive plan to buy back a substantial number of its own shares.    The improved offer will provide Mr. Icahn, who owns 5 percent of Phillips's stock, with a profit of $50 million on the investment.    Phillips, for its part, has managed to secure its independence after a bruising struggle. Mr. Icahn has promised not to attempt a takeover of the Bartlesville, Okla., oil company for the next eight years. And financial analysts maintained that the large debt that Phillips would take on to finance the costly purchase of shares would deter other bidders.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Arizona State Dean May Head F.D.I.C.
abstract: L. William Seidman, dean of Arizona State University's business school, and former economic aide to President Ford, has emerged as President Reagan's choice as the next chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, White House and Senate sources said yesterday.    One official, who asked not to be identified, said, concerning Mr.  Seidman, that ''the White House is circulating his name on Capitol Hill.'' The official added that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was doing its routine background check on Mr. Seidman.

headline: Casey Stake in Capital Cities
abstract: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, holds some 34,000 shares in Capital Cities Communications Inc., the company that agreed last week to acquire the American Broadcasting Companies.   Mr. Casey's holdings, according to his latest financial disclosure statement filed last May, are not a part of the diversified trust he set up in October 1983 after criticism from Congress about his finances.

headline: PEACE CORPS GETS 5,000 CALLS IN DRIVE FOR AFRICA VOLUNTEERS
abstract: The Peace Corps has issued a nationwide appeal for volunteers to begin famine relief and agricultural work in Africa, and officials say it has produced the largest number of inquiries since the heyday of the agency in the early 1960's.    On Thursday, the Peace Corps said it was seeking 600 volunteers to work in Africa. Officials said today that they had received more than 5,000 inquiries.

headline: 9 Freed in Ethiopia By Armed Rebels
abstract: Five French Air Force crewmen, abducted by armed rebels when their plane landed with tons of food for famine victims, were released unharmed today and flew back to Addis Ababa.    Meanwhile, representatives of a French volunteer medical organization, Doctors Without Borders, reported in Paris that four members of a medical team thought to have been captured along with the airmen were safe in Lalibela.

headline: Union Carbide
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation said its board had decided to maintain its regular quarterly dividend of 85 cents a share, payable March 1 to shareholders of record on Feb. 7. Several suits seeking billions of dollars have been filed against the company as a result of the disaster at its Bhopal, India, plant.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: Comfed Savings Bank, Lowell, Mass., announced the appointment of Joel Rosenberg as senior vice president and treasurer. The bank also named Henry W. Brodeur head of its new Corporate Relationship Funding Center.         *

headline: No Headline
abstract: Since the oil refineries opened in Aruba and Cura,cao half a century ago, the fortunes of these two sparkling Caribbean islands have largely followed the demand for oil. Now their prosperity is threatened, a casualty of the worldwide glut in oil refining capacity, and the islands face their severest economic predicament in memory.    At the end of March, the Exxon Corporation's oil refinery, which has provided about half of Aruba's annual income, will close. And the Royal Dutch/Shell Group's refinery, a major employer in Cura,cao, has said it may have to close as well unless the Government, which is already financially strained, buys two-thirds of Shell's money-losing plant.    The leaders of both islands, which lie just off the coast of Venezuela, say hundreds of layoffs and widespread pay cuts are inevitable - a situation that has already led to some peaceful protests among workers in Aruba.

headline: STOCKS UP IN HECTIC TRADING
abstract: Stock prices, particularly those of over-the-counter issues, continued their climb yesterday in hectic trading. But the closely followed Dow Jones industrial average eased from the record it set on Tuesday.    The Dow average of 30 blue-chip stocks closed at 1,287.88, off 4.74 points from Tuesday's high of 1,292.62. In the first hour, the Dow reached 1,299.36, close to the critical 1,300 point, but then fell back.

headline: Army Task Force To Help Hunt Mengele
abstract: John O. Marsh Jr., Secretary of the Army, has set up a high-level task force to help the Justice Department in searching for Dr. Josef Mengele, the Army said today.   It said formation of the task force, to be headed by Darrell Peck, the Deputy Army General Counsel, showed how seriously the Army viewed the search for Dr. Mengele, chief physician at the Auschwitz death camp.

headline: REAGAN'S SUPPORT IS KEY TO TAX SIMPLIFICATION
abstract: AFTER preliminary oratorical flourishes in his State of the Union Message, President Reagan turned to the issues of the day, and the very first one he mentioned - before the deficit, before war and peace, before abortion and education and crime - was taxes.    ''Let us move together,'' the President implored Congress, ''with a historic reform of tax simplification for fairness and growth.'' The present tax system, he declared, is ''unfair.''   ''The Treasury Department,'' the President said that day, ''has produced an excellent reform plan whose principles will guide the final proposal that we will ask you to enact.'' He added: ''Tax simplification will be a giant step toward unleashing the tremendous pent-up power of our economy.''

headline: U.S. Groups Conduct Interviews
abstract: Attorneys sent to Nicaragua by the International Human Rights Law Group, the Washington Office on Latin America and the office of Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, say they have conducted their own interviews with victims cited in Mr. Brody's report.    In a statement to be issued on Thursday, the attorneys said they had interviewed more than 30 people, adding, ''Although we were not able to investigate all of the affidavits on which Mr. Brody's report is based, most that we did investigate appear accurate in all material respects.''

headline: BIG AIRLINES' REGIONAL LINKS
abstract: When James McManus flew from Syracuse to London recently, he took an Empire Airlines flight directly to one of Pan American World Airways' gates at Kennedy International Airport in New York City and then boarded a Pan Am trans-Atlantic jet just a few hundred yards away.     The trip was better in several ways than before Empire's affiliation with Pan Am two years ago, said Mr. McManus, an employee of the Carrier Corporation. It was not only cheaper but the dash from one terminal to another was eliminated. Furthermore, both he and his luggage were ticketed straight through to London, and he earned extra miles on Pan Am's frequent flier program.

headline: Freddie Mac Plan Approved
