abstract: The Justice Department gave its approval today to a December stock dividend by a Government-chartered agency to some failing savings and loan institutions.   The transfer by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation - better known as Freddie Mac - had been challenged by the Office of Management and Budget.

headline: A.T.&T. Buys 10% Of Intermetrics Inc.
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company bought a 10 percent stake yesterday in Intermetrics Inc., a small software concern, after apparently making an unsuccessful bid to buy the entire company.   Under the arrangement with Intermetrics, A.T.&T. will pay $2.7 million for 10 percent of the company's stock, and can increase its holding to 30 percent during the next three years.

headline: The Japanese Stock Outlook
abstract: A SHARP break in prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange last spring sent the Nikkei Dow Jones average tumbling below 10,000 and caused global money managers to worry about the outlook for Japanese equities. Their concern, as it turned out, was overdone.   On Monday of this week the Nikkei average, which includes 225 of the largest-capitalization companies in Japan, finished at a record high of 12,501.01. Since then the index has moved lower, with dealers ascribing this action both to a bout of profit taking and nervousness created by the weakness of Wall Street stock prices. In a sharp decline yesterday, the index fell 83.87, closing at 12,414.80.

headline: A BROADWAY PROJECT, ZECKENDORF-STYLE
abstract: It may be that no developer in the city has more projects in various stages of planning and execution than William Zeckendorf Jr.    In addition to new buildings already on the market, he is moving forward with three residential buildings to be built at Battery Park City, with a mixed-use development at Union Square, with the planning of another on the site of the former Madison Square Garden at Eighth Avenue and 50th Street, with still another on Eighth Avenue at Columbus Circle and with others he is not prepared to mention.    Getting a project into construction is so lengthy and uncertain a proposition, Mr. Zeckendorf says, that it is necessary to have four or five in the planning stage simultaneously to maintain a steady production cycle. Any one of the four or five may hit a snag that will delay a start by months if not years.

headline: United Air Plan
abstract: United Airlines disclosed the design for a modernistic 42-gate, $300 million terminal, which is a key part of the $1.4 billion program to modernize O'Hare International Airport. The new terminal, which is scheduled to be completed in mid-1988, will include two 1,600-foot-long concourses and is designed to handle more wide-body aircraft. The terminal, designed by Helmut Jahn, a Chicago architect, will enable the Chicago-based United to double the number of passengers it can carry at O'Hare.

headline: NEW PEACE EFFORT BY LATIN NATIONS BACKED BY SHULTZ
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua met for an hour here today and appeared to clear the way for a resumption of the Central American peace efforts of the Contadora group.     After the meeting, Mr. Shultz played down the importance of Nicaragua's decision this week to suspend the acquisition of new arms systems and to reduce the number of its Cuban military advisers, saying it ''raises more questions than it answers.''         'Contadora Process' Stressed    ''I don't know that anything much has changed,'' Mr. Shultz continued, ''though perhaps there is the recognition all round that the center of negotiation must be the Contadora process and that the sooner everyone gets back to that process the better.''    The work of the Contadora group, which consists of Mexico, Colombia, Venezuela and Panama, was interrupted earlier this year by a dispute between Costa Rica and Nicaragua over a Nicaraguan youth who was arrested Dec. 24 after taking asylum in the Costa Rican Embassy in Managua.

headline: Market Place;   Mixed View Of Gas Stock
abstract: WHEN the Texas Oil and Gas Corporation reported some time ago that profits for its fiscal year ended Aug. 31, 1984, rose 17 percent, to $1.65 a share, management noted that this marked the 27th consecutive year of record earnings.   The Dallas-based company is engaged in the gathering, transporting and processing of natural gas. It also explores for and produces crude oil and natural gas. ''Texas Oil and Gas has been a religion stock within the energy group,'' said George D. Baker, an industry analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

headline: VANCE CONCERNED ABOUT SPACE ARMS
abstract: Former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, warned today against the deployment of weapons in space.      He said he supported a program of limited research to find defenses against nuclear attack, but Mr. Vance added that ''once we cross the line from basic research to deployment, we have very radically changed the basic strategic doctrine.''   Mr. Vance, Secretary of State under President Carter, spoke on the second day of hearings on the direction of American foreign policy. Only a few senators attended today's session.

headline: British Earnings Climb
abstract: Average earnings in Britain rose 1.2 percent in January from December and were up 7 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today.

headline: FOR UPROOTED ETHIOPIANS, LIFE IN THE GREENER HILLS
abstract: A freshly cut dirt road leads to this new settlement spread across a wide valley in southwestern Ethiopia.     Those settlers who have most recently arrived take shelter in long communal sheds made of savannah grass placed over frames of saplings; those who have been here a few weeks longer live in small, round bamboo dwellings with roofs of thatch.   Around the settlement, which is in the Kaffa region, are rolling mountains, but the area is without the dramatic peaks, canyons and mesas of the northern highlands where these people came from and where their families lived for generations.    Yet this area has things the north now lacks: trees and bushes, rains that still fall and soil that has not been eroded or depleted of nutrients. Here, the countryside is still green.

headline: Hong Kong's '84 Trade
abstract: Hong Kong's total trade in 1984 reached the equivalent of $57 billion, up 32 percent from the previous year, the Census and Statistics Department reported today. It said the United States was Hong Kong's biggest market, importing $7.8 billion worth of goods, up 40 percent from 1983.

headline: Jaruzelski Due in India
abstract: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, arrives in New Delhi on Monday  on his first official visit outside the Eastern bloc, a trip already blemished by reports of Polish involvement in India's spy scandal.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM;  REVIVAL IS POSSIBLE-AND NECESSARY
abstract: THE American labor movement   is in its worst slump since the  1920's. Walter Mondale's landslide defeat reinforced the perception that labor can no longer ''deliver the labor vote'' - even against a militant anti-union Republican. During Ronald Reagan's first term, 50 years' worth of union-backed social programs and protective labor legislation were attacked, dismantled or drastically curtailed.   Organized labor's growing political weakness reflects an erosion of strength on the job and at the bargaining table. Union membership has dropped sharply. The forces of foreign trade, capital flight, non-union competition, and deregulation have weakened traditional union strongholds.

headline: Signal Net Climbs 25.9%
abstract: The Signal Companies disclosed yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter of 1984 advanced 25.9 percent as sales edged up 3.3 percent.    The diversified company, which is based in La Jolla, Calif., said net income for the latest three months rose to $68 million, or 60 cents a share, from $54 million, or 47 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: CASTRO DROPS IN
abstract: Daniel Ortega Saavedra was inaugurated as President of Nicaragua today in a ceremony marked by the unexpected arrival of the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro.     Mr. Castro was expected to remain in Nicaragua overnight. Government officials suggested he might take part Friday in the dedication of a large sugar refinery outside Managua that was built with Cuban help.    Mr. Castro appeared buoyant as he stepped off a Cubana airliner at midmorning. He smiled broadly as he embraced Mr. Ortega and other Nicaraguan leaders, and waved in the direction of reporters.

headline: Australian's Trip Barred By Papua New Guinea
abstract: PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea, Feb. 16 (Reuters) - The Papua New Guinea Government canceled a visit today by the Australian Foreign Minister, William G. Hayden, to a refugee camp near the border with the Indonesian province of West Irian.    The Government said it had called off the trip after receiving reports that up to 70 members of a West Irian separatist movement were seen near the camp Friday.

headline: SIGNAL LOSES DECISION IN MERGER PRICE SUIT
abstract: The Chancery Court of Delaware has decided that the Signal Companies should have paid $22 per share, instead of $21, when it bought out shareholders of UOP Inc. in a 1978 merger. Total damages to be paid by Signal are expected to amount to more than $7 million.     The award stems from a favorable ruling by the Delaware Supreme Court two years ago in a class action suit brought by William B. Weinberger, a UOP minority shareholder. Signal already had owned controlling interest in UOP and bought out the 49.5 percent interest of minority shareholders for $21 per share after they agreed to the merger recommended by UOP's directors.

headline: Ogilvy Says It Is Tops In Direct Marketing
abstract: Ogilvy & Mather Direct, at age 12, is laying claim to the title ''World's Largest Direct Marketing Agency,'' long held by Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, in recent years a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam.    Olgivy bases its claim on 1984 billings of $240 million, an increase of 37 percent from 1983.    However, that leaves Young & Rubicam free to make some claims of its own. Y.&R. is billing $278 million in its direct marketing group of three agencies, which includes Wunderman.

headline: OHIO CRISIS HAS OTHERS WORRIED
abstract: The problems of Ohio's non-federally insured savings institutions have been confined to that state so far, but there are fears within the financial community that if the problem in Ohio is not cleared up quickly it might spread to institutions elsewhere that are not federally insured.   A survey this past weekend of executives of non-federally insured institutions indicated that some were concerned about the impact the Ohio situation ultimately may have on their depositors. Some have taken actions to make sure they have plenty of cash on hand today to satisfy the demands of their customers.   Financial analysts, however, were more worried. ''At some point, if this drags on too much longer, there's a systemic risk in those states where there is private deposit insurance,'' said Lawrence W. Cohn, chief bank- stock analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ''That's why everybody wants it over.''

headline: ITALIAN UNION ADVISER SHOT DEAD
abstract: A prominent economist for a labor federation was shot and killed here today, and the Red Brigades terrorist group claimed responsibility.     The police said Prof. Ezio Tarantelli, 43 years old, a leading adviser to the Roman Catholic-led union, the Italian Federation of Unionized Workers, was approached at noontime by two men in a university parking lot after he gave a lecture at Rome University.   They fired at him with a submachine gun and a revolver, the police said, and Professor Tarantelli was struck by at least 10 bullets. He died on arrival at a nearby university hospital.

headline: U.S. Considers Proposal
abstract: A State Department spokesman reaffirmed today that the United States was looking ''into the possibilities of the construction'' of a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation that could meet with American officials.

headline: Glemp Accuses Warsaw Of 'Malicious' Campaign
abstract: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic primate of Poland, accused the Communist authorities today of a ''malicious'' campaign against the church, and he rejected allegations that many Polish priests regularly engage in anti- state activities.   Speaking at a rare news conference, he said the nature of attacks on the church indicated an ''ideological struggle'' within the Polish leadership.

headline: WHY GOLD STILL LACKS REAL LUSTER
abstract: DESPITE the widespread feeling among professionals that gold is not likely to outperform other investments, at least one large investor in gold stocks is quite bullish about the prospects for the metal over the next few years. ''I think we're heading for a long-term bull market in gold,'' said John van Eck, chairman of the $800 million International Investors mutual fund. ''This is just the beginning. It looks as though we've seen the bottom.'' In fact, he even went so far as to venture that the price of gold ''could exceed its old high'' of $850 an ounce within the next three years.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Sallie Mae Plans to Sell $200 Million of Notes
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday announced plans for a $200 million offering of four-year floating- rate notes.   The interest rate on the series D notes will be reset weekly at 50 basis points higher than the bond equivalent of the 91-day Treasury bill auction rate.

headline: U.S. MAGAZINE CHRONICLES MUTINY ON A SOVIET WARSHIP IN '75
abstract: A United States naval magazine published this week what it said were details of a mutiny aboard a Soviet warship in 1975 that ended with an aircraft attack on the ship and about 50 sailors dead.   The article by Lieut. Gregory Young of the Navy in the magazine Sea Power says the highly unusual story began when the Soviet frigate Storozhevoy docked in November 1975 in Riga on the Baltic Sea for ceremonies commemorating the Russian Revolution.

headline: $300 Million Sale By Texaco Capital
abstract: Texaco Capital Inc. is offering $300 million of four-year, 11 1/4 percent extendible notes at a price of 99.682 to yield 11.35 percent to March 1, 1989, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

headline: U.S. REPORTED TO INVESTIGATE HANDLING OF GRENADA WEAPONS CASES
abstract: The Defense Department said today that it was investigating an admiral's attempt to bring Soviet-made rifles back from Grenada as souvenirs. Another inquiry is reportedly being conducted to see if lower-ranking servicemen sentenced in arms cases were treated fairly.    Deputy Defense Secretary William Howard Taft 4th, in a memorandum to John F. Lehman Jr., the Secretary of the Navy, asked for ''a complete report from you'' on allegations ''concerning illegal acquisition and importation of firearms and other war trophies after the Grenada operation'' by Navy and Marine personnel. Among those involved is Vice Adm. Joseph Metcalf 3d, who was in charge of the invasion of Grenada in October 1983.

headline: Three Sikhs Charged in India In the Killing of Indira Gandhi
abstract: One of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's bodyguards has been charged with murdering her, and two other Sikhs have been charged with criminal conspiracy in her Oct. 31 assassination, according to court documents.

headline: LORD WOLFENDEN, AN EDUCATOR AND BRITISH SOCIAL REFORMER
abstract: Lord Wolfenden, the man who helped change the way male homosexuals and female prostitutes are treated in Britain, died Friday in a hospital. He was 78 years old.   Lord Wolfenden, an educator and social reformer, became a household name in Britain as a result of his chairmanship of a Government committee from 1954 to 1957 that investigated male homosexuality and female prostitution. The Wolfenden Report recommended changing the law that made male homosexual acts punishable by imprisonment - lesbianism has never been illegal in Britain - and suggested that prostitution, which was not illegal, be allowed to continue.

headline: Expense Claim Withdrawn
abstract: General Dynamics has agreed to withdraw a bill for $491,840 charged to the Federal Government for 76 corporate flights its chairman, Mr. Lewis, made to his farm in Georgia, The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported today.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Italy Appoints Official To Lead Mafia Fight
abstract: The Italian Cabinet has appointed a new High Commissioner to coordinate the fight against the Mafia.

headline: U.S. SAID TO HAVE URGED KOREA DISSIDENT TO DELAY RETURN TILL MAY
abstract: State Department officials have urged Kim Dae Jung, the South Korean opposition leader, to accept a confidential guarantee from the Seoul Government that he would not be arrested if he delayed until May his return from exile in this country, Reagan Administration officials and associates of Mr. Kim said today.   But Mr. Kim said in an interview that it was too late for him to change his plans. He is scheduled to leave here on Feb. 6 and fly to South Korea, stopping overnight in Tokyo. An entourage of some 20 Americans is accompanying him to insure that he is not assassinated as was Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the Philippine opposition leader who was murdered when he returned to Manila in 1983.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM;  AS THE PERIL DECLINES, SO SHOULD THE PAY
abstract: IN 1969, following a two-year study   of the Armed Forces' compensation system, a panel of military officers concluded that ''because of its failure to support management effectiveness and because of its very high cost, the present military retirement system is an inefficient compensation tool.''  In that year, $2.4 billion was paid to 690,000 military retirees. Today, 16 years and eight additional studies later, the Pentagon estimates that in 1985 pension checks totaling over $17 billion will be sent to 1.4 million beneficiaries.   This sevenfold increase in retirement costs has far outrun the growth in any other element of military compensation, most notably active duty pay. Yet the military has staunchly resisted needed reform.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Police Search for Killers Of Russian in New Delhi
abstract: The police raided the homes of Afghan and Iranian refugees today, detaining 14 people and questioning hundreds of others in a hunt for the killers of a Soviet official.

headline: FED, REAGAN AND THE DOLLAR
abstract: THE soaring dollar was jolted again this week   by the warning of the Federal Reserve   Board's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, that there could be a ''very sharp decline'' in the dollar's value because market psychology could change rapidly.   Psychology obviously has a lot to do with the day- to-day course of the dollar, whose drops send interest rates up and the securities markets down. Yesterday, the dollar jumped on news that the money supply had grown faster than expected.    But the big question is whether the markets are starting to see a peaking out of the dollar resulting from fundamental changes in the economic and political climate and from the actions of the Fed, the Reagan Administration and Congress, as well as those of foreign central banks and governments.       Mr. Volcker, whether he intended to or not, knocked the bond market down and interest rates up with his Congressional testimony a week ago that the Fed had ended its progressively easier monetary policy of the last four months but had not yet decided to tighten.

headline: Kenyan Patrols Find 924 Elephant Tusks
abstract: Game Department and army patrols have recovered 924 elephant tusks valued at more than $300,000 in a 60-day poacher sweep in northeastern Kenya, the official Kenya News Agency said today.

headline: U.S. Criticizes Swiss On Explosives Case
abstract: The State Department today criticized Switzerland's handling of a Lebanese citizen convicted of transporting explosives.   It said a Swiss court in Bulach sentenced Hussein Atat Hani to an 18- month jail term Wednesday for transporting explosives but suspended the sentence and ordered his expulsion from the country.   The same day, the Swiss Minister of Justice announced that an Italian request for Mr. Atat Hani's extradition had been rejected, the department said.

headline: G.E. IS EXPECTING TO BE INDICTED IN BILLINGS FOR NUCLEAR WARHEADS
abstract: The General Electric Company expects to be indicted today on charges of defrauding the Government during work on a nuclear- warhead system, a company spokesman said.    Jack Batty, a G.E. spokesman at the company's Fairfield, Conn. headquarters, said last night, ''Yes, we expect the indictment resulting from work done through our aerospace group. But while it is entirely possible that during the course of performing these multi- million dollar contracts charging errors did occur, there was no criminal wrongdoing on the part of the company or its employees.''

headline: KENNEDY'S TRIP: 'STIRRING THINGS UP' IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: In South Africa, so the wisdom runs, the problems are easy to identify. The solutions are more elusive.     There was much that was apparent during the visit there by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, a visit that ended Sunday night when the Massachusetts Democrat left that racially divided nation and flew to Zambia. He held talks with President Kenneth D. Kaunda and Oliver Tambo, leader of the African National Congress, before returning home today.

headline: U.N. CHIEF VISITS VIETNAM FOR TALKS ON CAMBODIA
abstract: Javier Perez de Cuellar arrived here today on his first official visit as United Nations Secretary General and went directly to a series of meetings with Vietnam's Foreign Minister.    The Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, told reporters before Mr. Perez de Cuellar arrived that he expected their private talks tonight and on Tuesday to cover Vietnam's occupation of Cambodia and the wider issues of ''peace and stability in Southeast Asia.'' He said they would also discuss ''bilateral relations between Vietnam and the United Nations.''

headline: Austrian Minister Resigns
abstract: Austria's Minister of Construction and Technology, Karl Sekanina, resigned today after press allegations of financial misconduct. Chancellor Fred Sinowatz said that he had been unable to confirm the allegations and could not believe anything was wrong, but that the reports had hampered the work of the Government.

headline: Peru Rebels Kill 2 Officers
abstract: Maoist rebels shooting from a speeding car killed two police officers and wounded two others in daylight attacks in central Lima, the police said today. They said the Shining Path guerrillas killed a 28-year-old policewoman and a civil guard member and wounded two other guard members in three attacks Monday. The police said it was the first time Shining Path rebels had killed police officers in daylight in the capital.

headline: Futures/Options;A New Market For Dollars
abstract: IF the main purpose of trading futures on commodities or any other market instrument is to         earn dollars or hedge against changes in their value, then why not eliminate  all the intermediate steps and simply trade dollars?

headline: BRITISH SOLDIERS KILL A TEEN-AGER IN WEST BELFAST
abstract: Soldiers from the British Army's Ulster Defense Regiment opened fire today on a carload of teen-agers after the vehicle crashed into a roadblock. The 30 or so shots killed the driver, Paul Gerard Kelly, a 17-year-old Roman Catholic, and wounded four others, one seriously.     The names and ages of the others were not disclosed, but a man who lived nearby told reporters that the screams from the car sounded as though the ''boys in the car were very young.''    Gerry Adams, the Member of Parliament for West Belfast and president of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Provisional Irish Republican Army, declared, ''If last night's incident had occurred in any other town in Europe, the car would have been immobilized rather than the passengers being shot.''

headline: Jordan Says It Will Get Advanced Soviet Arms
abstract: Jordan will receive advanced ground- and air-defense weapons from the Soviet Union early this year, the army commander, Gen. Zeid bin Shaker, has announced.

headline: Germans of War Era Gone, Reagan Asserts
abstract: President Reagan, asked tonight why he had decided against visiting the site of a Nazi concentration camp during his visit to West Germany in May, said that few Germans who were adults during World War II and took part in it were alive today.    Mr. Reagan, who is to make the trip around the time of the 40th anniversary of VE-Day, said that the emphasis today should be on peace and friendship, not on war.

headline: ADVERTISING ;   MORE DIRECT MARKETING FROM GENERAL FOODS
abstract: In the March issue of Bon Appetit magazine is an ad for Thomas Garraway Ltd. of Madison, Wis., a direct marketer of gourmet foods, promising to deliver to the homes of America special premium cheeses, coffees, pastas, jams, meat and dessert sauces, cakes and cookies. All made by independent companies throughout the Western world and then shipped by Garraway.

headline: Hotline Talks Set for Today
abstract: United States and Soviet officials will meet here on Tuesday for technical talks on upgrading the hotline between Washington and Moscow, the State Department said today.

headline: VIETNAM'S ATTACKS CALLED HEAVY
abstract: State Department officials said today that Vietnamese attacks on Cambodian rebels operating along the Thai border were some of the heaviest ever and seemed aimed primarily at discrediting the rebels as an opposition force in Cambodia.   The officials said that while some of the fighting had spilled over into Thailand, there was no indication that the Vietnamese were intent on seizing any Thai territory permanently or engaging Thai forces in major battle.    The rebels, whose camps are situated only a few miles from the Thai border, often retreat into Thailand when pressed by the Vietnamese forces, which support the Government of Heng Samrin in Phnom Penh. Thai and Vietnamese units have tangled periodically and, according to dispatches from Bangkok, Vietnamese gunners shot down a Thai fighter plane today.

headline: Lord, Geller Sets Up Direct Marketing Unit
abstract: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein has created a new division, LGFE/ Direct Marketing, which will be headed by Barbara E. Corrigan as president. The new division will be based in the agency's Madison Avenue offices.    Previously, Miss Corrigan, 39 years old, was a vice president at Chapman Direct Marketing and the founder and president of MCM Direct Marketing.

headline: TRANSCRIPT OF INTERVIEW WITH PRESIDENT ON A RANGE OF ISSUES
abstract: Following is a transcript of an interview with President Reagan today conducted by Bernard Weinraub, Hedrick Smith, Leslie H. Gelb and Gerald M. Boyd, all of the Washington Bureau, as transcribed by The New York Times:         Military Balance    Q. We just want to start off with some foreign policy questions first. O.K.?   A. All right.   Q. And a question on arms control: Are we going into negotiations in a position of inferiority?   A. That we are not up to the strength level of the Soviet Union --    Q. Right.   A. -- militarily?

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Reagan Says He Regrets New Zealand's Policy
abstract: President Reagan, in a statement made public today, has told the newly arrived Ambassador of New Zealand that the United States ''deeply regrets the decision by the New Zealand Government to change the operational character of our previous cooperation under the Anzus alliance.''    The statement did not refer directly to a ban declared by New Zealand on port visits by American warships carrying nuclear weapons or propelled by nuclear power.

headline: Boston Bank Cites 'Systems Failure'
abstract: The Bank of Boston said today that its failure to report $1.22 billion in cash transfers with foreign banks stemmed from mistakes by at least 10 to 12 of the bank's departments as well as its auditors.    William L. Brown, the chairman of the bank, depicted the problem as merely a ''systems failure,'' caused by a misinterpretation of the Federal Register, which informs banks about new Government regulations.    Mr. Brown also insisted that there was ''absolutely'' no connection between the bank's failure to file the Federal currency reports and any illegal activity.         'Knowingly and Willfully'    The bank last week pleaded guilty to a felony charge of ''knowingly and willfully'' failing to report the $1.22 billion in cash transfers with nine foreign banks and was fined $500,000, a record. The currency law, which requires banks to report all cash transactions of more than $10,000, including international interbank transfers, was designed to help Federal authorities trace cash illicitly generated through narcotics, gambling and loan sharking, among other activities.

headline: I.B.M. Divides Operating Unit
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday split up the operating group that builds its mainframe computers and semiconductors.   At the same time, I.B.M. elevated Jack D. Kuehler, the 52- year-old executive who had been running the group, to a new post in which Mr. Kuehler will be responsible for all of I.B.M.'s United States manufacturing as well as for its worldwide development effort.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Union Carbide Ratings Reduced by Moody's
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation's debt ratings were reduced yesterday by Moody's Investors Service, which said the company's unsatisfactory financial performance was likely to continue ''until structural weaknesses in petrochemical and steel-related core businesses are corrected.''    The rating agency said that costs stemming from the accident at the pesticide plant of Union Carbide's 50.9 percent owned subsidiary in Bhopal, India, last month ''will be manageable, although a remote possibility of material liability does exist for the parent company.''    In addition, Moody's said Union Carbide's dividends ''are inappropriately high, given the unfavorable outlook for earnings.'' Union Carbide's accounting practices tend it overstate its earning power compared with other major chemical companies, the rating agency added.

headline: Bowater Inc. Issue
abstract: Bowater Inc., the largest producer of newsprint in the United States, today is offering $125 million of 12 3/8 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2015, at a price of 99.40 to yield 12.45 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The debentures, rated A-2 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's, yield about one percentage point more than the 12 percent Treasury bonds due in 2013. Because of sinking-fund payments beginning in 1996, the average life of the issue is 22.4 years.

headline: AUDITORS FACE U.S. SCRUTINY
abstract: Auditors who are entrusted to scrutinize the books of corporate America on behalf of investors and creditors will come under Congressional scrutiny starting Wednesday, when a House subcommittee opens what promises to be a long inquiry into the integrity of the big accounting firms.     The hearings, before the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, follow a successsion of well-publicized incidents in the past few years in which auditors gave a client's financial statements a clean opinion shortly before the company met with financial disaster.    These incidents - including the run on the Continental Illinois National Bank and the collapse of the Penn Square Bank, the United American Bank and others - renewed concerns on Capitol Hill over whether competitive cost pressures and the expansion of major accounting firms into other businesses have eroded the effectiveness and independence of auditors. The incidents also raised questions about whether the Securities and Exchange Commission had delegated too much of its oversight responsibility to self-regulatory bodies.

headline: 2 Chernenko Messages Published in Moscow
abstract: The Soviet Government press agency Tass published messages today from Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, to an Argentine and a northern European peace group.    Mr. Chernenko, 73 years old, is reported to be ailing and has not made a public appearance in nearly seven weeks.

headline: South Korean Output
abstract: Industrial production in South Korea fell 2.3 percent in January from December but was up 6.3 percent from January 1984, the Government said today. Exports of textiles, footwear and steel declined.

headline: Western Union Offers Discounts
abstract: The Western Union Corporation said it was offering discounts of up to $1,000 a month on its long-distance telephone service for users of its Easylink and telex message services.   The company said that, effective immediately, business customers would be able to apply as credits toward their monthly long-distance telephone charges 20 percent of their Easylink bills and use charges for telex, including worldwide telex, up to a maximum of $1,000 a month. Western Union said the discounts which cannot exceed the actual long- distance bill, would be applied to the following month's bill.

headline: Battle at Easco Taken to S.E.C.
abstract: Equity Group Holdings, a Washington, D.C., investment concern, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that its request for the Easco Corporation shareholder list was rejected by Easco.

headline: Gas Victims in India Protest Payment Delays
abstract: More than 7,000 victims of the gas leak at the Union Carbide plant here last month blocked traffic for six hours today to protest welfare payment delays.

headline: GUNMEN KILL LIBYAN DIPLOMAT ON A ROME STREET
abstract: A Libyan diplomat was shot dead near his home today but managed to fire on his assailants before collapsing on an icy street, the police said. He died clutching a gun in his hand.    The diplomat, identified as Farag Omar Mahkyoun, 31 years old, was the head of the press office at the Libyan Embassy.

headline: WUZZLES' TO 'INSECTOIDS' COME ALIVE AT TOY FAIR
abstract: Today marks the debut of the animals of Wuzzles, the ''plush people'' of Hugga Bunch, the warring forces of M.A.S.K., the women of the Princess of Power  and the ''insectoids'' of Sectaurs.         Each is a major toy line being introduced at the opening of the American International Toy Fair here. More important, all are hot character licensing properties.

headline: UKRAINE'S LEADER COMING TO U.S.
abstract: The Soviet Union's Ukrainian leader, who is a member of the ruling Politburo, will visit the United States next month, it was announced here today.    The Ukrainian, Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky, would be the highest Soviet visitor - with the exception of Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko - since Leonid I. Brezhnev was here in 1973.   Mr. Shcherbitsky will lead a delegation of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal national legislature. State Department officials said that while he is in Washington, from March 4 to 7, he will be received by President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

headline: I.B.M. Agreement In Rolm Unit Sale
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation, modifying a statement it made last week, said it had signed a ''conditional agreement'' to sell the Rolm Corporation's Mil-Spec Computer division to a employee group in a leveraged buyout.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Aerojet General Corp. , La Jolla, Calif., a manufacturer of aerospace products, has named W.M. Necoechea vice president-finance.     *       Crutcher Resources Corp., Houston, an oil and gas services company, has elected Jerry E. Goldress chief executive officer and a director.

headline: Nicaragua Loan Battle Shifts
abstract: The battleground over a $58 million loan to Nicaragua is expected shortly to shift from Washington to Vienna, where the Inter-American Development Bank will be holding its annual meeting next Monday and Tuesday.    The United States is expected to vote against the development bank loan but cannot block it without getting some other members to oppose it.

headline: NEW TAX RULES HELP AND HINDER INVESTORS
abstract: Investors received one of the few plums handed out on Capitol Hill last summer when Congress was busily cutting back on tax benefits to help trim the Federal budget deficit. They got a break on capital gains. The amount of time investors need to hold stocks or other assets for profits from their sale to be eligible for preferential tax treatment was reduced to six months and a day from one year and a day.   At the same time, however, Congress sharply restricted the capital gains that can be taken on bonds bought at a discount, and it put new limitations on the deductibility of interest on money borrowed to purchase bonds.    The reduced holding period for capital gains applies to assets acquired after June 22, 1984. So investors who purchased assets soon after that date and sold them in late December will be the first beneficiaries of the change and the only ones to benefit from the provision on 1984 tax returns.

headline: SALVADOR SAID TO BREAK GUNSHIP PACT
abstract: The Salvadoran Air Force is said to have used a second American-supplied aircraft as a gunship this week, apparently undercutting an understanding between the Reagan Administration and Congress.     The report came from witnesses to a recent battle and a source in El Salvador with knowledge of the plane's use.    American Embassy officials told reporters on Tuesday that one C-47 aircraft had been converted into a gunship and sent to El Salvador, equipped with special sights, night vision equipment and three specially mounted .50-caliber machine guns capable of firing over 1,500 rounds per minute.   The officials did not tell reporters that an additional C-47 was delivered. Today, the United States Embassy spokesman, Donald Hamilton, said the second plane was fully equipped to serve as a gunship, but under an agreement with Congress was not yet mounted with machine guns.

headline: BUSINESS BOOKKEEPING WITH A PLUS
abstract: A BASIC principle of efficiently computerizing any aspect of one's business is that the new system should parallel procedures with which one is already comfortable. Shaping one's business operations to suit the demands or whims of canned software is a guaranteed formula not only for frustration, but quite probably for added expense as well.    To every general rule there are, of course, exceptions. The spreadsheet programs developed for personal computers over the last five years opened up the world of instant answers to a gratifying number of the ''What if?'' questions posed while manipulating numerical data.

headline: FIGHT APARTHEID, TUTU TELLS INVESTORS
abstract: Bishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, urged foreign investors today to exert ''persuasive pressure'' for racial change in his country within the next 18 to 24 months.    If that tactic fails, he said at a news conference here, ''punitive pressures'' and economic sanctions should be introduced.    The statement was the clearest enunciation of his attitude toward economic sanctions the Bishop has made in recent months in South Africa, where public arguments against foreign investment are illegal. It was the strongest indication that he might in the future advocate such measures in this country.

headline: TWO SOUTH AFRICA CLERICS ARRESTED DURING PROTEST
abstract: The South African police arrested two leading anti-apartheid churchmen in Cape Town today as the clerics knelt on the pavement singing ''Onward Christian Soldiers.'' More than 200 supporters were detained with them    The arrests came at the start of an impromptu march on Parliament to protest the killing by the police of at least 19 black people last Thursday at Langa township, near the southern coastal city of Uitenhage.    Those arrested and held for about six hours included the Rev. Allan Boesak, President of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, and the Rev. Beyers Naude, General Secretary of the South African Council of Churches. A police spokesman said all had been released without bail and had been given the choice of paying an admission-of-guilt fine equivalent to about $25 or facing charges in court Wednesday under the Internal Security Act.

headline: Jews Protest Austria Action
abstract: Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress, expressed anger today at Defense Minister Friedhelm Frischenschlager's welcome of a Nazi war criminal and called for the Austrian official's dismissal. Others of the 2,000 people attending the opening of the group's international conference also protested the Defense Minister's welcome on Thursday morning for Walter Reder, a former SS officer who was freed from prison by Italy. Mr. Frischenschlager has said he met the former Nazi only to insure the secrecy of his arrival.

headline: LIMIT ON TESTIMONY IS CONSIDERED IN POLISH TRIAL
abstract: The seven judges presiding over the murder trial of four security policemen began deliberating today over whether to limit testimony or to call additional witnesses, whose statements in open court could implicate higher-ups in the slaying of a pro-Solidarity priest.    Their pending decision, which touches on the political aspect of the trial, was brought into sharp focus toward the end of the day, in which two police officers testified that within a day of the kidnapping of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, they told their commanding officer that an unmarked government car had been seen at the church in Bydgoszcz where the priest spoke shortly before his abduction.   Gen. Zenon Platek, the officer in question and the suspended director of the Ministry of Internal Affairs department that monitored church activity, repeated in his testimony that he could not remember being informed about the car by the two men whom he dispatched to report on the early investigation of the crime in Torun.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: World Bank Is Seeking $1 Billion for Africa Aid
abstract: The World Bank hopes to raise an extra $1 billion for Africa at a special fund- raising meeting of donor countries in Paris this week, but there are doubts that the target will be reached.         The United States has said it would refuse to contribute. Such other rich industrial countries as Japan and West Germany have kept mum on their plans. All prospective donors face budgetary restraints at home.

headline: FOR MUSCOVITES, LIFE GOES ON
abstract: If the Soviet Union stood at the start of a new era under a young leader, the fact was not immediately evident in the guarded reactions of Muscovites plying their daily rounds under gloomy skies.   Shoppers moved briskly in and out of stores along Gorky Street, hardly perturbed by the lines of soldiers sealing off side streets, and barely glancing at the motorcades of black limousines whizzing up and down the largely emptied avenue.      Schools Open for Funeral    Though the death of Konstantin U. Chernenko and the ascension of Mikhail S. Gorbachev filled the newspapers, radio and television, people in the street seemed reluctant to discuss the latest events and retreated behind generalities.   A middle-aged engineer ventured that ''no one lives forever'' and that, yes, it probably was better to have a younger man in charge. A couple at a cafe agreed, noting that a younger leader might have more initiative. Then they quickly bustled off, saying they were late for the theater.

headline: S.& F. CUTS RATINGS ON CARBIDE DEBT
abstract: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its ratings of the Union Carbide Corporation's debt yesterday to the lowest investment grade because of the Dec. 3 gas leak at the company's plant in Bhopal, India.    Union Carbide's senior long-term debt was lowered to BBBx from A, its subordinated long-term debt to BBB from A-, and its commercial paper to A-2 from A-1.    In a prepared statement, Union Carbide said the extent of the downgrading had been excessive.

headline: Business Digest;   SATURDAY, JANUARY 26, 1985
abstract: Companies    Irwin L. Jacobs has been buying Phillips Petroleum stock and intends to vote against the company's proposed refinancing plan. The Minneapolis investor said that he had not joined with anyone else in a challenge to Phillips management, but Wall Street sources say other big investors may also be acquiring Phillips stock. On the Big Board, Phillips was up 75 cents, to $48.75, with three million shares changing hands. The stock has gained more than $5 this week. Meanwhile, Phillips, which called a meeting for Feb. 22 for shareholders to vote on the plan, is understood to have arranged for $1.5 billion to finance the recapitalization. (Page 31.)    A new financing plan to finish the Seabrook 1 nuclear unit was announced by Public Service of New Hampshire and three underwriters. The plan would replace the ''Newbrook'' proposal, which called for setting up a new company to raise money. (31.)

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: New Y.&R. Venture With Tokyo's Dentsu    America's largest advertising agency, Young & Rubicam, is also the biggest proponent of joint ventures with other agencies. And it is all set to try again.

headline: Article 227392 -- No Title
abstract: Two of the nation's largest military contractors won Air Force work today worth nearly $100 million in a program to build mobile launchers for the next generation of strategic nuclear missiles.     The Boeing Aerospace Company of Seattle received a $49.9 million contract and the Martin Marietta Corporation's Denver plant a $46.9 million contract to continue development of a blast-resistant truck for launching the Air Force's single-warhead ICBM, informally called Midgetman.    The missile is to be the successor early in the next decade to the much larger, 10-warhead MX missile, whose initial production was authorized by Congress in 1983 after bitter debate. The future of the MX program is still uncertain, hinging on a go-ahead vote by both houses of Congress this spring.

headline: Power Cut in Mozambique
abstract: Rightist rebels sabotaged power lines from South Africa early today, leaving most parts of this capital without electricity, the official press agency reported. This was the fifth time the rebels have cut power supplies to Maputo since October. The rebels have been fighting a hit-and-run war against the left-wing Government of President Samora M. Machel since Mozambique's independence from Portugal in 1975.

headline: A RIGHTS REVIEW POINTS TO GAINS IN LATIN REGION
abstract: The State Department, in an annual review, has found continuing deprivation and abuses of human rights in most countries around the world. But a senior department official asserted that the most important trend consisted of improvements in Latin America.   Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, said at a news conference today, ''Worldwide, I think I would say that the only significant overall trend is the trend toward improvement in the Western Hemisphere.''   ''In the last five years, I think, we are now up to nine countries that have gone from military dictatorship to democracy,'' he said. ''Zero countries have gone from democracy to dictatorship.''

headline: 5,000 Flee Gas Cloud From Brazilian Plant
abstract: A cloud of toxic ammonia gas escaped from a fertilizer plant in a southeastern Brazilian town, causing the evacuation of 5,000 people and injuring at least 30, environmental officials said today.   Most of the 30 people who were hospitalized in nearby towns ''had vision and breathing problems, but none was in serious condition,'' said an official of the Sao Paulo state environmental agency in Cubatao, 260 miles southwest of Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Register Sets News Session The Des Moines Register and
abstract: Tribune Company, which has   invited offers to buy its operations, will hold a news conference tomorrow, after a company board meeting, and is expected to announce the winning   bidders. Among companies said to   have been invited to bid are the   Washington Post Company, the   Gannett Company, the Tribune   Company, the Morris Communications Company, the   Hearst Company and The New   York Times Company.  The Washington Post Company has been regarded in the   industry as most likely to be   the winning bidder for the company's flagship newspaper,   The Des Moines Register, but   one source said yesterday that   it was only ''one of the front-runners.''

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Morgan Analyst Plans Wider Scope
abstract: Barton M. Biggs, who has been picking stocks and moving markets for the last 12 years at Morgan Stanley & Company, is broadening his focus. To date, Mr. Biggs has primarily limited himself to comments on American equity markets; now he intends to take on the world.    In a letter to clients informing them of the firm's decision to expand its coverage of foreign equities, Mr. Biggs wrote, ''I am going to attempt to be a global investment strategist.'' In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Biggs said that the logic of such a move was inescapable.

headline: Allis Seeking An Extension
abstract: The Allis- Chalmers Corporation said it has asked its banks and institutional lenders to extend the expiration date of its current financing agreement to May 31, from March 15.

headline: FRANCE BOLSTERING NEW CALEDONIA BASE
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand tonight ordered the strengthening of the military base on the Pacific island of New Caledonia to protect what he called France's strategic interests in the southern Pacific.    The President spoke on television after returning from a 12-hour visit to New Caledonia, where 19 people have died in clashes between Melanesian nationalists demanding independence from France and French settlers who want the island to remain French. The white settlers are supported in their demands by Asian and Polynesian groups on the island.   President Mitterrand said foreign powers, which he did not name, were trying to ''get mixed up'' in the political crisis in New Caledonia. He added that the strategic interests of France in the area required it to keep out ''whatever foreign power'' might try to set up a presence on the island.

headline: BOTH SIDES IN GULF WAR AGAIN RAID CIVILIAN AREAS
abstract: Iran and Iraq continued the bombardment of civilian targets for a fifth day today, and the Iraqis were reported to be bracing for an Iranian ground offensive.   Iran kept up the heavy shelling of the southern Iraqi port city of Basra that it started Tuesday in retaliation for what it said were Iraqi air raids on an unfinished nuclear power plant and a steel complex a day earlier.   Long columns of Iraqi armor and troops were seen moving south and diplomats in Baghdad said they were part of a buildup to counter the expected Iranian ground thrust.

headline: Head of Detroit News Hints at Going Public
abstract: As president of the 112-year-old Evening News Association, corporate parent of The Detroit News, Peter B. Clark has his hands full.    In the last year the closely held company, controlled by descendants of James E. Scripps, has been a scene of unrest among dissident shareholders. In December the company spent $10 million to buy back 40,000 of its 484,000 shares to pacify the dissidents, who wanted more liquidity for their holdings.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1985        The Economy         Industrial production advanced 0.4 percent in January, a healthy showing in line with the gains in November and December. Output of automobiles jumped a strong 4 percent and military gear climbed 1.1 percent, but other manufacturing areas were weak. (Page 29.) Producer prices were steady in January, as energy and food costs tumbled. Economists foresee continued low inflation, in part because of the strong dollar. (31.)

headline: Hughes Contracts
abstract: The Army awarded Hughes Helicopters Inc. a total of $686.9 million in four contracts for production of AH-64 attack helicopters, plus another $3.1 million for AH-64 spare parts, the Defense Department said.

headline: Phibro-Salomon Coup Gives Gutfreund Reins
abstract: On Wall Street the appointment of John H. Gutfreund as sole head of Phibro-Salomon was seen as a major executive coup.   Mr. Gutfreund, 54, took over the helm of the giant investment banking and commodity trading house in August, pushing aside David Tendler, 46, his one-time boss.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Resources Chairman May Fight a Takeover
abstract: For years, Arthur R. Seder Jr. has carried in his wallet a tattered card imprinted with the letters of a standard military eye chart. He got it after he failed the vision test to become a bomber pilot in World War II.    When he failed the test, Mr. Seder became a navigator instead. But he memorized the letters on the eye chart and took the vision test again. He passed it, and went on to fly 25 missions with the 8th Air Force in England.

headline: ADVERTISING ;   Career Shift for Head Of Times-Mirror Unit
abstract: Thomas R. McCartin, who set up the Times-Mirror National Marketing Company in New York 14 months ago and has since served as its president and chief executive, confirmed yesterday that he would be leaving the company to return to Dallas, where he will be joining the Criswell Development Company, a real estate concern.   ''It's been a fun 23 years,'' he said of his newspaper career, ''but it's time to follow a different drummer.''

headline: MODERNIZING THE PARTY FORMAT
abstract: BECAUSE no company really likes to fix anything that isn't broken, until recently the direct sellers refused to tamper with their basic sales methods. Tupperware parties changed little from year to year, and Avon ladies continued to ring doorbells.   But now the familiar methods are not working so well. And all of the companies are tinkering with their sales techniques. As K. Douglas Martin, Tupperware's president, put it, ''We have to be more responsive to women's needs.''

headline: Burlington Road Plans Offering
abstract: Burlington Northern Inc. announced yesterday that one day this week it would offer $50 million of equipment trust certificates, due serially from Jan. 15, 1986, to Jan. 15, 2000.    Investment bankers from Salomon Brothers and Morgan Stanley & Company are acting as lead managers for the underwriting. The certificates have been rated AA-1 by Moody's and AAA by Standard & Poor's.

headline: MANILA SAYS REBELS GAINED IN '84, KILLING 2,000
abstract: The Philippine Defense Minister warned today that the Communist insurgency in this country was becoming increasingly bold and effective. He said a ''serious upsurge'' in rebel activities resulted in the deaths of 2,000 civilians and military personnel last year.    The Defense Minister, Juan Ponce Enrile, said the subversive and terrorist operations of the Communist insurgents ''constitute the most formidable threat to our national security today and will continue to do so.''

headline: THE WAR FOR INSTITUTIONAL COMISSIONS
abstract: EVERY piece of turf in the securities industry is being fought over, and none more viciously than commissions from the institutional equity business.    Commission rates are coming down; costs for personnel and new technology are going up. And the inventive minds in Wall Street are working overtime to devise new ways to beggar their neighbors. The latest practice - the ''third party'' business - is to give back to institutions that part of the commission that pays for research, custodian fees and other services ordered by money managers and pension plan sponsors.

headline: Bond Offering Set By Denver Utility The Public Service Company of Colorado, which provides electric and gas service in the Denver area, is offering $50 million of first mortgage bonds, underwriters announced yesterday. The bonds carry a 13 percent coupon and are priced at 100, with the issue maturing in 2015.
abstract: Proceeds will be used to finance the redemption of the company's outstanding 15 percent bonds before the maturity date of March 1, 1987.   Kidder, Peabody & Company and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets are the underwriters for the offering. The bonds are rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and Ax by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: Mays Studying Investors' Offer
abstract: J.W. Mays Inc. management has asked shareholders ''to take no action at his time'' in response to a $20 million tender offer for the retailer. A group of investors led by Sol Goldman, a New York real estate investor, has offered $12 a share. Mr. Goldman's group holds about 23 percent of the 2.2 million shares outstanding.

headline: Carnation's New Chief
abstract: When the Carnation Company announced last week that its president, Timm F. Crull, would become its chief executive officer on Feb. 1, succeeding H. Everett Olson, it chose a marketing-oriented executive to see the company through an important transition: its $3 billion sale to Nestle S.A., the Swiss food conglomerate.   Nestle's purchase of the Los Angeles-based food company was described by investment bankers as the largest merger outside the oil industry when it was announced last Sept. 4.

headline: MOTHER TERESA PRAISES ETHIOPIAN REFUGEE PLAN
abstract: Mother Teresa, founder of the Missionaries of Charity, praised the Ethiopian Government today for making ''a very good beginning'' in its effort to resettle victims of the famine that has stricken much of the African continent.     At the same time, Mother Teresa, who won the 1979 Nobel Peace Prize for her work among the poor of India, called on donor nations to support the plan by ''adopting'' resettlement sites.    She said this meant taking on full responsibility for establishing the new communities, including providing food, water, schools and health offices.

headline: U.S. Says It Destroyed Korean Airliner Tape
abstract: The Defense Department said today that the Air Force had erased a radar tape that traced part of the flight of a South Korean airliner shot down over Soviet territory in 1983, but that the tape had recorded the plane's fate.   A total of 269 people died when the plane, on a New York-to-Seoul flight, was downed by a Soviet jet after it went off course and entered Soviet airspace north of Japan.

headline: A TAX RISE COULD BUOY THE RECOVERY
abstract: WITH the current and projected Federal budget deficits reaching unprecedented heights, the need for a tax increase has never been greater. Yet that prospect creates a dilemma for economic policymakers. According to traditional analysis, any tax increase - especially one large enough to reduce the deficit significantly - slows spending and increases the likelihood of a recession. Such an economic contraction, in turn, adds to the already- bloated deficit as unemployment pushes upward again.    Our recent research, however, leads us to be skeptical of this orthodox approach, and to conclude that a tax increase would at worst be only mildly contractionary - and at best could even generate stronger growth.

headline: U.S. OFFICIAL TO PRESS CHILE ON ELECTIONS
abstract: The Reagan Administration said today that it was sending a senior State Department official to Chile to urge President Augusto Pinochet and opposition leaders to find a way to move toward elections.   Officials made it clear that the mission grew out of their alarm over continuing violence in Chile and what they regard as a worsening political situation.    The official, Langhorne A. Motley, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter- American Affairs, is to leave on Saturday and to remain in Chile through next Wednesday, the State Department said. He will be the highest-ranking American official to visit Chile in years.

headline: ISRAEL HAS AIRLIFTED 10,000 ETHIOPIANS
abstract: The Government, acknowledging for the first time that it has been secretly airlifting Ethiopian Jews from their drought- stricken country to Israel, said today that more than 10,000 had been brought out in the last few years.    They said the airlift was speeded up in the last year, when conditions in Ethiopia worsened and famine set in.   Although publicly acknowledging the existence of the operation, Israeli officials declined to give any details about how the rescue operation had been organized and what other countries were involved. They said any discussion of those subjects remained under military censorship inside Israel.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *       Ameritech, Chicago, the regional telephone company, yesterday raised its quarterly dividend to $1.65 a share, from $1.50 a share.     *       Atlanta Gas Light Co.  said it would build a $35 million liquefied natural gas plant in Cherokee County, Ga.

headline: Kroger to Buy Hook Drugs The Kroger Company said that it had agreed to acquire Hook Drugs Inc., an Indianapolis-based chain of 302 drugstores, for about $160 million in cash and stock.
abstract: The acquisition, which has been approved by both companies' boards, is subject to approval by Hook's shareholders. The offer was valued at $37 per share of Hook.

headline: Alleghany Assails Choice The chairman of the Alleghany Corporation,F.M.
abstract: Kirby, yesterday criticized the         decision made by the Department of Transportation Friday

headline: M.S. Walker Plans Campaign for Liqueur
abstract: M.S. Walker Inc. of Somerville, Mass., is in the spirits business, but unlike the giants it competes against it has been using very little advertising. Paul Shuman, its ad director, characterizes its marketing method as good products at moderate prices that sell on their price value.

headline: Broader Yen Trade Urged
abstract: A panel of Japan's key financial leaders today called for new measures to increase international trading in the yen, including the establishment of an offshore market in Tokyo.   With the report, most of the nation's major business leaders lined up behind the broad changes now taking place in Japan's financial and capital markets.

headline: Midcon Pipeline
abstract: The Midcon Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to build a $28 million intrastate natural gas pipeline in Arkansas with the Southwestern Energy Company. Midcon said it would have a 60 percent interest in the pipeline, while Southwestern would hold 40 percent. Midcon said the 16-inch pipeline would be 114 miles long and have an initial capacity of 75 million cubic feet daily.

headline: New Budget for Britain Focuses on Adding Jobs
abstract: In the face of growing hostility toward the British Government's handling of the economy, Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson today disclosed a budget for the next fiscal year that holds Britain to the economic policies laid out when Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher came to power in 1979.   In a 75-minute presentation to a rapt and occasionally boisterous House of Commons, Mr. Lawson proposed more limited income tax cuts than the Government had projected last autumn and ignored pressures to initiate a major spending program to combat Britain's record unemployment. But Mr. Lawson promised to cut the cost of creating new, low-salaried jobs and extend work training programs for youths.    The move to encourage new jobs by the elimination of the salary ceiling on which British employers pay a 10.45 percent national insurance tax, was the biggest surprise. That move will make it more expensive to employ higher-salaried workers but is expected to generate more than $910 million toward a program to reduce the insurance charges for lower-salaried workers and the self-employed. The overall effect is intended to encourage small entrepreneurs and make it cheaper for large businesses to hire unskilled workers.

headline: Senate Panel Backs S.B.A.
abstract: The first round in a bipartisan Congressional drive to save the Small Business Administration from extinction in the Reagan Administration budget was fought today without its prime antagonist, David A. Stockman.    Mr. Stockman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, was released early this morning after spending the night in Georgetown University Hospital.

headline: PROSPECTS;  On the Job Front
abstract: As 1985 unfolds, the ranks of the unemployed should thin, partly because the economy is still improving and partly because the nation's labor force is not growing as fast as the number of jobs, according to M.D. Levy, chief economist of the Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia.   He noted: ''Demographic patterns tell us that the number of people that will be entering the labor force this year, 3.1 million, continues the slight, but steady decline that began several years ago.''

headline: U.S. SAYS ISRAELIS SHOW LITTLE GAIN IN ECONOMIC PLAN
abstract: The Reagan Administration told Congress today that Israel had failed so far to make enough progress in its economic recovery plan for the United States to meet its request for a major increase in economic aid.   Facing a House subcomittee that was virtually unanimous in advocating approval of the $2.6 billion sought by Israel in new funds, the State Department's senior economic official said the new money would be wasted. He said it would ''disappear quickly'' because of Israel's failure to cope adequately with budgetary and fiscal problems.   Israel received $1.2 billion in economic aid and $1.4 billion in military aid for the 1985 fiscal year, which began last Oct. 1. It has asked, said W. Allen Wallis, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, for $800 million as a supplemental economic grant for 1985 and $1.8 billion in economic aid for the 1986 fiscal year.

headline: People
abstract: D. Kyle Felt has been elected an executive vice president of Warwick Advertising.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ;   40 Killed in Crash Of a Colombia Airliner
abstract: A commercial airliner crashed into a fog-shrouded mountain in southern Colombia during a storm today, killing all 40 people aboard, authorities said.   Colombia's Civil Aeronautics chief, Guillermo Penagos, said the wreckage of the Satena Airlines Fokker 28, a twin-engine turboprop plane, was found near San Vicente de Caguan, about 250 miles southwest of Bogota.   The plane left Bogota early today on a flight to Florencia and stopped in Neiva and San Vicente de Caguan before crashing.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 16, 1985        The Economy         The Administration will ask Congress to increase charges for a number of financial services the Government provides, including home mortgage insurance, farm credit and export loan guarantees, officials said. The charges would be paid either by the individuals benefiting from the services or by the agencies involved. But the proposals, intended to raise up to $4 billion a year in added revenue, are likely to run into stiff opposition. (Page A1.) Fed Chairman Paul A. Volcker asked for a cut in the budget deficit of at least $50 billion in the next fiscal year to impress the financial markets and achieve a decline in interest rates. (D21.)

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Note and Bond Prices Rise
abstract: Increasing confidence that inflation will remain low and the willingness of some investors to shift funds out of low-yielding short-term securities led to a modest rise in Treasury note and bond prices yesterday.     Although investor buying was well short of a stampede, and many potential buyers are still worried about an upturn in rates later this year, Government securities dealers said there was a modest amount of buying yesterday by small and large investors. By late in the day, the 11 3/4 percent Treasury bonds due in 2014 were offered at 103 21/32, up 10/32, to yield 11.31 percent. As recently as Jan. 4, the bellwether Treasury bond was offered at 100 1/2 to yield 11.68 percent.

headline: CASTLE & COOKE TO SELL BUMBLE BEE
abstract: Castle & Cooke Inc., the marketer of Dole pineapples and bananas and Bumble Bee tuna, agreed yesterday to sell most of the assets of Bumble Bee Seafoods to a group of investors that includes four managers of the seafood processor.     The company put Bumble Bee up for sale last June, as part of a move to get out of the seafood business.    Most details of the agreement were not announced, but Robert D. Cook, the recently elected president and chief executive officer of the Honolulu-based company, said the transaction would result in an initial cash payment of $40 million in the first quarter of 1985. The total price will be determined by the net book value of the assets sold. Analysts have placed the total price between $40 million and $60 million.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Post of President Is Filled by Centex
abstract: The Centex Corporation yesterday named Laurence E. Hirsch as president and chief operating officer of the housing, construction and cement manufacturer, which is based in Dallas. The 39-year-old Mr. Hirsch has been president and chief executive of Southdown Inc., a Houston-based cement, sugar and energy producer, since last spring.    Mr. Hirsch will fill vacancies created last November, when Jack McDonald, 51, resigned to pursue personal interests. Mr. McDonald had been president and chief operating officer since 1976.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Promotion at G.M.
abstract: The General Motors Corporation today named William Lane general manager of its Oldsmobile division and a corporate vice president. Mr. Lane, 55 years old, was previously general sales and service manager for G.M.'s Pontiac division. He succeeds Joseph Sanchez, who was appointed on Tuesday as president of G.M.'s new Saturn Corporation subsidiary.

headline: TEXAN'S BID TO SAVE MUSE AIR
abstract: M. Lamar Muse, who has spent 36 of his 64 years in the airline business, says he would like nothing better than to call it quits, and spend the rest of his life in his condominium in Austin, Tex., and at his summer home in Vancouver, British Columbia, where he can fish for salmon.    ''I'd rather be doing that than sitting in hot Dallas this summer trying to make this airline work,'' the garrulous executive said.   Yet, he added, he has little choice but to try to save Dallas-based Muse Air, founded by his son, Michael L. Muse. The airline, which is in a dogfight with rival Southwest Airlines, has never made a go of its flight operations - its profits to date are the result of tax credits. In the first nine months of 1984, Muse Air lost $9.3 million.

headline: Rating Is Lowered For Midland Bank
abstract: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it had lowered the rating on subordinated debt guaranteed by Midland Bank P.L.C. to A from AA-minus as a result of the fourth-quarter loss reported by Midland's Crocker National Corporation unit.   Commercial paper rating of Midland Bank and its subsidiary, Midland Bank Canada, was cut to A-1 from A1-plus, but ratings of obligations backed by a Crocker letter of credit were maintained at A for long- term issues and A-1 for commercial paper.

headline: Oil Prices Fall Again
abstract: Prices of crude oil and heating oil plummeted again yesterday on markets around the world, and traders talked of light crude oil slipping below $25 a barrel sometime soon.   Reaching that benchmark would have been almost unthinkable even several months ago, when the same oil sold for $29 or $30 a barrel. Since then, a glut of light oil and a mild winter have resulted in competitive price reductions by North Sea producers and some members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

headline: ONTARIO'S RULING PARTY CHOOSES NEW LEADER
abstract: The governing Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario today elected Frank Miller, the province's Industry Minister, as its new party leader. He will automatically become Premier of Canada's most populous and economically powerful province.    Mr. Miller, 57 years old, is considered the most right-wing of the four candidates who vied to succeed William Davis, who announced in October that he would retire.   Mr. Miller, who has held four Cabinet posts under Mr. Davis, supports endsto the minimum wage, to rent controls and to rules prohibiting doctors from charging more than limits set under the medical insurance system. A former car dealer, he stressed moderation in his campaign.

headline: ITALY ARRESTS U.S. TAX LAWYER IN FRAUD CASE
abstract: Italian officials said today that they had arrested an American lawyer for fraud and tax evasion in a case that United States and Italian officials said could have wide repercussions.     Robert Kobel, a spokesman for the foreign operations division of the Internal Revenue Service in Washington, said in a telephone interview that the case would make the point that Americans overseas were subject to American income taxes. In addition, he said prominent people were involved. ''It's going to blossom forth in a much wider way,'' he said.

headline: Lyon Metal Stock
abstract: Lyon Metal Products Inc. said it had authorized the repurchase of the 38 percent of its shares held by the investor Irwin L. Jacobs for $19 a share, or a total of $10.1 million. The repurchase clears the way for a previously announced leveraged buyout of Lyons through an employee stock ownership plan, company officials said. Mr. Jacobs has indicated to Lyon that he wants to sell his stake, the company said.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   President Resigns At New York Air
abstract: Lawrence J. Twill, president and chief executive of New York Airlines since last May, resigned yesterday.    Directors of the airline said Mr. Twill, who is 47 years old, intends to return to Wall Street.    Mr. Twill came to New York Air after seven years as managing director of institutional sales, research and trading at Rooney, Pace Inc., the investment banking firm. He was not answering questions from reporters yesterday.

headline: PATENTS;  Artificial Kidney Used in Dialysis
abstract: An artificial kidney has been invented for dialysis by Kyu H. Lee. He assigned patent 4,496,458 to Extracorporeal Medical Specialties Inc. of King of Prussia, Pa., which has recently transferred the rights to Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., Deerfield, Ill.

headline: NEW INTEREST IN SPECIALISTS
abstract: The winds of change are whipping the flags of the venerable New York Stock Exchange faster and faster these days. The Big Board has been exploring 24-hour trading in stocks of companies listed on the exchange and is studying the possibility of a merger with the Pacific Stock Exchange.    Now, it is readying a controversial proposal that could have even more far-reaching implications. That proposal, which the Big Board's staff is expected to recommend to its board of directors in early February, would pave the way for giant, well-capitalized firms such as Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. to own and operate specialist units on the floor of the exchange.   ''The specialist business has become much more risk-oriented,'' John Phelan, chairman of the stock exchange and formerly a specialist himself, said in an interview. ''It needs more capital to grow.''

headline: THE BATTERY GETS A NEW LEASE ON LIFE By Elizabeth Llorente
abstract: IT MADE our dolls cry and crawl, and our toy cars   race; now it makes our watches tick and our cameras click. Without it, life would have been quite different. It is the battery, taken for granted but an absolute necessity: the unsung wonder of technology.    Long lingering in the shadow of electronic gadgets, batteries have never drawn much attention, said Bill Perusek, manager of employee-community relations for General Electric in Gainesville, Fla. ''As long as they're around when they're needed,'' he said, ''people overlook them.''

headline: ENDLESS PAIN OF DIVIDED KOREA FAMILIES
abstract: One can stop almost anybody on the streets of this capital and the odds are high that the person has a relative in North Korea.     One woman whose husband works for the Government fled North Korea from the port of Hungnam. She was one of millions who headed south when World War II ended and a Soviet-supported Communist administration took over the North. A favorite uncle stayed behind.

headline: HATFIELD PRESSES FOR MILITARY CUTS
abstract: The chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee asserted today that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger ''cannot be a draft dodger'' and must accept a Pentagon budget smaller than he requested.   The committee chairman, Senator Mark O. Hatfield, said he would strive to freeze next year's military spending at this year's level.   That statement, and his comment about Mr. Weinberger, appeared to deepen the rift between Senate Republicans and the White House over a legislative package to reduce the deficit for the fiscal year 1986, which starts Oct. 1.        Budget Freeze or Tax Increase    Senator Hatfield, an Oregon Republican, said that without a freeze in the military budget, a tax increase would be inevitable. He also said he thought the Senate would approve a freeze.

headline: ADMINISTRATION SEEKS TO DOUBLE AID FOR PERU
abstract: The Reagan Administration plans to ask Congress to double military aid to Peru next year, which would make that country the largest recipient of United States military aid in South America, State Department officials said today.    With the increased aid, an Administation official said, ''we want to encourage the Peruvians to be in a position to fight their own, significant internal difficultiess.''    While struggling with crushing economic problems, Peru's democratic Government has also been battling the Shining Path guerrilla movement, which has terrorized parts of the country for several years.

headline: Busch Earnings Rise
abstract: The Anheuser-Busch Companies said today that net income increased 7.3 percent in the fourth quarter over the comparable period a year ago. Earnings were $71.9 million, or $1.38 a share, up from $67 million, or $1.25 a share. Revenue rose 5.5 percent, to $1.73 billion, from $1.64 billion.

headline: PICKENS-LED GROUP BUYING INTO UNOCAL
abstract: A partnership led by the Mesa Petroleum Company was disclosed yesterday as the mystery buyer behind the big run-up in the price of the stock of the Unocal Corporation, the nation's 12th-largest oil company. The group said that it had spent about $584 million to buy Unocal stock and that it had agreed to spend up to an additional $616 million for more shares.

headline: Lawter-Hach Tie
abstract: Lawter International Inc. said it had bought about 25 percent of the outstanding shares of the Hach Company for investment purposes.

headline: UNESCO ENTANGLED IN AN EAST GERMAN'S PLIGHT
abstract: The Director General of Unesco has accepted a resignation request from an East German employee who has been held in his country since he was charged with treason in 1980, according to Western diplomats here.    But according to a spokesman for Unesco, Director General Amadou- Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal has only received the request and has not yet acted on it. Members can write to Mr. M'Bow if they oppose granting the request, the spokesman added.    The East German in the case is Percy Stultz, who was the director of Unesco's Cultural Heritage Division when he was arrested on a trip home to East Germany on a charge of high treason and sentenced to three years imprisonment.

headline: Chicago Bank Loan Details
