abstract: The Continental Illinois Corporation said today that during the fourth quarter it collected $145 million in principal and interest on the $3.6 billion in troubled loans that it had turned over to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as part of the plan to rescue the bank.   Continental Illinois, which is managing the loans for the F.D.I.C., also said that it had forgiven $121 million in principal on certain loans.

headline: NEW ISSUES RAISED FOR U.S. ON GREECE
abstract: Administration officials said today that Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's unexpected decision to withdraw support for the re-election of President Constantine Caramanlis would intensify the debate in Washington on American policy toward Greece.   Mr. Papandreou's move, which led to the resignation today of Mr. Caramanlis, raises new questions on how the Reagan Administration should deal with Greece, State Department officials said.    ''There are many in this Government who would like to really stick it to Papandreou,'' one department official said. ''And there are many who still believe you can deal with Papandreou even though he likes to kick the U.S. at every opportunity.''

headline: Continental to Get 4 More Aircraft
abstract: Continental Air Lines said it had received the approval of a Federal bankruptcy court to acquire from the Texas Air Corporation, its parent company, four Boeing 737-300 aircraft. But the court stopped short of approving the purchase of 18 planes, initially sought by the Houston-based carrier as part of its expansion plan.

headline: WHAT'S NEW AMONG INDEPENDENT BOOKSELLERS
abstract: In the last two years, B. Dalton Bookseller, Waldenbooks, and several regional discount chains have opened more than a dozen outlets in and around Albany.  The spate of new book stores, many with bargain prices, spelled good news for avid readers in the area.  But for owners of independent bookstores, the encroachment of the giants into their territories meant hard times.  ''We've been surrounded-it's like a state of seige,'' said Barbara Shohet, co-manager of the Book House of Stuyvesant Park, a 10-year old Albany bookstore.  ''We're doing very nicely, but it's an uphill fight.''

headline: 15 Years of Talks
abstract: Charts and tables summarize the negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union. Page A9.

headline: Eusebio Mujal, Labor Leader From Cuba and a Castro Foe
abstract: Eusebio Mujal, an anti-Communist Cuban labor leader who fled to the United States within a month after the 1959 revolution, has died at his home in Washington his family said today. He was 69 years old.

headline: A FEBRUARY FIRESTORN THAT DRESDEN CAN'T FORGET
abstract: Two very different German visions of the past are coming into focus with the approach of the 40th anniversary of the Nazi surrender on May 8, 1945.   In prosperous West Germany, the anniversary evokes pain, embarrassment and ritual expressions of a distant guilt. The phrases ''zero hour'' and ''collapse'' are much in use to fix the date in the imagination - as if to say the Nazi enterprise, however evil, led, after all, to the collapse of a unified Germany, the sundering of the fatherland. It is a rare and bold West German politician who says openly it was a good thing the war was lost.   By contrast, in spartan, Communist East Germany the official mood is one of shrill enthusiasm. This month an entire front page of Neues Deutschland, the party daily, was filled with a bannered summons to start observing ''the 40th anniversary of the victory over Hitler fascism and the liberation of the German people.'' May 8 has been proclaimed an official holiday.

headline: Charter Co. Records Loss JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP)
abstract: The Charter Company,   which is being reorganized   under the Federal Bankruptcy   Act, reported today a 1984   net loss of $749.34 million, including $71.07 million in the   fourth quarter. The company, which has interests in insurance and oil refining, attributed $685 million   of the loss to discontinued   operations, the expenses of filing for bankruptcy and provisions for estimated losses on   disposal of assets which were   partially offset by gains on assets sold. In 1983, Charter had   net earnings of $53.89 million,   or $2.01 a share, and fourth-   quarter earnings of $7.16 million, or 24 cents a share.

headline: Pharmaceuticals
abstract: To the Editor:     ''Glory Days End for Pharmaceuticals'' (Feb. 24) suggests that the fact that ''most companies seem prepared to stick with significantly higher prices for their brands, despite evidence of consumer interest in generics'' reflects a ''denial of reality.''   I suggest it represents a specific interpretation of reality: The prescriber is not the one paying for the drug.

headline: PATENTS;  Number of Patents Rises to 72,149 in Year
abstract: The number of patents issued has increased substantially. The 1984 report of the Patent and Trademark Office, to be published soon, will show issuance of 72,149 patents during its fiscal year ended Sept. 30, compared with 59,715 in the previous fiscal year.

headline: Beatrice Sells 3 of Its Bakeries
abstract: The Beatrice Companies announced the sale of its bakeries in Lakeland, Fla., Birmingham, Ala., and Orangeburg, S.C., to Southern Bakeries Inc. of Lakeland for $31 million.

headline: THE TAXPAYER'S SHARE, IN PERSPECTIVE
abstract: Progressivity of Federal Taxes Declines   Federal Taxes in 1966 ranged from 7.8 percent of adjusted family income in the first tenth of the population to 21.1 percent in the top decile.  by 1985, largely as a result of the decline in the coporation income tax and the rise in payroll taxes, Federal taxes are expected to take 13.9 percent of adjusted family income in the first decile, a big rise, but to drop to 17.1 percent in the top decile.  State and local taxes declined slightly during the lst decade.      Income Distribution Little Affected by Taxes    The share of income of each quintile of the population before taxes remained virtually unchaged from 1966 to 1985.  But because the tax system became less progressive during the period, the distribution of income after taxes became slightly more concentrated, with the after tax income share of the top quintile rising a bit.

headline: Iran Lowers Oil Prices Closer to OPEC Levels
abstract: Iran has lowered its oil prices in line with those recently approved by the majority of members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today.   Iran initially disassociated itself from the new pricing structure adopted by the cartel last month.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: MONDAY, MARCH 11, 1985        The Economy         Japan's foreign trade surplus is spurring a huge flow of capital into other countries, particularly the U.S. Much of it is being invested in the Treasury securities issued to finance the Reagan Administration's budget deficits. (Page A.)        The housing industry is optimistic about a third year of modest success. Sales are up and new-home construction has started strong. The key may be the direction of mortgage rates. (D1.)

headline: Business and the Law;   Wide Debate Over N.L.R.B.
abstract: CHICAGO    AS labor's chieftains meet this week in Boca Raton, Fla., they will no doubt continue the debate that Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., started last year when he said the union movement might be better off if the National Labor Relations Board were to disappear and labor-management relations were to return to ''the law of the jungle.''   Since Mr. Kirkland made that remark, lawyers on both sides of the labor-management struggle have squared off over his suggestion that unions would have far more success organizing workers if both labor and management were to use their raw economic might, rather than the N.L.R.B., in trying to overpower each other. That was the situation that existed before the National Labor Relations Act of 1935.    Mr. Kirkland's thought is that labor, by using such techniques as secondary boycotts, which the N.L.R.B. moves quickly to stop, would be able to pressure more companies into recognizing unions.

headline: 'SOFT LANDING' NEEDED FOR U.S.
abstract: WORRIES about the American economy, stemming from the banking crisis in Ohio, have sent the dollar falling, the price of gold climbing, ruined the appetite of foreign investors for United States Government securities and corporate bonds, and pushed up interest rates.   In itself, the magnitude of the threat to the financial system posed by Gov. Richard F. Celeste's closing of 71 Ohio savings and loan institutions appears to have been vastly exaggerated. It is a much smaller threat than that resulting from the near- collapse of the Continental Illinois Bank. Where Continental Illinois had some $35 billion in deposits, all 71 Ohio savings associations have only about $5 billion in deposits. The Federal Reserve can supply all the liquidity the Ohio thrift institutions need to get through by putting up less than $250 million, where Continental Illinois, at peak, needed nearly $9 billion.

headline: BANK OF AMERICA DROPS LAW FIRM
abstract: Lord, Bissell & Brook, a leading Chicago law firm that had acted as attorneys for the scandal-ridden National Mortgage Equity Corporation of California, said today that it had carried out its duties in a ''professionally, morally and ethically proper manner.''    The law firm gave National Mortgage a clean bill of health in 1982 following charges that mortgages handled by the company appeared to have been overstated in value and that an ''inordinate number'' were in default. The charges were made by the Advance Mortgage Company, which was responsible for collecting payments on the mortgages.

headline: New Value Line Options
abstract: An options contract based on the Value Line stock market composite index began trading at the Philadelphia Stock Exchange today.

headline: JUDGE UPSETS U.S.-JAPANESE WHALING ACCORD
abstract: A Federal judge today voided a Reagan Administration decision to refrain from imposing sanctions against Japan for the killing of sperm whales by Japanese whalers in defiance of an international agreement.    The judge, Charles R. Richey of the United States District Court here, ordered Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige and Secretary of State George P. Shultz to certify Japan as being in violation of the moratorium on sperm whaling established by the International Whaling Commission in 1981.   Such certification would set in motion the Pelley Amendment, which requires that fish imports from nations that ''diminish the effectiveness'' of an international fishery conservation agreement be slashed. It also puts into force the Packwood-Magnuson Amendment, which requires that such nations lose at least 50 percent of their fishing quotas within United States's 200-mile economic zone in the first year and 100 percent of their quotas thereafter.

headline: STOCKS END MIXED IN HEAVY DAY
abstract: Stock trading soared yesterday, but prices ended mixed as profit taking hit some of the blue-chip issues.    The Dow Jones industrial average retreated 3.75 points, to 1,230.79, while the Dow Jones transportation and utility averages rose moderately, as did most other key market indexes.    Turnover ballooned to 155.3 million shares on the Big Board, from 124.9 million shares on Monday, on strong public as well as institutional participation. It was the eighth-biggest daily turnover ever. The busiest was on Aug. 3, 1984, when 236.8 million shares changed hands. First-hour volume yesterday of 51.57 million shares was the fifth highest ever.

headline: Treasury Realignment
abstract: Now that the former Merrill Lynch chairman, Donald T. Regan, has gone to the White House, the Treasury is mounting a search for ''someone who would be seen by Wall Street and financial markets generally as a very strong addition,'' according to one official.    The recruit, most likely someone employed in banking or on Wall Street, would be named Under Secretary for Finance, a new title.

headline: A LOCAL BEER NOT FOR EVERYONE
abstract: SOME of history's most momentous discoveries have    taken place in the kitchen, and so it was with Matthew Reich's.    Five years ago, Mr. Reich, who is now 33, and a friend bought malt, hops and yeast and brewed some stovetop beer. ''It was amazing to make alcohol, and then drink it,'' Mr. Reich recalled.    And it didn't stop there. ''If I could make it,'' he reasoned at the time, ''why not sell it?''

headline: THE MARKET
abstract: To the Editor:     Anyone believing the marketplace is the puppet to the large institutions is wrong.    Michael Blumstein says that investment managers have allocated a greater percentage of their portfolios to equities because they ''fear they will lose their large investment management fees if they park all their funds in fixed-income securities.'' Any money manager misplacing a high percentage of funds will find those large fees disappear when the market turns against him. Equities have outperformed bonds during the past decade - why isn't he arguing the equity shift was due to insight?

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: B.F. Goodrich Co., Akron, Ohio, said it planned to sell its Off-Highway Braking Systems division, which employs 290 and had 1984 sales of about $30 million. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Adviser to Peres Named
abstract: Avraham Burg has been appointed Prime Minister Shimon Peres's adviser for Jewish Diaspora Affairs, Mr. Peres's spokesman, Uri Savir, has announced. Mr. Burg, the son of Josef Burg, the Religious Affairs Minister, will be responsible for liaison between the Prime Minister's office and Jewish groups in the United States and around the world.

headline: Reuters Posts Rise in Profits
abstract: Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the world news and information organization, today announced pretax profits of $86 million in the year ended last Dec. 31, a 34 percent rise from 1983.

headline: THE BIG WINNERS IN THE PHILLIPS DEAL
abstract: Although the Phillips Petroleum Company is escaping with its independence intact, the view on Wall Street is that the real winners in the fight for control of the Oklahoma oil giant were Carl C. Icahn, T. Boone Pickens and the Phillips shareholders.  By forcing Phillips to sweeten its offer to shareholders, Mr. Icahn proved that he and T. Boone Pickens are an effective one- two punch. Even among those on Wall Street who have not been fans of either, there was unqualified admiration for their ability to come out ahead - and improve the lot of all Phillips shareholders in the process.     ''Carl Icahn forced Phillips to improve its deal,'' despite all the roadblocks it threw in his way, one Wall Street arbitrager said. In the process, Phillips also offered to kick in up to $25 million to pay for Mr. Icahn's expenses. ''He got a better deal for everybody; he's entitled to it,'' another trader said.

headline: Stevie Wonder Arrested
abstract: The singer Stevie Wonder, saying he was a ''conscientious criminal'' against oppression, was arrested along with a group of anti-apartheid demonstrators today outside the South African Embassy here. Protests have been held daily outside the embassy.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Applied Intelligent Systems Inc., Ann Arbor, Mich., a machine vision company, said it had completed the previously announced sale of a minority block of its stock to General Motors Corp. G.M. bought a 12.6 percent stake in the company and received warrants to buy an additional 13.3 percent over the next five years.     *       Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc.  and a group of investors told the Securities and Exchange Commission they had acquired the equivalent of a 5.3 percent stake in McDermott International Inc., an offshore oil and gas construction company.

abstract: LatestPreviousYearWeekWeekAgo       Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Dec. 31      $557,200 R $557,700 n.a.  Adj. Mon.Base (St.Louis Fed) *(1/9)      220,300 R 219,500 n.a. headline: General Felt, Michigan General
abstract: General Felt Industries told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in the Michigan General Corporation to about 1,868,000 shares, or 16.5 percent of the total outstanding. General Felt, a Saddle Brook, N.J., floor products concern, said its GFI Nevada unit bought 219,800 shares on Dec. 24.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS ;    Debt Issues
abstract: Aeroflex Laboratories is offering $25 million of 9 3/8 percent convertible subordinated debentures, due 2005, at a price of 100 through Drexel Burnham Lambert.     *       Fleet Financial Group is issuing $50 million of 8 1/2 percent, 25-year convertible subordinated debentures, at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.     *       Ford Motor Credit Co.  is issuing $100 million of annual extendible adjustable-rate notes, due 1997, at a price of 100 through Goldman, Sachs; the initial interest is 3/16 percentage points above the London interbank offered rate on one-year Eurodollar deposits.

headline: Business and the Law;   Unequal Rights In Voting Stock
abstract: ''ONE share, one vote'' has long been a bedrock notion in corporate America. In recent months, however, several blue-chip giants and scores of small new companies have adopted bylaws that allow for unequal voting rights. For example, one class of common stock, usually controlled by management, may allow 10 votes per share, while another class, owned by nonmanagement investors, may have just one vote per share or perhaps no vote at all.   This trend has caused the New York Stock Exchange to rethink its 59-year-old ''shareholder democracy'' rule that calls for delisting companies that authorize two classes of common stock with disparate voting rights. As the Big Board seems ready to loosen its rules as part of the heated competition to keep and win listings, corporate lawyers, members of Congress and Securities and Exchange Commission officials are debating the legal, managerial and economic implications of the move away from shareholder democracy.

headline: FPA Interest Of 25% Bought An undisclosed investor
abstract: bought about 25 percent of the   shares of the FPA Corporation   yesterday for about $11.5 million, but told the real estate   developer that his purchase   was for investment purposes   only. The buyer purchased about   one million of FPA's four million outstanding shares on the   American Stock Exchange yesterday morning, according to   Norman Greenough, senior   vice president and treasurer at   FPA.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: Two photographers were incorrectly identified in last Sunday's Business Section.  Gerald Davis took the photo of Frank Borman accompanying the Eastern Air Lines article.  Thomas Moon took the photo of Paul A. Samuelson and William D. Nordhaus, which appearde with the article about the new edition of 'Economics.'

headline: Utilities' Plan at Seabrook The three Maine utilities ordered by the Public Utilities Commission in that state to get out of the Seabrook nuclear power project have submitted plans to do so, a commission official said. But the bids received so far by the utilities do not cover their full share of the project, and price and other conditions remain to be negotiated.
abstract: The commission has threatened to order the three utilities to ''disengage'' from Seabrook if they cannot sell their shares.   The participants are the Central Maine Power Company, which holds 6 percent of the project; the Bangor Hydro-Electric Company, with 2.2 percent, and the Maine Public Service Company, with 1.5 percent.

headline: Data Bank;   January 27, 1985
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Anacomp Inc., an Indianapolis- based computer services company, said it had completed the sale of U.S.A. Communications Inc. to Outlet Communications Inc. for $22 million.          * Brokers Mortgage Service Inc., a regional mortgage banking company based in West Collingswood, N.J., said it had agreed to be acquired by the Travelers Corp. of Hartford in a deal valued at about $32 million.

headline: Anti-Semite Convicted In Toronto Case
abstract: Ernst Zundel, a German-born commercial artist and anti-Semitic pamphleteer, was convicted today of ''publishing false news'' in a tract declaring that accounts of the Nazi crimes against Jews are a fabrication.    The verdict from a District Court jury of 10 men and 2 women ended an eight-week trial in which Mr. Zundel's assertions that there were no gas chambers at Auschwitz and that Hitler had no intention of inflicting genocide on Jews captured front-page attention across Canada.

headline: 'WAR MACHINE' OR DEFENDER OF A BESIEGED NATION?
abstract: The threat that Nicaragua's Army may pose to other Central American countries has become a central issue in the debate over renewed United States financing for the rebels fighting to topple the Government.     The Administration says the army is a juggernaut, far larger than the other Central American militaries and poised to attack its neighbors. But Democrats in Congress and some officials in the Administration say they believe the White House has overstated its case.   At the same time, however, even many of the Administration's critics agree with two of President Reagan's other major concerns about Nicaragua: that many Sandinista leaders are Marxist-Leninists and that they have aided El Salvador's leftist guerrillas.        Reagan Sees a 'War Machine'    Mr. Reagan has accused the Nicaraguans of building ''a war machine'' that ''dwarfs the forces of all their neighbors combined.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: *       Allegheny Beverage Corp., Baltimore, said completion of its $225 million acquisition of Servomation Corp. from City Investing Co. had been postponed to April 22. Servomation is a vending machine operator based in Stamford, Conn.

headline: 85% OF BRITISH MINERS ARE BACK AT WORK
abstract: The British coal industry staggered back toward full operation today as most miners who had not already abandoned their strike marched back to their jobs. But some miners stayed at home and some who reported for work were turned away by unofficial pickets.    Preliminary figures indicated that more than 160,000 men, or about 85 percent of the normal work force, had turned up for work.   Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, speaking in the House of Commons, swept aside requests for a blanket amnesty for dismissed workers, asserting that those who had committed criminal acts ''must expect to face the consequences.'' She said ''the strike is very nearly over'' and appealed for a united effort to rebuild a competitive industry.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Insurance Helps to Cut Rates on State's Bonds
abstract: New York State, benefiting from strong local demand and an insurance policy guaranteeing payment of interest and principal, sold $110 million of new bonds yesterday at interest rates well below those available on other high-grade state and county bonds.    While New Yorkers have a tendency to confine purchases of tax-free bonds to those issued within their state because the interest is exampt from state and city (as well as Federal) income taxes, investors in other parts of the country could choose from an unusually heavy supply of new, high-quality tax-exempt bonds yesterday. In addition to the New York bonds, offered through the Chase Manhattan Bank, yesterday's major financings included bonds from Hawaii, South Carolina and Fairfax County, Va.

headline: THE MARKET ;   EVERY REGION GETS INTO THE TECHNOLOGY ACT
abstract: WHEN Ann Gleason scouted for a job as a design engineer, she decided to go West. All her life she had lived in the East - Virginia, Massachusetts, New Jersey - and she wanted to sample the Western life-style. ''I didn't want to deal with 'Silicon Valley,' with its high cost of living and its congestion,'' she recalled, so she picked Portland, Ore. Six months ago, Miss Gleason began work at the Lattice Semiconductor Corporation in Portland, and she delights in both the job and the location.   Miss Gleason's journey, and the contentment she has found at the end of it, reflect the increasing high- technology opportunities in cities around the nation like Portland, Atlanta, Dallas, Pittsburgh, Philadelphia - even New York.    The best-known technology centers, like Silicon Valley in northern California and Route 128 near Boston, continue to dominate the public mind. But as more and more cities and states try to reorient their economies from smokestacks to computers, a second tier of cities is becoming important in technology research and production. These locations spawn their own offshoots, and in time there is a critical mass that feeds on itself and generates more and more jobs. So an employee is no longer bound into one job and one company, but has good prospects at other companies in the same city.

headline: COMPETITIVENESS PANEL REPORTS ON U.S. LAG
abstract: A Presidential commission reported today that the ability of American business to compete with other countries has been slipping for 20 years or more.    Even in the high-technology field, the commission said, there have been setbacks for seven of 10 industries.    To reverse this trend, it urges numerous changes in Government policy, such as relaxing the antitrust laws, overhauling the tax system to stimulate investment in new technology, encouraging closer cooperation between government, business and labor, creating a Cabinet-level Department of Science and Technology and consolidating trade functions, including those now handled by the Commerce Department, into a new Department of Trade.    The report, called ''Global Competition: The New Reality,'' marks completion of the work of the President's Commission on Industrial Competitiveness, which President Reagan established in June 1983.

headline: Manila Says Exile Won't Face Arrest
abstract: The Justice Minister said today that a United States-based opposition leader, Jovita Salonga, charged with subversion, will not be arrested when he returns next Monday from nearly four years of voluntary exile.   ''So that he can pursue his political aspirations to the fullest, it is my desire that you review his case and take appropriate action,'' an official announcement quoted President Ferdinand E. Marcos as telling Justice Minister Estelito Mendoza.

headline: Sri Lanka Policeman Is Shot By Rebels in Troubled North
abstract: A policeman was shot dead today by Tamil separatist guerrillas in Sri Lanka's troubled northern province, a Government spokesman said.   He said a police sergeant and a patrolman were traveling in a jeep in Kilinochchi when they were shot by guerrillas on a motorcycle.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: VATICAN SYNOD: TIMING DRAMATIC, INTENT UNCLEAR
abstract: Pope John Paul II's unexpected call for a special synod to consider the results of the Second Vatican Council has presented Roman Catholics with an unusual, somewhat puzzling set of possibilities.  John Paul's announcement last Friday, on the 26th anniversary of the summoning of the Council by Pope John XXIII, stated little more than the Pope's desire to set aside two weeks to ponder the changes brought about by the Council. At the least, the timing of the synod - it is to end on the 20th anniversary of the close of Vatican II - is seen as an expression of the Pope's sense of drama and occasion.   Given the vague description of the synod, Catholics across the theological spectrum reacted with reserve. Many see it as a potentially valuable review of the Council's work but too brief a session to entail further change.

headline: Meese Is 'Somewhat Encouraged'
abstract: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that he was ''somewhat encouraged'' by the detention in Mexico of 12 suspects in the drug agent's kidnapping and killing, and he said he planned to ''increase our own efforts'' in working with Mexico against drug trafficking.    ''We are encouraging an all-out effort by the Mexican authorities,'' Mr. Meese said at his first news conference since being sworn in last month.    ''I have sent a personal invitation to the Attorney General of Mexico to meet with me as soon as conveniently possible,'' Mr. Meese said.

headline: DAILY STAPLES OF HONDURAS: WAR AND PLOTS
abstract: Walking around the slanted streets of Tegucigalpa leaves a visitor wondering how such a tranquil collection of adobe homes perched on the sides of a steep mountain valley could be the scene of so much plotting, scheming, wheeling and dealing.    The Honduran capital is a provincial little city that just happens to sit on the edge of the covert war in Nicaragua.   There is in Tegucigalpa's quiet streets an aftertaste of the violence just over the border. Hondurans themselves seem to have a new awareness of the risks of playing host to a war. Government officials, army officers and party leaders openly wonder how a small, impoverished country can protect its interests without becoming either a pawn of the United States or a victim of Nicaragua.

headline: MEXICO CITY SEEKS TO STEM THE TIDE OF PEOPLE
abstract: The letter, written by ''Pepe'' in a child's scrawl, tugs at the heart. ''Mommy, it's better that we go back,'' it says. ''Couldn't daddy really make it in the pueblo, where he knows how things work and everybody loves him? Where we could see him both in the morning and at night?    ''You tell him, because whenever I see him he's in a bad mood.''

headline: THE MIGHTY DOLLAR;  BEWARE OF ITS SHORT-TERM BENEFITS
abstract: THERE is no silver lining for  American industry in the overvalued dollar. At best, living with the current situation provides some short-term economic benefits at the expense of undermining our long- term capacity to compete internationally. At worst, it creates the potential for a dollar crisis that could raise interest rates and inflation, thereby pushing the United States into another recession. Neither the short-term trade-off, nor the potential for an eventual dollar crisis, is good for the economy.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   A New President Chosen by Boeing
abstract: The Boeing Company said yesterday that Frank Shrontz had been named president.    Mr. Shrontz, 53 years old, succeeds Malcolm T. Stamper. The aerospace company said that Mr. Stamper, who served as president from 1972, had been named to the new post of vice chairman. The announcements were made by T.A. Wilson, 64, chairman and chief executive officer.

headline: NEW CALEDONIAN RIGHTISTS DEFY FRENCH AUTHORITY
abstract: France, which has been trying to settle ethnic tensions in the Pacific territory of New Caledonia, has in the last few days faced a clear movement of defiance to its authority from anti-independence forces on the island.   But with its plan for independence apparently facing increasing resistance, the Government seems blocked by the impasse on the island and has no alternative approaches to the problem right now, French officials said today.   A major challenge to the French Government's authority in New Caledonia was posed Tuesday when some 20,000 to 30,000 opponents of independence demonstrated in the capital city, Noumea, in violation of a state of emergency that forbids gatherings of more than five people.   During the demonstration, leaders of the anti-independence movement, including the elected president of the territorial government, said they would no longer meet with Edgard Pisani, the French Government's special envoy to the island, and they demanded his recall to Paris.

headline: Empire, Ward
abstract: Empire of America, a Buffalo- based savings bank, said it would open three financial service centers in Montgomery Ward stores in Houston starting in May. The move will mark the first time Ward's, the nation's sixth-largest retailer, has opened such centers at its stores. Moneyplex Inc., a subsidiary of Empire, will offer banking, investment, insurance and real estate services by subleasing space in the centers, Empire said.

headline: O'NEILL TURNS AGAINST REAGAN
abstract: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. today attacked President Reagan's latest statements on Nicaragua, accusing him of going back on his word that the United States does not impose its will on other countries by force.    After weeks of deferring to the President in view of his landslide re-election victory, the Speaker broke with Mr. Reagan, signaling another confrontation on the issue of resuming so-called covert aid to Nicaraguan insurgents. Three times the Democratic-controlled House has voted down money for the rebels, who are known as contras.

headline: INVESTING;  THE PREDICTIONS OF A MARKET TIMER
abstract: FOR years, institutional investors have rated Robert J. Farrell, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, as the top market timer on Wall Street. But even he was caught off guard by the locomotive-like market of January. ''I was bullish about the year but thought we wouldn't start off well,'' he said candidly last week. ''So I was fooled by that rushing out in January.''   Despite the recent sharp increases in prices, Mr. Farrell is optimistic about the short- and long-term stock market prospects. ''I think the Dow is going to have one more good run,'' before a correction, he said. He foresees a temporary dip in the second quarter, but expects it to be ''pretty shallow.''

headline: Kodak in Accord To Buy Verbatim
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday announced an agreement to acquire the Verbatim Corporation, a leading maker of floppy disks that store computer information. The price would be $7.55 a share, for a total of $174.9 million.

headline: Advertising;   New Chief At Nadler Sets Goals
abstract: -year-old Nadler & Larimer in the fall as president, has now become chief executive. Arch Nadler, a co-founder who had been in the post, is assuming the less taxing designation of Florida-based consultant.    Mr. Calvillo, 44 years old, a former Marsteller and Young & Rubicam executive, is especially important to watch. He is the first top executive to be brought into the Mickelberry Corporation by its chief executive, James Marlas. Mickelberry, a publicly held holding company of advertising agencies, has been Nadler & Larimer's parent since 1980.

headline: Stock Prices Ease, With Dow Off 4.30
abstract: The stock market fluctuated sharply yesterday, rising in early trading before falling back to close slightly lower in a generally mixed performance. Trading remained heavy.     Analysts said that profit taking had cut into the early gains, which followed big increases since a rally began Monday. ''It was just a bit of a time-out period,'' said Leon G. Cooperman, co-chairman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''It was logical to expect some pausing after the kind of rally we've had this week.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, MARCH 9, 1985
abstract: International         India plans to file suit in the U.S. on behalf of Bhopal victims, a high Indian official said. The Indian Consulate in New York said a Minneapolis law firm, Robins, Zelle, Larson & Kaplan, has been retained. But a pre-trial hearing scheduled for Tuesday was delayed until April 16, and a consulate spokesman said that ''we have several weeks to reach a final decision'' on filing suit. (Page 1.)

headline: Markets Closed Stock and commodity markets, banks and Government
abstract: offices were closed yesterday   in observance of New Year's   Day.

headline: People
abstract: Josephine Cummings named senior vice president, executive creative director, and       Diane Till appointed vice president/creative director at Ted Bates/New York.     *       Seth E. Hoyt named advertising director at Cosmopolitan magazine.     *       Margaret Byrne Heimhold appointed publisher of American Film magazine.

headline: TOYOTA-G.M. CAR PRICE PUT AT $6,400 to $7,000
abstract: The car produced by the Toyota-General Motors venture will be priced between about $6,400 and $7,000 when it is introduced as the Chevrolet Nova on June 13, company officials indicated today.    That would be at least $1,000 more than Chevrolet's cheapest model, reflecting Chevrolet's intention to have the new car compete directly with the more expensive and more lavishly equipped cars being imported from Japan. The car is based on a Toyota Corolla model.

headline: HONDURAS ARRESTS A LEADER OF INDIAN REBELS FROM NICARAGUA
abstract: The Honduran police have arrested an anti-Sandinista Indian rebel leader after a Government warning that Nicaraguan guerrillas had overstayed their welcome in Honduras, the authorities said today.    Foreign Minister Edgardo Paz Barnica said the police were holding Steadman Fagoth M"uller, commander of the Indian rebel group known as Misura, at state police headquarters here.    A Misura spokesman said Mr. Fagoth was captured Thursday night by policemen who said he was ''violating Honduran immigration laws by interfering in the country's domestic affairs.''

headline: AFRICA'S DROUGHT SEARS THE LAND OF TIMBUKTU
abstract: A deep cavity interrupts the wind- scoured landscape of sand dunes and scattered brush outside this ancient town.     Men from the nearby village of Bouquiat have been digging here with shovels and hands every day for many sunrises, they say, and their sweat and sinew have thus far created a hole 56 feet deep and 115 feet wide. In the valley of the looming man-made cliffs, they have struck a small pool of water.    ''In a faraway time,'' a leader of the village explains, there was a great well here, providing for the needs of the surrounding population. Surely, the village reasoned, there must be water here now.

headline: OPTIMISM FOUND AT AGENCIES
abstract: YESTERDAY'S annual pulse   taking among ad agency leaders found most of them in fine fettle from last year and expecting continued financial health in 1985.    The pessimism award, however, went to Edward H. Meyer, chairman and president of Grey Advertising. ''The economy is clearly slowing down,'' he said. But he did not say anything like ''All is lost.''

headline: DISPUTE FLARES OVER INDIA ENVOY POST
abstract: President Reagan has selected John Gunther Dean, the United States Ambassador to Thailand, as the new American envoy to India, overruling State Department officials who had urged the appointment of another career diplomat, Administration officials said today.   State Department officials said Mr. Dean, who was the last American Ambassador in Cambodia, in 1975, had actively sought the India job and was given it at the behest of Michael K. Deaver, the White House deputy chief of staff.   ''It was kind of a surprise,'' said a ranking State Department official. Another State Department official said Mr. Dean ''lobbied actively for the job.''

headline: TRIAL OF 26 OPENS IN AQUINO KILLING
abstract: The armed forces Chief of Staff and 25 other men went on trial today in the 1983 assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.   The defendants are also charged in the killing of Rolando Galman, the man the military accused of shooting Mr. Aquino.   Prosecutors offered little today to support accusations of a broad military conspiracy, relying almost entirely on testimony given in a 10-month independent inquiry into the killing. The board concluded that Mr. Aquino was killed by one of two military escorts on a stairway leading from the airliner.

headline: 4 U.S. Companies Vie for Saudi Pact
abstract: Four major American companies have proposed a total of 50 projects in Saudi Arabia in their bid to win multibillion-dollar military contracts in the kingdom, the Saudi Arabian newspaper Arab News reported.

headline: CONTRACEPTION BILL ADVANCES IN IRISH PARLIAMENT
abstract: Ireland's coalition Government narrowly won initial approval in Parliament tonight for a measure to allow the sale without a prescription of contraceptives to anyone 18 years or older.   The legislation, an amendment to the current law, was bitterly opposed by the Roman Catholic Church.    Contraceptives can now be sold legally only for ''bona fide family planning purposes,'' which has been interpreted to mean married couples only and only with a medical prescription.

headline: ADVERTISING ;   Beber Silverstein Gains
abstract: Beber Silverstein, which earlier this year became the agency for Coty's Sophia fragrance, has now been chosen to do the creative work for its Coty Musk for Men cologne and the Coty Wild Musk perfume. Coty is a division of Pfizer Inc., which does its own media buying.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 4, 1985:

headline: U.S. TO RULE ON LIFTING MOVIE ANTITRUST DECREES
abstract: The Justice Department's antitrust division is expected to rule imminently on an issue that could radically affect the movie business by changing the way films are distributed.     The chief of the division, Assistant Attorney General J. Paul McGrath, is evaluating whether complicated consent decrees that impose restrictions on six major movie distributors should be terminated after being in force for more than 30 years.   The question of whether the so- called Paramount decrees should be dissolved or modified is one that provokes sharp disagreement. Mr. McGrath said that the major distributors who are subject to the decrees would generally favor their termination. Theater owners, however, maintain vehemently that loss of the decrees could jeopardize their continued existence and would also hurt movie-goers.

headline: DOLLAR ERODING ASSETS ABROAD
abstract: American companies with operations abroad long used hedging techniques to protect earnings from the ravages of foreign currency fluctuations. But, lulled by an accounting change that serves to protect those earnings, many American companies have stopped hedging, and now find their corporate equity being eaten away by the strength of the dollar - and the shrinking value of their assets in foreign countries.     Until 1981, increases or decreases in the value of assets held abroad had to be reflected in earnings, as well as in equity. But an accounting rule change that year allowed companies to show the unrealized changes in the value of foreign assets only on their balance sheets, and not in earnings.

headline: KOREA'S UNPOPULAR GIANTS
abstract: In the showroom where the Daewoo Corporation proudly displays its wares, giant panda dolls stand next to shelves of jogging shoes. Grand pianos bump up against scale-model tractors, cranes and ships. Personal computers vie for space with video recorders and stuffed toy rabbits.    But the same diversity that pleases Daewoo executives worries Government economists and angers the general public, who resent what they see as monopolies that keep domestic prices high and small businesses badly overmatched.

headline: MILITARY RULE YIELDS TO CIVILIANS IN BRAZIL TODAY
abstract: Brazil's armed forces step down Friday after 21 years in power, leaving the country's new civilian Government with the unenviable task of imposing unpopular austerity measures in order to tackle an acute economic crisis.     Late tonight, less than 12 hours before he was to receive the sash of office, the 75-year-old President-elect, Tancredo Neves, underwent emergency surgery for an acute intestinal inflamation, and doctors said the surgery was successful.    With dozens of foreign delegations in town, congressional leaders said the inauguration would take place as planned, with the elected Vice President, Jose Sarney, temporarily occupying the presidency. Mr. Neves's unexpected operation - doctors said they had hoped to postpone surgery until after the inauguration - temporarily switched attention from the difficult legacy that he will inherit to the more immediate question of his health.   But the incoming Government's principal challenge lies in the continuing economic threat to Brazil's stability. Mr. Neves, who was chosen by a 686- member Electoral College last January, has defined his challenge as ''the very difficult task'' of simultaneously fighting inflation and recovering traditional rates of economic growth.

headline: A STATEMENT BY GROMYKO ON THE TALKS
abstract: Following is the official text of a statement issued today by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, before he left for Moscow:      For two days the U.S. Secretary of State, George Shultz, and I had conversations in accordance with the agreement reached previously. The conversation addressed acute problems concerning cessation of the arms race and removal of the threat of nuclear war. The Soviet side particularly stressed the importance of preventing the militarization of outer space.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: American Telephone and Telegraph Co.  has announced that it will guarantee payment of principal and interest on the long-term debt of ATT Technologies, formerly known as Western Electric.     *       The Chicago Mercantile Exchange has filed with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to trade three zero coupon Treasury bond futures contracts with maturities of 5, 10 and 20 years. Last week, the Chicago Board of Trade filed an application with C.F.T.C. to trade zero coupon Treasury bond futures.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   United Technologies Names 2 to Head Units
abstract: The United Technologies Corporation yesterday named two executives to head a restructured Building Systems Company - now its energy management and building automation subsidiary - and a new unit, United Technologies Communications and Services.    Richard P. Webb, 43, formerly chairman and chief executive of Building Systems, was named to the same posts at the new unit, which makes telecommunications equipment and leases office space and office services to clients.

headline: CAMPBELL SOUP OFFICIAL TO HEAD CITICORP UNIT
abstract: Citicorp said yesterday that James R. Emshoff, an executive at the Campbell Soup Company for the last six years, had been named president of Citicorp Diners Club Inc., the domestic arm of the company's travel and entertainment card subsidiary. The appointment is effective immediately.    Mr. Emshoff, 42, succeeds William Moxley, who left the position last July. The post had been vacant since then. Mr. Emshoff was at Diners Club headquarters in Chicago yesterday and was not available for interviews.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: Austin Co. , an engineering and construction concern based in Cleveland, has named Thomas J. Judge executive vice president and chief operating officer.

headline: MANAGING CREATIVE PEOPLE;  SOOTHING TEMPERS AND EGOS
abstract: THERE is one point on which all managers of creative people seem to agree: Running a creative shop is no picnic. It means catering to fragile egos and explosive temperaments without letting prima donnas ride roughshod on management or their own colleagues. It means maintaining a flexible working environment without letting chaos triumph over order. And it means knowing how to say ''no'' to some ideas without discouraging their proponents from readily offering others.   Most managers are fairly clear on what they will   not  put up with. For example, Jay Chiat, president of the advertising agency Chiat/Day, gives creative employees who complain about the lack of privacy in the company's open-office setup two choices: Learn to live with the setup or leave. ''We don't suffer prima donnas well,'' he said. Similarly, Steven Poses, who owns six Philadelphia restaurants, recently fired a chef who was acting high-handed in the kitchen. ''The first five months with some super chef is fun, but after awhile it wears on the staff,'' he explained.

headline: FOR BRASH CHALLENGER, ANGER AND FRUSTRATION
abstract: Gary Kasparov's disappointment and frustration at the termination of the world championship chess match in Moscow makes perfectly good sense despite his 2-point deficit in the contest.    The 21-year-old challenger had won two games in a row against an opponent - Anatoly Karpov, the 33-year-old world champion - who was faltering, even with an enormous 5-3 lead.   On Nov. 24, Mr. Karpov won Game 27 to increase his lead in the series to 5-0. He then needed only one more victory to retain the world championship that he was awarded in 1975 when Bobby Fischer refused to defend.

headline: CHARTER LINE SAYS SUDAN STOPPED EXODUS OF JEWS
abstract: A Belgian charter airline said today that because of pressure from the Sudan it had stopped carrying Ethiopian Jews from the Sudan to Israel.    ''The mission was interrupted independent of the company,'' Paul Degeiter, the spokesman for the airline, Trans European Airways, said in a telephone interview. ''It was not we who stopped it, but the operation had to be terminated.''

headline: Czechs Said to Detain 11 After Raid on Home
abstract: Eleven people, including two activists from the Charter 77 human rights group, have been detained since the Czechoslovak police raided a private home on the outskirts of Prague Monday, emigres in Vienna said today.

headline: Sterling Seeks Takeover Bars Sterling Drug Inc., the subject of strong takeover rumors
abstract: in recent weeks, is asking   shareholders to amend its   bylaws so that the company   would be less vulnerable to an   unfriendly takeover attempt. Among the changes proposed   in its proxy material for the   May 7 shareholders meeting,   the company wants to prohibit   the payment of ''greenmail''   without first getting shareholder approval.

headline: Sri Lanka Minister in U.S.
abstract: Sri Lanka's Minister of National Security, Lalith Athulathmudali, met today with Secretary of State George P. Shultz but said he had not asked for military aid to help combat Tamil guerrillas. A State Department spokesman said Friday that no change in the present ''modest'' military training program was contemplated.

headline: RUNNING RCA FROM BEHIND THE SCENES
abstract: HANGING on the wall in the hall leading to his office are 12 black-and-white photographs, fastidiously arranged in two rows, one above the other. They signify 65 years of leadership - the 12 chieftains, starting with Owen Young in 1919, of the RCA Corporation.     It has been a busy wall. Four of the pictures have gone up in the last nine years. The last portrait to be hung - of a sharp-featured, smiling face - is, of course, that of Robert R. Frederick, who took over from Thornton F. Bradshaw as RCA's chief executive officer a week and a half ago. If all goes as the RCA powers hope, the 13th picture will not be nailed up for another six years.    Mr. Frederick, at the age of 59, took the helm of a fabled $10 billion electronics, communications and entertainment giant that had been rocked over the last decade by management convulsion and some memorable product flops. Since he came from General Electric to RCA in September 1982 as president and chief operating officer, Mr. Frederick has brought discipline and planning, and he has worked to snuff out a culture of fear and despair fomented by past rulers.

headline: U.S. DRUG AGENT KIDNAPPED
abstract: The United States Embassy announced today that an agent of the Drug Enforcement Administration had been kidnapped in the western Mexico city of Guadalajara. The kidnappers were believed to be involved in drug trafficking in Mexico.    The kidnapping was the first of a United States narcotics agent in Mexico since the two countries began the current phase of a joint anti-drug effort in 1975.

headline: MISSOURI COUPLE IS ACCUSED OF ILLEGALLY EXPORTING ARMS
abstract: A Federal grand jury has indicted a Missouri couple for illegally exporting an antitank- missile-guidance system and other advanced military equipment to South Africa and other foreign countries, the United States Customs Service announced here today.   The indictment charges that Werner Ernst Gregg and his wife, Roswitha L. Gregg, exported the equipment between 1980 and 1984 without obtaining the licenses required under laws that regulate the export of military items or of high-technology items that could be used in weapons.   The indictment also charges that the Greggs failed to report more than $1 million of income on their Federal tax returns over the same period.    The Greggs surrendered to United States marshals today. Bond was set at $400,000 for Werner Gregg and $100,000 for Roswitha Gregg by Magistrate Calvin Hamilton in Federal District Court in Kansas City, according to Customs Service officials.

headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS ;   Soybean Prices Climb; Feeder Cattle Mixed
abstract: Commodities markets in New York and Chicago reacted calmly today to the death of the Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko.   The news, which might once have rocked the precious metals markets and sent grain futures surging, was overshadowed by routine technical and fundamental factors.   ''There should be no change in domestic policies which would affect grain imports,'' said Laurie Law, who works for E.F. Hutton.

headline: SHULTZ URGES U.S. NOT TO CUT BACK ON ARMS OUTLAY
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told Congress today that progress in the new arms negotiations with the Soviet Union required continued spending for the MX missile and the $26 billion space-defense research plan.    Speaking with reporters after briefing Senate and House members separately, Mr. Shultz said he had told them, ''If the Soviets can get what they want out of us without giving up anything in return, they would love it.''   ''Our coat is off, our sleeves are rolled up, we are ready to go to work,'' Mr. Shultz said. The timing of the negotiations agreed to Tuesday in Geneva still has to be worked out, and Mr. Shultz said, ''I think it's important that these negotiations get started in good time.''

headline: G.M. Planning Plant Conversion
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said it would spend about $105 million to convert a major part of its former Oldsmobile division manufacturing complex in Lansing for assembly of a new front-wheel-drive car, possibly as early as 1987. G.M. said conversion of a part of the plant, which now builds rear-axle cars, would result in temporary layoffs for about 500 workers, beginning in June or July.   The plant had previously been scheduled to close in June, but Robert Stempel, a G.M. vice president, said a labor agreement reached last month aimed at improving productivity was a ''major factor'' in the decision to convert it for car assembly. G.M. declined to give details of the new car to be built.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 14, 1985:

headline: BANK OF BOSTON'S MANY FACETS
abstract: To many in New England, the Bank of Boston Corporation is a monolithic, powerful financial institution that helps form the bedrock of the region's economy and that they feel they know well.    But the bank does occasionally show a face that few recognize.   This happened most recently with the guilty plea last week by the principal unit of the Bank of Boston, the First National Bank of Boston, to Federal charges that it had committed a felony by not reporting $1.22 billion in cash transfers between the United States and Europe, incurring a record $500,000 fine.   John M. Walker Jr., the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Enforcement and Operations, has said that the cash movements resembled a money-laundering operation.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Compaq Computer   $6,800,000

headline: PICKENS'S INVESTMENT IN UNOCAL
abstract: Fred L. Hartley has been both unconventional and conservative, delivering what many analysts describe as steady, above-average results during the nearly two decades that he has run the Unocal Corporation.   Yet, like most large oil companies confronted with excess worldwide production and flagging demand, Unocal, parent of the Union Oil Company, has struggled. Profits fell for the first time in eight years in 1983, then rebounded by 12 percent last year.   Moreover, it has been more than four years since Unocal's stock reached its peak of $56.50 a share late in 1980. Stockholders also receive one of the sparest dividend payments among the major oil companies, with a yield at about 2 percent of the current stock price.

headline: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY FRIAR
abstract: Following is the text of a statement issued today by the Rev. Leonardo Boff in response to Vatican criticism of his writings, as translated by The New York Times from the Portuguese:      1. Through this document, the highest doctrinal body of the church has spoken authoritatively.

headline: POPE'S TRIP TO PERU DIDN'T CLEAR UP DISPUTE
abstract: Supporters and critics of the theology of liberation both say their views fared well as a result of Pope John Paul II's visit to Peru this week.    Church officials had hoped the Pope would clarify his position on liberation theology, a doctrine that encourages the poor to take political action to improve their lives and that has its roots in Latin America.    The Peruvian Bishops have been split over whether the doctrine should be condemned. Some say it dangerously uses Marxist analysis and stresses political rather than spiritual liberation. Supporters say the theology only deals with the lives and struggles of the poor as reflected in the Gospel.

headline: Chief of Lucky Stores Taking Less Active Role
abstract: S. Donley Ritchey, who has been chairman and chief executive at Lucky Stores Inc. for five years, has informed the company's board that as of June he intends to take a less active role in managing the firm.   Mr. Ritchey said that after the annual shareholders meeting on June 6, he would relinquish his duties as chief executive, but he would remain as chairman until June 1986.    At the June meeting, the board is expected to name John M. Lillie, who is the president and chief operating officer, to the post of chief executive.

headline: GREEK TOWN ON WRONG SIDE OF CYPRUS DEBATE
abstract: Seven Greek Cypriot men sat on the porch of the coffeehouse in this once Greek town near the tip of the country's northeastern panhandle.    They drank no coffee and they hardly spoke. They looked glumly across the silent street toward the Greek Orthodox church, which was deserted.   It was a typical Greek village coffeehouse scene, but without the usual animation. The men said it was like this every day, morning and afternoon, and had been for 10 years.

headline: Arthur Andersen
abstract: Arthur Andersen & Company, the nation's largest accounting firm, said that it was negotiating to bring the SGV Group, an East Asian accounting cooperative with 3,500 personnel, into Andersen's international organization.

headline: U.N. FARM AGENCY SETTLES A DISPUTE
abstract: Representatives of Western countries and the oil- producing nations reached agreement today on the outlines of a plan designed to save the United Nations agency that helps farmers in the third world.    The agency, the International Fund for Agricultural Development, had been threatened with bankruptcy because of a decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to cut its contributions, and the United States' angry reaction.   The proposed agreement, which still requires formal approval by the United States, would accept a lower OPEC contribution to a smaller budget.   The battle over the organization took on particular importance in light of famines that have taken hold in large parts of Africa, and because of the recent American withdrawal from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

headline: Philippine Grenade Kills 8
abstract: A grenade exploded in a cock-fighting pit in a central Philippine town, killing eight people, including the two soldiers who smuggled it in, the state-run press agency said today. Twelve other people were wounded in the New Year's Day blast on eastern Samar Island, 370 miles southeast of Manila. It was not known if the soldiers detonated the grenade on purpose or by accident.     ,

headline: Intel Net Tumbles by 50.7%; NCR Climbs 8.4%
abstract: The Intel Corporation reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter profits plunged by almost 50.7 percent from the period a year earlier.    Net income for the quarter was $23.2 million, or 20 cents a share, compared with $47.1 million, or 40 cents a share, for the previous year's quarter. Revenues for the fourth period were $416.1 million, up 25.2 from $332.4 million in the quarter a year earlier.

headline: Conrail Unions Back Alleghany
abstract: Railroad union leaders today decided to support the Alleghany Corporation's bid to buy the Government- owned Consolidated Rail Corporation.

headline: STRUGGLING DATAPOINT'S ALLURE
abstract: For nearly three years, the Datapoint Corporation, one of Wall Street's high-technology favorites in the early 1980's, has been struggling with only modest success to reverse the misfortunes caused by an accounting scandal.     Analysts say that the company, distracted by the after-effects of the scandal, has been slow to adapt to the rapid technological advances in the computer industry, and that the market response to its newer products has been slow, too. As a result, its earnings performance has been poor since 1982, and analysts do not see much improvement before 1986. In the fiscal year 1984, ended July 31, Datapoint earned $26.4 million, or $1.29 a share, on $600 million in sales.

headline: RELATIONS SOUR BETWEEN ETHIOPIA AND WESTERN FOOD DONORS
abstract: Relations between the Ethiopian Government and the Western nations and organizations involved in the famine relief effort here appear to have reached their lowest point since huge amounts of aid began to pour into this country last autumn.     In recent days the two groups have leveled serious charges at one another, both in public and in private.   ''There's a lot of bile flowing,'' an international civil servant said. ''This Government has been very obstructive and very difficult to help.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *       Allied Corp.  said it that its Bendix Corp. subsidiary had agreed to delay its acquisition of King Radio Corp. until after Jan. 31.     *       Charter Medical Corp., Macon, Ga., said its agreement with Saudi Medical Services to provide health care at King Khalid Military City will end Jan. 31.

headline: South African Gold
abstract: South Africa's gold mines produced 21.88 million ounces of gold last year, up from 1983's 21.85 million ounces, the Chamber of Mines said today.

headline: STOCKS MIXED IN HEAVIER TRADING
abstract: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday in heavier turnover as traders reacted to statements by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, concerning Fed policy and the course of the economy.    The Dow Jones industrial average, off almost 4 points in early trading, ended the day up 2.54 points, at 1,283.13, after being ahead almost 6 points about 3 P.M.    Most other measures of the market's movement closed lower. The New York Stock Exchange composite index dipped 0.01, to 105.11, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged 0.15 lower, to finish at 181.18.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: CURRENCY MARKETS ;   Dollar Reaches a Peak Against Pound, Franc
abstract: The dollar continued its seemingly relentless rise in foreign exchange markets yesterday, winding up at record closing highs against the currencies of Britain, France, Italy and Canada and at a 13-year high against the West German mark.    While the currency did retreat in late New York trading from its highs of the day, which traders said was mainly a result of profit taking, it ended the day higher against all major currencies from its close on Friday.    The price of gold rose, too. The late quote at the Republic National Bank in New York was $303.75 a troy ounce, up $3.05 from the late bid Friday.

headline: Colgate Posts Loss In the 4th Quarter
abstract: The Colgate-Palmolive Company, hurt by a previously announced charge of $114 million for restructuring its manufacturing operations, yesterday reported a loss of $91.1 million for the fourth quarter.    Colgate earned $30.7 million, or 38 cents a share, in the 1983 final quarter.    The worldwide producer and distributor of household and personal- care products and, through acquisitions, food, health and leisure products, said that sales slipped eight- tenths of 1 percent, to $1.18 billion, from $1.19 billion.

headline: TV Movies
abstract: To the Editor:     Surely, neither Barry Diller nor Len Goldberg need to have TV history rewritten on their behalf (''ABC's Creativity: An Advantage Lost,'' Dec. 9). While they were just beginning their careers at ABC in the mid- 1960's, Mort Werner, Grant Tinker and Herb Schlosser at NBC and Sid Sheinberg at Universal were producing the first made-for-TV movies (called NBC World Premieres): ''Fame is the Name of the Game,'' ''Doomsday Flight,'' ''How I Spent My Summer Vacation,'' ''Borgia Stick,'' et al.      PAUL L. KLEIN New York, Dec. 11

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Angus Chairman Seeks Nutrasweet
abstract: Roger Secrist, chairman and chief executive officer of the Angus Chemical Company, is bidding for one of the hottest items in the sweetener business. But at the moment he has no idea when or if his bid will be accepted.    Earlier this month, Mr. Secrist's company, a division of the Pacific Gas Transmission Company, offered an undisclosed amount of money for the patent and factory rights to G.D. Searle & Company's fast-growing Nutrasweet business. Nutrasweet is the brand name of Searle's low-calorie aspartame sugar substitute.

headline: California Utility Mortgage Bonds
abstract: Southern California Edison offered $225 million of first and refunding mortgage bonds, due March 15, 2015.

headline: S.E.C. SUES ACCOUNTANT FOR E.S.M.
abstract: The accountant who audited the books of the defunct E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. was charged today by the Securities and Exchange Commission with knowingly filing false and misleading auditing reports and with receiving secret payments from E.S.M. officers totaling $125,000.    A Federal judge in the Southern District of Florida issued a temporary restraining order against Jose L. Gomez, a managing partner in the Fort Lauderdale, Fla., offices of Alexander Grant & Company, the nation's 11th-largest accounting firm, enjoining him from any further commission of such acts.   The judge, Jose A. Gonzalez Jr. of Miami, also froze all of Mr. Gomez's assets and ordered him to give an accounting by next Tuesday of all payments he has received since 1977 from any of E.S.M.'s four companies and their officers.    Today's action is the latest twist in a complex financial debacle that began with the March 1 closing of E.S.M., a securities firm based in Fort Lauderdale. The closing led in short order to the collapse of an Ohio savings and loan. That collapse, in turn, touched off a banking panic in Ohio, which has forced the closing of 71 thrift institutions there and sent tremors through national and international financial markets.

headline: Advertising;   T.W.A. Ads Stress Leadership
abstract: STEWART G. LONG, senior vice president, marketing and sales, arrived in his newly created post at Trans World Airlines in mid-August, and by September had asked his agency, Ogilvy & Mather, for a new campaign to replace the five-year-old ''You're Going to Like Us.''    What he wanted was some sort of a superiority claim, because experience overseas for the carrier had taught him that such advertising acts as a self-fulfilling prophecy by stimuling employees to deliver.    ''If everybody felt No. 1 and acted No. 1 every day, the customers would see it immediately,'' he said in his 42d-floor office at 605 Third Avenue, with the Pan Am symbol peeping in from a neighboring colossus.

headline: Olivetti Buys Acorn Stake IVREA, Italy, Feb. 20 (Reuters) - Ing. C. Olivetti & Company, Italy's fast-expanding
abstract: computer and office automation group, stepped in to   rescue Britain's ailing Acorn   Computers Ltd.  Olivetti said that it would pay  $11 million to acquire a 49.3   percent stake in the British   company.

headline: REAGAN REPORTED TO WANT INCREASE IN SALVADORN AID
abstract: The Reagan Administration, increasingly concerned about political problems facing the Salvadoran President, will probably ask Congress for more military and economic aid to El Salvador this year, senior Administration officials said today.     Congress approved $326 million in economic aid and $128 million in military aid to El Salvador for the current fiscal year. The officials said the Administration would like to bring military aid up to about $200 million and add at least $100 million in economic assistance.    Recent United States intelligence assessments have reported that El Salvador's President, Jose Napoleon Duarte, is confronted by the most serious threat to his Government since he took office last June, the officials said.

headline: Nashville Unit Bonds Priced A $91 million financing by the
abstract: Health and Educational Facilities Board of Nashville and   Davidson Counties, Tenn., was   priced yesterday with an initial   interest rate of 5 1/2 percent for   bonds that may be redeemed   by investors on Jan. 15, 1986,   and 6 1/2 percent for bonds that   may be redeemed on Jan. 15,   1988. Strong demand enabled underwriters to reduce yields by   one-quarter percentage point   from the levels suggested initially.

headline: Statements on Killing
abstract: Following are the texts of the statements sent by Mr. Joyce to Prime Minister Peres, and a statement issued in Tel Aviv by Brig. Gen. Ephraim Lapid of the Israeli Army:       NBC Statement    Two CBS employees have been killed and a third critically injured by what eyewitnesses have called an unprovoked and deliberate attack by Israeli forces while they were covering military actions at Kfar Melki, near Sidon.   Thus far, Israeli military authorities have not responded to our inquiries about the attack. But two eyewitnesses, Alain Meargues of French National Radio and Marine Jacquemin of French TV, have told us that our camera crew was taping a U.P.I.T.N. camera car which had been damaged by Israeli troops, that our own car was clearly and unmistakably marked as a camera car, and fire by an Israeli tank was directed at our people with intent to kill.

headline: A MASTER OF COMPROMISE TAPPED FOR THE TREASURY
abstract: WASHINGTON ''ARE you listening, Darman?'' the news reporter shouted at the walls inside the White House.    Hardly an act of madness, the outcry was a safe enough guess that Richard G. Darman, assistant to the President, was silently listening by speaker in his basement office, attentive as Richelieu to this particular day's round of questions being put by news reporters up in the briefing room to President Reagan's spokesman, Larry Speakes.    A 41-year-old specialist in legislative strategy, budgetary initiatives, Oval Office paper flow, Presidential wordsmithing, news media intrigues and a portfolio of other matters large and small, Mr. Darman will soon be leaving the West Wing to take the post of Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, the department's No. 2 job.    While the very walls of the White House may seem less attentive with his departure, the corridors of the Treasury Department, one block away, undoubtedly will reflect the greater hurry of this unusual executive who for more than a year has been quietly preparing for the approaching clash in Congress over changing the Federal income tax.    If Mr. Darman remains true to form as strategy architect and confidant of his patron, Secretary of the Treasury-designate James A. Baker 3d, he will also become deeply involved in a dozen more issues ranging from international monetary affairs to the deficit problem.

headline: STOCKS HIT RECORD IN ONE-DAY RALLY
abstract: Stocks took off on Friday, ending what had started as a quiet week. The Dow Jones industrial average went as high as 1,306.76 before falling back in last-minute profit taking to close at a record 1,299.36, up 23.52 on the week. Traders apparently were excited about several developments, including a 1.7 percent surge in the index of leading economic indicators, the lifting of quotas on Japanese car imports and other signs that the economy is rolling ahead without new inflation.           The dollar was busy all week , soaring Monday, dropping Tuesday and plunging Wednesday as European central banks, in one of the biggest intervention episodes ever, sold about $1 billion in dollars to support their currencies. But later in the week traders, convinced of the dollar's long-term strength, bought.

headline: GREEK SOCIALISTS IN SURPRISE SHIFT
abstract: The governing Socialist Party threw Greek politics into confusion today by unexpectedly withholding its support from President Constantine Caramanlis and nominating its own presidential candidate for next Friday's election.    Mr. Caramanlis quickly withdrew from the race with a statement noting that the Socialist Party's leader, Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, had been the main person to urge him to run.    The President is elected by Parliament, and without the support of the Socialists, Mr. Caramanlis, whose 78th birthday was Friday, had no chance of getting the necessary two-thirds vote.

headline: CURRENCY PLAN STIRS SKEPTICISM
abstract: American and international monetary officials here voiced skepticism today over plans reported in Paris aimed at generating greater currency stability by concentrating more international pressure on domestic American economic policy.    They said that although the United States backed greater international economic cooperation, the chances of foreign governments influencing domestic American policy were small.    Moreover, they added, the United States shied away from establishing any more institutions to bolster multilateral economic surveillance, since at least half a dozen institutions already existed that could do the job.

headline: Suitors Sue Datapoint
abstract: A group of investors that is trying to take control of the Datapoint Corporation filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court seeking to block a change in Datapoint's bylaws that would make a takeover more difficult.   The group, led by Asher B. Edelman, a New York investor, also proposed to replace Datapoint's directors with its own slate of candidates.   Datapoint's chairman, Harold E. O'Kelley, sent a letter to shareholders on Jan. 29 saying that a takeover of Datapoint by the group ''is likely to work to the detriment of all of our shareholders because it is not likely to generate the best possible price.''

headline: A.T.& T.'S QUARTER NET $379 MILLION
abstract: Closing out its first year since the breakup of the Bell System, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday reported healthy fourth-quarter earnings. Analysts said the results were an encouraging conclusion to a trying and tumultuous year.    A.T.&T. said it earned $379 million, or 34 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, up from $317 million in the third quarter. Fourth-quarter revenues were $8.4 billion, compared with $8.01 billion in the third period.

headline: Shultz Denies U.S. Aid Goes to Managua Foes
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that American foreign aid money had not been diverted to support the Nicaraguan rebels.   Mr. Shultz suggested, however, that recipients of American aid might be using their own money to aid the rebels, who are fighting Nicaragua's leftist Government.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Bill Auction Begins After Holiday Delay
abstract: This week's auction of Treasury bills will be held today because the Government securities market was closed yesterday for the Presidents' Day holiday.    Other Treasury financings include a $9 billion auction of two-year notes tomorrow and an announcement today of plans to sell $7 billion of new five-year Treasury notes on Feb. 26.    In advance of this week's bill auctions, the outstanding three-month bill was bid late Friday at 8.21 percent, while the six-month issue was 8.28 percent. The new two-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis with a yield of about 10 percent.

headline: COLECO GIVES UP ON THE ADAM
abstract: Coleco Industries abandoned its beleaguered Adam home computer yesterday, and said it would concentrate on what it seems to do best: selling low-tech Cabbage Patch dolls.    The Hartford-based toy manufacturer said it was selling off its inventory of Adam systems, only 18 months ago one of the promising entries in the chaotic home computer industry, and would post a ''substantial loss'' for the fourth quarter and the year. Analysts speculated yesterday that the company could take a write-off of as much as $75 million, before taxes, and would report a loss for the year of perhaps $55 million.   Nonetheless, Wall Street cheered the move as overdue, and Coleco's stock surged on the Big Board in heavy trading. It closed at $14.375, up $2.25. Part of the rise was attributed to Coleco's announcement that sales of its Cabbage Patch Kids, the cuddly dolls whose booming success shocked company executives in both 1983 and 1984 as much as Adam's failures, topped $500 million in 1984.

headline: 1984 Gainers and Losers on the Amex
abstract: Amex-listed common stocks that showed the largest percentage gains and declines in 1984. Prices are adjusted for any splits, and listings include no stocks that had fewer than 1,000 shares traded or that traded for less than $2 a share.     GAINERS Stock1984 ClosePercent Change From '83 CloseComment        LOSERS Crystal Oil3 1/477.4Oil refiner with big debt is hurt by declining prices for crudeWebcor Electronics2 1/475.0Glut in consumer market hurts telephone manufacturerHelionetics5 3/474.2High-tech company has a sharp drop in earningsO'okiep Copper3 1/273.8South African producer hurt by low pricesTexscan5* 73.3Maker of cable-TV equipment hurt by industry slowdown        Source: Associated Press

headline: MORE AID WOULD NOT HAVE WORKED
abstract: THE plight of the American  farmer has received more publicity in recent weeks than perhaps at any time in recent memory. Congress moved with abandon to provide significantly expanded Federal credit and other assistance to farmers, although the measure was vetoed by President Reagan.  Farm supporters raise the specter of the demise of the family farm, a collapse of the banking system, food shortages, and equally catastrophic events. Farmers blame misguided Government embargoes or unfair foreign export subsidies for the decline in farm exports and income, but the blame lies squarely on the Federal Government's economic policies.

headline: BARBIE TRIAL, DUE THIS YEAR, LIKELY TO BE NARROW IN SCOPE
abstract: French prosecutors expect to try Klaus Barbie for crimes against humanity by the end of the year, but the case they have developed against the former Gestapo chief of Lyons will not involve the torture and murder of France's greatest Resistance hero.   As evidence against Mr. Barbie is assembled by the investigating magistrates and the charges against him are pared down, it has become clear that the trial will deal with three specific charges, instead of the eight originally announced.  The three charges exclude Mr. Barbie's role in the arrest and death in 1943 of Jean Moulin, the underground chief, and the Nazi police official's campaign of repression against French Resistance fighters.
