If lawyers' evaluations are correct, the case against Mr. Barbie, who is 72 years old, will concentrate on about 800 of his Jewish victims, offering a microcosm of a beastly system rather than a confrontation with the Nazi mechanism on its widest, most brutal scale.

headline: Article 040074 -- No Title
abstract: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., maker of Vaseline, Q-tips, Ragu spaghetti and other nationally known consumer products, announced yesterday that it would buy the Stauffer Chemical Company for $1.25 billion in cash.     The deal, announced jointly by Ralph E. Ward, chairman of Chesebrough, and H. Barclay Morley, chairman of Stauffer, followed the unanimous approval of both boards, and calls for Chesebrough to pay $28 a share in a public tender offer to begin today.    Mr. Ward said that Chesebrough was buying Stauffer ''to give us some new products'' through its research capability, but analysts maintained that Chesebrough was protecting itself against a possible takeover.    Chesebrough, with headquarters in Greenwich, Conn., reported sales last year of an estimated $1.8 billion. Stauffer, based in Westport, Conn, reported 1984 sales of $1.5 billion.

headline: Italian Policeman Killed; Red Brigades Claim Role
abstract: A policeman was shot dead today in a town south of Rome, and a group claiming to be part of the Red Brigades took responsibility.

headline: Court to Rule on Private RICO Suits
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve a growing legal controversy over the use of the powerful Federal anti-racketeering law in civil lawsuits that allege ordinary business fraud.   Usually referred to as RICO, the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act was enacted in 1970 to give Federal prosecutors a new weapon against organized crime. But it was so broadly worded that it became increasingly popular as the basis for private civil lawsuits.   Accounting firms, banks and both small and large corporations found themselves caught up in litigation under RICO, which permits a private plaintiff to collect triple damages plus attorney fees for proving that he has been ''injured in his business or property by reason of a violation'' of the act.

headline: 26 in Manila Charged In the Aquino Killing
abstract: A Government prosecutor charged the armed forces chief, Gen. Fabian C. Ver; two generals and 23 other men today in the killings of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino and the man the army had said was his assassin.    Brig. Gen. Luther Custodio, chief of aviation security, and 16 other soldiers were charged with direct participation in a military conspiracy to kill Mr. Aquino as he stepped off a plane Aug. 21, 1983, after three years of voluntary exile in the United States.

headline: TANAKA'S ILLNESS MAY UNSETTLE JAPANESE POLITICS
abstract: Doctors announced tonight that former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka, the most powerful figure in Japanese politics, had suffered a more serious stroke than initially suspected.     The doctors said Mr. Tanaka's convalescence would take two to three months, far longer than was believed when his illness was disclosed last Thursday.   The absence of the 66-year-old Mr. Tanaka from normal activity for several months could have significant consequences for Japanese politics.    Among other things, political experts here said, a long illness may intensify challenges to his authority that already had begun within the governing Liberal Democratic Party. Moreover, if it is broadly suspected that he will never regain full health, his powerful political machine may begin to seek a new leader or even drift apart.

headline: ABC Effort To Improve TV's Image
abstract: Even before he assumes the title of president of communications/ABC Broadcast Group in June, James E. Duffy will deserve it. He'll be communicating all over the place.    Even while still president of the ABC Television Network he will in effect be spokesman for an unusual educational program cum TV industry image effort as he appears in specially made TV commercials on his own network and in personal appearances in the great outback giving interviews to the local press. He will be appearing on local TV and radio talk shows and at Rotary luncheons, a knowledgeable industry voice answering viewers' questions and enlightening community leaders on the realities of television, its contributions, limitations and woes, its mechanics, challenges and aspirations.

headline: Times Sells 6-Acre Parcel
abstract: Harry B. Helmsley and Irving Schneider, president and executive vice president of Helmsley-Spear Inc., have purchased a plot of about 6 acres on Manhattan's West Side from The New York Times Company, it was announced yesterday by Mr. Helmsley, Mr. Schneider and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman of the Times Company.         The plot extends south from 65th Street to south of 62nd Street fronting on West End Avenue. Once the site of a Times printing plant, the plot has been used in recent years by The Times as a garage area for its fleet of delivery trucks. It is one of the last remaining tracts of its size in midtown Manhattan.

headline: Debenture Sale Set by K Mart
abstract: The K Mart Corporation is offering $250 million of 12 3/4 percent sinking fund debentures due in 2015 at a price of 99 3/4 to yield 12.782 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs.    The new debentures, which were awarded after the company solicited bids from several groups of securities dealers, are part of a $500 million shelf registration filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Feb. 19.

headline: VOLCKER'S ECONOMIC CONCERNS
abstract: With the Federal Reserve poised to fix its money supply targets for 1985 next week, Paul A. Volcker, its chairman, told Congress today that he worried more about fast economic growth and dependence on foreign savings than about the possibility of recession.    In more than two hours of questioning by the Senate Budget Committee, Mr. Volcker was not asked about monetary policy. His opening statement provided little hint of what the Federal Open Market Committee, the system's main policy-making arm, might decide at its two-day meeting that begins Tuesday.

headline: Discount Plan Set by A.T.&T. BASKING RIDGE, N.J.
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company   will offer discounts on office   supplies, business equipment,   travel and other services to   customers who choose the company as their long-distance carrier, the company said today. Customers can use the discounts for one year after choosing A.T.&T., it said.

headline: Swiss Prices Up 3.5%
abstract: The cost of living in Switzerland rose 3.5 percent during the year ending Jan. 31, the highest 12-month inflation rate in nearly two years, the Federal Office of Industry, Trade and Labor said today. Prices were up 1 percent from December, the office said.

headline: PATROLS IN GERMANY:POSTWAR VESTIGE
abstract: The fatal shooting of an American officer in East Germany last Sunday violently marred one of the most smoothly functioning relationships between the United States and the Soviet Union: administering their vestigial occupation rights in Germany.  The carefully tempered anger of the United States over the killing of Maj. Arthur D. Nicholson Jr. by a Soviet sentry appeared to suggest a wish to contain the incident and not allow it to disrupt the arms talks.   Similarly, Western diplomats noted that - in contrast to the adamant position taken on the downing of a South Korean airliner in 1983 - the Soviet Union had expressed ''regret'' over the slaying even while accusing the officer of having taken pictures inside a restricted military area.        Responses Were Restrained    The calibrated responses of both sides were typical of their daily dealings in observing agreements arising from their roles as onetime allies who defeated and occupied Nazi Germany.

headline: Warning to Pilots From Pan Am
abstract: Pan American World Airways has warned that it would furlough 299 pilots and shrink its fleet if its pilot union does not accept reductions in 27 percent pay raises that were due them on Dec. 31.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM PAPER ISSUED BY THE VATICAN
abstract: Following are excerpts from a document on the Rev. Leonardo Boff issued by the Vatican Congregation for the Doctine of the Faith today and translated by The Associated Press from the Italian:        Notification on the book ''The Church: Charisma and Power - Study of Militant Ecclesiology'' by Father Leonardo Boff.   The book intends to assist in the solving of problems of Latin America and in particular Brazil. That intention on one hand calls for serious attention to the concrete situations to which the book refers, and on the other hand - corresponding realistically to its goal - the need to include them in the great task of the universal church, which interprets, develops and applies, under the guidance of the Holy Spirit, the common heritage of the one and only Gospel, given by God one time only for our faith.   In that way, the unique faith of the Gospel creates and builds, over the centuries, the Catholic Church, which remains one throughout the different ages and in the differences between the many individual churches.

headline: REAGAN'S BUDGET REPORTED TO SEEK 1.5% SPENDING RISE
abstract: President Reagan will send Congress a budget calling for the lowest rate of growth in spending in two decades, according to Administration officials and budget documents.     The President's budget, to be submitted Monday, will ask for $973.7 billion in the next fiscal year, or 1.5 percent more than the Government now expects to spend this year. The present Government estimate is that outlays this year will come to $959.1 billion.   If Congress accepts the President's 1986 budget in every respect, which is unlikely, and if current spending estimates are borne out, the growth rate in Federal spending will be the lowest since 1965.         Cuts at 8 Departments    In the budget for the 1986 fiscal year, which starts Oct. 1, Mr. Reagan proposes outright reductions in spending, not just a slower rate of increase, for 8 of the 13 Cabinet departments, including Agriculture, Education, Energy, and Housing and Urban Development.

headline: Stocks Are Mixed; Airlines Fall Again
abstract: Stock prices were mixed again yesterday as airline issues continued under pressure. Trading slackened a bit.    The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day off 1.33 points, at 1,227.36, but advances widely outnumbered declines, 966 to 616. The Dow gained 9.27 points for the week.

headline: CBS, Ziff-Davis
abstract: CBS Inc. said it had completed the previously announced purchase of the consumer magazine publishing operations of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company. The price was $362.5 million. CBS said the antitrust division of the Justice Department had told the company that it had no objections to the transaction.

headline: NCNB to Sell Unit
abstract: The NCNB Corporation announced the sale of its Transouth Financial Corporation subsidiary to First Nationwide Savings for $85 million.

headline: Katy Sale Talks
abstract: Katy Industries confirmed in a statement that discussions were continuing on a possible sale or merger of its 98 percent owned Missouri-Kansas- Texas Railroad Company. Katy said that it could not predict when a definitive agreement would be reached or if the Interstate Commerce Commission would grant approval. The company also said that its 1984 results, to be reported this month, would reflect greater loss reserves for its Midland Insurance Company subsidiary than previously reported.

headline: NEW HEAD FOR SATURN UNIT
abstract: William E. Hoglund, a financial executive who has demonstrated a flair for automobile marketing, today was chosen president of the General Motors Corporation's Saturn subsidiary.   He succeeds Joseph J. Sanchez, who died of a heart attack Jan.  6, after just a few weeks in thA post as chief 'xecutive of G.M.'s newest operating unit. Mr. Sanchez was 54 years old.    Mr. Hoglund's new ob represents at least a nominal demotion, since he will have to give up his title of group executive. He will remain a vice president of 'he corporation, however, reporting to Lloyd Ruess, the head of G.M.'s Chevrolet, Pontiac, G.M. of Canada Froup.

headline: COPING WITH A STRONG DOLLAR
abstract: After four years of watching from the sidelines as the dollar soared, the Federal Government has grown concerned enough over the dollar's value that it has been making efforts to nudge it lower. Both the lowering of interest rates and the recent direct intervention in the currency markets suggest a shift in policy.    The difficulty is that the new posture could create as many problems as the overvalued currency itself.    First, such attempts at financial engineering of the marketplace are an inexact science at best, economists say. Especially in the last few years, with the dollar having defied the standard influences on its movements, it is difficult to know what will affect it, and by how much.

headline: Merger Talks Held By Castle & Cooke
abstract: Castle & Cooke Inc., the financially troubled food and real estate company, said today that it was involved in preliminary discussions with another company about a possible merger. The company said the agreement might be a no-premium merger, meaning that Castle & Cooke stockholders might receive less than the market value of their shares.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   President of Pabst Planning to Leave
abstract: William F. Smith Jr., president and chief executive of the Pabst Brewing Company, said yesterday that he expects to announce his resignation within two weeks in the wake of the company's takeover by Paul Kalmanovitz, the California brewer and investor.    ''I think we have tremendous philosophic differences and I know he doesn't want me as chief executive of the company, so I don't think it would be worthwhile for me to stay,'' Mr. Smith said in a telephone interview from the company's headquarters in Milwaukee.    ''At this point I think it would be best if I exercised my contract and left,'' Mr. Smith said. Under the terms of his contract with Pabst, Mr. Smith, who is 49 years old, can collect more than $560,000 if the company is taken over. He said he did not know how soon he would leave the company after formally submitting his resignation, adding that he has no definite plans for the future.

headline: Radio Stations in Israel
abstract: The Government has agreed to allow Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty to broadcast to the Soviet bloc from a transmitter in Israel, United States and Israeli officials said today.

headline: Iran Executes Drug Dealers
abstract: Iranian authorities executed 29 convicted drug dealers in Teheran and in Meshed, the semi-official newspaper Kayhan of Teheran said Monday. A total of 258 people in Iran have been put to death for drug offenses since February 1984.

headline: A STAGE SET FOR A DISASTER
abstract: The dozen workers interviewed after the Bhopal accident later maintained that the stage for disaster had already been set when they reported for duty at the sprawling chemical plant on Dec. 2, a mild and relaxed Sunday afternoon in the central Indian city.   A refrigeration unit designed to keep the methyl isocyanate cool and nonreactive had been shut off and the chemical was warmer than allowed by the plant's operating manual, they said.

headline: SFN Shareholders Approve Buyout
abstract: Shareholders in the SFN Companies have approved a $425 million leveraged buyout of the company.

headline: TAX REDUCTION TACTICS THAT NAKE A DIFFERENCE
abstract: WHAT taxpayer is not delighted to find yet one more deduction that will enable him to hold onto a few more dollars of his hard-earned money. George Scharfenberger, the chief executive officer of the City In vesting Company, for instance, has made finding tax-saving deductions his hobby. He often spends his free time poring over tax materials, and tells friends that he does not consider his weekend complete unless he has figured out a new way to save on his taxes.    ''The key is I keep meticulous records of everything,'' he said, adding that he files information on four personal computers, one for each of his residences.    But even for those who are not prepared to devote such time and effort to the task, there are a number of easily employed tactics to reduce tax bills, from using income averaging where appropriate to setting up a special trust that allows beneficiaries to be taxed at a lower rate.

headline: NICARAGUA SEEKS JAILED REBEL
abstract: Nicaragua has asked Honduras to extradite Steadman Fagoth M"uller, the anti-Sandinista Indian leader who was arrested in Honduras last week.   The official Sandinista newspaper Barricada reported today that Foreign Minister Miguel d'Escoto Brockman had made the extradition request to his Honduran counterpart, Edgardo Paz Barnica.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM;  ARBITRAGE-THE UNAVOIDABLE MALAISE
abstract: RECENTLY, Wall Street's risk arbitragers have taken several well-publicized baths. They are accustomed to this, although the size of some of the losses has seemed to give new meaning to the term risk. (Their losses after T. Boone Pickens's waltz with Phillips Petroleum have been estimated at $100 million.) At the same time, they have been attacked for contributing to the volatility of the market, touching off gyrations in stock prices that scare investors from the market.    It is not the activities of these admitted speculators that should concern us, however, as much as the attitude toward stocks that they exemplify - an attitude that has come to dominate the market and that some say has always dominated it. This is the search for short-run performance, for almost instant gratification.

headline: SECRET PAPERS FOUND IN INDIA ESPIONAGE CASE
abstract: An Indian magistrate said today that intelligence officials had found many incriminating documents, including photocopies of military deals and secret military information, in the homes of several Government officials and others arrested in a major espionage scandal here.     One of the suspects had worked in the Prime Minister's office for 15 years.   The magistrate, Bharat Bhushan, said, ''The police told me that the suspects were passing on vital information connected with defense and our national security to certain foreign powers, although they have not disclosed the names of these powers.''    On Friday, Mr. Bhushan ordered eight men suspected of spying for foreign agencies into police custody until Jan. 28.

headline: MUBARAK VISITS JORDAN FOR TALKS, THEN HE AND KING GO TO BAGHDAD
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met here today for talks on the stalled Arab-Israeli peace process, then made a surprise visit to Baghdad to express support for Iraq in its new fighting against Iran.    Their sudden departure for the Iraqi capital came only three hours after President Mubarak arrived in Amman to discuss efforts to revive the long- stalled Arab-Israeli peace process.   Egyptian and Jordanian officials said Mr. Mubarak came to Jordan to discuss with King Hussein the outcome of his talks with President Reagan and other senior Administration officials last week in Washington.   The two leaders decided on their trip to Baghdad during their meeting at the King's downtown palace and a lunch later at King Hussein's official residence, officials said.

headline: Death Toll Climbs In Indian City Clashes
abstract: Six people have been killed in the south Indian city of Hyderabad in violence set off by voting disputes.   The Press Trust of India said two people died in the city today: a man who was stabbed to death when a curfew was relaxed and another who died of stab wounds he received Friday.

headline: Advertising;   Publicker's Cleanser Strategy
abstract: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES of Greenwich, Conn., which is committed to taking on the huge household cleanser industry, has selected four-year-old Gleckler & Spiegel Advertising to help.    Down the road the Publicker ad budget could well grow to $4 million a year, which may be nothing for Procter & Gamble but is exceedingly attractive to Gayle Gleckler, the agency's chairman, and Joel R. Spiegel, its president.    Publicker's marketing strategy, as outlined at the agency the other day by William A. Lynch, the client's general manager, is to ''combine a trusted brand name with lower cost.'' Making the names trusted will be the agency's job.

headline: Verdict on Jersey Woman Is Due Feb. 27 in Nigeria
abstract: The verdict in the case involving Marie McBroom, a New Jersey woman facing death by firing squad if convicted of illegally trafficking in oil, will be handed down Feb. 27, a special military tribunal announced.

headline: Digital's Plans After Rainbow
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation, which earlier this week said it had quit making its Rainbow personal computer, said yesterday that it would announce details next month of a new product that could be used to upgrade the Rainbow and Decmate personal computers. Joe Nahil, a Digital spokesman, said the company had not planned to disclose the new product yet but decided to indicate its intentions now after some Rainbow users inferred that Digital was abandoning the personal computer market.

headline: HUNGARY BALKS AT REAGAN VISIT
abstract: The White House made a bid to include Hungary on President Reagan's trip to Europe this spring but was turned down by the Hungarian Government, a high-ranking Administration official said today.   According to well-placed Administration officials, the idea of an East European visit by President Reagan was originally put forward by Secretary of State George P. Shultz as a way to broaden high-level American contacts with East European countries and to show the President's interest in improving East-West relations.

headline: Grey Becomes Agency For Itokin America
abstract: Grey Advertising, in addition to being one of the largest national advertising agencies, is not adverse to grabbing hold of a retail account when the opportunity arises. As a matter of fact it has considerable expertise in that area.

headline: TRADE FIGHT WITH JAPAN
abstract: After years of protesting and posturing by the United States over the spread of Japanese goods in the American market and this nation's lack of access to the Japanese market, trade relations between the two countries appear to be at the boiling point.  The Japanese announced today that they would let their automobile shipments to the United States grow 24.3 percent over the next year. They hoped that this step would defuse some of the acrimony over trade, since they were under no commitment to impose any limit whatsoever.     But Congress saw no concession at all in such a figure. Beyond that, the Japanese failed to deal with the principal American objection to their trade policies: their reluctance to open Japanese markets to American goods in the way that the United States is open to Japan.

headline: Polish Court Hears Data From Autopsy on Priest
abstract: The club used to beat the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko was displayed here in the courthouse today as material from the autopsy of the pro-Solidarity priest was reported at the trial of four security policemen charged with his murder.   Maria Byrdy, a 75-year-old pathologist, told the court that the club, admittedly wielded by the key defendant, former Capt. Grzegorz Piotrowski, had been used to hit the 37-year-old priest at least 13 times on the night of Oct. 19, the day he was abducted and slain.

headline: Kodak Reports 74.4% Rise in 4th-Quarter Profit
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company, citing the positive impact of its staff-reduction program, reported yesterday that its earnings in the fourth quarter of 1984 climbed 74.4 percent as sales rose 7 percent.    The Rochester-based company, the world's largest producer of photographic equipment, said that net income in the latest three months jumped to $204 million, or $1.32 a share, from $117 million, or 70 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales rose to $2.75 billion from $2.57 billion.

headline: BANK CREDIT RULINGS CAUSE CONCERN
abstract: Bankers, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and municipal bond lawyers are dismayed at recent Federal court decisions holding that banks' letters of credit may be obligations that are Government-insured for up to $100,000, like a deposit.     Bankers are concerned because the court rulings could require them to pay F.D.I.C. insurance premiums on billions of dollars of letters of credit they have issued for businesses or as backing for bonds and other securities.   The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit in Denver, hearing a case stemming from the July 1982 failure of the Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma, found on Dec. 27 that the bank's letter of credit backed by a promissory note fulfilled the legal definition of a deposit, and was therefore backed for up to $100,000 by the F.D.I.C.   The Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee, Northern Division, reached a similar conclusion last October in a case in which Jacob F. Butcher used a letter of credit from the United American Bank in Knoxville, Tenn., to back his bid to buy the stock of another bank. Mr. Butcher, who was then chairman of the United American Bank, has since been indicted for bank fraud in other transactions.

headline: USAir to Reward Frequent Fliers
abstract: USAir Inc. became one of the last major airlines to offer a frequent- flier plan, saying such plans ''have become a permanent feature imbedded in airline marketing'' and necessary to remain competitive.   Randall Malin, the Washington- based airline's executive vice president for marketing, acknowledged that in recent years USAir had lost some business travelers who had gone to other carriers that offered frequent-flier plans.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Fund Officer Fights Poison Pill' Plan
abstract: Michael Price, a vice president at the Mutual Shares Corporation, a no- load mutual fund, and T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, have this in common: They do not like the ''poison pill'' method of blocking an unfriendly corporate takeover by making the target company's shares prohibitively expensive.    Last week Mr. Pickens assailed the Phillips Petroleum Company for introducing a poison pill provision that would give its shareholders the right to $62 a share in notes if anyone buys at least 30 percent of the company.    Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier, who has a 5 percent stake in Phillips, has proposed paying $60 a share for 45 percent more of the company, and he has offered $50 a share for the remaining half.

headline: TREASURY BILL RATES RETREAT
abstract: Interest rates on Treasury bills fell sharply yesterday, as traders and some investors reacted to the three- day closing of 71 Ohio thrift units by shifting funds into the ''safe harbor'' of the Treasury bill market.     By late afternoon, the three-month Treasury bill was bid at 8.43 percent, down about 3/8 percentage point from 8.79 percent a day earlier. The six- month issue was down a quarter percentage point, to 8.95 percent.

headline: SOO LINE WINS BID FOR MILWAUKEE
abstract: A Federal judge in Chicago today ruled in favor of a $571 million bid by the Minneapolis-based Soo Line Railroad Company for the bankrupt Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad Company, known popularly as the Milwaukee Road.   In favoring the Soo Line, Judge Thomas R. McMillen ruled against a $786 million offer by the Chicago and North Western Transportation Company for the same properties.    Judge McMillen said that a takeover by the Chicago and North Western of the Milwaukee Road would have hampered competition and led to too much track abandonment, since both railroads share many of the same markets.

headline: Delta Buys Planes
abstract: Delta Air Lines has ordered four more Boeing 767-300's at a total cost of about $260 million, the Boeing Commerical Airplane Company said.

headline: WEST IS COOL TO SOVIET PLAN ON TROOP REDUCTIONS
abstract: The Soviet Union has made a new proposal for troop reductions in Europe, and Western diplomats said today that it appeared to be an attempt to put into treaty form several suggestions Moscow has made in the past.   They said that the proposal, made at the Vienna talks on conventional forces in Central Europe, appeared to skirt two major Western objections and that it was not likely to ''break the logjam'' in the 11-year negotiations.   On Thursday, the Soviet Union proposed a mutual withdrawal of 33,000 troops from the Warsaw Pact and North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces. It suggested reducing troop figures to 900,000 men on each side.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *       Alaska Pacific Bancorporation, Anchorage, has named Michael J. Burns president of Alaska Pacific Bank.     *       Bulova Watch Company Inc., Flushing, Queens, has named Paul S. Sayegh executive vice president.

headline: American Brands Fills Vacant Financial Post
abstract: American Brands Inc., the tobacco company that is diversifying into consumer goods and financial services, said yesterday that William J. Alley, a former insurance executive, had been named chief financial officer.    Mr. Alley, 55, fills a vacancy that occurred Feb. 14 when Charles A. Mehos died. Mr. Mehos, who was 64, had held the post since 1979.

headline: COASTAL IN OFFER FOR RESOURCES
abstract: The stock of the American Natural Resources Company surged to a 52- week high in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as company officials indicated that they would fight an expected acquisition attempt.     The stock jumped by 4 1/8, to 53 3/4, following reports in The Wall Street Journal that the Coastal Corporation, the Houston-based oil and gas company, would soon make a bid for American Natural Resources, also an oil and gas concern.    American Natural Resources, which is based in Detroit, said on Thursday that it was establishing a publicly traded limited partnership for its oil and gas reserves, a move several analysts said was taken to make a takeover more difficult.

headline: Federated Net Climbs 16.7% Federated Department
abstract: Stores Inc. said yesterday that   its fiscal fourth-quarter profit   rose 16.7 percent. The increase   included a one-time extraordinary gain. Federated said its quarterly   profit was $201.5 million, or  $4.14 a share, which included  $28 million in one-time gains,   mainly from sales of shopping   center properties, against  $172.7 million, or $3.55 a share, a   year earlier.

headline: CHRYSLER ADDS TO RECORD YEAR
abstract: Three years ago the American automobile industry was on the ropes, with the Big Three companies reporting a combined loss of $1.34 billion for 1981.    Today it wrapped up its best year ever, as the Chrysler Corporation reported 1984 earnings of $2.38 billion, or $18.88 a share, more than triple the       $700.9 million, or $5.79 a share, earned in 1983. That brought the Big Three's combined profits for the year to $9.81 billion, easily eclipsing the old record of $6.15 billion set in 1983.   The General Motors Corporation earlier reported record earnings of $4.52 billion last year and the Ford Motor Company posted record net of $2.91 billion.

headline: Greece Rebuffs Turkey On Proposal for Talks
abstract: Greece rejected a proposal by the Turkish Prime Minister, Turgut Ozal, for talks on Greek-Turkish differences, calling it an insincere offer designed for an international audience.   The Government spokesman, Dimitri Maroudas, said there could be no talks while Turkish troops occupied northern Cyprus and Turkey laid claim to disputed areas of the Aegean Sea.   The Turkish Prime Minister said in an interview in Ankara on Tuesday that he was willing to meet with Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou ''anywhere, anytime.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Crescent Oil and Gas Corp., Denver, said that it had agreed to a merger with a group of closely held oil and natural gas companies but that present Crescent shareholders would retain only 14 percent of the company. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: 14 Children Die in Ghana
abstract: Fourteen children were killed Thursday when they fell down a 300-foot unused well in a school playground, the Ghana News Agency reported today.

headline: ISRAEL SAID TO ACCEPT INSTALLATION OF VOICE OF AMERICA TRANSMITTER
abstract: Israel has informed the United States that it will permit the installation of a Voice of American transmitter in Israel to enhance American broadcasts to the Soviet Union, political sources said today.   The decision in principle by the national unity Government of Prime Minister Shimon Peres was conveyed to Washington several weeks ago, the sources said. Nonetheless, Israeli Government officials today declined to comment on the decision for fear of drawing any more attention to the transmitter, which they fear might cause problems for Soviet Jews.

headline: VIETNAMESE SHELL CAMBODIA FOES
abstract: Vietnamese troops hammered Cambodian rebel positions along the Thai-Cambodian border today with a 40-minute artillery and mortar attack, and some fighting was reported in the Rithisen camp.   But reports from guerrillas at the front said the attacking Vietnamese held all key positions in the camp and that only small-scale skirmishes occurred today.

headline: CLOUDS OF DOUBT OVER SWEDEN'S GARDEN OF EDEN
abstract: The Tower of Babel stood in Uppsala, and wandering Swedes spread order and civilization afar. Greek goddesses were really Swedish women who had trekked south, their language becoming the tongue of perfection, the vernacular in paradise.    Swedenborg, the 18th-century mystic philosopher, considered such theories, and mulled over the idea that Sweden was the original Garden of Eden. His contemporary, Olof Rudbeck, insisted that Atlantis, no myth, never mind the cold, had existed right here at home, the light of the universe, the hope of mankind.

headline: NEW RESTRICTIONS PUT ON CAR, COMPUTER USE
abstract: Taxpayers who bought cars or personal computers since last summer, with the intent of writing off part of the cost as a business expense, may be disappointed to find the tax benefits have been sharply restricted.     Under pressure to reduce the Federal budget deficit, and irked by some luxury car dealers who were advertising tax benefits as if they were standard equipment on new models, Congress applied the brakes to business deductions claimed for cars used more for personal pursuits than business. It also applied similar restrictions to computers.    Professionals and businessmen motoring around in new luxury sedans or sports cars will also discover the Federal Government is no longer as generous a benefactor in helping subsidize the extra comfort and style with tax breaks.    ''If the car you bought was an expensive car, you're going to find the tax benefits reduced, and if you don't use your car or computer more than 50 percent for business you're going to find the tax benefits reduced,'' said Robert M. Brown, a tax partner in the Washington office of Peat Marwick, a major accounting firm.

headline: Brock in Japan
abstract: Japan must act quickly to open its telecommunications market to avoid a serious United States backlash, Mr. Brock, the special trade representative, was quoted today as saying by a senior Japanese trade official.

headline: European Investment
abstract: European industry is expected to increase investment an inflation-adjusted 9 percent this year after an estimated increase of 7 percent in 1984, the European Economic Community's executive commission said today.

headline: People
abstract: *       Bernard Ganis , advertising sales director at CBS Magazine Network, has been named vice president.     *       Nancy Ryan , director of advertising at Abraham & Straus, has been promoted to vice president.     *       Shelley Zuckerman has been appointed executive vice president at Lobsenz-Stevens.

headline: JAPANESE COMPANIES IN U.S. SEEN EXCELLING
abstract: Japanese companies operating in the United States perform better than American corporations, according to a study prepared by the Columbia University Graduate School of Business.   The study attributed the success of the Japanese companies to their emphasis on quality and cultivation of a warm relationship between labor and management.   It found that the success arises not just from the Japanese culture and work ethic, but also from a management style that can be transplanted with modifications to the United States.        Areas of Achievement    ''The Japanese companies generally outperformed their American counterparts in terms of quality products, the absenteeism rate, the relationship with workers and their relationship with customers,'' said Martin K. Starr, a professor at the business school who wrote the report with Nancy E. Bloom, a graduate student.

headline: I.R.S. Calls Protests Defused
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service said today that it now had the ''tax protest movement'' under control.     The agency's chief counsel, Fred T. Goldberg Jr., said that some of the actions were regarded as ''sincere protests against nuclear armament, or just against the Government,'' but increasing numbers of them were the result of mail solicitations by tax-protest groups. He said the groups provided kits and instructions on how to defeat the tax collector.

headline: Bank of Boston Reiterates Denial on Employees
abstract: The Bank of Boston said today that it stands by its earlier statement that no one in the bank benefited from its dealings with the city's organized crime family, despite reports that a Federal grand jury is investigating two of the bank's recently retired employees for helping the underworld group launder money.   Barry Allen, a spokesman for the bank, added that, ''as far as we know, the case is closed.''    ''We don't have any knowledge that any employee of the bank is being investigated,'' he said. But sources familiar with the inquiry said today that subpoenas were being issued.

headline: Market Place;The Bears Turn Bullish
abstract: THE explosive stock market rally that ripped         through Wall Street last week ran counter to

headline: TEXT OF U.S. STATEMENT ON WITHDRAWAL FROM CASE BEFORE THE WORLD COURT
abstract: Following is the text of a statement made public today by the State Department and called ''U.S. Withdrawal From the Proceedings Initiated by Nicaragua in the International Court of Justice'':      The United States has consistently taken the position that the proceedings initiated by Nicaragua in the International Court of Justice are a misuse of the Court for political purposes and that the Court lacks jurisdiction and competence over such a case. The Court's decision of Nov. 26, 1984, finding that it has jurisdiction, is contrary to law and fact. With great reluctance, the United States has decided not to participate in further proceedings in this case.        U.S. Policy In Central America    United States policy in Central America has been to promote democracy, reform and freedom; to support economic development; to help provide a security shield against those - like Nicaragua, Cuba and the U.S.S.R - who seek to spread tyranny by force, and to support dialogue and negotiation both within and among the countries of the region. In providing a security shield, we have acted in the exercise of the inherent right of collective self-defense, enshrined in the United Nations Charter and the Rio Treaty. We have done so in defense of the vital national security interests of the United States and in support of the peace and security of the hemisphere.

headline: PATENTS;  New Adhesives Assigned to NASA
abstract: Anne K. St. Clair and her husband, Terry L. St. Clair, who are both senior chemists in the materials division of the Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., were granted a patent this week for adhesives to be used in the structural bonding of advanced aircraft and spacecraft.

headline: Killings in El Salvador Said to Be on the Rise
abstract: After a lull of almost a year, political assassinations by extremist groups are on the rise again in El Salvador, according to the human rights office of the Roman Catholic Church and United States officials.   According to a monthly report by Tutela Legal, the human rights monitoring body of the Roman Catholic Church, killings by right-wing death squads and Government security forces jumped from 12 in December to 29 in January.   A preliminary tally compiled by the United States Embassy from newspapers indicated that 36 civilians were killed in political violence in the first two weeks of January, compared with 16 in the last two weeks of December.

headline: General Cinema Gives New Titles to 2 Officers
abstract: The General Cinema Corporation, the bottling and movie theater operating company, yesterday announced a number of changes among its top-level executives.    The major changes involved upgrading the titles of two executive vice presidents, Robert J. Tarr Jr. and J. Atwood Ives.    The company said that Mr. Tarr, 41, had been named president and chief operating officer. Since September 1983, when the company established an office of the chairman, Mr. Tarr has served as executive vice president and chief operating officer. Mr. Tarr joined General Cinema in 1976 after a career as an investment banker with Paine Webber Inc.

headline: GOLD BRIEFLY FALLS BELOW $300 LEVEL
abstract: The price of gold fell briefly below $300 an ounce in London trading yesterday, its first drop below that critical psychological level in a major market since June 1982, during the worldwide recession.     Although the price later moved back above $300 in London and never fell below that in New York, analysts said they thought gold might drop as low as $260 an ounce in the near future.    ''We're knocking on the door to a real breakthrough below 300,'' said Michael D. Kelley, vice president of the Prudential-Bache Metal Company, a dealer in precious metals.    ''It seems to me that we'll have to see some selling,'' said Peter Feuerstein, an economist at the Chase Manhattan Bank who specializes in gold and foreign exchange. But, he said, ''I don't see a dramatic decline in the next six months, maybe to the low 290's.''

headline: HOUSE REPORT CLEARS AGENCIES OF AIDING KILLERS IN SALVADOR
abstract: A House Intelligence Committee report has concluded that the United States intelligence agencies operating in El Salvador ''have not conducted any of their activities in such a way as to directly encourage or support'' the activities of right-wing death squads.   The report, completed this month, came in response to charges in Congress that Central Intelligance Agency officers and others may have trained, organized, financed or advised Salvadoran security forces that had engaged in death squad activities.

headline: PRESIDENT SENDS 2 TRADE ENVOYS FOR TOKYO TALKS
abstract: President Reagan has sent two senior officials to Japan to try to win trade concessions before Japan reorganizes its telecommunications industry, the White House said today.    The reorganization, to take effect Monday, may limit foreigners' access to the Japanese market for communications equipment, American officials and business executives fear.    The Cabinet will meet early next week to discuss the talks; if they have been fruitless, top officials are expected to consider supporting legislation providing for trade reprisals against Japan.    The two officials, Lionel H. Olmer, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade Administration, and Dr. Gaston Sigur, a Japan specialist on the National Security Council, went to Tokyo Friday night.

headline: Market Place ;   The New Look At Del Webb
abstract: PHOENIX    The Del E. Webb Corporation added more   flexibility and cash to an already sound balance sheet last month when it sold its three Nevada casinos to a group of investors for $80.4 million.   The agreement, which netted the company $53 million in cash before taxes, was another step in Del Webb's transformation into what is now a company principally involved in managing and developing recreation and gaming operations as well as commercial and residential real estate.    Analysts credit Del Webb's chairman, Robert K. Swanson, with rescuing the company from a brush with bankruptcy in his first year as chief executive, in 1981, and putting it on an increasingly sound footing by reducing its exposure to hard times in construction and gaming. With one exception, in Atlantic City, Mr. Swanson has limited Del Webb's activities to the Southwest.

headline: Merrill Lynch Unit Chief Out Merrill Lynch & Company
abstract: said that, at the company's request, Donald H. Rundlett had   resigned as chairman and chief   executive of Merrill Lynch Private Capital.

headline: Great Northern Modernization
abstract: Robert F. Bartlett, president of the Great Northern Paper Company, said the company planned a $155 million modernization of its East Millinocket newsprint mill.

headline: LITTLE IN NICARAGUA ESCAPES WAR'S ONSLAUGHT
abstract: After four years of fighting, the increasingly fierce war between the Nicaraguan Government and the rebels seeking its overthrow is the dominant factor in the country's political and economic life, according to Nicaraguans and diplomats here.    The rebels have not been able to take and hold a single Nicaraguan town. But the country's economy is in bad shape and Sandinista leaders say the rebels are to blame for that. They say the rebels' war of attrition has forced the Government to take measures restricting civil liberties in defense of national security.    The restrictions include the reimposition of press censorship, which is applied especially vigorously to the major opposition daily, La Prensa; the limits on campaign activities preceding the elections last November, and the recent orders preventing some opposition leaders, such as Arturo Cruz and Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, from entering the country.

headline: Money Fund Assets Decline
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined for the first time in 17 weeks, falling $2.14 billion, to $211.38 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Net Income   Percent

headline: 'PROLETARIAN RECTITUDE' RUNS AMOK UNDER CHINA'S NEW ECONOMIC POLICY
abstract: A minor official named Liu Baoqin had an eager audience when he told villagers outside Peking last summer that he could get 200,000 Japanese television sets through contacts in Hong Kong.     With a new form of prosperity sweeping rural China, imported television sets have taken the place of bicycles and sewing machines among the most prized of household possessions. So officials in Yutian County were all ears when Mr. Liu sketched a deal under which the sets could be imported and resold for a profit of 30 million yuan, about $10.7 million.    As it turned out the whole thing was a fraud. After Mr. Liu had taken 12.6 million yuan in advance payments for the nonexistent sets, and placed two million yuan in his own bank account, he was arrested in a luxury hotel across the border from Hong Kong. With his fellow swindlers, he is awaiting trial on charges that carry a maximum sentence of death.

headline: NICHE FOR AMERICAN NATIONAL
abstract: Last year, when most of this city's major banks were mired in trauma and uncertainty, the American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, the city's fifth-largest bank, put together a record year by capitalizing on the problems of its hometown competitors.   It did this by continuing to do what it does best: serving the highly profitable ''middle market'' of small and medium-sized companies.   So successful was 1984 for American National that its earnings jumped by 32 percent, its client roster by more than 20 percent and its loans outstanding by 30 percent. In addition, the First Chicago Corporation, the city's largest bank holding company, impressed by American National's record, acquired the bank from the Walter E. Heller International Corporation last May.

headline: A.N.R. Studies Other Offers The American Natural Resources Company has confirmed that it is considering
abstract: several alternatives to the proposed tender offer of the   Coastal Corporation, including   the possibility of seeking a   merger with a friendly suitor.  Coastal has offered $60 a   share, or $2.3 billion, for American Natural Resources' 37.8   million shares.

headline: STAKES SEEM HIGH IN PAKISTAN VOTE
abstract: After nearly eight years of martial law and despite the arrest of hundreds of political activists, there are small signs that an election of some consequence is going to be held in Pakistan next week.    The voting for a new National Assembly and provincial assemblies is to occur Monday and Thursday, and Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, the President, has promised to return the nation to civilian rule if it goes smoothly.    The general's critics, discussing his promise to return Pakistan to civilian rule, say he has promised an end to martial law since he took power in 1977 but that the transition has never come to pass.     In this vibrant port on the Arabian Sea, where tens of thousands of demonstrators have taken to the streets in past years, rallies today consist of a few hundred people. The rallies break up soon after they start. Demonstrations, processions and loudspeakers are banned.

abstract: LatestPreviousYearWeekWeekAgo       Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Dec. 24      $557,600 $550,900 $525,200 Adj. Mon.Base (St.Louis Fed) *(1/2)      219,600 215,800 n.a. headline: Chile Hints at New Ties With the U.S.
abstract: The Chilean Government gave a positive account today of recent meetings with a high-ranking State Department official and hinted at new cooperation between the two countries.   The meetings, an official communique said, permitted representatives of the two countries ''to examine the state of bilateral relations, and to look for new areas of cooperation.''

headline: INDIA'S SPY SCARE SLOWS ARMS DEALS
abstract: Indian officials, concerned by the uncovering of a major espionage network, have slowed talks on buying billions of dollars worth of advanced weapons from Western countries competing for the contracts, a Western diplomat says.     The network reportedly extended to the office of the Prime Minister and to the Defense, Commerce and Finance Ministries.   The Western diplomat said Friday that officials in the Defense and Finance Ministries were shaken by the extent of the network, which purportedly sold military, economic and other Government secrets to diplomats from the Soviet Union, Poland, East Germany and France. Many officials were ''lying low,'' he said, and were apparently unwilling to make major decisions while the spy ring continued to unravel.

headline: SANDINISTA FORCING THOUSANDS OUT OF WAR ZONE
abstract: The Nicaraguan Government has begun the forced evacuation of thousands of peasants from the countryside in a drive to deny local support to rebels operating in the north, according to evacuees and international relief agency officials.   The program has two objectives, according to Sandinista officials here and Western diplomats in Managua who specialize in military matters. The first is to deprive the rebels of material support and intelligence by removing relatives and neighbors sympathetic to them from war zones.   But equally important, these sources said, is the creation of ''free-fire zones'' where the Sandinista People's Army can operate freely against the rebels.

headline: OUTSIDE DIRECTORS BACK EASTERN CUTS
abstract: The outside directors of Eastern Airlines at a special board meeting yesterday gave a strong endorsement to management's step extending 18 to 22 percent wage cuts that had been due to run out on Dec. 31, according to union leaders.    The directors took the step despite a strong and emotional appeal at the meeting by Charles E. Bryan, the president and chairman of District 100 of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, that Frank Borman, the chairman of Eastern, had broken an agreement with the union by extending the cuts last week.   Mr. Bryan, whose union has 12,000 members and is the largest at Eastern, said in a telephone interview: ''I'm extremely disappointed. I advised them that they left us no alternative but to go to court.''

headline: NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE ISSUES
abstract: Most Active N.Y.S.E. Issues in 1984

headline: A NERVOUS DAY IN CURRENCY PITS
abstract: When the opening bell sounded this morning, telephones to the foreign currency traders here at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange were ringing off their hooks, with investors rushing to place orders.    The dollar's plunge today and Tuesday, following its leap to new records on Monday, has sent trading volume soaring on the Merc's International Monetary Market.    The market is a 13-year-old division of the Merc, where futures contracts for gold, 90-day Treasury bills and West German marks, British pounds, Japanese yen and Swiss and French francs are traded. In addition, the Merc trades option contracts on pounds, marks and Swiss francs.

headline: International Paper's Loss
abstract: The International Paper Company yesterday reported a loss in the fourth quarter of $74 million, compared with a profit of $68.7 million, or $1.25 a share, a year ago. Sales were level with the previous year at $1.1 billion.

headline: PATENTS;  System for Storing Genealogical Records
abstract: A Florida mother and two daughters received a patent this week on a system for storing genealogical records. Patent 4,501,559, granted Beth H. Griswold, and her daughters, Gail E. and Alexandra F. Griswold, of Melbourne Village, says that a minimum number of pieces of paper will cover several generations and various ancestors.  The system, which the Griswolds are promoting through a workshop called Straightline, includes a basic surname chart for recording successive generations by male surnames, family charts including the female connections and personal charts with precise information about individuals.

headline: MUBARAK URGES U.S. TO REVIVE SUDANESE AID
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said today that the United States was wrong to withhold financial aid from the Sudanese until they straightened out their economy. He said he would recommend that the decision be reversed when he visits Washington next month.   The Egyptian leader told reporters that he would discuss the matter with President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan before leaving for the United States.

headline: Housing Unit Offering Made
abstract: The New York Housing Development Corporation offered $31.75 million of multifamily development bonds.    The bonds, which are backed by a letter of credit from Citibank, consist of serial bonds with maturities ranging from 1985 through 1996, a term bond that matures in 2007 and is putable on Jan. 1, 1997, and a capital appreciation or zero coupon bond that matures on Jan. 1, 2007.

headline: New Hope for Clues In Italian Scandals
abstract: The arrest earlier this month of Francesco Pazienza by the United States Customs Service may shed some light on scandals that have rocked Italy in the past five years, including the collapse of the Banco Ambrosiano.     Mr. Pazienza, a 38-year-old Italian business consultant, was arrested in New York on March 4 by Customs officials, who described him as ''Italy's No. 1 fugitive.'' He is being held on behalf of the Italian authorities without bail pending extradition proceedings, which are expected to be completed in about a month.    Italian authorities believe Mr. Pazienza can assist their inquiries into not only the collapse of the Banco Ambrosiano, the main interest of the American investigators, but also the equally complex scandals involving the Propaganda 2 Masonic lodge and its relationshp to parts of the Italian secret services.

headline: Return From U.S. Exile
abstract: Mr. Kim's return to South Korea today ended more than two years of exile in the United States.    South Korean authorities had said earlier that Mr. Kim would be taken to his house in Seoul, where presumably his movements would be restricted. The Government had withdrawn earlier threats to return Mr. Kim to prison, where he had been serving a 20- year sentence on sedition charges.    Two members of the United States House of Representatives and other Americans escorted Mr. Kim here on the trip from the United States, which included an overnight stay in Japan. The Americans had joined Mr. Kim to help guarantee his safety.

headline: Trade Deficit Is Confirmed
abstract: The United States had a record trade deficit of $107.6 billion last year on a balance-of-payments basis despite the first improvement in exports since 1981, the Commerce Department said today.    It confirmed figures released last week showing an even deeper merchandise trade deficit of $123.3 billion. Today's report also covers last year's trade activity but omits such factors as military sales and the cost of shipping and insurance.

headline: Textile Import Curbs Urged
abstract: Arguing that imports are threatening the domestic textile industry, more than 130 members of Congress pledged today to support legislation that would restrict foreign apparel entering the United States.   ''If the current trends in job losses due to import penetration are allowed to continue, massive economic hardships will result for those who depend on this industry for their livelihoods,'' said Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina.

headline: Hathaway Sets Northwest Tie CHICAGO, Jan. 18 - Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and its
abstract: subsidiaries - companies controlled by Warren E. Buffett,   the Omaha-based investor -   have purchased a 6.1 percent   stake in Northwest Industries   ''for investment purposes,'' according to a filing made today   with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Despite the Berkshire Hathaway move, officials at Kelly,   Briggs & Associates said they   were still seeking to complete financing for a leveraged buyout   of Northwest for $1 billion.

headline: FRANCE'S CLOUDED FUTURE
abstract: The results of France's two-stage regional elections have accentuated the now widespread notion that the Socialists will fall from power in parliamentary elections next year.  But the outcome of the voting for regional councils on Sunday, in which the conservative and centrist opposition made clear advances, has not clarified a second area of conjecture about the country's political future. It is that France could be moving into a period of institutional instability, something it has not known since the Fourth Republic and the days in the 1950's before the presidency of Charles de Gaulle.     Because the victories of the opposition in the local elections dovetail with polls on the electorate's intentions for the 1986 legislative voting, they make a strong case that Socialists will be unable to retain power alone. Yet the results suggest a series of potential circumstances that in a year's time could raise the question, who governs France?

headline: Your Money ;   Responsibilities Of an Executor
abstract: It may be an honor to be named executor of an   estate, but it is much more than that. For he or   she often has a big job to fulfill in carrying out the provisions of the will.   The executor is held to high standards of fiduciary responsibility and charged with acting as a reasonably prudent person in protecting the interests of the heirs. Whether or not you have previously agreed to serve as executor - and those writing a will should certainly ask at the time the document is drawn up - you are under no obligation to accept this task when the testator dies. But if you do, then be prepared for what might become a time-consuming burden.

headline: DOW UP BY 20.76, TO 1,223.50
abstract: Stocks soared yesterday in heavy trading after Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, reiterated at a luncheon meeting that inflation was continuing under control.     The broad advance, with rising issues outnumbering declining ones by 1,298 to 367, came after the market had been down in the morning. The rally pushed the Dow Jones industrial average up 20.76 points, to 1,223.50.   That was its best one-day gain since Dec. 18, when the average jumped 34.78 points. The market barometer has gained 38.54 points in the last four sessions.

headline: Film Decrees Will Continue
abstract: The Justice Department said today that it would not try to modify or end decrees that have regulated movie distribution for more than 30 years because the studios were not willing to initiate such proceedings.    The so-called Paramount decrees require major studios to license films for distribution on a theater-by-theater, picture-by-picture basis.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: *       Air Wisconsin Inc., Appleton, said it had agreed to buy Mississippi Valley Airlines Inc. for $10 million.          * Ericsson Lightwave Cable , a joint venture of Ericsson Inc. and Atlantic Richfield Co., said it was increasing the capapcity of its Harrisonville, Mo., plant to produce more than $100 million worth of fiber optic cable a year.

headline: U.S. Delays Payment To a U.N. Fund
abstract: The United States Government is holding up a $23 million contribution to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities because of American concerns that it might go to support forced abortions in China, a spokesman for the United States Agency for International Development said today.    Kate Semerad, the spokesman, said the agency's Administrator, M. Peter McPherson, had postponed payment pending ''a careful review'' of the United Nations program.   United Nations officials have denied that the United Nations funds supported coercive birth-control practices.

headline: Car Sales Rose by 3.3% In Early March Period
abstract: Sales of new American-made automobiles increased 3.3 percent in the March 1-10 period from last year, the manufacturers reported today. Several of the auto makers offered financial incentives to customers during the period.   The six companies - General Motors, Ford, Chrysler, American Motors, Volkswagen and American Honda - sold a total of 193,896 new cars in the period, which had eight selling days this year and nine in 1984. The industrywide daily selling rate of 24,237 units was the highest for the early March period since 1981, when the companies were offering cash rebates to buyers.

headline: SURGE IN STOCK INDEX OPTIONS
abstract: Trading in stocks and stock options has languished in the past year, but trading in index options, which reflect the overall movement in the stock market, has grown by leaps and bounds. And no index option has succeeded more than the S.&P. 100 index option, which is traded on the Chicago Board Options Exchange.    Trading in the S.&P. 100 index option, which in effect gives investors the right to buy or sell the package of stocks making up the Standard & Poor's index of 100 blue chips at a set price on some future date, quintupled in 1984, to 250,000 contracts a day. At the same time, trading in individual stock options on the C.B.O.E. dropped by 18 percent, to about 232,000 contracts a day.

headline: Your Money;   Varied-Benefit Outlook Bright
abstract: FLEXIBLE benefit plans at corporations,   popularly known as ''cafeteria'' plans, received a big lift last year. First, the Internal Revenue Service published its long-awaited proposed regulations to put into effect the 1978 law creating such plans. Then Congress passed the Deficit Reduction Act defining elements of these programs. However, at the end of the year the situation was clouded by a Treasury Department proposal.    Last November, the highly publicized and controversial Treasury Department tax proposals included a section to eliminate the tax preference for cafeteria plans. As a result, some specialists in the field have again expressed concern about future applications of flexible benefits, which include a smorgasbord of alternatives from which an employee can choose.

headline: Journalists Protest Israeli Move
abstract: The Foreign Press Association in Israel today protested the Israeli Army's treatment of Beirut-based journalists in southern Lebanon and urged it to lift restrictions on news coverage in the area.  On Wednesday, the Israeli Army detained five reporters from the north for four hours and confiscated their material.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Battle at Fortune Financial
abstract: John B. Sweger, the 65-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of the Fortune Financial Group Inc., whose principal subsidiary is the Fortune Federal  Savings and Loan Association, admits that he has not had much operating experience in the thrift business.         But Mr. Sweger, who spent most of his working life in the construction industry, says that a dissident group of shareholders engaged in a costly proxy  fight with Fortune's management knows even less about the business than he does.

headline: ISRAEL BARS BEIRUT-BASED JOURNALISTS FROM ENTERING SOUTH LEBANON
abstract: The Israeli Army today banned Western journalists based in Beirut from entering territory it controls in southern Lebanon.    The order came as the Israelis imposed a dusk-to-dawn curfew on southern Lebanon in the sixth day of what Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel called an ''iron fist'' crackdown on Shiite Moslem-led resistance to the occupation.   ''Journalists who will attempt to arrive from Beirut and from other areas in Lebanon which are not under I.D.F. control will not be allowed to cross into areas where the I.D.F. is currently deployed,'' the Israeli General Staff said in a letter hand-delivered to the Tel Aviv bureau of The Associated Press to be relayed to journalists here. I.D.F. stands for Israeli Defense Forces.    ''Recently, I.D.F. checkpoint commanders have been issued strict orders to prevent the crossing of journalists from the north into areas in the south under I.D.F. control.'' the letter said.

headline: TEXACO'S OFFERED PRICE FOR U.S. OIL CUT BY $1
abstract: Texaco Inc. yesterday cut the price it will pay for the most common kind of American oil by $1 a barrel, reflecting continued weakness in the markets and the expectations of many traders that prices will drop further.   The company is now willing to pay $28 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark American grade, which is among the lowest levels for a major producer.   Texaco is the first partner in the Arabian-American Oil Company, which includes the big companies that produce Saudi Arabian crude oil, to cut its posted price to $28. Other partners, such as the Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation, still post a price of $29 a barrel. The cuts in posted prices put pressure on the official oil prices of Saudi Arabia and other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

headline: Advertising;   Combating An Image Problem
abstract: MEDIA GENERAL BROADCAST SERVICES, whose chief business is obtaining broadcast time and print space for advertisers at discount rates, is in the midst of an advertising campaign for itself.    The company's million-dollar promotional effort in the business and advertising trade press is aimed at erasing any lingering doubts about its integrity - doubts that appeared in the wake of tax-evasion charges brought against its founder, William B. Tanner.    Mr. Tanner sold the company, then called the William B. Tanner Company, in late 1982 to Media General Inc., the giant communications concern. He was indicted in 1983 on three counts of income tax fraud and one count of mail fraud related to his activities at the company, particularly in the way he handled its accounting procedures. He pleaded guilty to the four counts on Jan. 31, and will be sentenced later this year.

headline: PROFIT TAKING IS CITED
abstract: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday after soaring on Thursday.     The Dow Jones industrial average, which climbed 20.76 points on Thursday, dropped 5.41 points yesterday, to 1,218.09. But advances on the New York Stock Exchange led declining issues by 917 to 730.

headline: AMID SIDON'S JOY, A SETTLING OF SCORES BEGINS
abstract: The past caught up with Mohammed Habli here today.    For the 32 months of the Israeli Army's occupation he was one of a triumvirate of local militia leaders that Sidon residents say were ''enforcers'' for the Israelis, terrorizing the population.    Now that the Israelis are withdrawing from southern Lebanon - their last troops left Sidon on Saturday - their ''collaborators,'' as they are called, are increasingly under attack.   Dozens of Lebanese and Palestinians who helped the Israelis have been assassinated in the past few weeks. In Sidon last week, in the middle of the day, a masked gunman killed a pro-Israeli militiaman in a video game arcade; a bullet-riddled body was found another morning with a sign reading, ''Collaborator.''

headline: Polish Gang Leader Seized
abstract: Zdzislaw Najmrodzki, Poland's most wanted criminal and leader of a gang that stole goods worth $1.6 million, has been recaptured after his sixth prison escape 50 days ago, the official press agency said today. Mr. Najmrodzki, who faces up to 25 years imprisonment, led a gang that robbed luxury apartments and hard currency shops.

headline: POPE OFFERS MASS IN EQUADOR
abstract: Pope John Paul II received tumultuous greetings here today as he spoke out on behalf of the poor of the third world.   The Pope said mass before about a million people in a park in the center of this city, a marriage of modern high- rise structures and a historic center of rambling white buildings, a reminder of the city's Spanish colonial past.

headline: THRIFT UNIT SALE BILL POSTPONED
abstract: An Ohio Senate committee today put off until next week consideration of legislation that would allow an out-of-state bank to acquire Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati, which has been in the control of a state-appointed conservator since its collapse March 9. Citicorp, the giant New York-based bank holding company, has been negotiating to purchase Home State.

headline: Chile Is Reported Ready To Allow Political Parties
abstract: A member of Chile's ruling junta said today that he had told a visiting American official that the military Government would legalize non-Marxist political parties this year.   The junta member, Adm.

headline: Technology;   Computer Chip Juggles Tasks
abstract: LONDON    ANYONE struggling to soothe an upset infant while carrying on a telephone conversation and making dinner can take comfort from the thought of how glorious the performance would seem to a computer designer. Computers can handle incomprehensible amounts of information at dazzling speed, but they are, for all intents and purposes, hopeless at doing several things at once. Somehow, they have to sort out an order in which to handle each piece of information.   Although the computer's sequential approach works wonderfully on some problems, and acceptably on many more, many computer designers concerned with building the super information processors of the future - sometimes known as fifth-generation computers - believe that the path to a real breakthrough is through systems that operate more like the human mind. Their jargon for simultaneously handling several problems, or several parts of one problem, is ''parallel processing.''

headline: ISRAELIS GET LEBANESE AND SYRIAN VIEWS OF PULLOUT
abstract: A United Nations Under Secretary General, Brian Urquhart, told senior Israeli officials today that the Lebanese and Syrian Governments still had doubts about Israel's intention to withdraw fully from southern Lebanon.   Senior Israeli officials said they responded to Mr. Urquhart that the Lebanese and Syrians were completely out of touch with the reality of what Israel intended to do. They warned that if Lebanon and Syria did not take control of the areas Israel plans to evacuate by Feb. 18, there would be chaos and killings between the Lebanese religious and political groups - for which the Israelis said they would not be responsible.   Mr. Urquhart, who spoke here after visits to Damascus and Beirut, met separately with Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir to brief them on his conversations with Syrian and Lebanese leaders, and heard essentially the same response from all three, Israeli officials said.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Unionist Director In Talks at Eastern
abstract: Charles E. Bryan, president and general chairman of the machinists union at Eastern Air Lines and a director of the company, has not had much time to celebrate the fact that on an operating basis the fourth quarter was the carrier's most profitable ever.    Instead, he has been deeply involved in a pivotal round of negotiations that will decide whether or not Eastern will continue to exist. But unlike a year ago, when Mr. Bryan was instrumental in pursuading his membership to accept sharp pay cuts in return for stock ownership, he says that the current round of talks may produce a different result.

headline: PROSPECTS;  A Currency War Chest
abstract: The Administration is still refusing to intervene strongly in foreign exchange markets to moderate the dollar's rise - or, when it happens - its fall. Officials insist the move would be costly and largely ineffective.
