headline: GARMENT MAKER RENTING FACTORY IN THE SOUTH BRONX
abstract: For years, New York City officials have encouraged manufacturers in Manhattan's crowded garment district to move their cutting and shipping operations to less congested areas of the city, particularly, in recent years, to the South Bronx.   The city has had little success in arranging any coordinated relocation to that area, but there have been some individual moves. The latest, and one of the biggest, is now under way.   Special Additions Inc., a large manufacturer of maternity clothes, is keeping its offices and showrooms on Seventh Avenue in Manhattan. But it is moving its cutting and shipping operations from the West Side to a 78- year-old restored factory building in the Port Morris section of the South Bronx.

headline: SOVIET-INTELSAT PACT RAISES CONCERNS
abstract: The Soviet Union wants to become a major force in the development and use of communications satellites for television broadcasting, high-speed data transmission and other telecommunication services, American officials and other analysts said today.    They made their comments in response to the tentative agreement reached between Moscow and the 109- nation International Telecommunications Satellite Organization on an exchange of information. The agreement, which was disclosed Tuesday, is expected to lead to Soviet membership in the communications network, which was founded by the United States 21 years ago.    But the American officials said the relationship could cause ''problems'' if Moscow tries to use it to acquire advanced technology that is barred by American export regulations.

headline: U.S. Antitrust Chief to Leave WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -
abstract: The Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division,   J. Paul McGrath, said today   that he would leave his post on   April 1 and return to private   practice with his former law   firm in New York City.  At the firm - Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood   - Mr. McGrath will become   the partner in charge of its litigation department.  Mr. McGrath, who is 44 years   old, took over the antitrust division in December 1983, succeeding William F. Baxter.

headline: Court in Aquino Case Suspends Sessions
abstract: The court trying Gen. Fabian C. Ver and 25 others in the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. in 1983 suspended sessions today until Monday after key witnesses withdrew or failed to appear.   General Ver is on leave from his post as armed forces chief of staff.

headline: U.S. AND ISRAEL SET PACT TO END TARIFFS BY 1995
abstract: All tariffs between the United States and Israel would be eliminated within 10 years under an agreement the two countries have just concluded - the first free-trade pact that Washington has reached with any country, Administration trade officials said today.    President Reagan will formally submit the accord to Congress on Tuesday, and most legislative analysts expect relatively easy and quick approval - before the summer.    Israel sought the agreement as a means to spur economic development and to cement both economic and political ties with Washington.         A Further Refinement    For the United States it represents a further refinement of the use of trade to help countries that it considers strategically, and politically, important.

headline: PENTAGON HALTS SOME PAYENTS TO A CONTRACTOR
abstract: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he would suspend for 30 days a small part of the Pentagon's payments to the General Dynamics Corporation while the Defense Department looks into possibly improper billings by the nation's largest military contractor.     In a speech at an American Legion convention here, Mr. Weinberger also announced a review of billing procedures and a tightening of claims for overhead expenses of all major military contractors.   The General Dynamics suspension involves payments for general and administrative costs, or overhead. This is 8 percent of the company's Government billings, according to a statement issued by General Dynamics. A Pentagon spokesman, Michael I. Burch, told reporters the 30-day suspension represents about $40 million.

headline: U.S. and Soviet Delegations Hold Work Session in Geneva
abstract: United States and Soviet negotiators held their first working session on strategic nuclear weapons today as Moscow warned that Congressional approval of 21 more MX missiles presented ''new logjams'' at the talks.

headline: U.S. SAYS BOSTON BANK KNEW OF RULE ON CASH
abstract: A vice president of the Bank of Boston was told by Federal bank regulators as early as 1982 that the bank was not in compliance with international currency reporting regulations and the official promised to correct the situation, Treasury officials said today.     The disclosure contradicts a repeated assertion by William L. Brown, chairman of the bank, that the reason for the bank's failure to comply with the currency reporting requirements was that it was unaware of them until 1984.   Earlier this month the Bank of Boston pleaded guilty to failure to report $1.2 billion in cash transfers with Swiss banks from 1980 to 1984 and was fined $500,000, a record amount.        Chairman's Remarks on Filing    Mr. Brown said at a news conference on Feb. 11 that the bank had simply failed to notice the regulations in the Federal Register, and he said that in June 1984, ''as soon as we had determined that these reports were required to be filed, we did so.'' To underscore his point, Mr. Brown held up a copy of the Federal Register showing how many regulations it contained and how small the print was.

headline: BRAZILIAN INAUGURATION ENDS THE GENERALS' RULE
abstract: Civilian rule was restored in Brazil today for the first time since 1964, even though the 75-year-old President-elect underwent emergency surgery late Thursday and was unable to take the oath of office.     As Tancredo Neves, the President- elect, was recuperating, his running mate, Jose Sarney, was sworn in and designated as interim President. Mr. Sarney then swore in the 27-member Cabinet and received the heads of foreign delegations, including Vice President Bush.    Doctors said Mr. Neves was recovering well from a two-hour operation for an acute intestinal inflammation known as diverticulitis.   ''He should be out of the hospital in a week and be ready for work in two weeks,'' Dr. Renault Mattos, his physician, said today.

headline: Three Sell Shares In Investing Firm
abstract: Three principals of Underwood, Neuhaus & Company said they had sold their positions in the Houston-based investment banking firm to new investors and two current managers.

headline: Patents;  Computer Network System
abstract: A multi-computer communications system was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The inventors listed in patent 4,493,021 are Anil K. Agrawal, Philip G. Mullen and V.V. Vadakan, engineers at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: March 11, 1985 SECURITY COUNCIL   Meeting on the Middle East - 3 P.M.

headline: I.B.M. DROPS PCJR PRODUCTION
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it will cease production next month of its PCjr home computer, a machine that never quite caught on in the marketplace.   I.B.M. said it was taking the action because inventories were sufficient to meet future demand. The company said it would continue to market the remaining computers and to support the product by providing software, spare parts and optional hardware attachments.   Nevertheless, the surprise announcement in effect signals the end of the PCjr, a product that was once expected to establish the same dominance for I.B.M. in the home market that its initial PC established in the office market.

headline: HUSSEIN SAYS U.S. MUST TAKE A ROLE IN PEACE PROCESS
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan says he can move no further toward reviving the long- stalled Middle East peace process unless the United States agrees to meet with a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation. He has also ruled out any peace talks that do not include the Palestine Liberation Organization.    ''I have done my utmost to move towards peace,'' King Hussein said in an interview Friday, the first he gave to a Western newspaper since he and the P.L.O. signed an accord Feb. 11. That accord is the basis for a joint bid for peace in the Middle East.

headline: POLE ACCUSED OF PRIEST'S MURDER TELLS OF BITTERNESS IN SECRET POLICE
abstract: A key defendant on trial here for killing an activist priest described the ranks of the secret police today as frustrated, bitter and demoralized because they were prevented from moving against Roman Catholic priests who collaborated with the Solidarity underground.    In an abrupt half-hour digression, the witness, Grzegorz Piotrowski, a former captain, said that once when the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, the pro-Solidarity priest he is charged with murdering, was released from a day's detention ''I saw adult men cry like children.''   He also affirmed that he had told pretrial investigators ''there would be no trouble in obtaining volunteers if he issued a call for police willing to maltreat the activist clergyman.''    This segment of testimony centering on the defendant's charge that the Government was soft on the church and that political authorities tied the hands of the secret police made it appear at times that it was the murdered priest and even the Minister of Interior, Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, who were on trial rather then Mr. Piotrowski and three other dismissed employees of the state security department that monitored religious groups and minorities.

headline: LOAN TALKS AT EVANS
abstract: The Evans Products Company, burdened with $600 million in term loans that came due Tuesday, said yesterday that it was discussing the possible restructuring or refinancing of the loans with its lenders, and also was exploring sales of its assets to repay the debt.     The company, which operates a building materials retail chain and manufactures truck trailers and rail cars, gave no further details of its circumstances, or the negotiations, in a statement released from the Miami headquarters of its chairman, Victor Posner, the widely known financier who has built a $1 billion empire with holdings in more than 40 companies. Mr. Posner bought a 43 percent stake in Evans, which is based in Portland, Ore., in 1981.    One analyst, however, who asked not to be identified, said that the $600 million debt included loans on two subsidiaries, the Evans Financial Company and the Evans Transportation Company.

headline: IN SHIFT OF POSITION, SOUTH AFRICA SAYS IT MAY SPARE SQUATTER CAMP
abstract: The authorities said today that they were prepared to develop the Crossroads squatter camp outside Cape Town as a black residential area, apparently abandoning earlier plans to raze it.    However, Gerrit Viljoen, the white minister responsible for the destinies of many blacks, told Parliament in Cape Town that some blacks in the camp who refused to cooperate with his plan for redevelopment could still face compulsory resettlement.   Last week, 18 people died in clashes with policemen in Crossroads prompted by rumors that the squatter population was about to be forcibly removed. Right-wing whites opposed to the Government's racial policy said the minister's announcement represented a capitulation to black pressures.

headline: Bomb Blast in Netherlands
abstract: A bomb severely damaged a power relay station near this northwestern Dutch town today, but the police said electricity supplies were not affected. No one claimed responsibility for the bombing and no arrests were made.

headline: Iraq Announces Attacks On Three Cargo Vessels
abstract: Iraq said its jet fighters attacked three ''naval targets'' today in the Persian Gulf.

headline: Kuwait Votes for Parliament
abstract: Kuwaitis voted today for a new Parliament in the only Persian Gulf Arab country with an elected assembly able to initiate laws and change or reject government bills. Only 3.5 percent of Kuwait's 1.7 million people are allowed to vote under a franchise restricted to men over 21, most of whom must be able to trace their roots in Kuwait back to 1920.

headline: THE NEW RULES ON MEDICAL EXPENSES
abstract: ''The Internal Revenue Service has a heart,'' says the accounting firm of Arthur Young & Company in its guide to completing 1984 tax returns. ''Tax law is fairly generous in defining medical expenditures that may be deducted from your income.''    To illustrate the ''heart'' of the I.R.S.: Virtually any payment you have made to someone who has diagnosed, treated, or prevented an illness, including mental illness, is deductible, regardless of whether the preson who provided the service was a physician, chiropractor or Christian Science practitioner.  You can also deduct the cost of surgery and of procedures ranging from face lifts and hair transplants to electrolysis.  And this past year, the Internal Revenue Service ruled that the cost of special schools for disabled or emotionally disturbed children may be deducted as well as part of the ''founder's fee'' that elderly people may be required to pay before they enter a retirement home.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: Abraham & Straus , the New York- based department store, said four executives had been promoted to the rank of senior vice president: Frank Brooks, Francesco Cantarella, Robert E. Oberlin and James C. Pressey.     *       Coldwell Banker , Los Angeles, a full-service real estate company and a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Co., has appointed Rodney A. Briggs executive vice president.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Jan. 10, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Trade and Law Commission on Negotiable Instruments - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Council for Namibia - 10:30 A.M.

headline: Showdown Feared Over Japan Trade
abstract: First the Japanese refused to buy American baseball bats. Then communications satellites. Now it is vitamin E.    The news was transmitted to the State Department in a recent cable from Ambassador Mike Mansfield in Tokyo. New pharmaceutical testing requirements put into effect by the Ministry of Health and Welfare, the cable said, would ''effectively bar'' American vitamin E face cream and other vitamin E products from what is now a $40 million-a-year export market in Japan.

headline: Tesoro Terminates Funk Agreement
abstract: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said it had terminated its previously announced agreement to buy Funk Exploration Inc., a privately held oil and gas producing company, for $160 million.    Tesoro said it had placed $10 million in an escrow account as earnest money and, as a result of its termination of the deal, that money would be paid to Funk.

headline: State Power Yields Reduced Strong investor demand enabled securities dealers to reduce slightly yields on about
abstract: $268.8 million of New York   Power Authority bonds. When   issuers negotiate terms of a   bond sale with securities dealers, bond yields announced on   the first day of the offering are   frequently adjusted up or   down, depending on investor   demand.

headline: SHAMIR CALLS JORDAN-P.L.O. PACT IN NO WAY AN 'OPENING TO PEACE'
abstract: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that the agreement between King Hussein of Jordan and the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, in no way amounted to an ''opening to peace.''   ''We do not see this agreement as being any opening to peace in the region,'' Mr. Shamir said this morning before leaving on a trip to Europe. ''It is our belief that there is no lack of peace programs, but rather a lack of readiness and desire for peace on the Arab nation's part.   ''Israel continues to stand by its adherence to the Camp David agreements and its readiness to conduct negotiations with Jordan without preconditions,'' Mr. Shamir said.

headline: U.S. CLARIFIES LETTER ON BANK
abstract: In what it called a clarification, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency said today that a letter it issued Tuesday did not mean to imply that the agency had cited the Bank of Boston in 1982 for a violation of the international currency reporting regulations.   H. Joe Selby, the Senior Deputy Comptroller for Bank Supervision, said in a new letter today that, instead, the Bank of Boston had been cited in 1982 for a violation of the currency regulations involving its cash transfers with domestic banks.   The earlier letter seemed to contradict repeated claims by the Bank of Boston that it was not aware it was violating the international currency reporting rules until 1984. The Bank of Boston pleaded guilty last month to failing to report $1.2 billion in cash transfers with Swiss banks from 1980 to 1984, and was fined $500,000.

headline: Marriott Hotel Account To Lewis, Gilman
abstract: Marriott Hotels and Resorts, based in Washington, yesterday assigned its domestic advertising account to Lewis, Gilman & Kynett, the Phildelphia subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding.

headline: Data Bank;    February 17, 1985
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: Depositor Bill Gains on Coast
abstract: A bill that would enable the state to make a temporary loan to 12,500 depositors of the failed Western Community Money Center of Walnut Creek, Calif., passed the state Senate by a vote of 31 to 4 today.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Bonds Rally in Light Trading;    20-Year Issue Brings 11.86%
abstract: The bond market yesterday reclaimed some of the territory it gave up in its big decline on Wednesday, pushing interest rates down slightly after a week of increases.     The market remained nervous, however, and analysts said that signs the economy is gaining new strength after a lethargic third quarter last year give little hope of any further decline in interest rates soon.   ''Some rebound was to be expected after the declines we've had,'' said Lacy Hunt, chief economist for Carroll, McEntee & McGinley, a bond dealer. ''But it is just technical, and volume was extrememly light.''

headline: ORGANIZING YOUR FINANCIAL RECORDS
abstract: Taxpayers who spent the last few weeks   emptying receipt-stuffed shoe boxes and   thumbing through canceled checks to prepare their 1984 returns by April 15 may react with dismay to the suggestion that they now organize their financial records for their 1985 returns, although the deadline is more than a year away.    ''The best way to deal with a large unpleasant task is to break it into small parcels,'' said Stephanie Winston, author of ''The Organized Executive.'' Set aside 30-minute intervals - while you watch ''Dallas,'' say - and tackle those shoe boxes, she advised. ''It's surprising how quickly you'll finish.''

headline: Craxi and Peres Meet; No Mideast Plan Seen
abstract: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy told Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel tonight that the time was not yet right for a new Middle East peace initiative.   ''There are not yet enough conditions for a new peace initiative,'' Mr. Craxi told Mr. Peres, who arrived today on a three-day visit to Italy.

headline: TRADING INCREASES
abstract: Expectations of lower interest rates helped push stocks strongly ahead yesterday with both prices and volume reaching their best levels of the new year.     The Dow Jones industrial average, lost some ground in late trading but still ended the day 11.04 points higher, at 1,202.74. It had been up nearly 14 points in the early afternoon. Advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declines by 1,075 to 519.

headline: PICKENS MAY MOVE ON UNOCAL
abstract: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, said yesterday that he might try to take over the Unocal Corporation, owner of the Union Oil Company of California.     He said no decision had been reached whether to proceed and gave no indication of how much he might offer. At present market prices, Unocal stock is worth nearly $9 billion.   Unocal, which markets gasoline under the orange ''76'' label, is expected to fight Mr. Pickens tenaciously, but it declined immediate comment on the long-expected move.

headline: Federated to Sell Boston Store Unit
abstract: Federated Department Stores Inc., the Cincinnati-based retail company, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Boston Store division to P.A. Bergner & Company for $80 million.     The division, which is based in Milwaukee, operates eight department stores and their associated distribution systems in Wisconsin.

headline: Donaldson Deal Is Completed
abstract: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States said it had completed its $430 million acquisition of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette investment company, which became an Equitable subsidiary.

headline: Americans in Mali Crash
abstract: Two Americans were among the 51 victims in the crash of an Air Mali plane near Timbutku, Mali, last Friday, the United States Embassy said today. The embassy confirmed the deaths of Joseph Jacquellart, a resident of New York state and his wife, who was not an American citizen. Mr. Jacquellart's hometown was not immediately available.

headline: PARTI QUEBECOIS REFECTS HARD LINE ON SEPARATISM
abstract: The Parti Quebecois, which came to power in 1976 with a vision of independence for Quebec, today set aside separatism as a goal for the foreseeable future.   At a special congress in Montreal, 61 percent of the 1,536 delegates voted to change a party platform adopted last year that would have made a vote for the Parti Quebecois in the next election a vote for Quebec's independence.   They substituted a less binding formulation that described independence for the French-speaking province as a ''fundamental objective.''

headline: Consolidated Sets Vote on Name
abstract: Consolidated Foods Corporation stockholders will be asked at a special meeting in March to approve a change in the company's name to the Sara Lee Corporation, the company said today.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Charter Medical
abstract: The Charter Medical Corporation said that the board of Health Group Inc. had agreed to sell substantially all Health Group assets to Charter and Owens-Illinois Inc.

headline: Phelps Dodge In Copper Deal The Phelps Dodge Corporation said it had signed a letter
abstract: of intent to sell a ''significant   minority interest'' of its copper   mining properties in Morenci,   Ariz., to the Sumitomo Corporation of Tokyo and its Sumitomo Metal Mining Company   affiliate. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: NEW STAKE IN ASAROO
abstract: A successful Australian corporate investor, Robert Holmes a Court, has acquired a 10 percent interest in Asarco Inc., setting off speculation about whether he plans to attempt a takeover of the big American mining company.     Mr. Holmes a Court, 48 years old, who has built a business empire around his Bell Group in Perth, Australia, was not available for comment on the Asarco investment, according to Reuters.

headline: Iraq Reports Raid Off Iranian Oil Island
abstract: Iraq said today that its jet fighters had raided a ''very large naval target'' in the Persian Gulf as part of its attempt to blockade the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island.    Iraq often uses the phrase to refer to supertankers.

headline: ON PARADE: THE TOMMY'S NEW GUN
abstract: For the first time in 20 years, the British infantryman is being re-equipped from head to toe.    Although the Americans disagree with the British about the lightweight helmet, and although that essential article, the boot, still causes blisters, most of the attention has focused on the new SA 80 rifle, which is a cinch to shoot but stubby and too short for the British Army's traditional ceremonial drill.   Not to allow new technology to mar ceremony, the army has rewritten the drill, which will be introduced at the Queen's Birthday parade in 1987. It was demonstrated recently at the School of Infantry in Warminster by a group of guardsmen in red tunics and black bearskin helmets.

headline: British Army Defuses Big World War II Bomb
abstract: British Army bomb experts today defused a one-ton bomb - one of the biggest dropped on England during World War II - but the police said it was still unstable and posed a threat to homes in the area.

headline: INTEREST RATES SLIGHTLY LOWER
abstract: Interest rates for short- and long- term Treasury securities fell slightly yesterday.    Although many securities dealers and economists predict that the Federal Reserve will not adjust monetary policy to encourage higher interest rates at today's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, their conviction has not yet attracted sizable investor demand for this week's auctions of Treasury notes and bonds.   Investors often wait until the last minute before committing funds at major Treasury financings, and their normal caution has been increased recently by concern that interest rates will rise later in the year, even if the Fed holds monetary policy stable in coming weeks.         Federal Funds Below 8 1/2%    A slight decline in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market to less than 8 1/2 percent helped raise prices slightly yesterday. But market participants said the results of Treasury auctions the next three days would be a more telling sign of investor attitudes.

headline: 33 Killed in Sri Lanka As Train Is Blown Up
abstract: A train was blown up 180 miles north of here Saturday night and 22 soldiers and 11 civilians were killed, the police reported today. The police blamed Tamil separatist rebels for the explosion.

headline: AUTOPSY DISCLOSES SEVERAL DISEASES
abstract: Konstantin U. Chernenko died of lung, heart and liver disease, according to an autopsy report signed by the chief Kremlin physician, Dr. Yevgeny I. Chazov, and nine other doctors.   The 73-year-old Soviet leader's main medical problem was a common, incurable, chronic lung disease called emphysema. The strain of the emphysema, in turn, severely damaged Mr. Chernenko's heart, enlarging it, causing it to fail, and finally stopping it at 7:20 P.M. Sunday, according to the report.    In addition, the report said, Mr. Chernenko's liver was destroyed by two common diseases, chronic hepatitis and cirrhosis. These liver disorders can have many causes, such as viruses, drugs or alcohol. The Kremlin doctors were not specific about the cause in Mr. Chernenko's case.

headline: Chronology of Ohio Banking Crisis
abstract: March 4: A court orders E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., a securities dealer based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., put into receivership amid allegations of fraud.       March 7, 8: Worried depositors withdraw some $90 million from the Cincinnati-based Home State Savings Bank, which will likely incur huge losses from its transactions with E.S.M.       March 9: Home State decides to close.

headline: 'SPOT' BUILDERS IN QUEENS CATERING TO A 'NEW MARKET'
abstract: Here and there, now and then, a piece of land becomes available for new housing construction in established residential communities such as Middle Village, Maspeth or Elmhurst in central Queens. When it does, the ''spot'' builder takes notice.    Henry J. Fabian is one of them. He was born in Middle Village and still lives there in a house he built five years ago. His office at Fabian Construction is in Maspeth.

headline: SALES OF NEW HOMES JUMP BY 6.2%
abstract: Sales of new single-family homes rose 6.2 percent in February, the biggest increase in five months, the Government reported today.   Sales were put at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 638,000 last month following a slight decline of five-tenths of 1 percent in January, according to the report by the Commerce Department and the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The January drop originally was reported as a 2.6 percent rise.

headline: Club Med U.S. Account Awarded to N.W. Ayer
abstract: The N.W. Ayer agency, which already does tourism advertising for the United States and for the Bahamas, has been hired by Club Med as the agency for its 17 United States vacation retreats.

headline: 4% Drop Against Mark
abstract: The dollar's fall against the mark today culminated a week in which it has lost almost 4 percent of its value against the West German currency.    ''The problems of the American economy have long been perceived by experts, but for a good while the markets failed to heed the judgment that United States growth was based on a disbalance,'' said Leonhard Gleske, a board member of the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, and the director of its foreign-exchange operations. ''What we are experiencing is a return to the fundamentals, to the realities.''

headline: ADVERTISING;Accounts
abstract: WNEW Radio, Metromedia's flagship station in New York, to Holland & Callaway Advertising.

headline: Iranian Drive Foiled, Iraqis Report
abstract: Iraq said tonight that its forces foiled an Iranian offensive Monday night on the Hawizah marshes in southern Iraq and were preparing a counterattack on the rest of the invading troops.

headline: Europe Curb on Fakes
abstract: Tougher rules to keep counterfeit goods out of the Common Market were proposed today. Imports found to be counterfeit would be seized.

headline: Economic Scene ;   What Goes Up Comes Down
abstract: Is the high-flying dollar about to come down? Despite the erratic swings in the currency market   this week, exacerbated by the statements and interventions of central bankers, the general view of traders and bankers around the world is that the ''fundamentals'' have not changed and that a steep downfall of the dollar is not imminent.    Those fundamentals include United States advantages over other major countries, such as a more dynamic economy, lower inflation, higher after-tax real returns on capital, a positive spread in interest rates, the size and diversity of the capital market and the nation's political stability, which makes it a safe haven in turbulent times.       Those are the factors, optimists say, that have attracted such a huge influx of foreign capital, and nothing has happened to change them. Central banks can alter the daily flow of events but, as has happened before, this too will pass.

headline: Gromyko Appeals to Italy
abstract: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, who is visiting here, called on Italy today to oppose the space-defense system proposed by the United States.   Italy has so far expressed an ambivalent position on President Reagan's space-defense plans, which the Soviet Union is determined to stop.

headline: Predictions
abstract: To the Editor:     ''Behind Reagan's Economic Shuffle'' article (Jan. 14) states that: ''The mainstream economic community . . . has failed correctly to predict the impact of Mr. Reagan's major moves.'' Some would argue that when professionals make mistakes because they don't recognize the limitations of their techniques (in this case the statistical rear-view mirrors known as 'econometric models') they have failed miserably.

headline: Return of Chinese Boat Delayed by High Seas
abstract: The Government announced today that high seas had caused a 24-hour delay in return of a Chinese torpedo boat that drifted into South Korean waters after a mutiny.   The South Koreans are to return the two crew members said to have mutinied on Friday and killed six crewmen and wounded two others.

headline: Muir Cornelius Moore Chosen by Thrift Unit
abstract: Muir Cornelius Moore, which specializes in financial advertising, has landed the account of Northeast Savings of Hartford, an institution that operates in Connecticut, upper New York State and Massachusetts.

headline: Money Fund Assets Rise
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $714 million, to $210.08 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

headline: Accounts
abstract: El San Juan Hotel in Puerto Rico to AC&R Advertising.

headline: VIDEO GAME'S FALL SURVIVED
abstract: When the Bally Manufacturing Corporation began diversifying in the late 1970's, spending the jackpot it had won selling pinball and Pac-Man machines, its aim was to expand into less cyclical businesses. The company was not seeking a life preserver in case the then-thriving video arcade games business collapsed.   But collapse it did. And today, Robert E. Mullane, Bally's chairman and chief executive, readily acknowledges that, were it not for the company's diversification into casinos, amusement parks and health clubs, Bally might have gone the way of the nickel pinball machine.    ''I wish we could say we were farsighted in diversifying,'' Bally's chain-smoking, 52-year-old chairman said. ''Even in our worst-case scenarios, we never dreamed the video game business would disappear the way it did.''

headline: IT'S DAY ONE IN GENEVA: JOKES AND NO COMMENT
abstract: At the end of seven hours of talks today between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, a notice was chalked on the blackboard at the overflowing American press center here: ''Official: No Briefing.''    Mr. Shultz is still expected to convene a news conference on Tuesday, after the discussions are scheduled to end and after a communique has been issued.   But this was the first time in the two and a half years that Mr. Shultz and Mr. Gromyko have been meeting in such places as New York, Washington, Madrid and Stockholm that Mr. Shultz or an aide had not promptly and publicly given the American version of what had happened.    The difference this time, according to one American aide, pressed for an explanation, was that ''this time we're seeking results, and not propaganda points.''

headline: ACCOUNTANTS CAN REGULATE THEMSELVES
abstract: THE current Congressional hearings on the accounting profession have pointed up the common misconception that a ''clean opinion'' by an auditor on a company's financial statements is a guarantee that the company won't subsequently fail. In fact, such an opinion provides the public with reasonable assurance that the representations of management reflected in the company's financial statements comply with generally accepted accounting principles.    Some members of Congress have raised questions about the ability of the profession to properly oversee its members. In truth, many of the criticisms of individual auditors are unfounded, and the profession remains fully capable of assuring that the highest standards of fairness, integrity and objectivity are maintained.

headline: HOW IMPORT RISE AFFECTS U.S.
abstract: Of every dollar that Americans spent last year to buy goods, 20 cents went for imports. That amounts to a staggering $1,421 per person, according to figures released Wednesday by the Commerce Department.   Lured by the rising dollar ; ich makes them cheaper, and by robust American demand for all kinds of goods, imports surged 26.4 percent last year, to $341.2 billion. The rise was almost across the board: low technology as well as high technology, capital goods as well consumer goo s.    Japanese cars, Mexican oil and French wine were all among the imports. They improved the American standard of living by holding prices down - but at the cost, at least in the short term, of American jobs.
