headline: Debt Issues
abstract: M.D.C. Corp.  filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $75 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2000, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.     *       Motorola Inc.  filed for a shelf offering of up to $200 million in debt securities, through Goldman, Sachs & Co.     *       Rio Grande Industries, a unit of the Anschutz Corp., has filed for $80 million of senior subordinated notes due 1995 and $100 million of subordinated notes due 2005, through Morgan Stanley & Co.      Preferred Stock    *       Aircal Inc.  is offering 3.2 million shares of $1.20 convertible exchangeable preferred stock at a price of $10 a share, through Paine Webber Inc.     *       Travelers Corp.  is offering 4 million shares of convertible exchangeable preferred stock at $50 a share, through Morgan Stanley.

headline: THE MANY TESTS FOR DRUG ABUSE
abstract: In January, the Internatioal Business Machines Corporation said it was initiating urinalysis for positions at every level.  The announcement recieved widespread publicity.  But I.B.M. was by no means the first to adopt medical employment testing for reasons other than insurance --and it is unlikely to be the last.

headline: DOW ENDS AT RECORD 1,299.36
abstract: Stock prices surged to new highs on a wave of institutional buying yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at a record 1,299.36, up 15.35 points, after being as high as 1,306.76 at midafternoon.    The previous record was 1,297.92, set on Feb. 13, when the Dow climbed 21.31 points. Since then, it has hovered around 1,280.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   President Resigns At Burger King
abstract: Jerome B. Ruenheck, president and chief operating officer of the Burger King Corporation, is resigning, a spokesman for the Miami- based company confirmed yesterday.   John F. Weir, the Burger King spokesman, said Mr. Ruenheck was leaving ''to pursue other opportunities.'' Mr. Ruenheck, whose Chicago home has an unlisted telephone number, could not be reached for comment. Mr. Weir said he and J. Jeffrey Campbell, Burger King's chairman and chief executive officer, would probably comment later on Mr. Ruenheck's departure.

headline: Troops Are Deployed For Bangladesh Election
abstract: Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, the President of Bangladesh, deployed troops at stations where the people will vote Thursday on whether they approve of his continuation in office until national elections can be held.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Rates Steady in Quiet Trading
abstract: Interest rates were unchanged to slightly higher in quiet trading yesterday as many credit market participants stayed on the sidelines waiting for the Federal Reserve's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, to review monetary policy in testimony today before the Senate Banking Committee.     ''Recent signals from the Fed show no change in policy, but nobody seemed willing to stick their neck out before the chairman speaks,'' said one Treasury note trader.    The latest signal from the Fed came shortly before noon when the central bank arranged temporary purchases of securities for the third consecutive business day. The Fed's purchases add reserves to the banking system and have helped keep the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market from rising much above 8 1/2 percent.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST WEDNESDAY, MARCH 13, 1985
abstract: Companies         Castle & Cooke and Flexi-Van agreed to merge.  Flexi-Van, which is controlled by David H. Murdock, would become a subsidiary of the combined company, but its management would have most of the power. Castle & Cooke has been severely threatened by debt problems. (Page D1.)         Leaders of American Natural Resources and Coastal met in a sign that Coastal's hostile takeover offer may turn friendly. American said no agreement was reached at the meeting but that there may be ''future discussion.'' (D1.)

headline: Scott & Fetzer Interest Cited
abstract: An investment group led by the New York arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky stated, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, that it holds 5.5 percent, or 633,800, of the common shares of the Scott & Fetzer Company, and that 140,000 of those shares were bought between Dec. 28 and Feb. 19. Scott & Fetzer, a Westlake, Ohio, company that markets a variety of consumer products, including World Book encyclopedias and Kirby vacuum cleaners, last year rejected an offer of $60 a share, or $420 million, from the Boesky group.

headline: New Du Pont Plastic for Cars The Du Pont Company said
abstract: that it had developed nylon-   based thermoplastics that   could replace steel exterior automobile parts, thus lowering   construction costs.  Du Pont said the new plastic   resins, called Bexloy, were   suitable for bumpers, fenders,   doors and other exterior panels   because they could go through   a paint oven at temperatures   up to 300 degrees and maintain   their shape.

headline: Florida Bank Bid
abstract: Hugh F. Culverhouse, a Tampa, Fla., lawyer, said that he had started a tender offer for 758,723 common shares of Florida Commercial Banks Inc. at $30 a share, or a total of $22.8 million. Mr. Culverhouse said he might buy more shares if the offer, which expires Feb. 28, is oversubscribed. The offer would raise his interest to between 51 and 54 percent of the outstanding shares, from 32 percent. Florida Commercial was quoted at $28.50 bid in over-the-counter trading yesterday, up $3.75.

headline: Careers;  Computer Jobs Rise At Schools
Eban Opposes a Transmitter Wanted for Voice of America
abstract: Abba Eban, chairman of Parliament's foreign affairs and security committee, said today that he opposed setting up a transmitter on Israeli soil to relay Voice of America broadcasts to the Soviet Union.   The Israeli Government has not yet replied to an official American request to set up the transmitter.

headline: Egypt Confirms Plan To Free Coptic Leader
abstract: The Government officially announced today that Pope Shenuda III, patriarch of the Coptic Orthodox Church, would be allowed to resume his duties and leave the desert monastery to which he was banished three years ago.    President Anwar el-Sadat, a month before his assassination in 1981, accused Pope Shenuda of fomenting unrest and stripped him of official recognition.

headline: Market Place ;   Falling Dollar's Beneficiaries
abstract: The dollar's swings on the currency market in   the last four years have done much mischief   to the balance sheets and profit-and-loss statements of American companies with heavy international exposure. As the dollar soared, earnings denominated in foreign currencies slumped - and then slumped even further as the dollar continued its climb. Some analysts are starting to think that 1985 may be the year that those companies get their revenge.   Given the dollar's almost perverse propensity to strengthen, rare is the forecaster who is willing to insist that this year will be different. But a vague feeling that the end may really be near is starting to creep into the thinking of many analysts. This is causing them to look at some companies a bit differently.

headline: Boesky Stake In Holiday Inns Ivan F. Boesky, the New
abstract: York investor, and a group of   companies he controls disclosed that they had acquired   an 8.6 percent stake, or   2,980,200 common shares, in   Holiday Inns Inc., which they   bought from Jan. 8 through   Jan. 31. Holiday Inns, however, said   that Mr. Boesky had tendered   2.25 million of those shares as   part of a previously announced   company plan to repurchase 6.3   million of its common shares at  $49 a share. Mr. Boesky bought   his stock for an average of  $47.30 a share. Separately, Holiday Inns reported a 33.1 percent increase   in net income in the fourth   quarter, to $20.5 million, or 59   cents a share, from $15.4 million, or 42 cents a share, a year   earlier. Revenues rose 9.3 percent, to $429.5 million.

headline: Merger Canceled At National Can
abstract: The National Can Corporation said its proposed merger with a subsidiary of Miami-based NVF Company would not be completed. Nearly a year ago, NVF, which is headed by Victor Posner and owns 37.2 percent of National Can, announced its intention to merge with the Chicago-based manufacturer of packaging products in a deal that would pay stockholders $40 a share, or a total of $410 million.

headline: NEW SNAGS DELAY STEEL TRADE PACT
abstract: The United States and the 10-nation European Common Market have hit last- minute snags in negotiating limitations on shipments of European steel pipe and tube to this country, officials on both sides said today.    They reported that negotiations would continue, and said they still hoped a final accord would be nailed down this week. Although the negotiators had wanted to finish their talks by midnight tonight, they said that an extra few days would make no difference in steel markets because the limitations being discussed would not become effective until well into 1985.    The negotiators were reported to be in agreement on what they had regarded as major issues but were bogged down on some secondary points.

headline: BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST UP IN MONTH TO A RECORD
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest was up 801,324 shares in the month ended March 15, to a record 250.2 million shares. The previous high was set last month, when short interest totaled 249.4 million shares. The short interest for the period a year earlier totaled 182.7 million shares.   In the same period, the short interest on the American Stock Exchange rose 180,732 shares, to 18.1 million shares.    A short position can result from the sale of borrowed stock in the hope of buying the same issue at a later date and at a lower price to cover the sale.

headline: Saatchi & Saatchi Shifts Top Executives
abstract: Saatchi & Saatchi of London, which grew from nothing to join the world's top 10 advertising agencies in only 15 years, did it without its founding brothers, Maurice and Charles, ever taking on the mantle of a corporate title.

headline: Factory Orders Up 4.3% in Reversal
abstract: Orders to American factories for manufactured goods rose 4.3 percent in November, the biggest increase in 17 months, the Commerce Department said today.    The department said new orders, which are viewed as a good indicator of future production activity, totaled $193.8 billion, an increase of $8 billion from the October level.   The gain followed three consecutive monthly declines and was further proof that the economy rebounded in November from a period of anemic growth, analysts said.

headline: ;   Former Head of Abbott Is Genentech President
abstract: G. Kirk Raab, who resigned last month as president and chief operating officer of Abbott Laboratories, was selected to assume those positions at Genentech Inc., the biotechnology company.   Mr. Raab, 49, succeeds Robert A. Swanson, 37. Mr. Swanson, who helped found Genentech in 1976, will remain as chief executive.

headline: Debt
abstract: First Bank System is issuing $150 million of 12-year floating-rate notes, through underwriters led by Credit Suisse First Boston, with interest 1/8 point above the London interbank rate.     *       Gulf and Western Industries offered $125 million of 11 5/8 percent notes due in 1992 at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 11.73 percent, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody; the notes are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBBx by Standard & Poor's.     *       Homac Mortgage Securities Corp.  filed a shelf offering of $500 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through Salomon Brothers.

headline: G.M.-Japan Talks
abstract: The General Motors Corporation wants Japan to allow G.M.'s affiliates, Isuzu Motors Ltd. and the Suzuki Motor Company, to export about 234,000 vehicles to the United States in the year ending March 1986, a G.M. official said. Henry Leonard, vice president of the G.M. Overseas Distribution Corporation, said that G.M. wants to import about 150,000 subcompacts from Isuzu and 84,000 from Suzuki for sale by its Chevrolet division. Under the existing quotas, which the Reagan Administration has said it will not push to extend, Isuzu can export 49,500 cars and Suzuki 17,000.

headline: TAX CUT PROPOSAL IN INDIA BUDGET RECALLS REAGAN PLAN FOR STIMULUS
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, in a notable break with past policies, has proposed a sweeping program to cut taxes for businesses and wealthy individuals and reduce government regulation of key parts of the economy.    The Prime Minister's program bears more than a passing resemblance to some of President Reagan's ''supply side'' initiatives. Consciously or not, Mr. Gandhi seems to have borrowed a page from Mr. Reagan's textbook in an effort to shake up the Indian economy.    The program, introduced in his Government's budget last week, has drawn praise from several quarters, including some associated with the political opposition.

headline: In Italy, the 'Dollarone' Fuels Inflation Worries
abstract: ''Inflation and Superdollar: Craxi Calls the Ministers,'' read the headline on the front page of La Repubblica last week. L'Unit a, the Communist paper, had a funny cartoon of the dollar: Under George Washington's picture, instead of ''One Dollar,'' it read ''Dollarone.''

headline: REAGAN WELCOMES ARGENTINE LEADER
abstract: President Reagan welcomed the President of Argentina to the White House today, an occasion that Mr. Reagan used to renew his denunciations of the Government of Nicaragua.     ''The free people of this hemisphere must not stand by and watch the Communist tyranny imposed on Nicaragua spread to the free lands of the Americas,'' Mr. Reagan said.    His comments on Nicaragua were in contrast to President Raul Alfonsin's opening statement about the Sandinista Government, in which he stressed the need for ''dialogue'' and what he called a ''longstanding principle'' of international law in Latin America opposing intervention.    ''I am convinced that it is through dialogue that we will be able to reach peace,'' the Argentine leader said in a speech on the White House South Lawn.

headline: Mordechai Oren Dies; Israeli Jailed by Czechs
abstract: Mordechai Oren, a prominent Israeli leftist who was jailed in Czechoslovakia in the 1950's on trumped-up charges of espionage, died Wednesday in a Jezreel Valley hospital. He was 79 years old.   Mr. Oren, a prominent leader of the Mapam Party, a Soviet-oriented but Zionist group, was arrested while on a trip to Czechoslovakia on Dec. 31, 1951. The following year he was called as a witness by the prosecution at the trial of Rudolf Slansky, the Communist Party secretary general who was later hanged for ''high treason, espionage and economic sabotage,'' and 13 other prominent Czech Communists, many of them Jewish. In 1953 Mr. Oren, who was himself accused of espionage, was sentenced to 15 years in prison.

headline: CINCINNATI THRIFT UNIT SEEKS SALE
abstract: Officials of the Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati said over the weekend that they were trying to sell the institution. It suffered a run last week following the collapse of E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., a securities dealer based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.     The Home State Savings Bank, which is state-chartered, said late Friday night that it would not open for business on Saturday, as normally scheduled, and that negotiations were under way to sell it to another financial institution.   Home State was one of several banks and thrift units involved with E.S.M. Government Securities when it collapsed March 1. The Cincinnati savings bank had invested in Treasury securities valued at more than $600 million in repurchase agreements with E.S.M.

headline: ANTI-SEMITE IS ON TRIAL, BUT DID ONTARIO BLUNDER?
abstract: Each day the scene is the same. A van rolls up to the courthouse, men in hardhats and business suits emerge and television cameras faithfully record all.    The leader of the group is easy to spot: he usually wears a different colored hardhat from the rest, and always a bulletproof vest.   He is Ernst Zundel, 46 years old, one of the world's leading distributors of anti-Semitic literature, author of ''The Hitler We Loved and Why,'' and center of an increasingly stormy debate over civil liberties in Canada.

headline: Kelso's Offer
abstract: The Scott & Fetzer Company said that its board had approved the company's definitive merger agreement with an affiliate of Kelso & Company but that the transaction was subject to various conditions, including govermental and shareholder approval. Kelso had made a sweetened leveraged buyout offer of $62 a share, $1 more than the previous proposal, for a total of about $440 million. Scott & Fetzer makes vacuum cleaners and household and industrial products.

headline: Beatrice Credit
abstract: The Beatrice Companies Inc. is arranging a $1.3 billion backup line of credit to support its existing commercial paper program in the United States and to enable the company to gain access to the Euronote market. Bank of America International Ltd., which is arranging the line of credit, said today that the three-year facility was a restructuring of an existing financing arrangement, and would allow Beatrice to issue Euronotes with maturities of up to six months.

headline: PROGRESS AT CONTINENTAL BANK
abstract: It has been six months since the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation brought in two executives to deal with the morass of bad loans at the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company.    In that short period, however, Continental's new leaders - John E. Swearingen, chairman of the bank's holding company, and William S. Ogden, chairman of the bank - have made more progress than most people anticipated. That view is held not only by Mr. Swearingen and Mr. Ogden, but also by some banking regulators in Washington. The bank's profit of $36.6 million in the fourth quarter also lends support to that notion.

headline: B&B Direct Changes Its Name to Direct Inc.
abstract: To encourage the appearance of independence, B&B Direct, the direct marketing subsidiary of Benton & Bowles, has changed its name to Direct Inc.    The announcement was made yesterday by John Verdon, president and chief executive, who explained that more than half the agency's $30 million in billings in 1984 came from clients who were not Benton & Bowles clients. He also promised that the unit would get close to $50 million in billings this year.

headline: Low Inflation's Beneficiaries
abstract: MANY analysts believe the currently benign inflation rate - slightly under 4 percent versus nearly 12 percent a few years ago - will continue for some time. This, they say, should provide investment opportunities in disinflationary industries such as chemicals, basic metals, consumer durable goods and pharmaceuticals.    Other experts, however, point out that since the nation has been in a disinflationary climate for the last five years the attractiveness of commodity- based companies may be waning. They contend that better investments may be found in fields such as financial services.

headline: NEW PERIL SEEN FOR ISRAELIS AFTER PULLOUT
abstract: Many authorities and military experts here believe Israeli troops are likely to be faced with more guerrilla attacks, not fewer, after the first stage of their planned phased withdrawal from southern Lebanon.     There has already been a noticeable increase in the past few days in attacks on the Israelis and the local militia forces they set up, most of them in territory they will still be holding after they pull out of the area around Sidon.   The Israeli Government, tired of the disastrous occupation because of the incessant ambushes made largely by militant Shiite Moslems, decided on the withdrawal plan over sharp internal objections.   But if the major goal is to cut down the attacks and the casualties, the withdrawal from Sidon will present several new problems, according to diplomats in Beirut, Western military sources, Lebanese factional leaders and others familiar with the area.

headline: New Brazil Chief in Assurance on Debt
abstract: Brazil's newly elected civilian President, Tancredo Neves, today sought to reassure the international banking community by dismissing leftist calls for a unilateral moratorium on the country's foreign debt payments.    ''A moratorium would resolve none of Brazil's financial problems,'' he said in his first news conference since his election Tuesday. ''It would cause total disarray in the economy. I see no need for it. What we must do is pay what we owe.''

headline: Erbamont Chief Is Out; Head of Unit Gets Post
abstract: Erbamont N.V., a maker of chemotherapy drugs for treating cancer, said that David W. Ortlieb had ''vacated'' his positions as president and chief executive officer.    The company, with offices in Stamford, Conn., is owned by Montedison S.p.A. of Italy.

headline: Salvador Cleric Reports 86 Killed in a Week
abstract: Archbishop Arturo Rivera y Damas of San Salvador said today that 86 people died in political violence last week, eight of them civilians killed by right-wing death squads.   ''The ominous death squads have assassinated eight people, leaving marks of cruelty on their mutilated bodies,'' the prelate said in his weekly homily.   He said the church human-rights organization had reported that another 5 civilians, 61 guerrillas and 12 soldiers died in battles between the army and left-wing rebels.

headline: Safety Rules Called Burden
abstract: A top White House policy adviser has told senior Federal officials that United States health and safety regulations are inhibiting technological development and undermining the ability of American companies to compete in the world market.   Michael A. Driggs, a special assistant to President Reagan for policy development, has recommended that the Administration take additional steps to review and, if possible, reduce Federal regulation in high-technology industries selling new chemicals, pharmaceuticals, pesticides and biotechnology products.    In a cover note accompanying a 32- page report recently submitted to the 11 members of President Reagan's Commission on Industrial Competitiveness, Mr. Driggs said, ''The harsh fact is that health, safety and environmental regulation has come to have a significant unnecessary inhibiting effect on technological innovation in the United States.''

headline: Minnesota Paper Has Had Series Of Crises
abstract: In his cluttered office at The Minneapolis Star and Tribune, a deputy managing editor was describing one legacy of the series of crises the newspaper has endured in the last three years.     ''I don't think everyone is uneasy, but you've got to be ready for anything,'' said A. Hallock Seymour, deputy managing editor for administration. ''You have to enjoy chaos.''    Since 1982, Minnesota's largest newspaper has gone through the merger of the morning Tribune and the afternoon Star into The Star and Tribune, two rounds of layoffs, new leadership in almost all of the paper's top positions, and the removal of John Cowles Jr. as chairman of the Cowles Media Company, which owns the paper. The company's board of directors is dominated by Mr. Cowles's relatives.

headline: People
abstract: *       William H. Croke named executive vice president, director of account services at Stan Merritt Advertising.     *       Howard J. Meditz named executive vice president, director of marketing/account services and a partner in Grossberg Tudanger Meditz Advertising.

headline: GLORY DAYS END FOR PHARMACEUTICALS
abstract: LAST month, the privately held Swiss drug company, Hoffmann-LaRoche, dealt a harsh blow to its American work force: Disappointed by the flow of new products here and preparing for the imminent expiration of its lucrative patent on Valium, the company said it would lay off 1,000 employees, more than 12 percent of its American payroll.   It was a highly unusual move for a company that for years towered well above its competitors. But the meaning was clear: After years of profits so fat that they immunized the $30 billion American pharmaceutical industry against economic downturns, the big drug companies have suddenly found themselves mired in the same sort of troubles that have plagued less-glamorous industries for years. Spiraling imports, legislative changes and new competition at home and abroad have struck hard. And with new blockbuster products harder and harder to come by, America's supremacy as the world's premier maker and seller of prescription drugs could be in jeopardy.    ''The pressure is on us, if we're going to survive at the growth rates we had in the past,'' said John J. Horan, chairman of Merck & Company, one of the world's pacesetting pharmaceutical houses.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Pasta & Cheese to Levy, Flaxman & Associates, for its retail stores and product advertising.

headline: PROTECTING YOUR PENSION-AND SPOUSE
abstract: SINCE January, millions of workers across the country have been receiving notices from their employers asking them to make some tough decisions about retirement benefits. The questions stem from the Retirement Equity Act of 1984, which went into effect for most workers this year.    ''Employees should pay very close attention to the mail they are getting,'' warned Judith F. Mazo, director of research at the Martin E. Segal Company, a New York benefit consulting firm. If employees don't act now to reject certain benefits, Miss Mazo explained, ''they will get lower pensions when they retire.''

headline: A NEW TEAM CHECKS IN AT THE GREAT WALL HOTEL
abstract: PEKINGJohn Kapioltas smiled when someone suggested that the Sheraton Corporation's entry into the hotel business in China was like the cavalry riding in.    ''I wouldn't say we see it quite like that,'' the 57-year-old chairman of the worldwide hotel chain said last week. He was alluding to his company's contract, signed last Monday, to take over management of the Great Wall Hotel, which has failed to draw enough guests to make money.    The $75 million luxury hotel is a prestige project owned jointly by an American company, the E-S Pacific Development and Construction Company, and the Chinese state tourist monopoly, the China International Travel Service. It represents the largest single investment involving American interests since Deng Xiaoping and his fellow reformers in the Communist Party reopened China to foreign equity holdings six years ago.

headline: Reliance Bid For Western The Reliance Financial Services Corporation, which is controlled by Saul P. Steinberg,
abstract: the New York financier, said   that it was prepared to offer $72   a share, or a total of $288 million, for the Western Casualty   and Surety Company.

headline: NORFOLK'S CONRAIL BID GETS LIFT
abstract: The Justice Department today gave its qualified approval of a proposed merger between the Norfolk Southern Corporation and the Consolidated Rail Corporation, a move that appeared to strengthen Norfolk's prospects for being selected by the Government to purchase Conrail.    The other two finalists for Conrail, the Alleghany Corporation and an investment group led by J. Willard Marriott Jr., have no railroad interests, and thus their bids were not reviewed by the Justice Department.    The Justice Department concluded that a merger of Norfolk Southern and Conrail ''would have a significant adverse affect on competition,'' and that it would oppose the plan unless Norfolk sold certain sections of track where the two railroads now competed.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Mar. 18, 1985:

headline: Data Bank;   January 13, 1985
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: New Top Executive For United Telecom
abstract: United Telecommunications Inc. announced yesterday that William T. Esry, an executive vice president and chief financial officer, would become president and chief executive after the company's annual shareholders meeting on April 23.    The announcement of Mr. Esry's appointment was part of a realignment by the top management of United Telecom, a diversified telephone and communications company based in Westwood, Kan. News of the changes was released after a board meeting in Naples, Fla.

headline: Data Bank;   January 6, 1985
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: POLE DENIES APPROVING PLAN TO HURT ACTIVIST PRIEST
abstract: A security policeman on trial here with three subordinates in the killing of a pro-Solidarity priest denied today that he or high-ranking Interior Ministry officials had approved any physical violence against the clergyman.   He said that to have approved such violence would have been inconsistent with ''socialist humanism.''   Instead, the witness, Adam Pietruszka, who was stripped of his colonel's rank after his arrest for aiding and abetting the crime, indicated that it was his chief accuser and co-defendant, Grzegorz Piotrowski, a former captain, who led the abduction and killing of the dissident priest on his own initiative.

headline: Tax-Burden Changes Cited WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -
abstract: Over the last 20 years, total tax   burdens have increased for   lower-income individuals, remained roughly the same or   risen slightly for middle-income earners and declined   sharply for those with the highest incomes, according to a   study published today by the   Brookings Institution.

headline: Sweden Deficit Is Cut
abstract: Sweden's current account deficit narrowed in November to 200 million kronor, or $22 million, from a deficit of 700 million kronor a year earlier, the central bank said today.

headline: MARKET PLACE ;   The Growth Of Schwab
abstract: As founder and chairman of Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount broker, the 47-year-old Mr. Schwab likes to study the habits of investors - 900,000 of whom are customers of his fast-growing firm.    ''Our customer profile shows that 57 percent have been in the market for 10 years, and 60 percent spend five hours a week on their portfolios,'' he said yesterday. ''One out of every two persons has two accounts, one with us and another with a full-commission broker. Our average customer does three trades a year.''

headline: Chinese Plane Crashes; 38 Aboard Are Killed
abstract: A Soviet- built domestic airliner crashed Friday while landing at the Jinan airport in eastern China, aviation authorities said today.

headline: A Switch on Cigarette Tax
abstract: Higher excise taxes on cigarettes may be a step nearer because of a change in position by the American Association of Retired Persons, representing 18 million people, practically all of whom vote. The taxes would be earmarked for Medicare, which provides medical care for those over 65.

headline: U.S. AND JAPAN IN BATTLE TO EXPAND AIR SERVICE
abstract: When American and Japanese negotiators sit down at the bargaining table Monday, the Americans will find themselves in an anomalous position - for a change, they will be the ones defending themselves against charges of closed markets.    The market in question is the sky, and the charges the latest in a long and increasingly acrimonious series of negotiations on aviation rights. Since 1952, when Japan and the United States signed an aviation treaty in the last days of the American occupation, the Japanese have charged that the treaty was heavily weighted in favor of the United States. Negotiations to revise the treaty have gone on continuously for more than 30 years.

headline: PROFITS SCOREBOARDCyanamid$50,800,000
abstract: -8.0       American Petrofina 17,300, 000       -26.1       Asarco Inc. (236,300,000)       -       Capital Cities Commun. 38,200,000       x10.1       E G & G Inc. 13,400,000       x6.3       Emerson Electric Company 92,400,000       x14.6       First Boston Inc. 23,9 00,000       x19.5       Great Northern Nekoosa 24,600,000       -19.3       G. Heileman Brewing 5,800, 000       -46.8       Lone Star Industries 38,500,000       x0.8       Piedmont Aviation 16,1 00,000       x35.3       Revere Copper & Brass 8,600,000       -32.3       Rubbermaid Inc.11,800,000       x10.3       Signal Companies 6 8,000,000       x25.9       Southmark Corporation 23,400,000       x32.2       Stanley Works 22,400,000       x7.7       Tenneco Inc. 130,000,000       -46.1       Textron Inc. 34,500,000       x50.7       United Telecommunications 49,300,000       x14.4    See accompanying notes for special items.  (Loss)

headline: Batus Head to Succeed Retiring Chief Officer
abstract: Henry F. Frigon has been elected chief operating officer of Batus Inc., the company said yesterday.   In addition to Mr. Frigon's election, Batus said that Charles I. McCarty, chairman and chief executive since 1982, would retire at the end of the year. Mr. Frigon, who has been president of Batus since 1980, will succeed Mr. McCarty as chief executive upon his retirement, Batus said.    Batus, based in Louisville, Ky., is the holding and management company for the United States interests of its British parent, B.A.T Industries.

headline: REAGAN CONFERS ON ARMS STAND
abstract: President Reagan and his top foreign policy advisers completed discussions today on the United States position in arms control talks with the Soviet Union next week in Geneva.   Mr. Reagan met for about an hour with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Robert C. McFarlane, the national security adviser, on the estate of the publisher Walter H. Annenberg.

headline: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1985
abstract: Markets         The Fed said that the basic money supply grew slightly faster last year than previously reported, and that growth has continued at a rapid clip. But earlier in the day, the central bank added funds to the banking system. That put downward pressure on short-term interest rates. (Page D1.)         Stock traders took profits after Wednesday's surge to record levels. The Dow Jones industrial average retreated 10.04 points, to 1,287.88, and broader measures also pulled back. Volume continued heavy, at 139.7 million shares. (D6.)

headline: XEROX HAS LOSS
abstract: Philip Morris Inc. reported yesterday that earnings declined 50.6 percent in the fourth quarter of 1984, reflecting the write-down of its Miller Brewing Company facility in Trenton, Ohio,    Philip Morris said that net income in the latest three months dropped to $104.5 million, or 85 cents a share, from $211.4 million, or $1.68 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. The quarterly decline registered by the country's largest cigarette maker was the first in about 16 years.    The write-down of the carrying value of the completed but inactive Miller Brewing facility - originally announced on Nov. 28, 1984 - reduced net earnings by $145.6 million, or $1.19 a share.   Philip Morris said it had written down the carrying value of the Brewery because it could not project an opening date in light of current excess capacity.

headline: CANADIAN LEADER LINKS SPACE-ARMS ROLE TO JOBS
abstract: Canada may consider getting involved in President Reagan's research on a space-based missile defense system if it generates more employment, according to Prime Minister Brian Mulroney.    He spoke during a news conference Saturday in Winnepeg, which has felt the effect of the recession.   ''I suppose, if somebody came forward and said, would we be interested in bidding for a part of a contract which would create, say, 10,000 jobs in Winnepeg-Fort Garry, I think we would have to take a look at it,'' Mr. Mulroney said, referring to the election district in which Winnipeg is situated.

headline: Chicago's Archbishop Voices 'Misgivings' on 'Star Wars'
abstract: Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago tonight expressed ''profound misgivings'' about the Reagan Administration's Strategic Defense Initiative, popularly known as ''Star Wars.''

headline: Mortgage Lending Off
abstract: Mortgage lending by savings institutions fell to $10.2 billion in November, from $11.7 billion in October, and $11.6 billion in November 1983, the United States League of Savings Institutions said.

headline: OHIO THRIFT UNITS MAY REOPEN TODAY
abstract: The Ohio Legislature this morning approved emergency legislation that would permit some of the 70 state-insured savings and loans that were closed Friday to reopen.    Gov. Richard F. Celeste was expected to sign the legislation immediately, and a spokesman for the Governor said some institutions may be allowed to reopen as early as today.    The measure would allow an institution to reopen as soon as it applied for Federal deposit insurance and state banking officials determined that the thrift unit was in strong enough financial shape to qualify for the insurance.    The impact of the crisis spread to international financial markets yesterday and was blamed for a rise of about $36 an ounce in the price of gold and a sharp decline for the dollar. (Page D1.)

headline: Soviet Airliner Crashes; Catastrophe, Paper Says
abstract: A Soviet airliner able to carry as many as 90 passengers crashed near Minsk on Friday, according to reports reaching here today. Officials gave no casualty figures, but a newspaper called it ''a catastrophe.''

headline: PENTAGON BARRING GENERAL ELECTRIC FROM FUTURE JOBS
abstract: The Air Force announced today that it had suspended the General Electric Company from future Pentagon contracts because of the company's indictment earlier this week on charges that it falsified claims and lied to the Government about work on a nuclear warhead system.     The temporary debarment, announced by Air Force Secretary Verne Orr, was the first such action ever taken against a major Defense Department supplier. G.E. is the nation's fourth-largest military contractor.    The Air Force also requested $208 million in voluntary refunds from General Electric and the Pratt & Whitney division of the United Technologies Corporation for making greater-than- expected profits on contracts for supplies of aircraft engine spare parts.         Intensified Crackdown    Today's actions reflect an intensification of the Defense Department's crackdown on the growing problem of its errant contractors. (Page D4.)

headline: Winans Denies Money Offer Prompted a Column
abstract: R. Foster Winans, a former Wall Street Journal reporter, denied in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday that the offer of money was one of the reasons that he wrote a particular column. That contradicted a sworn statement that he gave a year ago.    Mr. Winans, who is on trial with two co-defendants for conspiracy and securities fraud, testified that the possibility of a big payoff from a stockbroker for a positive article about the Digital Switch Corporation ''had absolutely no influence on my news judgment or the news column that appeared.''   This rebutted his sworn statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission that ''it was a factor, yes.'' when he had been asked if the offer of a ''distribution'' of up to $100,000 ''was a factor in your determining to write the article.'' A tape recording of that statement was played in court yesterday.

headline: THE SAFEKEEPING OF ELECTRONIC FILES
abstract: WERE watch fobs to return to vogue again, probably the one most coveted in today's office community would be the security key to I.B.M.'s new AT personal computer. The key, by whose means one can effectively shut down the system, limiting access to the machine to oneself, was in its own way a marketing coup.   In the absence of a watch fob, twirling this key about, or fingering it as if it were a worry stone, has become the latest Yuppie status symbol.   Although purchasing a computer simply to flaunt one's success would obviously be wanton excess, the concept behind the very existence of such a key points up an aspect of personal computing all too often given short shrift in the pell-mell rush to equip the office with the fastest machine and the most feature-filled softwareavailable - namely, the question of security. The concern of security is not only with the physical safety of equipment from theft, but also the safeguarding of information utilized by the machine.

headline: Egypt Cuts Oil Price by 50/
abstract: Egypt, which two weeks ago walked out of the conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, on Friday cut the February price of its benchmark crude oil 50 cents a barrel, to $27.50.   Egypt is not a member of OPEC but has attended meetings and voluntarily cut production to help bolster prices.

headline: ADVERTISING;New Agency for Cliftex
abstract: Chalk, Nissen, Hanft has been chosen by the Cliftex Corporation, a Bedford, Mass., manufacturer of men's and women's tailored apparel. The ad agency puts the billings at $1.25 million. Rubin-Walter handled the account for 10 years.

headline: 'NOTHING TO TALK ABOUT' AFTER FIRST DAY BACK
abstract: For all the furor over Ohio banking, Bunies Stephens was greeted in the usual manner when he entered the Century Savings Bank's Oakley branch here at 11:45 this morning, as one of only two customers at its three teller windows. ''How're you doing today?'' called Amy Whited, one of the tellers. ''Never bad,'' Mr. Stephens replied, as he made a small withdrawal.    The scene at Century Savings, the first privately insured Ohio thrift unit to reopen with full service under emergency legislation, was calm to the point of sleepy today. The quiet was in startling contrast to the panic of the last 10 days that had long lines of worried depositors clamoring to withdraw funds from Ohio's privately insured savings banks. In response to that panic, Gov. Richard F. Celeste declared a banking holiday.

headline: DEBATE OVER INTEREST TRENDS
abstract: The credit markets face a week of heavy supply in both Treasury and tax-exempt securities. The supply of corporate debt issues remains light, and is dominated by a $400 million offering of 30-year debentures of the Eastman Kodak Company.    In addition to today's regular auction of new Treasury bills totaling $14 billion, the Treasury has scheduled a $6.25 billion auction of four-year notes tomorrow, $5.75 billion of seven-year notes on Wednesday and $4.25 billion of 20-year bonds on Thursday. After repayment of maturing issues, the bill auctions will raise about $500 million needed to finance the budget deficit, while the $16.25 billion package will raise nearly $12.9 billion.

headline: Canadian Hostages Freed
abstract: Three Kingston Penitentiary inmates who barricaded themselves in a prison hospital with five hostages have released them all unharmed, officials at Canada's oldest jail said today. The release ended a 16- hour siege at the maximum security prison, which houses 400 convicts. A nurse in the prison hospital was released late Thursday night and the other four hostages were freed this morning, officials said.

headline: Financial Corp.
abstract: The Financial Corporation of America said its evaluation of its loan portfolio had not been completed in the time previously anticipated and it now expects 1984 results to be released by the end of March. The company had earlier said it expected to release the figures by the second half of February. As a result of the evaluation completed so far, ''we have instituted more stringent procedures in the areas of loan documentation, appraisal techniques and underwriting standards,'' William J. Popejoy, chairman, said.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: March 12, 1985 SECURITY COUNCIL   Meets at 10:30 A.M. on complaint by Lebanon.     Meets at 3 P.M. on situation in South Africa.     Special Committee on the Charter - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Intergovernmental Working Group on International Standards of Accounting and Reporting - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.          Committee on Nongovernmental Organizations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: BIG BOARD IN MERGER DISCUSSION
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange confirmed reports yesterday that it had been holding discussions with the Pacific Stock Exchange about ''a possible joint venture that could include a merger of the two stock markets.''     ''Our discussions with the Pacific Stock Exchange have been quite serious,'' said Richard Torrenzano, a vice president and spokesman for the giant New York exchange. ''But no agreement has yet been reached other than to continue the discussions.''

headline: Advertising;   Redbook Increases Ad Budget
abstract: THE management of Hearst   Magazines, which acquired   Redbook two years ago specifically to create a medium to reach the female segment of the baby-boom generation, is now tossing an extra $250,000 into the publication's advertising budget to protect its turf.    And, while the existing budget of $750,000 is being spent in four-color ads in the advertising trade press for the third phase of the ''juggler'' campaign, the new money will be sunk into monthly full back pages in The New York Times in hopes of making an indelible impression that they have ''THE ONE AND ONLY BABYBOOMERBOOK FOR WOMEN.'' The spaceless ''babyboomerbook'' is the latest creative contribution from Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson.    And it was in that agency's well-appointed, lower Fifth Avenue offices yesterday that Alan M. Waxenberg, Redbook publisher, and Richard J. Sarno, associate publisher, ad director and mid-40's Yankee pitcher, displayed the kind of enthusiasm they hope will catch on with advertisers.

headline: 2 SYRIAN HIJACKERS SURRENDER
abstract: Two Syrians being deported from West Germany hijacked a Lufthansa airliner today and forced it to land here. Agents posing as a reporter and a lawyer persuaded the pair to surrender after a five-hour standoff, authorities said.    The eight crew members of the plane were held throughout the five hours, but the 33 passengers had been released earlier, in two groups. The pilot, Roland Lohmeier, said a stewardess was cut on the neck by broken glass and other stewardesses had been threatened with knives.

headline: Andrew on Falkland Mission
abstract: Prince Andrew, who flew helicopter missions in the 1982 Falkland War against Argentina, will return soon to the British islands in the South Atlantic for a five- month tour of duty on naval patrol, the Defense Ministry said today.

headline: SOVIET, VOICING REGRET, BLAMES U.S. FOR SHOOTING IN EAST GERMANY
abstract: The Soviet Union today called the shooting of an American officer in East Germany ''regrettable,'' but placed the entire blame on the American side.   In the first published comment on the incident, the Government press agency Tass said the officer, Maj. Arthur D. Nicholson Jr., was spotted by a sentry taking photographs through the window of a storage building on a restricted Soviet military installation. Tass said the officer was wearing camouflage gear.   ''Acting in strict compliance with military regulations, the sentry demanded in Russian and in German that the stranger stop,'' Tass said. ''When the latter failed to comply and tried to flee, the sentry fired a warning shot into the air. Since the intruder did not stop even after this, the sentry had to use his weapon. He fired and killed the intruder.''

headline: Chiat/Day Scores Two
abstract: Chiat/Day, New York, got a double play Friday. It picked up both the Trump Casino Hotel in Atlantic City and William Grant & Sons, the spirits importer.

headline: Management Shifts at Airbus PARIS, March 4 (AP) -
abstract: Jean Pierson, a senior executive of France's state-owned   aircraft manufacturer, Aerospatiale, has been named to   succeed Bernard Lathi ere as   president of Airbus Industrie,   the European consortium that   produces jetliners.

headline: SENATE, ASSAILING JAPAN, CALLS FOR IMPORT CURBS
abstract: The Senate today passed, 92 to 0, a resolution condemning Japan's ''unfair'' trading practices and calling on President Reagan to retaliate by curbing imports to reduce a $37 billion trade deficit.    Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, said the resolution warns the Japanese that ''there is a fairly strong protectionist attitude here.'' The measure is the chamber's toughest position so far against any trading partner.

headline: Iranian Ship Crippled By Iraqi Jet Attack
abstract: An Iranian bulk carrier, the 18,000-ton Iran-Emdad, was attacked and crippled by an Iraqi jet fighter in the northern Persian Gulf, shipping executives here said today.    The executives said no one was wounded in the attack Friday that hit the stern of the freighter as it was heading with ballast for the Iranian port of Bandar Abbas.

headline: Mitsubishi's U.S. Plans
abstract: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation will increase color television production in the United States by 50 percent, to 600,000 sets, this year, a company spokesman said today.

headline: CANADA'S NUCLEAR MOTHERLODE
abstract: KEY LAKE, Saskatchewan    In this remote outpost 600 miles   north of the United States border,   there appears to be little besides sub-zero cold, driving snow, the odd moose and the much more numerous ravens.   But, underground, there is ura    ''Just make a note,'' said Josef Spross, operations manager for the giant uranium mine here, as he pointed to a large outcropping of steel gray rock. ''This is the richest uranium mine in the world.''    It also is one of the few with a huge customer base - and thus, a seemingly guaranteed   Despite an international glut that has reduced worldwide uranium mining to 70 percent of capacity, Canada has found export markets for 85 percent of its output. Since the richness of its ores makes it the undisputed low-cost producer of uranium, it is expected to hold that leadership spot. ''Nobody has the ability to compete toe to toe with the Canadians,'' said an American trade association official. Indeed, Canada's uranium output has gone from 17.7 million pounds in 1979 to 29.1 million pounds last year - nearly twice United States output.

headline: A 2D BANK IN BOSTON SAYS IT DIDN'T REPORT BIG CASH TRANSFERS
abstract: The Shawmut Bank of Boston, the third-largest bank in Massachusetts, disclosed today that it had failed to report some international cash transactions and had improperly exempted some of its customers from Federal currency-reporting regulations.    In a statement, the Shawmut Bank said it had discovered the errors last month after the Bank of Boston pleaded guilty to failing to report $1.2 billion in cash transfers with Swiss banks and was fined $500,000, a record amount. The Bank of Boston has since also said that it improperly exempted businesses of a local organized crime family from the currency-reporting rules.    In its statement, the Shawmut Bank said it had failed to report $162 million in cash transfers since 1980 with seven foreign banks, including banks in Spain, Portugal, Ireland, Canada and Switzerland. The statement said 27 customers, including schools, churches, hospitals, airlines and commercial companies, had been improperly placed on the bank's list of concerns exempted from the reporting rules. The bank would not identify them except to say they were longtime clients.

headline: Coca-Cola Net Up 4.7% ATLANTA, Feb. 21 (AP) - The Coca-Cola Company said today that its net income rose 4.7 percent in the fourth quarter from a year earlier, when the company had a one-time gain of $4.3 million from discontinued operations.
abstract: The world's largest soft-drink maker said its profit rose to $130.5 million, or $1 a share, in the fourth quarter from $124.6 million, or 91 cents a share, a year earlier.    Revenues rose 2.9 percent, to $1.78 billion, from $1.73 billion a year earlier, Coca-Cola said.

headline: VOLCHER VIEW ON CURRENCY
abstract: The Federal Reserve's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, suggested today that some type of fresh, coordinated action by governments would be desirable to reduce gyrations in the currency markets.    Although Mr. Volcker did not outline such a plan and did not indicate he favored any immediate steps, he was understtood to be referring to intervention by central banks.   European central banks have intervened heavily on occasion since late February. The United States, by contrast, has made small sales of dollars as a token contribution to the effort because the Reagan Administration is philosophically opposed to intervention.

headline: Control Data
abstract: The Control Data Corporation plans to introduce three computers later this month with memories four times larger than current models.

headline: Panama Meeting Held To Discuss Peace Plan
abstract: Four Latin American foreign ministers opened a two-day meeting here today to discuss objections by some Central American countries to a regional peace plan.   Panama's Foreign Minister, Fernando Cardoze, predicted that the five Central American nations that the proposal is intended to cover would eventually agree to the plan put forth by his country and the three other mediators, but he said success depended on their own good will.

headline: Data Bank;   March 24, 1985
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: Chevron-Gulf
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission gave the Chevron Corporation the go- ahead to complete its $13.3 billion merger with the Gulf Oil Corporation.

headline: Largest Shareholder Will Be Itel's Chairman
abstract: The Itel Corporation yesterday named Samuel Zell, its largest shareholder, as chairman, to succeed Herbert Kunzel. The change will take place after the annual meeting on April 18.    Mr. Kunzel led Itel during one of the largest and most complicated reorganizations to avoid bankruptcy in United States corporate history. The 76-year-old executive has been chairman since 1982. He had been a director since the previous year.

headline: I.R.S. RELAXING RULES ON USE OF CARS FOR BUSINESS
abstract: Under pressure from business people and Congressional leaders, the Internal Revenue Service announced today that it was relaxing its record-keeping requirements for some taxpayers who drive company cars or drive their own cars on business.    Under the new rules, many people who use the cars only incidentally on personal matters would not have to keep detailed ledgers documenting each trip.  Salesmen and others who drive partly for business and partly for other reasons would still have to keep careful records.    Last year, Congress passed a law intended to insure that taxpayers pay taxes on the value of their personal use of company cars and that they did not take excessive deductions for the business use of their own cars.

headline: HOSPITAL SUPPLIERS STRIKE BACK
abstract: Several years ago, Abbott Laboratories, one    of the nation's leading hospital suppliers,   landed a large contract to sell intravenous pumps to a medical group in Texas.   ''They said the reason we won the contract was that we had the highest-priced product,'' said Charles J. Aschauer, an executive vice president at Abbott. Concerned that health-care costs were skyrocketing to unsustainable levels, Mr. Aschauer remembers how uneasy he felt about the stated reason for his company's victory. ''When you saw that happen, you knew something had to give someday,'' he said.   And indeed it did - with a vengeance. The nation's health-care industry is now being rocked by a revolution, begun in late 1983, that is drastically changing the way Americans are being treated for everything from cataracts to hardening of the arteries. And nowhere is the economic fallout more visible than in the hospital-supply business, which is groping for ways to dig itself out from one of its worst years on record.

headline: New Assignments For Three Agencies
abstract: A number of agencies were in the pleasurable position of announcing new assignments yesterday.    Bozell & Jacobs was celebrating the landing of a piece of Texas Instruments business that could amount to $20 million in billings.

headline: Suspect in Kidnapping Is Said to Flee Mexico
abstract: A Mexican suspected in the kidnapping of a United States drug agent left Mexico over the weekend with the help of Mexican police officers, an American official said today.   The official, Francis M. Mullen Jr., head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, identified the man as Rafael Caro-Quintero.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Feb. 21, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on Non-Use of Force - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: THE LORDS ARE ON CAMERA, LIVE AND QUITE LIVELY
abstract: The House of Lords - live, from Parliament - had its world television premiere today. It was five hours long.     The broadcast, the first live coverage of a parliamentary debate here, marked the beginning of a six-month experiment that the unelected chamber agreed to try last November. No cameras have ever been allowed in the House of Commons.

headline: Two Vice Presidents Promoted by Conoco
abstract: Conoco Inc., the nation's 13th-largest oil company, announced the promotion of two division vice presidents as part of a realignment of its petroleum operations.    Archie W. Dunham, a 19-year company veteran, will assume the new post of executive vice president for petroleum products on April 1, and Colin H. Lee, who joined Conoco in 1960, will become executive vice president for supply and international refining and marketing on May 1.

headline: Advertising;   Competing Brands Of TV
abstract: WHEN advertisers and agencies deal with the video media, said Susan Gianinno, a candidate for a Ph.D. in developmental psychology, they are no longer dealing with a commodity category but rather with one made up of brands that compete for attention and loyalty.    And those brands are regular television, cable television and public television. By the very act of selecting one of them, she said, the viewer makes a statement about himself that gives the advertiser a clue on how best to reach him with a message.    Mrs. Gianinno, senior vice president and director of creative research at Young & Rubicam, said that at her agency awareness had grown of a factor that is gaining importance in reaching today's consumer. She calls it ''value level communication,'' which is a commercial's ''ability to communicate a sensitivity to, or understanding of, the consumer's personal values.''

headline: Caterpillar Sees Progress on Cuts
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said in its new annual report that it was ahead of schedule in meeting its goal of cutting costs by 21 percent from 1981 levels. The company, based in Peoria, Ill., originally set 1986 as the deadline, but now said it would reach the goal this year.

headline: New Chief At Storage
abstract: The Storage Technology Corporation yesterday named Ryal R. Poppa, an experienced corporate turnaround specialist, as its new chairman and chief executive. Storage Technology filed last Oct. 31 for protection from its creditors under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE: 1984'S NEWSMAKERS IN FINANCE ;   Regan on Defensive Over Tax Proposal
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan has been on the offensive most of the year against the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker. But he found the tables turned recently when he presented his proposal to overhaul the nation's tax system.   Repeatedly in the last year, Mr. Regan has blamed many of the country's economic woes on Mr. Volcker. The Fed chairman's ''penurious, remarkably tight'' management of the nation's money supply has been slowing economic growth, the Treasury Secretary contended.

headline: ISRAEL PLANS NEW SETTLEMENTS
abstract: Sites for six new Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank were approved today by the Government, an Israel official involved in the decision said.    They would be the first such settlements to be established in the West Bank since the Government of national unity took office in September.   Officials said two of the approved sites are in the northern part of the West Bank, two in the Hebron area and one each in the Jordan Valley and the Jerusalem area.

headline: LAND OFFER UNSETTLES TRIBE IN MEXICO
abstract: In this small, gritty village 80 miles south of the border, where the loudest sound is the gurgling of a crystalline brook, the Texas band of Kickapoo Indians is keeping its secret winter traditions alive.    The mountain village, isolated by a bone-jarring 20-mile drive from the nearest paved road, is neither Mexican nor American in nature. Wood cooking fires burn in the small, oval huts made of saplings with straw mats on the floors. Water is drawn from efficient- looking concrete wells that dot the settlement. Pickup trucks are parked next to the oval huts of the 200-year-old tribe.

headline: SOUTH LEBANON BATTLES WIDEN
abstract: Ten days of clashes between Christian and Moslem forces around Sidon in southern Lebanon widened today to involve Palestinians in two refugee camps in that area.    The latest fighting broke out between Christian militiamen in the village of Mieh Mieh and Palestinians in a neighboring camp of the same name, local radio stations reported.

headline: U.N. Chief in Singapore
abstract: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said today that Hanoi wants a ''peaceful and negotiated settlement'' to the Cambodian problem but remains far from the positions of the regions's non-Communist countries. Mr. Perez de Cuellar conferred last week with officials from Vietnam, Laos and Thailand about restoring peace in Cambodia.

headline: A.M.C. Layoffs
abstract: The American Motors Corporation said it planned to cut daily car production at its Kenosha, Wis., assembly plant by 15 percent and place 600 hourly workers on indefinite layoff, effective Monday. The company said the steps were part of an effort to reduce inventories in the face of weak sales of subcompact cars.

headline: Olin Paper Deal
abstract: The Olin Corporation said that it had agreed to sell its Ecusta cigarette paper and fine printing paper business for $130 million in a leveraged buyout to a group to be organized by the First Boston Corporation.

headline: Pan Am In Accord With Pilots
abstract: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with its pilots' union for a new contract.   The settlement greatly enhances Pan Am's chances of averting a strike by the Transport Workers Union, which has set a deadline of midnight tonight to reach an agreement. A strike could damage Pan Am's bookings ahead of the important summer tourist season.

headline: Blacks Boycott Classes In Johannesburg Area
abstract: Thousands of black students boycotted classes today after a weekend of riots left six people dead and at least 79 under arrest.   About 20,000 pupils stayed away from 39 schools this morning but a Government spokesman said others showed up for classes at seven other schools around Johannesburg.

headline: Austrian Defense Chief Censured by Chancellor
abstract: Austria's Chancellor publicly censured his Defense Minister today for meeting and escorting a returning Nazi war criminal who had been freed from an Italian prison.   Chancellor Fred Sinowatz said the Defense Minister's meeting with Walter Reder, a former Nazi SS officer convicted of leading a massacre of at least 600 Italians in the village of Marzabotto, was a ''serious political mistake.''

headline: Israeli Soldier Killed
abstract: An Israeli soldier was killed today in an exchange of fire with Lebanese Army troops, the military command here said.   A communique said the soldier belonged to a force that had pursued suspected guerrillas and had been attacked by a Lebanese Army force stationed in Kuthariyat as- Siyad, a villlage more than a mile inside territory restored to Lebanon Feb. 16.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Massachusetts Electric In $114 Million Offer
abstract: The Massachusetts Municipal Wholesale Electric Company, a seller of electricity to 28 municipally owned utilities in the state, is offering about $114 million of speculative rated, long-term bonds through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.    For $57 million of 13 5/8 percent bonds due in 2017, underwriters set a tentative price of 99 1/4 to yield 13.72 percent and for $57 million of 13 percent bonds due in 2018 the tentative price was 95 1/2 to yield 13.62 percent.

headline: CBS OFFICIAL IS GIVEN ISRAELI ACCOUNT OF CAMERAMEN'S DEATHS
abstract: A vice president of CBS News, Ernest Leiser, met today with senior Israeli officials and said he received a detailed explanation of how two CBS cameramen were killed by an Israeli tank shell in Lebanon last week.   Mr. Leiser met for two hours at the Prime Minister's office with Uri Savir, the spokesman for Prime Minister Shimon Peres, and Lieut. Col. Raanan Gissin, from the Israel Defense Force spokesman's office.   Mr. Leiser said in an interview after the meeting that ''if the Israel Defense Force account is to be believed, the shooting could have been a tragic mistake.''   He added: ''The Israeli tank crew could have been far enough away so that they could not have identified the cameramen. However, the Israeli account does not jibe with what we were told, and are continuing to hear, from witnesses in Lebanon, who said that the Israeli tank commander could easily see that the CBS car was a press car, with a press crew, and that no shooting was coming from around them.''

headline: PERU'S CATHOLICS AWAIT POPE'S VISIT
abstract: Pope John Paul II arrives here Friday and is expected to discuss his views on the teachings known as liberation theology.     It is an issue that is of particular interest in Peru, where the country's 53 bishops are at odds over the theology. In addition, a foremost exponent of the theology and a man widely regarded as its founder, the Rev. Gustavo Gutierrez, is a Peruvian.

headline: Some Monday Closings
abstract: Some New York banks may be closed, and the markets in Government securities will be shut, on Monday because of the observance in New York State of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., which was Jan. 15. Stock exchanges will be open as usual.

headline: Court Backs Sharing of State Antitrust Immunity
abstract: Two Supreme Court decisions today clarified the extent to which a state's immunity from antitrust suits also protects local governments and private enterprises that carry out state policies.    The decisions, representing the Court's clearest statements in a particularly confused area of antitrust law, were likely to be welcomed by both local governments and private business. The Court permitted the antitrust defendants in both cases - a Wisconsin city and an association of truck companies - to share their respective states' antitrust immunity.

headline: U.S. and Laos to Search For Missing Americans
abstract: The United States announced today that it would conduct a joint excavation with Laos from Feb. 10 to Feb. 21 of the site where a United States C-130 cargo plane crashed in southern Laos after it was shot down in December 1972.

headline: Inflation Rate 5% in Britain
abstract: Britain's annual inflation rate rose to 5 percent in January, an increase from the December rate of 4.6 percent, the Government reported Friday.    Employment Minister Tom King dismissed the rise as a short-term fluctuation and said cold weather pushing up prices of fresh fruit and vegetables was largely to blame.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA'S IRON HAND
abstract: After weeks of talk of racial ''reform'' from white officials, the familiar images of South Africa's recent history have reasserted themselves: the police firing on black demonstrators in a crowded squatter camp; the 3 A.M. rap at a flimsy door by a security operative come to search a home and detain those opposed to white rule.    Sixteen people are now reported to have died in the police action in the Crossroads squatter camp outside Cape Town on Monday and six black activists face treason charges after their arrest on Tuesday.   South Africa seemed to be showing that the sinews of raw, white power remain as taut as they were before the advent of ''constructive engagement,'' the Reagan Administration's policy of bringing about racial changes through diplomatic persuasion instead of confrontation.        Arrests Are Protested    The debate, as far as United States policy makers are concerned, centers on whether the Government's harsh tactics, so reminiscent of Sharpeville in 1960 and Soweto in 1976, reflect the uncertainties and anxieties that, historically, have surrounded efforts at easing the state's racial policy.

headline: Careers;   Courses Offered in Recycling
abstract: FEW college graduates think of   career paths in the junk business. Yet in almost every sizable town there is a junkyard that sends along old cars, bathtubs, metal parts and other waste material to a technially sophisticated and sometimes prosperous recycler.    Indeed, at a time when disposing of waste has reached crisis proportions in some areas, recycling has become a big business nationwide.

headline: NORTHEASTERN AIR CHAPTER 11 FILING
abstract: Northeastern International Airlines, which got its start three years ago offering low-cost fares between Long Island and Florida, filed yesterday for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.     Airport officials at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where the airline has its headquarters, said the carrier had suspended many of its flights, leaving hundreds of passengers stranded at the airport.    Calls to the company's headquarters were answered by a recording that said the phones had been disconnected.    Jack Barker, a public relations officer for the Federal Aviation Administration, said that Stephen L. Quinto, the president of the airline, had told him that Northeastern planned to keep operating three Boeing 727's and fly 16 daily trips to Philadelphia, Midway Airport at Chicago, and MacArthur Airport on Long Island, and to four cities in Florida: Orlando, West Palm Beach. St. Petersburg and Fort Lauderdale.

headline: PATENTS ;   System to Protect Offshore Oil Rigs
abstract: A Japanese engineer has designed a protection system for offshore oil drilling rigs anchored in hazardous ice-bound waters. Patent No. 4,505,618, designed by Nobuyoshi Yashima of Funabashi, Japan, was financed jointly by the Atlantic Richfield Company of Los Angeles and the Mitsui Engineering and Shipbuilding Company of Tokyo.

headline: New Digital Model
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation, making another bid to bolster its presence in the personal computer market, introduced an enhanced version of its Rainbow personal computer. In introducing the Rainbow 190, Digital said it would concentrate its personal computer efforts on the office environment, and not on selling individual machines through retail channels, where the company struggled. The Rainbow 190 costs $6,495, has 640,000 characters of basic memory and a 10 million-character storage disk and will be available in July, Digital said.

headline: Texas Air Makes Debenture Offer
abstract: The Texas Air Corporation is offering $30 million of 10 percent exchangeable subordinated debentures due in 2005 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

headline: REAGAN ASSERTS SANDINISTAS USE 'STALIN'S TACTIC'
abstract: President Reagan accused the Nicaraguan Government today of using ''Stalin's tactic'' in relocating thousands of citizens who he said ''do not support their tyrannical regime.''    Mr. Reagan was referring to recent reports that the Government had been moving residents out of their homes in the north of Nicaragua, where fighting has been under way between Government troops and United States-backed rebels. The object, according to Sandinista officials and Western diplomats in Managua quoted in the reports, is to deny the rebels material support and intelligence from sympathizers, and to allow the creation of ''free-fire zones'' where the army can operate without fear of harming civilians.    The President, speaking here before a group of about 100 merchants, businessmen and others from Central American countries, also charged that the Sandinista Government had attempted to ''dwarf and bully'' its neighbors.

headline: PRODUCT QUALITY: PROFITABLE AT ANY COST
abstract: QUALITY is free. This simple gospel has been spreading in recent years at many of America's best known companies, such as I.B.M. and General Motors, have recognized quality's competitive potential.   The proponents of this new doctrine begin with the idea that most companies incur large and unnecessary costs because they fail to do things right the first time. A manufacturing process that is error-free would avoid a multitude of expenses. Efforts to reduce manufacturing defects and to improve product reliability will almost invariably lead to a reduction in a company's costs. It is in this sense that quality is said to be free.

headline: THE COMPUTER;  THE HOME ROBOT IS STILL IN TODDLER STAGE
abstract: The star of the show in the middle of Stephen Iavarone's living room is singing ''America.'' The pitch is off and the projection is lacking, but then the singer is only 19 inches tall and about the size of a portable vacuum cleaner. The audience, Mr. Iavarone's family, is appreciative.   The performer is a robot, the Hero Junior, one of several that are available for use in the home as an educational tool, a helping hand around the house and a toy. A common sight on factory assembly lines, robots for the home have been available to consumers for about two years.

headline: A Busy Reaction on the Big Board
abstract: The two companies whose merger came undone Monday were the two most actively traded today.    Shares of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, which led the New York Stock Exchange's list with 3.7 million shares changing hands, fell $1.825 in today's trading, to $18.125, as money managers and professional Wall Street traders reacted to the announcement after the close of the Big Board on Monday that its $3.3 billion merger agreement with the Occidental Petroleum Company had been canceled.   The decline was less than expected. Shamrock's stock had dropped to $17.125 in third-market trading late Monday, and it had traded below $18 before the merger rumors circulated last Friday.

headline: A SOBERED U.S. HOME FIGHTS TO REBUILD ITS FORTUNES
abstract: HOUSTON LAST July, when the U.S. Home Corporation auctioned off 108    houses and condominiums, some 500 people turned up in a windowless hotel ballroom here, lured by the prospect of big bargains.    Their instincts were right. Many of the homes had been on sale for 7 to 15 months and that translated into big price cuts. A 2,900-square-foot house with an original price of $149,950 attracted a top bid of $86,500. A two-bedroom condominium that originally sold for $52,950 went for $31,000. In a housing market staggered by a depressed oil industry, the average house sold for 61 percent of its retail price.

headline: Czech Plan to Pay Debt
abstract: Czechoslovakia expects to pay its foreign debts in full by the end of the year, Prime Minister Lubomir Strougal told Parliament today. Western analysts put the debt at between $2.7 billion and $3 billion.

headline: Briton Ends Nicaragua Trip
abstract: Neil Kinnock, the leader of the opposition Labor Party, returned today from a visit to Nicaragua urging that Britain increase its aid to that country and calling on President Reagan to end United States support for right-wing rebels there.

headline: ASSESSING TECHNOLOGY LEAKS
abstract: Two years ago, a group of Boy Scouts walking along the beach in the State of Washington spotted a red-and- white sphere bobbing in the water. On its sides, written in Russian and English, was the phrase ''USSR Academy of Sciences,'' suggesting that it was an innocuous research buoy.   But when military investigators examined the sphere's innards, they concluded that it had a more sinister purpose. It was actually a military sonobuoy that had been dropped offshore, the investigators say, to eavesdrop on Trident missile submarines based in nearby Bremerton.    Moreover, the acoustic buoy appeared to have been copied from American designs and electronic components. It even contained an extraneous screw, threaded the wrong way, that served no purpose whatever but was identical to the extraneous screws an American designer had used as a ''signature.''

headline: ADVERTISING ;   Accounts
abstract: * Catholic Digest magazine to Decker, Decker & Freas.

headline: BOND PRICES DECLINE SHARPLY
abstract: A weeklong trend toward higher interest rates in the credit markets accelerated yesterday, with bond prices opening the new year by tumbling sharply.     The decline was aggravated, analysts said, by the large new supply of Treasury notes and bonds this week in a relatively thin market. With the Federal Government running up ever-increasing budget deficits and another Treasury auction scheduled for today - $4.25 billion of 20-year bonds will be sold - the prospect is for the market to remain under some pressure in the near term, analysts said.    ''The market is having difficulty absorbing all the new supply,'' said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist for Drexel Burnham Lambert. ''The weight of all that supply is going to keep pressure on the market.''

headline: Philips ECG Sets Layoffs Upstate SENECA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP) - Philips ECG Inc. will lay off about 400 workers in Seneca Falls next month as it consolidates its manufacturing of color television picture tubes in Ohio, the company said..
abstract: Philips ECG will continue to employ about 900 people locally in corporate headquarters and in the manufacturing of color data-display tubes, such as those used with computers, Mary Monnet, a spokesman, said.

headline: Baghdad Reports Exchanges Of Artillery Fire With Iranians
abstract: Iraqi gunners scored ''direct and effective hits'' on ''defeated'' Iranian soldiers today along a 120-mile stretch of desert separating the two warring countries, according to an Iraqi war communique.

headline: Market Place ;   Diverse Views Of Du Pont
abstract: Shares of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company finished 1984 at 49 1/2, after dropping 4.8 percent for the year. But yesterday the stock of the nation's largest chemical producer sold at 54 1/2, its highest price in 13 months. On the New York Stock Exchange, Du Pont closed at 53 7/8, down 3/8.    This improvement reflects some recent favorable opinions on Wall Street regarding Du Pont and other basic chemical companies - a group that has suffered from a variety of problems. Also, chemical stocks have benefited recently from the vastly improved performance of the overall equity market. This is a sort of ''a rising tide lifts all ships'' response.

headline: Dealer Denies Financial Woes
abstract: Landmark Government Securities, a 12-year-old dealer in government securities, yesterday denied market rumors that it was in financial difficulty.    After E.S.M. Government Securities in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was closed early this month, government securities dealers said they had been reviewing their customers and business procedures, but none cited the Austin, Tex., company as a source of trouble.

headline: Eastern-CF Pact
abstract: Eastern Airlines said that it would expand its passenger and freight service in an agreement with CF Air Freight Inc., a unit of Consolidated Freightways, and that the new service would enable the carrier to offer ''significantly reduced passenger fares.''
