Russell L. Ray, a senior vice president of Eastern, said that the service would increase night flights between Houston and nine other cities. One airline analyst said that the freight carried could pay for the fuel and labor of the flights, enabling Eastern to offer very low fares to such destinations as San Francisco and Los Angeles.

headline: Arms Negotiator Named
abstract: President Reagan nominated Robert Blackwill, a career Foreign Service officer, today as the American representative at negotiations in Vienna on reducing nonnuclear forces in Central Europe. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Blackwill will succeed Maynard Glitman, who is negotiating at the American- Soviet talks in Geneva on medium- range missile forces.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: Ameritrust Corp.  filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of up to $200 million of senior subordinated debt.     *       Arizona Bancwest Corp.  filed for an offering of $35 million of floating rate subordinated capital notes, due 1997, through Salomon Brothers Inc.     *       Comcast Corp.  filed for an offering of $40 million of convertible subordinated debentures, due 2010, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

headline: CHURCHES ON CUTTING EDGE OF THE APARTHEID BATTLE
abstract: At a recent mass meeting in Soweto at which the intent was overtly political, the proceedings were opened by a black cleric who offered, amid the clenched-fist salutes and cries of ''Amandla!'' or ''Power!'' a prayer for ''those who subvert the system.''    There was singing, too, by church choirs that mingled with other chants - a rhythmic roll call of black martyrs that invoked the names of Oliver Tambo and Nelson Mandela and other exiled or imprisoned leaders of the outlawed African National Congress.   A week later in Pretoria, in a separate context that reflected a similar blend of religion and politics, the state dropped charges against a Roman Catholic Archbishop, Denis Hurley, who had been accused of contravening the law by criticizing a police unit that was said to have committed atrocities in South-West Africa.   For more than two decades, most of South Africa's churches have moved ever closer to the cutting edge of confrontation with the state, as represented by the National Party Government of President P. W. Botha and its predominantly Afrikaner supporters.

headline: Texas Utilities Rating Change
abstract: For the third time in a little more than a year, Texas Utilities Electric, a unit of the Texas Utilities Company, has been given a lower debt rating by Standard & Poor's. Until late February 1984, when S.&P. made its first reduction, the company was one of the few utilities in the country whose bonds were rated AAA.

headline: REMAINING OHIO UNITS TO REOPEN
abstract: For the first time since Gov. Richard F. Celeste ordered 71 privately insured savings and loan institutions closed 10 days ago, all will be reopened for at least partial withdrawals on Monday, state banking officials said today.     Thirteen of the closed thrift institutions were given clearance over the weekend to reopen on a full-service basis on Monday. That brings to 18 the total number of thrift units that will be operating on an unrestricted basis. All of the 18 have either received or applied for Federal insurance, a condition required for reopening; one has merged into another institution.

headline: China Opens 109 New Places To Trips by Foreign Visitors
abstract: China said today that it would allow foreigners into 109 more cities and counties.

headline: EFFECTS OF DROP IN OIL PRICES
abstract: THE animosity among the oil ministers at the   emergency meeting of the Organization of   Petroleum Exporting Countries in Geneva has been leaking out. Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba of the United Arab Emirates, head of OPEC's market monitoring committee, accused Nigeria of ''stabbing OPEC in the back'' by exceeding its production quota.    Thus has it ever been when cartels, whether in oil or drugs, lumber or concrete, lose control of a market. The weakest members then covertly cut prices or produce more than their quota.

headline: URUGUAY INSTALLS CIVILIAN PRESIDENT
abstract: Julio Maria Sanguinetti took office as the elected President of Uruguay today, restoring this country's long democratic tradition after 12 years of military rule.     The inauguration also underscored the trend toward democracy throughout Latin America: Uruguay became the eighth country in the region to pass from military to civilian government since 1979.    Mr. Sanguinetti, a 49-year-old lawyer with centrist political views, immediately pledged that government by fiat ''will not happen again because all Uruguayans will turn democracy into our great national cause.''        Foreign Dignitaries Present    The new President was sworn in before Congress and an array of foreign dignitaries, including the Presidents of Argentina, Bolivia, Colombia, Costa Rica, Guatemala and Nicaragua and the Prime Ministers of Spain and Italy.

headline: Iraqi Planes Said to Raid 'Naval Target' in Gulf
abstract: Iraqi jet fighters ''scored a direct hit on a large naval target'' near Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal today and returned safely to base, an Iraqi military spokesman announced in a communique read over the state television.   In Iraqi military parlance, a ''large naval target'' usually indicates an oil tanker.

headline: I.R.S. CRACKING DOWN ON MANY TAX SHELTERS
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service rarely gives hints as to what tax return items automatically raise red flags for its auditors, hoping the secrecy will keep all taxpayers cautious. But the I.R.S. has made no secret of its escalating war against tax shelters.    Using new weapons obtained from Congress last summer, along with its own stockpile of enforcement measures, the I.R.S. is attacking investors in questionable tax shelter schemes. And taxpayers who manage to escape the I.R.S. assault will find their tax shelter deductions have been cut back by Congress in other ways.    Taxpayers who have invested in what are suspected as being ''abusive'' shelters may well feel the wrath of the I.R.S. coming to bear even before their return is audited - or even before their return is filed.

headline: United Airlines' Parent Posts 19.4% Profit Rise
abstract: UAL Inc., the parent of United Airlines, had earnings of $67 million, or $1.76 a share, in the fourth quarter last year, up 19.4 percent from earnings of $56.1 million, or $1.54 a share, in the fourth quarter the previous year.    Revenues for the quarter totaled $1.67 billion, up slightly from $1.66 billion the year before.

headline: ARGENTINE PRESIDENT IS HONORED
abstract: President Raul Alfonsin of Argentina said in New York yesterday that the United States cannot expect Latin American nations to share its national security concerns unless they have political democracies of their own to defend.   When the United States applies these national security criteria to its relations with Western Europe, that is a view Europeans can understand and support because they have freedom and prosperity, too, he said.   ''To achieve security it is necessary that one have the desire to defend something that he already has,'' the Argentine leader said. ''But what meaning can there be for the majority of a population in defending a freedom it does not enjoy or a prosperity it does not have?''

headline: People
abstract: *       Ernest A. Brown will join Lou Beres & Associates, Advertising as executive vice president and general manager.

headline: Helicopter Case Report
abstract: The United States Customs Service had intelligence information that could have prevented the illegal shipments of more than 80 American-made helicopters to North Korea, according to an internal report by Commerce Department officials investigating the shipments.   A Commerce official familiar with the investigation said today that, according to the report, the Customs Service received intelligence information about North Korea's plans to obtain the helicopters in September 1983 but did not make it available to export authorities at Commerce.

headline: PRODUCER PRICES DECLINE 0.1%
abstract: Producer prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent in February despite a jump in fruit and vegetable costs, the Labor Department said today.    The decline, the first since a dip of the same amount in October, was attributed to the largest fall in energy prices in almost two years and to lower prices for meat, fish and poultry.   Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, noted that wholesale prices have risen just seven-tenths of 1 percent in the last 12 months, which he called ''a remarkable achievement as far as holding down inflation.'' He added, ''Producer price inflation remains at rock bottom.''

headline: ICAHN GETS DREXEL AID ON PHILLIPS
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the financier, said yesterday he had accepted commitments from his investment bankers, Drexel Burnham Lambert, to provide $1.5 billion of the funds he needs to buy the Phillips Petroleum Company in his $8.1 billion takeover bid.    The funds, raised in the last 24 hours, according to Mr. Icahn, came from unidentified ''financial institutions.'' Sources friendly to Phillips have suggested that these institutions may include savings and loan associations, possibly placing depositors' money at risk.

headline: 3 FRENCHMEN LINKED TO INDIAN SPY CASE
abstract: Indian investigators were reported today to have implicated at least three French nationals in an extensive espionage ring that purportedly passed sensitive military information to the West.    Disclosures about the spy ring have shaken the Government here and led to the resignation of one of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's top advisers, as well as the arrest of more than a dozen Indian officials and businessmen.    Prime Minister Gandhi first disclosed the existence of the espionage operation last Friday, but since then he and his aides have refused to give out details on an official basis.

headline: ARMS TALKS: THE RECORD SO FAR;   Major Developments Since 1970
abstract: March 5, 1970. Treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons is ratified.  Sept. 30, 1972. First agreement on limiting strategic arms is ratified.

headline: FOR MAYAS OF GUATEMALA, CALAMITY STRIKES AGAIN
abstract: To an outsider it appears to be sadness, sharpened by fear, that lines the faces of Indian peasants who can be seen bent double under loads of firewood and dried corn in the highlands of Guatemala, where the horse and wheeled vehicles are still luxuries.    The Indians backed the losing side in a bitter guerrilla war here and have paid the cost. As the Guatemalan Army mops up the remnants of Marxist rebel units in its fourth year of a major counterinsurgency drive, the peasant villagers of the region are trying to rebuild their shattered lives.   ''They will pretend any boss is a good guy,'' said a relief worker who has dealt with the Indians of northern Quiche Province in recent months. ''What they're doing right now is surviving.''

headline: FINAL STATEMENTS ARE MADE IN POLISH MURDER TRIAL
abstract: The key defendant in the trial of four state security men made his final statement today, stressing his Communist ideals while accepting qualified guilt for the slaying of a pro-Solidarity priest.    The defendant, Grzegorz Piotrowski, who is the only one of the four facing a possible death penalty, asked clemency for two others, Waldemar Chmielewski and Leszek Pekala, when sentence is pronounced Thursday.    Earlier, the two wept as they made short statements of their own, declaring their guilt and asking leniency.

headline: U.S. ISSUES GUIDELINES ON 'VERTICAL' ACCORDS
abstract: The Justice Department issued guidelines today that are intended to clarify what kinds of arrangements between manufacturers and distributors the antitrust division regards as lawful.     J. Paul McGrath, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division, said the guidelines amounted to a blanket assurance that the department ''will not challenge vertical practices used by firms with less than a 10 percent market share.'' The term ''vertical practices'' refers to relationships between sellers and their business customers, such as restrictive sales or exclusive purchase agreements.

headline: Young Entrepreneur Taps College Market
abstract: Many young people experience a major outbreak of the entrepreneurial spirit during their college days.   Stephen R. Edelen, now 24, had an outbreak while at the University of Colorado and while a member of the class of '82 at Georgetown.

headline: Texas Instruments Off
abstract: Texas Instruments Inc. yesterday reported a 16.6 percent decline in net income for the fourth quarter.

headline: THE AUTO INDUSTRY'S BIG YEAR
abstract: American consumers bought a total of 14.1 million cars and light trucks in 1984, giving the automobile industry its best sales year since 1979.    Although total sales fell below the peaks set in the mid-1970's, the robust year should produce record- setting profits for the Big Three auto makers, which are expected to report combined earnings of about $10 billion.   That sum would easily surpass the previous record of $6.15 billion set last year and is well above the $4.5 billion earned in 1978, when total car and truck sales reached 15 million. Even allowing for inflation, $10 billion in profits for last year would be appreciably lusher than the 1978 earnings.

headline: POLITBURO MEMBER AND DELEGATION ABRUPTLY CURTAIL VISIT TO THE U.S.
abstract: A Soviet Politburo member, Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky, unexpectedly cut short the American visit of his Soviet delegation today and planned to return to Moscow on Monday, State Department officials said tonight.    The abrupt and unexplained announcement provoked immediate speculation in the Administration tonight that Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, had either died or was incapacitated.    If a successor were being named, Mr. Shcherbitsky would be needed in Moscow to attend an emergency meeting of the Politburo, which is the policy- making organ of the Soviet Communist Party.          Analysts Are Summoned    Senior officials in the European bureau of the State Department and intelligence analysts were summoned to the State Department tonight. One official said Western monitors had noted that Soviet radio stations had begun to play serious classical music, which in the past has been an indication that a high official has died.

headline: Thomson McKinnon Censure
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had censured Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. in connection with its stock- loan program.   Brokerage houses such as Thomson McKinnon are allowed to lend, for a fee, the shares that people buy on margin.

headline: RESTAURANT CHAIN CHIEF RESIGNS
abstract: Diversifoods Inc., which has been in turmoil since October, said today that its chief executive was leaving the company at the request of the board and that the fourth-quarter dividend was being omitted.    Donald N. Smith is stepping down both as chief executive and president. He led an investor group that included other senior managers and Allen & Company, a New York investment firm. The group proposed a leveraged buyout of the company in October.

headline: SECOND ABDUCTOR OF POLISH PRIEST SAYS ORDER CAME 'FROM THE TOP'
abstract: The second of three former security officers who have admitted killing the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko testified today that their leader had been authorized ''from the top'' to proceed even if the pro-Solidarity priest appeared to be dying.   As the trial resumed, the defendant, Waldemar Chmielewski, offered his testimony in a stammer that he said had developed since his arrest.    Like Leszek Pekala, who preceded him to the witness stand, Mr. Chmielewski described the abduction and killing in October as a plot orchestrated by his superior, Grzegorz Piotrowski.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: General Homes Corp.  is issuing $50 million of 15 1/2 percent, 10-year subordinated notes, at a price of 100, through Shearson Lehman/American Express.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: *       AMR Corp., Dallas-Fort Worth Airport, has named John C. Pope senior vice president-finance and treasurer of both AMR Corp. and its American Airlines Inc. subsidiary.     *       American Satellite Co., Rockville, Md., has appointed George P. Roberts president.     *       Asarco Inc., a mining company, has elected John L. Clendenin, chairman of BellSouth Corp., to its board.

headline: Sperry Statement
abstract: The Sperry Corporation, which broke off merger talks last week with the ITT Corporation, said yesterday that ''we are not now in discussions with anyone nor are we planning to hold discussions with anyone.'' The statement, which seemed to leave open the possibility of future talks, came after widespread rumors about the company's availability for takeover pushed the stock up $3 a share at one point yesterday. The stock closed at $51.375, up 37.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Washington Post Gets Cowles Stake
abstract: The Washington Post Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 17 percent of the Cowles Media Company of Minneapolis. Analysts said the move might set the stage for the Post Company eventually to take control of the newspaper company and its principal asset, The Minneapolis Star and Tribune.   Terms of the transaction were not disclosed, but several analysts said that the Post Company had probably agreed to pay $100 a share or more for the 532,000-share block of stock that belonged to Kingsley H. Murphy Jr., a member of the Cowles board, and his family.

headline: RECEIVER ASKS COURT TO RELEASE E.S.M.'S ASSETS
abstract: The court-appointed receiver for E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. delivered a plan to a Federal district judge late today trying to unfreeze some of the firm's assets to relieve the financial distress that its closing has caused for municipalities that were its customers.    In addition, the receiver, Thomas Tew, asked the court for an emergency motion to force the Bradford Trust Company of New York, the principal clearing agent for E.S.M, to turn over the assets and records of E.S.M. that it possesses. The motion says that Bradford, when asked to turn over the records and assets, ''wrongfully refused to do so, contending that it possesses a lien upon the securities as well as any other assets of the E.S.M. companies.''

headline: COASTAL BID IS ACCEPTED BY A.N.R.
abstract: The American Natural Resources Corporation today accepted the Coastal Corporation's cash offer of $65 a share and said it would complete a friendly merger that includes curbs on Coastal's freedom to break up American Natural or move its headquarters.    The total value of the transaction is about $2.5 billion. It will make Coastal the owner of one of the largest gas distribution networks in the country, with more than 21,000 miles of pipelines ranging from Texas and Louisiana to the Middle West and the Rocky Mountain states.        Other Interests    American also owns interests in more than 1,500 oil and gas wells and has Appalachian coal mines that produced 3.9 million tons in 1984. It owns a one-quarter share of the Great Plains Coal Gasification Project, which is nearing completion.

headline: BIG FINANCIAL HOUSECLEANING
abstract: Oil companies are marking down the value of their oil properties. Timber companies are marking down the value of their forest lands. Soap and beer companies are marking down the values of their manufacturing facilities.     In a huge financial housecleaning, businesses have been slashing the reported worths of their assets at the expense of fourth-quarter earnings to put their balance sheets in order.

headline: Time-Life Books Head
abstract: William Henry has been named president and chief operating officer of Time-Life Books Inc., the publishing subsidiary of Time Inc. announced yesterday.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: Lone Star Industries announced plans to purchase its 8 percent sinking fund debentures, due in 1997.     *       ATT Credit Corp.'s planned $600 million note issue was given a prospective AA-1 senior debt rating by Standard & Poor's.

headline: American Who Swam Into Laos Is Released
abstract: The Government of Laos today freed an American who accidentally crossed into Laotian territory while swimming in the Mekong River last week, according to Thai officials and an associate of the freed man.   The freed man, Jon Robert Phillips, 29 years old, of Rumson, N.J., was on vacation in Thailand when he swam out into the river last Friday to sunbathe on an island that he was not aware belonged to Laos, according to Thai and American accounts.

headline: Ads Can Copy U.S. Currency WASHINGTON, Feb. 22
abstract: The Treasury Department announced today that it   would allow reproductions of   United States currency to be   used in advertisements if certain requirements were met. The department said the   reproductions could not be in   color and they must be either 25   percent smaller than the actual   money or 50 percent larger.

headline: ;    ;   Provincetown Air Is Ceding Control
abstract: Provincetown-Boston Airline Inc., the closely held commuter airline, said yesterday that it had agreed to cede voting control of the troubled carrier to Hugh F. Culverhouse, a prominent Florida businessman and owner of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers football team.   Mr. Culverhouse was given the right to vote the shares of John C. Van Arsdale and Peter E. Van Arsdale, brothers whose approximately 3 million shares constitute a 66 percent controlling interest in Provincetown- Boston, according to George Kean, a spokesman.    In return, Mr. Kean said, Mr. Culverhouse agreed to guarantee a $1 million loan to P.B.A. by the Southeast Bank of Miami and the First National Bank of Boston. Mr. Culverhouse also obtained a two-year option to purchase up to 2.2 million Providence-Boston shares for $1 a share, and a warrant to buy 500,000 shares at $2 each within the next six months. The shares, which are thinly traded in the over-the-counter market, closed Thursday at a bid of $3.75. Trading was suspended yesterday. Mr. Culverhouse also will join the board of airline, which is based in Naples, Fla.

headline: Soviet Gives First Report Of Afghanistan Deserter
abstract: For the first time since Soviet forces joined the fray in Afghanistan in 1979, the Kremlin acknowledged today that one of its soldiers had deserted. But it said he chose to return home after finding only ''sleazy propaganda and dubious love'' in the West.

headline: STOCKS UP AS RALLY CONTINUES
abstract: Stock prices shot up yesterday, resuming their four-week-long rally after a one-day setback on Friday.   ''The market has shrugged off its momentary worry that interest rates might tighten up again, to come back with a very powerful performance,'' said Thom R. Brown, executive vice president of Butcher & Singer Inc. in Philadelphia.   The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 12.36 points, to 1,290.08, close to its record of 1,292.62 set last Tuesday.   Broader measures set records, as they did last week. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 1.72, to a new high of 180.35. The New York Stock Exchange composite index of more than 1,500 stocks climbed 0.93 point, to 104.16, also a record.

headline: Advertising;   Sunshine Biscuits Campaign
abstract: WHILE all around it for the last two years rumbled the Great Cookie War attracting combatant after combatant, Sunshine Biscuits held its peace waiting for the right moment to enter the fray.    Everything depended on developing the right weapon.    The war was started by an outsider, Procter & Gamble, a marketing superpower, which used its Duncan Hines division as a battering ram and a soft, chewy chocolate-chip cookie as its not-so-secret weapon.    Similarly armed were such established cookie makers as Nabisco and Keebler, while Pepsico's Frito-Lay added to its traditional snack-product armory to join in the fun.

headline: JAPANESE PONDER THE PUZZLE OF THE BAD SAMARITANS
abstract: On a Yokohama- to-Tokyo commuter train one recent morning, a young woman was sexually molested repeatedly by a man carrying a razor.    The assault continued for an hour on two trains, according to the police. They said dozens of passengers sat by and did nothing despite the woman's crying.   Three weeks ago, on the Chiyoda subway line in Tokyo, a teen-age boy who lay sprawled across a seat happened to touch a 65-year-old man with his foot. When the older man, Akira Kimura, complained, the boy got up and punched him in the face several times.

headline: Dominelli Pleads Guilty
abstract: J. David Dominelli and an associate pleaded guilty today to Federal charges stemming from the collapse of Mr. Dominelli's investment empire last year, formalizing a plea bargain agreement reached earlier this month. Mr, Dominelli pleaded guilty to two counts of mail fraud, one count of bankruptcy fraud and one count of income tax evasion. He faces 20 years in prison and $107,000 in fines.

headline: GENERAL MILLS MAY SELL TOY AND FASHION UNITS
abstract: General Mills Inc. said yesterday that its board had authorized management to explore the sale of the company's toy and fashion businesses, including Parker Brothers and Kenner Products toys, Izod Lacoste and Ship 'n Shore apparel and Monet Jewelers.     The divestiture, which would be the largest in the consumer goods field in some time, would involve about $1.4 billion of General Mills' $5.6 billion sales in the fiscal year 1984 and also one-fourth of its operating profits. General Mills is the nation's second-largest maker of cereals, operates restaurants and has a variety of consumer goods businesses and specialty retail companies.    After the company's disclosure in Minneapolis of the possible sale, General Mills' common stock rose $1.50 on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $49.875, on volume of 323,700 shares.

headline: Swedish Profit Forecast
abstract: Swedish corporate earnings will continue to rise in 1985, but at a slower pace than in 1984, executives at leading publicly traded companies predicted. The daily newspaper Svenksa Dagbladet said today that its survey had found that nearly half of the executives at 70 major industrial companies expect pretax profits to rise at least 10 percent in 1985.

headline: COMPANY'S BOARD HAD ITS DOUBTS
abstract: The ruptured merger that stunned Wall Street on Monday left it mystified yesterday.     With both companies officially silent, the investment community had few clues as to why the Diamond Shamrock Corporation had backed away from its pending marriage to the Occidental Petroleum Corporation. Sources close to Occidental said the Street's surprise at the 11th-hour jilting was no greater than the sense of disbelief at Occidental.   As best could be discerned, the directors of Diamond Shamrock balked at the deal for several reasons. According to sources privy to the two companies' deliberations, the Diamond Shamrock directors had their doubts over Occidental's financial outlook, they disliked what they felt was a rush to judgment, and they were hardly encouraged by the steady erosion in Occidental's share price at the very moment their decision was being ironed out.

headline: C.D. Yields Up Sharply
abstract: For the second consecutive week, yields on money market deposits were little changed in the latest week, while yields on six-month certificates of deposits increased sharply.    With an unclear outlook for interest rates, consumers ''are shortening up on length of maturity in certificates of deposit,'' Kenneth H. Thorn of Chemical Bank said. In money market mutual funds, the average number of maturity days remained unchanged at 45. George R. Mateyo, president of Carnegie Captial Management Company of Cleveland, said a shorter average number of maturity days would mean that fund managers expect interest rates to rise. An increase is an indication of lower rates.

headline: Eaton in China Accord
abstract: The Eaton Corporation announced on Tuesday that it had entered into a license agreement with China under which the company's heavy-duty truck transmissions would be built in China.

headline: Women's Income
abstract: To the Editor:     Mr. Hale's comments (''Women's Interest Income,'' Prospects, Feb. 17) about the impact of falling interest rates on the incomes of elderly and widowed women are taken out of context and thus misleading. As data from the Social Security Administration's Retirement History Survey show, in the late 1970's, the median amount of income from interest, dividends, and rents is less than $500 per year for the fewer than half of older women without spouses who received any at all. Social Security benefits are the single largest source of income for older women.        JANE SJOGREN Assistant Professor Simmons College Boston, Feb. 20

headline: PATENTS ;  A System To Monitor Laser Drill
abstract: WASHINGTON   Two scientists on the staff of the  International Business Machines Corporation were granted a patent this week for a technique to monitor a laser tool used for drilling holes through composite, multilayered materials. The system interprets sound waves generated by the interaction of the laser pulses with the material being drilled.

headline: CURRENCY MARKETS ;   Gold Falls, Dollar Rises In Day of Calm Trading
abstract: The dollar recovered yesterday, and gold prices sagged. Trading was quiet and nervous after one of the currency markets' most volatile days in the last decade.   Gold, which rose about $36 an ounce Tuesday, fell $14 yesterday to a late bid of $324 at The Republic National Bank in New York.

headline: Mali Airline Says 3 Americans Died in Crash Near Timbuktu
abstract: Three Americans have been identified as among the 13 foreigners who died in the crash of an Air Mali passenger plane Friday outside Timbuktu, the airline said today.   Air Mali listed the Americans as Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Jacquellart and Hugo Wild, who were said to work for the United Nations Development Program.

headline: WORLD LEADERS GATHER IN MOSCOW TO PAY CHERNENKO LAST RESPECTS
abstract: Leaders from around the world gathered in Moscow today to pay their respects at the bier of Konstantin U. Chernenko, who is to be buried beside the Kremlin wall on Wednesday.     As mournful music played, the new Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, led his Politburo colleagues in honoring Mr. Chernenko, who died Sunday at the age of 73. Thousands of Muscovites in heavy winter coats shuffled through the House of Unions to pay their last respects to Mr. Chernenko.   Vice President Bush arrived here with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, bearing what he said was ''a message of peace'' from President Reagan. ''We have no greater hope and no greater goal than to create a more stable and constructive relationship with the Soviet Union,'' he said.

headline: Article 221222 -- No Title
abstract: The First Chicago Corporation announced today that it was offering $200 million in notes as part of its plan to increase its primary capital as the Comptroller of the Currency had ordered.   In November, the Comptroller put pressure on the First National Bank of Chicago, the banking subsidiary, to agree to increase its primary capital to 6 percent of the bank's assets. That order came after the bank holding company shocked Wall Street by charging off $279 million in problem loans in the third quarter.

headline: Thrift Units' Monthly Data
abstract: Thrift institutions experienced little change in deposit growth in November and mortgage lending activity also remained about the same as in October, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

headline: CLAMPDOWN ON STUDENTS REFLECTS KENYAN UNEASE
abstract: Recent unrest among university students here has illuminated the uneasiness that the Government of this East African nation still feels nearly three years after an unsuccessful attempt to overthrow President Daniel arap Moi.     After a week of disturbances last month, in which at least one student was killed, the Government closed the country's main university campus indefinitely, arrested several students and ordered others to return home and report to their local authorities.    Students at the University of Nairobi's College of Architecture and Engineering and the College of Humanities and Social Sciences boycotted classes after university officials expelled three students and withdrew scholarships from five others. The Government told all students to resume classes, but the students defied the order.

headline: New Chairman Chosen At Dominion Resources
abstract: William W. Berry will become chairman of Dominion Resources Inc. and its Virginia Electric and Power Company subsidiary, the company said. He will succeed T. Justin Moore Jr., 59, who is retiring May 1.   Mr. Berry, 52, has been president of the utility based in Richmond since 1980. He was elected chief executive in 1983, and will retain the title. Jack H. Ferguson, 53, who has been executive vice president of Virginia Electric and Power, will become president.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Bond Prices Climb In Active Trading
abstract: Bond prices rose smartly for the second consecutive trading session yesterday, as traders were encouraged by additional signs of further softening in commodity prices. Trading activity, which had been light earlier in the day, picked up by midafternoon, market participants said.     ''Most people were thinking that this would be a quiet market, but the news that Britain and Norway are considering lowering their oil prices and estimates that the Producer Price Index figure for December could show a decline made this a solid day,'' said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, government securities dealers. ''If one can count on low inflation, bonds are the best buy in town.''

headline: Coastal Proposes New A.N.R. Board
abstract: The Coastal Corporation proposed a new board of directors for the American Natural Resources Company, which it is seeking to acquire for $60 a share, or $2.3 billion, and said that it will challenge in court the company's new by-law amendments.   The amendments, which the American Natural Resources board adopted last month, require advance notification to it of stockholder proposals and director nominations for any stockholder meeting.

headline: A CLOSER LOOK AT GAS UTILITIES
abstract: IT is no secret that many energy-related stocks   are faring poorly in the market, mainly as a result of the weakening price structure of crude oil. Last Friday, for example, issues setting 52- week lows on the New York Stock Exchange included Schlumberger Ltd., a world leader in the oil services industry, and the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), one of this country's largest producers of petroleum.    But one sector of the energy business, while neglected by most investors, has been thriving amid little fanfare. This sector consists of the companies, mostly local or regional in their operations, that distribute natural gas to consumers.

headline: REAGAN, GREETING A SOVIET LEADER, SAYS THE U.S. DOES NOT SEEK WAR
abstract: President Reagan agreed with a visiting Soviet Politburo member today that the Soviet people would not start a war against the United States, but added, ''Unfortunately, the people in the Soviet Union don't have much to say about what their Government does.''   The comment, as related by Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, came during what was described as an hourlong ''lively give-and-take'' between Mr. Reagan and Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky, the Soviet visitor.   Mr. Shcherbitsky, who heads a delegation of legislators, is the Communist leader of the Ukraine, the Soviet Union's second most important republic, after Russia.      Star Wars' the Main Topic    He told reporters on leaving the White House that he had spent most of the time ''trying to prove'' to the President that it ''is not worthwhile'' to continue the research program into the proposed space-defense system popularly known as ''Star Wars.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Associated Seeks Share in B. Altman
abstract: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, which owns Lord & Taylor and other retail stores, said yesterday that it was negotiating to join the investor group that plans to buy B. Altman & Company.    The group needs a retailer to operate the Altman stores because Sanford J. Zimmerman, former chairman of Abraham & Straus and the only retailer in the group, has dropped out of the partnership.    John DeGraff, Mr. Zimmerman's lawyer, said yesterday that his client had transferred his interest to the other partners for an undisclosed sum. Mr. Zimmerman gave no reason for withdrawing. His immediate plans, Mr. DeGraff said, are to expand his Cohoes Specialty Stores Ltd., in Cohoes, N.Y.

headline: Bethlehem Loss
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said that it expects to incur a loss of between $60 million and $80 million in the first quarter of this year. This compares with a loss of $54.6 million in the comparable period a year ago. The company made the statement in announcing that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of five million shares of new common stock to be underwritten by Salomon Brothers Inc. Bethlehem, the nation's third-largest steel company, after United States Steel and LTV Inc., said results for the rest of 1985 would depend on President Reagan's program to curb foreign imports of steel.

headline: AUSTRALIAN PRESSING ASARCO
abstract: Robert Holmes a Court, an Australian entrepreneur, turned up the heat yesterday on Asarco Inc., the big mining company that he may be interested in acquiring. Asarco responded by suing Mr. Holmes a Court in Federal court in New Jersey.     Mr. Holmes a Court's Bell Resources Ltd. said in Perth, Australia, that it had sought clearance under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act to increase its holding in Asarco to 50 percent. This law requires companies considering an acquisition involving $15 million or more to notify the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission. Then there is a waiting period of 30 days, or 15 for a tender offer, before further action can be taken.

headline: CABINET AIDES OUT IN PAKISTAN VOTE
abstract: Voters dealt an unexpected rebuff to President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq on Monday by turning seven of his Cabinet aides out of office in elections to a new National Assembly, according to returns announced today.    Among those defeated was Defense Minister Ali Ahmad Talpur, who was running in Sind Province. His rejection was viewed as stemming from ill feelings brought on by eight years of martial law under General Zia.   In addition, about 30 members of the existing national legislature, whose members were picked by General Zia, lost in their attempts to win seats in the new assembly. About 40 members won, but the defeat of so many was also interpreted as a loss for the President.

headline: COMPUTER TERMINAL LEADER
abstract: Low-key and unabrasive, Bernard K. Tse does not fit the mold of the brash and flamboyant entrepreneurs who capture the headlines here. And his business - computer terminals - lacks the glamour of some high-tech fields such as microchips and biotechnology.   But his success is every bit as dramatic as those of his Silicon Valley neighbors. Virtually overnight, Wyse Technology, a company founded by Dr. Tse and his wife, Grace, both Asian immigrants, has become the world's leading producer of computer terminals outside of the major computer companies themselves.   Sales for the fiscal year, which closes at the end of this month, are expected to exceed $75 million, quadruple the $18 million of the previous year, which in turn was quadruple the $4.3 million of the year before that. Earnings are expected to exceed $6 million, or $1.05 a share, triple the level of a year ago. The company stock, first issued last October at $7 a share, is now trading at about $11 in the over-the-counter market.

headline: More Debt, Less Worry
abstract: Although consumers increased their non-mortgage installment debt by a huge 20.4 percent in 1984, they are likely to take on even more, according to Robert A. Schwartz, senior financial economist at Merrill Lynch & Company. For 1985, he said, consumer installment debt will rise 10 or 12 percent.

headline: WEST BANK UNIVERSITY FAULTS ISRAELI ARMY ACTION ON PROTEST
abstract: A university in the West Bank today issued the results of an investigation into the behavior of Israeli Army soldiers in putting down a demonstration last year in which a student was shot and killed by Israeli troops.   At a news conference in East Jerusalem, officials of the school, Bir Zeit University, presented their findings, which they said were compiled from the sworn affidavits of witnesses. The officials called on the Israeli Government to follow up with a state inquiry.

headline: Polish Loan Bid Reported
abstract: The Polish Government is seeking fresh loans totaling $1.7 billion from its Western creditor governments, according to European government officials.

headline: KEEP THE DUAL INSURANCE PALN WORKING
abstract: THE collapse last week in Ohio of   the Home State Savings Bank  and its insurer, the Ohio Deposit Guarantee Fund, have understandably called into question the ability of private insurers to protect consumers' savings. Yet, whatever the outcome in Ohio, it wouldn't be fair to indict the entire system of private deposit insurance for the shortcomings of one insurer.  Until this week, private deposit insurance systems - some dating from the 1930's - operated in five states (North Carolina, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Ohio and Maryland). With the Ohio Legislature passing a bill last week requiring all state banks to carry Federal insurance, the number of private insurance systems has fallen to four, insuring total deposits of more than $26 billion. These insurers represent the state side of the dual banking system that has existed since the 19th century.

headline: Sperry Off; Burroughs Gains 16%
abstract: Two of the country's leading computer producers reported earnings results yesterday for the quarter ending Dec. 31, with the Sperry Corporation showing a 17 percent drop in profits and the Burroughs Corporation reporting a 16 percent gain.    Sperry said that net income for the period, its third fiscal quarter, dropped to $61.2 million, or $1.09 a share, from $73.7 million, or $1.42 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose 23.7 percent, to $1.46 billion, from $1.18 billion.

headline: Mexico Oil Prices Stable
abstract: Mexico's export oil prices for the month of March will remain at the same level as in February, Pemex, the state oil monopoly announced today. Prices will remain at $27.75 a barrel for its light Isthmus crude, and $25.50 for the heavier Maya variety.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Morgan Stanley Shifting Merger Unit Leadership
abstract: After handling a record $50 billion in mergers and acquisitions last year, Morgan Stanley & Company is shuffling the leadership of the department that pulled in that business.   Joseph C. Fogg 3d, the 38-year-old director of mergers and acquisitions, will move in July to a new position that - although still undefined - will encompass a number of areas in the company's investment banking division.

headline: Missile Models Claim Is Settled WASHINGTON, March 12
abstract: The Martin Marietta   Corporation has repaid the   Government $200,000 to settle a   dispute over billing the Air   Force for the cost of producing   gift models of its Titan missile,   the Air Force said today.

headline: Boesky Sells Stake In 2 Concerns
abstract: Ivan F. Boesky, the New York investor, and a group of companies he controls have sold their shares in ARA Services Inc. and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. in separate deals valued at more than $131.4 million. according to Securities and Exchange Commission filings.   Mr. Boesky sold 1,345,600 ARA shares, or 11.2 percent of the food service company's stock outstanding, to the ARA Holding Company for $71.75 a share, or a total of $96.5 million.

headline: Futures/Options;   The Industry Comes of Age
abstract: WHEN the leaders of the futures industry gather tomorrow       at the posh Boca Raton, Fla., Country Club for their 10th annual conference, there will be many new faces and accents seen and heard among the roughly 1,200 participants.    Many of the newcomers at the Futures Industry Association conference will be bankers and other members of financial institutions who until a few years ago would never have associated publicly with anyone involved in futures trading. Such dealings were then considered to be gambling.   But Richard L. Sandor, senior vice president of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., observed last week:   ''Given the uncertainty of the financial markets these past few years, the only gamblers are those with fiduciary responsibilities who don't use the futures and options markets. That many do use them explains why the volume of Treasury bond futures alone was $31 billion in 1984, compared with $30 billion for all futures traded in 1975.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: NEW GERMAN TV: IDIOT CULTURE OR BREATH OF AIR?
abstract: Consolidating his grasp on a dispirited nation, Hitler revolutionized politics through his discovery of the enormous power of the spoken voice carried by radio.         In no little measure because of Hitler's exploitation of the airwaves, the prevailing tone of voice on radio and television in postwar West Germany is self-consciously calm, flat, unemotional, And the country's two big semiautonomous public television stations - although many important positions are held by those from the left side of the political spectrum - are earnestly didactic, highbrow and quite dull.

headline: Atlantic Capital Makes Brnf Offer
abstract: The Wilmington Trust Company, trustee for the Brnf Liquidating Trust, said the Atlantic Capital Corporation had offered to buy the assets of Brnf Liquidating for $160 million. Atlantic Captial has set a deadline of Feb. 15 for the offer, but the directors have notified Atlantic that an extension will be needed to evaluate the proposal.   The trustees of Brnf Liquidating, which acquired the significant assets of the Braniff International Corporation in bankrutpcy proceedings, called a Feb. 25 special meeting of the Brnf certificate holders to consider the cash offer.

headline: WILL PRESS HIS INDEPENDENCE PLAN
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand said today that he would leave Thursday for the French terrority of New Caledonia, where 20 people have been killed in a violent struggle over independence.   The announcement of the trip to the island group east of Australia was a surprise, and came in response to a question during a televised interview with four reporters.   ''I am going to express what I believe to be reason and to support the High Commission,'' Mr. Mitterrand said.

headline: American Capital Convertible Notes
abstract: The American Capital Bond Fund priced $50 million of five-year convertible extendible notes.

headline: Heavy Snowfall in Armenia
abstract: The worst snowstorm in 30 years whipped into Armenia this week, dumping waist- deep snow that closed roads, pulled down power and telephone lines and damaged farms and factories. In three days, from Sunday through Tuesday, the snowfall in parts of the southern republic was 50 percent greater than the annual average, with winds gusting up to 75 miles an hour.

headline: Gandhi, in Punjab, Promises Program to Revitalize State
abstract: Rajiv Gandhi, making his first trip as Prime Minister to the Punjab, announced measures today that are intended to rejuvenate the state.

headline: A FLURRY OF NEW TAX RULES FOR 1985
abstract: CAUGHT in a blizzard of paperwork to prepare their 1984 returns, few taxpayers have the energy to worry about their 1985 tax bills this early in the game. But a host of new tax rules were rung in with the new year, and those who take steps now may be able to save money by maximizing the benefit - or minimizing the damage - caused by the changes.    The flurry of new rules were enacted in last year's tax act and various other laws dating back to 1981. Among the January moves: the Internal Revenue Service raised the interest rate on underpayments to 13 percent from 11 percent, so taxpayers' mistakes will now be more costly. Following is a rundown of some other recent regulatory changes that are of interest to individual taxpayers.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * The Minnesota Twins to Campbell- Mithun Advertising.

headline: Geo Magazine to Stop Publication
abstract: Geo, a magazine known for striking color photographs and a shifting editorial identity, will cease publication with the February issue, company officials announced yesterday.    The magazine, which is owned by Los Angeles-based Knapp Communications Corporation, had been losing from $500,000 to $1 million a month during the last year, according to a senior company official who asked not to be identified. Knapp also publishes Architectural Digest, Bon Appetit and Home.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *       Adobe Oil and Gas Corp., Midland, Tex., and Madison Resources Inc. said their boards had approved in principle the companies' previously announced merger plan.     *       Bucyrus-Erie Co., a construction and mining concern based in Milwaukee, said Northwest Engineering Co. had bought its construction machinery business.

headline: Texaco Halts Sale
abstract: Texaco Inc. said it had terminated the proposed sale of some agribusiness properties it acquired in its acquisition of the Getty Oil Company.

headline: Digital Computer
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation is making a bid for the small-business segment of the multiuser computer market with the introduction of the Micropdp-11/SV, priced at $5,995. Company officials said the new system can support up to four users simultaneously and includes a central processing unit and 512,000 bytes of main memory.

headline: U.S. APPEALS TO IRAN TO FORSAKE A MILITARY SOLUTION
abstract: The United States appealed to Iran today to acknowledge that a military victory could not be achieved in the four-and- a-half-year-old war and to accept a negotiated settlement.    The appeal came in the aftermath of what American officials have characterized as an Iranian defeat in a weeklong offensive.    Administration officials conceded that the chances of Iran's yielding to American and other international pleas were minimal, but one senior official said, ''We have to keep trying and hoping that the sheer numbers of Iranians killed on the battlefield will persuade Khomeini to try another tack.''    Iraq has repeatedly agreed to accept a United Nations cease-fire and negotiation, but the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran has refused to do so until President Saddam Hussein of Iraq resigns and Iraq agrees to pay reparations. Partly because of Iran's refusal to negotiate unconditionally, the United States has been publicly sympathetic to Iraq and critical of Iran, even while officially professing neutrality in the war.

headline: MCI, U S West In Pact on Suits
abstract: The MCI Communications Corporation and U S West Inc. announced an agreement to resolve the involvement of three U S West units in two antitrust suits that MCI had brought against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the former parent of what is now U S West.   Under terms of the agreement, MCI will receive a cash payment and the three U S West telephone companies - Northwestern Bell, Pacific Northwest Bell and Mountain Bell - will enter into various business relationships with MCI.

headline: PLAYING THE EXPLOSION IN V.C.R. SALES
abstract: AS the entertainment revolution has spread, one of the most conspicuous phenomena of the past year has been the explosion in sales of video cassette recorders. Americans alone are expected to buy 10 million to 12 million of these machines in 1985, up from 7.3 million last year.   At this stage, investors wanting to capitalize on the V.C.R. craze are limited to a few companies that specialize in the production or distribution of the movies, what the industry calls the ''software.'' The machines themselves, the ''hardware,'' are manufactured by such major electronics companies as the RCA Corporation and the Sony Corporation, and V.C.R.'s contribute only a small portion of their revenues and profits. Consequently, V.C.R. sales have a relatively small impact on these companies' stocks.

headline: G. BARRACLOUGH, 76, HISTORIAN
abstract: Geoffrey Barraclough, a historian of medieval and contemporary Europe who had distinguished teaching careers in Great Britain and the United States, died Dec. 26 of lung cancer in the village of Burford, England. He was 76 years old and had lived in Great Britain in recent years.   Mr. Barraclough taught at Brandeis University from 1968 until his retirement in 1981, taking only a two-year leave to lecture at All Souls College, Oxford University. Previously, he was a teacher at Cambridge University, the University of Liverpool, the University of London, and the University of California at San Diego.

headline: AMERCAN RETURNS TO CHINA TO SET UP AUTONOMOUS UNIVERSITY
abstract: Thirty-five years ago Shu-Park Chan, a 20-year-old captain, fled from Hainan Island, one of the last footholds of the Chinese Nationalist Army. Now he is Professor Chan, and he is returning to the Chinese mainland to establish the country's first modern autonomous university.    With all of the 815 colleges and universities in China run by the Communist Party, from the choice of curriculum to the hiring and firing of professors, the decision by the Chinese Government to allow and even promote a university that will not be Government- regulated is a major departure from China's education system, Professor Chan says.

headline: THE COMPUTER;  WHAT EVERY DATABASE NEEDS: A MANAGER
abstract: VIRGINIA DELCONTE joined the commercial insurance division of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company in 1981 as a database administrator. On a typical day the division, in Windsor, Conn., churns out piles of data that have to circulate from one division to the next and from one user to another. It is Miss DelConte's job to store that information in one or more of the commercial division's eight databases, which are like electronic card catalogues.  The 28-year-old Miss DelConte, who was a data consultant for the Control Data Corporation before joining Aetna, decides what goes into the databases and how the information is stored for easy accessibility. According to employment experts, positions like hers are likely to grow as companies place greater and greater value on information processing. For example, her own division recently added two people and is seeking to build up the staff further.

headline: DOWNWARD PRESSURE ON BONDS
abstract: The credit markets should get a clearer picture of just how strong the economy is this week, when a slew of reports, including the Commerce Department's ''flash'' estimate of the real growth rate in the first quarter, are scheduled to be released.     Uncertainty about the pace of economic activity has been building among market participants for two weeks, as reports from February on key components, such as industrial production and retail sales, have sent conflicting signals to traders and have caused bond prices to lurch up one day and then down sharply the next.    Signs of weakness are apparent, but analysts say that growth remains solid and that a further rise in bond yields is almost certain by midyear.    Richard Green, president of Money Market Services Inc., an economic information service concern in Belmont, Calif., said that ''the market got a little excited about the softness in the February data we have seen, but now it is beginning to reassess that prospect, and bond prices will be subject to downward pressure for at least the next two months.''

headline: Tyco's Bylaws
abstract: The board of directors of Tyco Laboratories Inc. changed the concern's bylaws to make a hostile takeover more difficult to accomplish. Under the new bylaws, adopted Dec. 11, a hostile takeover would require the approval of 80 percent of the company's voting stock rather than 50 percent. Irving Gutin, vice president of the fire protection, cable television and solar power concern, which is based in Exeter, N.H., said he was unaware of any efforts to take it over.

headline: AN INDEPENDENT COURSE SEEN FOR DOME CANADA
abstract: In a move that may signal a gradual dissociation of the two companies, Dome Canada Ltd., the oil and gas company that is 48 percent owned by Dome Petroleum Ltd., has named H. Earl Joudrie president and chief executive officer.   Mr. Joudrie, 50, will succeed J. Louis Lebel, 66, who is retiring as president of the exploration and production company, based in Calgary, Alberta. Fred H. McNeil, 68, will relinquish his title as chief executive but will remain chairman of the board. Mr. Lebel will remain a director.

headline: Nissan U.S. Car Plans
abstract: The Nissan Motor Company said that it would produce its first car in the United States on March 26, ahead of schedule. The company had said it would start making two-door Sentra front-wheel-drive sedans in late April or early May at its Smyrna, Tenn., factory, which has made only light trucks since it opened 18 months ago.

headline: Treasury Bond Prices Tumble
abstract: Treasury bond prices dropped sharply yesterday as securities dealers sought to attract buyers for recently auctioned Treasury securities and the sizable amount of notes and bonds sold yesterday by large institutions.     The impetus for lower prices was increased by the fear that foreign central banks could make a concerted effort to quell the rise in the value of the dollar this weekend. Rumors that foreign central banks might try to curb the appreciation of the dollar through intervention in the foreign exchange markets or capital controls have swept through the financial markets with regularity each Friday the past few months. If the value of the dollar were to fall, traders expect that prices of American debt securities would drop as foreigners liquidated their holdings.

headline: Gas Glut
abstract: To the Editor:     ''Scrambling for Profits in a Gas Glut'' (Dec. 30) sustains much of the mythology that surrounds the natural gas industry. The word ''market'' appears in various forms (market- sensitive, spot market, market prices, gas market, marketplace, industrial market, market-out, market- competitive, free-market) more than 30 times, yet the word ''marketing'' appears only twice.

headline: VISION OF SPACE DEFENSE POSING NEW CHALLENGES
abstract: President Reagan's vision of defensive systems to render nuclear weapons ''impotent and obsolete'' is moving strategic thinking and nuclear competition toward a new era.     For Mr. Reagan's vision has done nothing less than to assault the core of nuclear philosophy, namely deterrence based on the threat of retaliation. He and his senior aides are saying that the 40 years of nuclear peace built on that threat cannot last and is, in any event, immoral.    Most experts say they think that perhaps decades of research will be required before they know with confidence whether the vision can be translated into workable technology.         Consequences of the Vision    Yet proponents and critics alike are well aware that the vision itself, along with accelerated research programs and the attending debates, is shaking the foundations of American military policy - strategic doctrine, the shape of military spending, alliance relations and arms control.

headline: DOLLAR'S HECTIC WEEK ENDS ON A CALM NOTE
abstract: The dollar yesterday ended one of the most turbulent weeks in the history of floating exchange rates with uncharacteristic calm. Resisting intervention by several central banks, the dollar was little changed in light trading.   Intervention, and resistance to it, dominated the week. The dollar soared until Tuesday morning and then plunged. It fell further on Wednesday on concerted intervention by several European central banks but then rose moderately on Thursday, despite continued intervention.

headline: TACTIC THAT'S 'POISON' TO BIDS
abstract: Wall Street's ''poison pills'' appear to be deadly medicine - even though no company has actually had to swallow one yet.     The poison pill is an increasingly popular defense against takeovers. Though it can take different forms, the basic strategy involves a company giving its stockholders the right to buy shares at a special price, or get other benefits, when a hostile bidder tries to take over the company - making such a takeover prohibitively expensive, or ''poisonous,'' for the would-be acquirer.    The defense, and the phrase, emerged in the course of Lenox Inc.'s 1983 battle to fend off a takeover by the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation - although Lenox ultimately decided to dissolve its pill and accept a bid from Brown-Forman. Still, most takeover experts see the poison pill as a perfectly effective preventative: No company that has adopted the pill has ever had to use it.

headline: Cigarette Boasts Tie-In With Yves St. Laurent
abstract: Here is an announcement indicating that either the cigarette business or fashion designing, or perhaps both, have reached new heights of something.    The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company is going to test-market Ritz, a 100-millimeter filter-tip cigarette for women.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Feb. 4, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on Non-Use of Force - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: LAWMAKERS SAY U.S. IS MISUSING AID TO SALVADOR
abstract: A Congressional caucus accused the Administration today of having supplied ''insufficient, misleading and in some cases false information'' on aid for El Salvador.    A report issued by the Arms Control and Foreign Policy Caucus, a bipartisan group, says economic and military aid, which will total at least $557 million this year, is worsening El Salvador's problems and prolonging the civil war. One reason, the report says, is that most of the spending has been military, despite Administration claims that most has been for economic and social development.    It says the Administration has ''provided Congress with overly optimistic reports'' on the war.

headline: CATHOLIC BISHOPS URGE LAWMAKERS TO BAR MX FUNDS
abstract: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops sent a letter to all members of Congress today urging them to vote against funds to produce the MX missile.    The letter from the United States Catholic Conference, copies of which were dropped in Congressional post offices this afternoon, was timed to reach members of Congress before the first of four votes on the intercontinental missile beginning Tuesday.    The Catholic conference, which consists of about 285 Roman Catholic bishops in the United States, said its opposition to the missile was based on these two considerations: ''the potentially destabilizing impact of this weapons system on the nuclear arms race,'' and ''its cost, viewed in light of pressing human needs here and elsewhere in the world.''         Most Specific Opposition    The letter was clearly the most specific and firm opposition to the MX missile expressed by the Roman Catholic Bishops. A Catholic official who is informed on the drafting of the letter said there was little or no opposition to it among the bishops.

headline: Reagan Thanks Syria For Aiding Reporter
abstract: The White House said today that President Reagan telephoned President Hafez al-Assad of Syria Saturday to thank him for Syria's aid in the return of an American reporter.   ''He thanked him for his role in assisting Jeremy Levin,'' a White House spokesman, Mark Weinberg, said.

headline: IRAQIS THREATEN TO WIDEN FIGHTING
abstract: Iraq warned today that it was prepared to expand the Persian Gulf war to ''every corner of Iran'' unless Teheran agreed to a comprehensive peace settlement.    The warning came as Iraqi war planes were reported to have attacked three Iranian cities and merchant ships in the gulf.   Al-Jumhuriya, a Government daily newspaper, stated in an unusually harshly worded editorial that Iraq would not permit the war to continue. Iran's only alternative was total peace or ''an overall destructive war,'' the newspaper said.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Glucksman to Start A Consulting Firm
abstract: After less than five months as an executive vice president of the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, Lewis L. Glucksman plans to resign to start his own corporate finance consulting company, a spokesman for the American Express Company, Fireman's Fund's parent, said yesterday.    Mr. Glucksman, 59 years old, came from Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, where he was chairman before that firm's acquisition last May by Shearson/ American Express Inc. He had gained sole possession of the top spot at Lehman Brothers by forcing out his co-chairman, Peter Peterson, in a celebrated power play in mid-1983.    Phone calls to Mr. Glucksman's offices in New York and Novato, Calif., where Fireman's Fund is situated, were not returned. The American Express spokesman, Walter Montgomery, said Mr. Glucksman had not resigned officially yet, but such a move was expected. He added that Mr. Glucksman would remain as an adviser to Fireman's Fund.

headline: French Utility Has Loss
abstract: The state-owned gas utility, Gaz de France, reported a loss of 3.02 billion francs, or $270 million, in 1984, up from a loss of 2.38 billion francs in 1983, a spokesman said today.

headline: PATENTS;  Tire Inflation System Set From Driver's Seat
abstract: In heavy-duty vehicles, such as used by the military, it is often desirable to change the tire pressure to meet conditions on or off the road or on desert terrain.

headline: BRAZIL STRUGGLES TO ADJUST TO LEADER'S ILLNESS
abstract: Brazil appeared headed today for an extended period of government under an acting President as the 75-year-old President-elect, Tancredo Neves, struggled to recover from his third major abdominal operation in 11 days.     Doctors said that Mr. Neves was in ''satisfactory'' condition after surgery Tuesday to stem internal bleeding. They also said that a slight infection at the point of incision in Mr. Neves's abdomen was being treated with antibiotics.

headline: Allis in Talks On Farm Unit
abstract: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation, a producer of industrial machinery and equipment, said that it was holding talks regarding its money- losing farm equipment division with several companies, including the Deutz Corporation, the farm equipment subsidiary of Kl"ockner-Humboldt-Deutz A.G. of West Germany.    Allis, which is based in Milwaukee, said that no definitive agreements had been reached. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Allis- Chalmers closed at $9 a share yesterday, up 87.5 cents, or 10.7 percent, making it the ninth-biggest percentage gainer.

headline: U.M.W. Selling Stock in Bank
abstract: The United Mine Workers of America has agreed to sell its controlling interest in the National Bank of Washington for about $70 million, the bank announced. The buyers are three New York investors and a number of senior officers of the bank, including Luther H. Hodges Jr., the chairman of the Washington Bancorporation, the bank's holding company.

headline: U.S. IS REBUFFED ON VISIT BY SHIP TO NEW ZEALAND
abstract: The United States said today that New Zealand had ''definitively turned down'' an American request for a port visit by a Navy destroyer because Washington would not say if it carried nuclear arms.    American officials said the move, announced today by Prime Minister David Lange, threatened the future of the South Pacific alliance of the United States, New Zealand and Australia.    The State Department said tonight that naval exercises planned next month by the three countries had been canceled because of New Zealand's action.         Viewed as a Test Case    The Reagan Administration had made the proposed port call a test case of New Zealand's seven-month-old an tinuclear policy and had indicated that a rejection would lead to a reap praisal of the alliance, known as Anzus.

headline: ISRAELI OFFICIAL CRITICIZES BANK STOCK REGULATORS
abstract: Israel's state comptroller today harshly criticized the Government and the Bank of Israel over the collapse last year of commercial bank shares in which thousands of small investors lost their savings.   A long-awaited report by the comptroller, Yitzhak Tunik, blamed the Government and the central bank for ignoring the dangers of allowing commercial banks to manipulate their shares on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange.   By buying and selling their own shares, the banks inflated their paper value to as much as triple the real worth of their assets, creating what most Israelis considered a guaranteed investment.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1985        Markets         The dollar advanced sharply in European trading and extended its gains in light trading in the U.S. The dollar rose above 3.30 West German marks for the first time in 13 years, while solidifying its position above 10 French francs. The pound dropped to $1.0870 in London. Analysts said the dollar was propelled by an expectation of higher interest rates in the U.S. Gold fell $1.75, to $302, in late New York trading. (Page D1.)         The stock market ended narrowly mixed.  The Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.55 point, to 1,276.61, and the more broadly based market indexes showed similarly modest increases. Volume rose to 111.1 million shares even though some traders were home for the Lincoln's Birthday holiday. (D10.) Bond prices were little changed in very reduced trading. (D21.)

headline: New York Financier Turns to Washington
abstract: Peter del Col has been a New York banker and financier for virtually all of his professional life. But before the end of this year his financial fortunes will in large part rest on what happens in and around the nation's capital.    Last week Mr. del Col, 50, a group of other investors and members of senior manangement at the National Bank of Washington agreed to purchase controlling interest in its parent, the Washington Bancorporation, from the United Mine Workers of America. The union, which began buying its stake in the bank in the 1940's, gained control in 1949. It agreed to sell its 76 percent stake to the group for $70 million.

headline: U.S. TO ASK ARABS TO CLARIFY HUSSEIN-ARAFAT AGREEMENT
abstract: The United States intends to ask Arab leaders whether the framework agreement worked out by King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, could lead to Middle East peace negotiations.   As a result of discussions with Jordanian, Egyptian and other Arab leaders in recent days, the Reagan Administration has learned that the framework accord is limited to broad negotiating principles and is regarded by King Hussein himself as only a first step, with many details to be worked out.    Although senior Administration officials said that this could be the most hopeful sign coming out of the Arab world in two years, there were so many open questions - such as whether direct Arab-Israeli talks would result, or whether the P.L.O. would now accept United Nations Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338 - that it would be premature to be optimistic about the immediate prospects.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   New Company Offers Municipal Insurance
abstract: Rapid growth of the municipal bond insurance business - where loss experience is low to nonexistent and annual premiums were well in excess of $200 million last year - continues to attract new companies. Last year, about 21 percent of all new tax-exempt bonds were insured, and analysts expect that percentage may rise to 25 percent this year.    Yesterday, Bond Investors Guaranty Inc. became the fourth major company in the bond insurance business, and said its bonds would be rated AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The company is initially capitalized at $125 million and is equally owned by the American International Group, an international business insurance company; the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the Government Employees Insurance Company; Phibro-Salomon Inc., and the Xerox Credit Corporation.

headline: PATENTS;  An Alarm Alerts Fatigued Drivers
abstract: A way to alert car drivers that they are excessively fatigued was patented this week for the Nissan Motor Company of Japan.

headline: WITH WOTNESSES VANISHING, AQUINO TRIAL WITHERS
abstract: When it began a month ago, the court case against the Chief of Staff of the Philippine Armed Forces and 25 other men in the assassination in 1983 of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was hailed here as ''the trial of the century.'' But today the trial is the subject of widespread cynicism, even apathy, among Filipinos.     Witnesses regarded as vital to the prosecution have inexplicably vanished. The soldiers charged in the purported military plot are being kept not in jail, but in more spacious and comfortable special barracks.

headline: SETTING ASIDE URANIUM PACT
abstract: ONCE again, uranium is making lawyers glow. An extraordinary arbitration has concluded by setting aside a long-term supply contract for uranium, in part because the price collapsed soon after the contract was made. The case raises troubling questions on the frontiers of contract law: in particular, whether courts should set aside long-term contracts because of dramatic price changes in the market.   The traditional view was that parties should be held to their bargains, because the very reason for entering long-term contracts was to lock in current prices.

headline: Quake Felt in North Japan
abstract: A strong earthquake shook the northern Japanese islands of Honshu and Hokkaido early today, the Central Meteorological Agency reported. There were no immediate reports of damage or casualties. The quake had a preliminary reading of 6.8 on the Richter scale, with the epicenter in Akita Prefecture.

headline: No Survivors Found In Bolivian Plane Crash
abstract: A team of Bolivian climbers fighting high winds and snow reached the wreckage of an Eastern Airlines jet nearly 20,000 feet up a mountain today and reported finding no survivors, the airline and the United States Embassy said.

headline: Insiders' Rules Studied
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering easing rules that prohibit corporate executives from earning short-term profits by trading their company's stock.   The commission's staff is studying the regulations to determine if changes in the marketplace, such as the proliferation of executive stock options and hostile takeovers, have made laws, dating 50 years, either too cumbersome or unfair.    ''We are doing a comprehensive review,'' said Jo Ann Zuercher, chief of the Office of Disclosure Policy. ''We think the current rules are very difficult to follow. They developed piecemeal over a period of time and we are looking to see if we can rationalize them.''

headline: USG Official in Line To Get Two Top Posts
abstract: The USG Corporation, formerly the United States Gypsum Company, said yesterday that its board intends to elect Richard J. Day to the posts of chairman and chief executive officer. The appointment is effective June 1, the company said.    Mr. Day, who is 59, has served as president and chief operating officer at USG since February 1981. He will succeed Edward W. Duffy, 65, who will retire at the end of May.

headline: Economic Scene ;   5-Year Budget Projections
abstract: At his news conference Wednesday night, President Reagan urged the press to ''rally around and help with a few editorials'' in support of his position that the Administration should no longer be required by Congress to submit five-year budget projections.   ''There isn't any economist in the world who can do that and accurately tell you what you're going to need down the road,'' he said.    The requirement that the Administration make long-term budget projections stemmed from the October 1967 report of the bipartisan Presidential Commission on Budget Concepts, on which key members of the Johnson Administration, Congressional leaders and private economists and budget experts served.       Concerned about inflationary pressures from the Vietnam buildup of military spending and the rise of Great Society spending programs, the commission, responding to the urgings of business and other groups, decided that the inability of Congress and the public to see the distant consequences of present decisions was a major weakness of the budget process.

headline: FOR THE WOMEN, STILL A LONG WAY TO GO
abstract: Although a gowing number of young women are studying the quantitatively-based disciplines that prepare them for careers in science, engineering and computer science, their prospects for employment and advancement in industry and academia drag woefully behind those for men.  ''Ten years ago, many us thought that merit would be recognized and rewarded in these fields regardless of a person's gender, but we've been proved totally wrong,'' said Betty Vettor, Executive Director of the Scientific Manpower Commission, ''I don't expect opportunities to equalize within the next twenty years,'' she added.  Still, Dr. Vettor and others point out, women have been making inroads into scientific, engineering and computer fields. Between 1965 and 1982 (the latest year for which figures are available), there was a 10 percent increase in the number of women majoring in the physical and life sciences, engineering, mathematics and computer science, according to ''The Professional Women and Minorities'' report of the Scientific Manpower Commission. On the graduate level, the growth was somewhat higher: a 12 percent increase in master's degrees and a 15 percent increase in doctoral degrees.  These increased percentages do not, however, point to a change in women's preferences about career fields, according to Sue E. Berryman, a resident consultant with the Rand Corporation in Washington, D.C.  They simply reflect the growing representation of women in all fields in college.  ''As long as girls expect to assume the major child-rearing responsibilities of their families, they will be less likely than boys to choose quantitative occupations that require major educational and labor force commitments,'' said Dr. Berryman, who conducted the study, ''Who Will Do Science?'' for the Rockefeller Foundation.

headline: Horsehead-Great Lakes Tie
abstract: In a corporate takeover that would result in one of the largest privately owned manufacturing companies in the United States, Horsehead Industries said yesterday that it planned to acquire the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation.   Horsehead is a holding company whose operations include the New Jersey Zinc Company, a former subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries. New Jersey Zinc, one of the nation's oldest companies, invented the American process for making zinc oxide. The purchase price of the planned transaction was not disclosed.

headline: CURRENCY MARKETS ;   Dollar Reaches Highs; Gold and Silver Down
