abstract: The dollar, which soared during 1984 despite predictions by economists that it would fall, began 1985 on the same contrary note yesterday by reaching a record high against the British pound and the highest level against the West German mark in more than a decade.   Gold and silver prices fell to two- and-a-half-year lows, losing ground as the dollar rose. The Republic National Bank in New York said gold was bid at $302 an ounce as of 4 P.M., down $5.75 from the late bid Monday. Currency and bullion markets were closed Tuesday in observance of New Year's Day.

headline: FOR THE PUBLIC IN CANADA, THE PRIVACY WATCHDOG
abstract: When an employee of Canada's Employment and Immigration Commission requested a disability parking permit, she was instructed to fill out a blanket medical form, including such details as her mental health, alcohol intake and family medical problems.    The woman reluctantly complied, but later asked Canada's Privacy Commissioner whether so much information was necessary. He checked and said it was not. As a result, the medical form has been revised.

headline: GUATEMALA SCHEDULES ELECTIONS
abstract: Guatemalans will elect a civilian President and members of Congress on Oct. 24, and the nation's military chiefs will hand over power on Jan. 14, 1986, the Government announced today.    Gen. Oscar Humberto Mejiia Victores, Guatemala's chief of state, the Supreme Electoral Tribunal and the National Constituent Assembly announced the election plan in a joint statement.

headline: Family Media Inc.
abstract: Family Media Inc., a closely held publisher, said that it had purchased Savvy magazine.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ;   The Second-Term Outlook
abstract: As President Reagan begins his second term, the financial markets are one area in which he can point to progress during his first four years in office.   To the extent that the credit and stock markets are a barometer of society's confidence in the future, lower interest rates and higher stock prices suggest that the outlook is brighter than it was four years ago.    As to the future, economists and investors are quick to warn about the perils of huge budget deficits, but few forecasters expect any quick or dramatic changes in the financial markets.   ''With short rates steady, long rates are not likely to vary much,'' said Mitchell J. Held, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''Deficit reduction talk, favorable inflation prospects and pockets of weak economic numbers'' could encourage some drop in note and bond yields, he said, but those impulses should be offset by ''strong economic growth'' and worries that short-term rates will trend higher later in the year.

headline: P.L.O., CRITICIZING EGYPT'S PLAN, CALLS FOR A U.N.-SPONSERED PARLEY
abstract: A spokesman for the Palestine Liberation Organization in Tunis today criticized Egypt's call for direct peace talks between Israel and a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation. He said an international peace conference with P.L.O. participation was the ''proper framework'' for making peace.    The spokesman in Tunis also called for an active American role in the talks.    A P.L.O. statement on the Egyptian initiative was made public today by its press agency, Wafa. A translation and the statement's meaning were discussed in a telephone interview tonight with a senior P.L.O. spokesman.

headline: Eastern Talks With Unions
abstract: Eastern Airlines technically defaulted on $2.5 billion in bank loans last night when its three labor unions failed to agree to wage concessions before a midnight deadline.

headline: PATENTS;  Data on Sea and Wind Collected by Satellite
abstract: A method of measuring sea surface temperature and wind speed from a satellite was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration by Joseph M. Stacey, a staff member at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in California.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: The official Iranian press agency, monitored in Cyprus, said one person died and two were wounded when an Iranian Government building in Teheran was attacked with grenades today. Meanwhile, an Iranian bank in Frankfurt, West Germany, was set afire today, and 14 people were injured. Two groups opposed to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, said they were responsible for the attacks.

headline: Evacuation Plan Is Rejected
abstract: A proposal recommending the complete evacuation of southern Lebanon by the end of May was defeated today in the Parliamentary Foreign Affairs and Security Committee in Jerusalem.   It was proposed by Victor Shemtov of the left-wing Mapam opposition.   The subject is to be discussed again Wednesday when a Government statement is to be made about the situation in Lebanon.

headline: Gold Swindle Guilty Plea WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 6
abstract: The former executive   vice president of the International Gold Bullion Exchange,   a defunct Florida company accused of swindling investors   out of millions of dollars,   pleaded guilty today to state   fraud and larceny charges. James Alderdice, 28 years   old, who also faces state and   Federal charges in Florida,   was released on his own recognizance, according to David Fishlow, a   spokesman for State Attorney   General Robert Abrams. Mr. Fishlow said prosecutors   had dropped 30 of the 34 counts   against Mr. Alderdice in return   for his plea - to two counts of   grand larceny and two of securities fraud - because his   older brother, the late William   Alderdice, ran the company.

headline: ISRAEL'S IRON MESSAGE
abstract: The chief objective of Israel's new aggressive military policy in southern Lebanon, military analysts here say, is to make Israel's northern border secure.  In adopting what has been called an ''offensive defense,'' the analysts say, Israel has finally turned its back on the idea of improving its security by installing a more stable or sympathetic government to the north.   Instead, they say, the idea now is to make Galilee secure by sending a message to the Lebanese about what life will be like in the future if there are attacks on northern Israeli settlements from southern Lebanon.        Iron Fist or Velvet Glove?

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: BANGKOK DISPLAYS VIETNAM SOLDIERS
abstract: Huynh Quoc Tuan, his rumpled shirt too big for his small frame, was barefoot and trembling this morning when Thailand's top military chiefs paraded him before the press.   A week ago this 18-year-old plumber from Saigon who did not want to be a soldier, came over Ampil's Bridge No. 3 and deserted the Vietnamese Army.    According to Thai authorities, more than 30 of Mr. Tuan's fellow soldiers have done the same since early January, when the Vietnamese took the Ampil border camp, the headquarters of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. The Thais say the defections have become regular; two more were recorded Wednesday.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: March 28, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Outer Space Legal Subcommittee - 10.30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Human Rights Committee - 10.30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad hoc committee on Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States - 10.30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: MARKET DEPRESSED IN MANILA
abstract: Last October, the local radio program carrying the daily trading session on the Manila Stock Exchange was finally pulled off the air. In better times, the program had been a continuous chatter of transactions being announced in the shorthand of company names and share prices.    ''But by last year,'' explained Ramon Gonzales, an executive at a big Manila brokerage house, ''it was mostly just long periods of silence.''    Reflecting the economic troubles and political uncertainty in the Philippines, the Manila stock market - composed of two exchanges, the Makati and the Manila, which trade the same issues - may well have been the worst-performing market in the world last year.

headline: AN APARTHEID FOE CONFIRMS RUMORS
abstract: The president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, a prominent opponent of white rule here, said today that he had a ''relationship'' with a female church worker. The admission confirmed what had been reported as rumors circulated by South Africa's security police to discredit him.     The church leader, the Rev. Allan Boesak, who is married and has four children, admitted his relationship with the church worker, Di Scott, in a speech to a crowd of 2,000 supporters in Cape Town.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Allied Mills, Sydney, Australia, agreed in principle with the Pillsbury Co. to form an venture to develop, manufacture and market consumer goods in Australia and New Zealand.     *       Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen, a private investment banking firm, completed its acquisition of the food service equipment group of the Beatrice Companies for $116 million.

headline: A CONVERSION'S IMPACT ON CLINTON HILL
abstract: The red brick of the sprawling 1,200-unit Clinton Hill Apartments complex in Brooklyn stands out starkly amid the old converted mansions that line Clinton Avenue just east of Fort Greene Park. But the conversion of the 12-building complex to a co-op has melded more smoothly than many had expected into this rapidly changing section of Brooklyn.     And while the conversion has not been as financially successful as its sponsor had hoped, it has had a major psychological impact on Clinton Hill and the local real estate market.    ''The first thing people ask when they come here is: 'Are those projects?' '' said Earl Drummond, a real estate broker who works in the area. '' 'No,' we say, 'that's a co-op.' They're much more likely to buy when they hear that.''

headline: Tidewater's Chairman Plans to Resume Course
abstract: John P. Laborde plans to keep on positioning Tidewater Marine Inc. for a recovery in the oil and gas industry, now that a $415 million bid from Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, has been rejected.    Mr. Laborde professes not to have been ruffled by the Jacobs offer. ''From the outset, our relationship has been friendly,'' Mr. Laborde said of Mr. Jacobs. '

headline: Peat Marwick Suit Over Penn Square
abstract: Peat Marwick, an international accounting firm whose audit of the failed Penn Square Bank has come under attack, filed suit Tuesday against two Federal agencies for their role in the 1982 closing of the Oklahoma City bank.   The firm said it had filed a complaint against the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the United States Comptroller of the Currency in Federal District Court in Oklahoma City. It said the F.D.I.C.'s refusal to arrange new funds for the bank or a merger with a healthier institution was a ''grossly arbitrary and capricious abuse of discretion.''

headline: Colorado Issue
abstract: Arvada, Colo., offered $30.1 million of general obligation bonds at competitive bid yesterday.

headline: SEMICONDUCTOR SETS 2-WEEK SHUTDOWN
abstract: The National Semiconductor Corporation has told its employees that it is closing down production for two weeks in February because of a slowdown in sales of computer chips.    At the same time, however, semiconductor industry stocks, including National Semiconductor, surged yesterday in response to a feeling that the worst of the slump is now over.   Linda Baker, a spokesman for National, said the company told its employees Wednesday that it would shut down production in Santa Clara, Calif., its headquarters, Feb. 11 through Feb. 24.

headline: REAGAN REPORTED TO INVITE GORBACHEV TO TALKS IN U.S. WITH GOAL OF ARMS ACCORD
abstract: White House officials said tonight that President Reagan was extending a ''personal invitation'' to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the new leader of the Soviet Union, to meet in the United States in hopes of improving relations between the two countries.   The officials said Mr. Reagan would ''prefer'' a meeting in the United States because talks between American and Soviet leaders over the last decade have taken place abroad.    The officials said Mr. Reagan's message would be delivered Wednesday to Mr. Gorbachev by Vice President Bush, who is leading the American delegation to the funeral of Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, who died Sunday evening.        Thoughts of Legacy    A ranking White House official said Mr. Reagan ''was beginning to think about his legacy.'' The official added, ''He wants to meet Gorbachev at a mutually agreed-on date; he wants to work out an accommodation on arms control.''

headline: Space Station Teams Picked
abstract: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has chosen six industry teams for advanced design work on elements of the $8 billion space station to be constructed in the next 10 years.   The fixed-price contracts, which are still to be negotiated, will be for 21 months of space station work beginning April 15.

headline: NATO CHIEF FINDS CONVENTIONAL FORCES LACKING
abstract: The Supreme Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization told Congress today that NATO military forces continued to be heavily overmatched by the Warsaw Pact and would be forced to surrender or resort to nuclear weapons within days of a Soviet attack.     The officer, Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, said the NATO conventional forces would quickly be overrun because of shortages of munitions, a lack of bomb-proof shelters for aircraft and because the United States does not have the airplanes to get reinforcements to Europe in time.    General Rogers also said he believed the European allies were paying an ''equitable share'' to build up NATO forces, and he urged Congress not to pressure the Europeans for more military spending by threatening to cut American troops there.   The general's remarks, in testimony to the Senate Armed Services Committee, came as some members of Congress are bracing for a re-examination of NATO's military operations.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1985        The Economy         A $973.7 billion budget will be sent to Congress today by President Reagan. It proposes to sustain a buildup of the military while shrinking the domestic budget. (Page A1.)

headline: MOSLEMS REVILE ISRAEL OVER BLAST IN LEBANON
abstract: Chanting ''Death to Israel!'' and ''America, the Great Satan!,'' thousands of Moslem demonstrators marched through the streets of West Beirut today to protest the death of 15 people in a bomb blast in a Shiite village in southern Lebanon.    Shops and schools were closed here and in two other major Moslem areas, Sidon in the Israeli-occupied south and Baalbek in the east, after Moslem clerics called for ''a day of anger'' over ''Israel's murderous crime.''

headline: GROMYKO AND POPE DISCUSS PEACE AND SOVIET CATHOLICS' ROLE
abstract: Pope John Paul II and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, met for nearly two hours today and discussed world peace and the situation of the Roman Catholic Church in the Soviet Union, a Vatican spokesman said.   It is believed that Mr. Gromyko was also seeking to enlist the Pope's opposition to the United States plan for a space- based defense system.   The Pope has so far declined to take a stand on the issue, and Vatican officials seemed to go out of their way to emphasize that he placed greater priority on reports of religious persecution in the Soviet Union.

headline: INDIA SAYS CARBIDE ITSELF IS RESPONSIBLE
abstract: A senior Government official said today that India was prepared to prove in court in the United States that the Union Carbide Corporation bears direct responsibility for the toxic gas leak at its pesticide plant in Bhopal last year.    The official said India would reject assertions of Union Carbide officials that the chemical accident resulted from errors and violations by its subsidiary, Union Carbide India Ltd.    At a news conference held Wednesday in Danbury, Conn., to release Union Carbide's report on its investigation of the disaster, company officials said responsibility for safety rests with the plant staff in Bhopal, not with corporate headquarters.   Warren M. Anderson, Union Carbide's chairman, said the subsidiary in India bears legal responsibility for the disaster. Union Carbide owns 50.9 percent of the Bhopal plant, which is operated by Indians working for Union Carbide India.

headline: Drivers Decide: Buy or Lease?
abstract: THE 1984 tax law reduced the tax benefits for   people who purchased an automobile since   last summer and use it for business 50 percent of the time or less. As one result of this provision, individuals have been paying greater attention to the possibility of leasing, rather than buying, a vehicle.   Long a familiar business device, auto leasing has increasingly been used by the public, even before the latest tax legislation. The American Automotive Leasing Association estimates that half of the approximately five million cars under lease are for personal use, including those driven by doctors, lawyers and other professionals who are entitled to certain tax deductions not available to the average consumer. The annual market for personal leasing of new cars is now about 800,000 units, according to the association, with independent leasing corporations, car dealers, car-rental companies, automobile manufacturers and banks among the lessors.

headline: British Telecom Net Down 4.5%
abstract: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said today that its after-tax profit for its fiscal second quarter slipped 4.5 percent from the period a year earlier.   Pretax earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 30, 1984, rose 49 percent, to $:365 million, or $453.6 million, from $:245 million a year earlier.

headline: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT JUMPS 28%
abstract: The United States foreign merchandise trade deficit hit $10.3 billion in January, a 28 percent jump from the previous month, as a flood of imports swamped the country's best export performance in more than three years, the Government said today.   Analysts said a rebounding United States economy and the strong dollar led to the import gains and they predicted those factors would combine to insure that America's trading woes would worsen further this year.

headline: Handwriting
abstract: To the Editor:   ''Passing the Penmanship Exam'' (''What's New in Employment Testing,'' Feb. 24) correctly reported on the increasing use of handwriting analysis in personnel selection. It perpetuated, however, the serious error of using the terms graphology and Graphoanalysis interchangeably.

headline: SALVADORAN REBLES WAGE ASSASSINATION CAMPAIGN
abstract: Leftist guerrillas have carried out a series of political assassinations and several attacks on municipal buildings as El Salvador prepares for national legislative and local elections next Sunday.     The rebels have taken responsibility for six political killings in recent weeks and are strongly suspected of shooting six other rightist political figures in the last two months, including several members of the extreme conservative National Republican Alliance. Rebel units have also burned 11 mayor's offices and 7 telephone company buildings in the period before the elections.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Jan. 31, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on Non-Use of Force - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad Hoc Committee on Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M.

headline: REAGAN REJECTS MUBARAK'S PLAN FOR MIDEAST TALKS
abstract: President Reagan praised President Hosni Mubarak today for trying to revive interest in Middle East diplomacy, but rebuffed the Egyptian leader's proposal that the United States meet with a joint delegation of Jordanian and Palestine Liberation Organization representatives.   Mr. Mubarak came to Washington promoting a plan by which the United States would meet with the Jordanian- Palestinian group as a preliminary step toward eventual talks between it and Israel.   According to American officials, Mr. Mubarak advocated that plan forcefully, arguing that if Washington would stop refusing to deal with the P.L.O., this could encourage P.L.O. hard- liners to agree to talks with Israel.   But Mr. Reagan repeated to Mr. Mubarak that the United States would not talk to the P.L.O. before it unequivocally accepted Security Council Resolutions 242 of 1967 and 338 of 1973. In the recent agreement with Jordan, the P.L.O. accepted ''all'' Security Council resolutions, but some of its leaders subsequently condemned Resolution 242, which calls on Israel to give back land occupied in the 1967 war in return for secure and recognized borders.

headline: Oil Currency Shift Weighed
abstract: The European Economic Community's executive commission has been holding meetings with oil-producing countries and with oil market operators since the start of the year to promote use of the European Currency Unit as a reference currency for crude oil and oil product transactions, commission officials said Friday.    Commission sources said they expected talks had begun at last month's meeting between commission officials and officials of the Gulf Cooperation Council in Bahrain.

headline: DATAPOINT SUITOR TALKS TO 3D PARTY
abstract: Continental Telecom Inc., the communications company, said yesterday that it had had ''discussions'' with Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, about acquiring the Datapoint Corporation.     But the company added in a prepared statement from its Atlanta headquarters that it had reached ''no understandings of any nature'' with Mr. Edelman. A company spokesman said that ''an appropriate announcement'' would be made if any understandings were concluded.

headline: Norway Trade Surplus
abstract: Norway's trade surplus grew 27.1 percent in 1984, to $4.35 billion, as oil exports rose, the Government said today.

headline: Hart Arrives in Moscow
abstract: Senator Gary Hart, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination last year, arrived in Moscow today for a visit that he said would center on the new Soviet- American arms negotiations. Mr. Hart arrived with his wife and two children for a five-day visit at the invitation of the Soviet authorities.

headline: German Trade Surplus
abstract: West Germany's trade surplus narrowed in December to $1.92 billion from November's $2.2 billion, the Government said today.

headline: Mexican Train Derails, Killing 7 and Injuring 182
abstract: A passenger train derailed near Calpulalpan, killing at least 7 people and injuring 182, the police and the Red Cross said today.

headline: Cambodians Are Moved Deeper Into Thailand
abstract: At least 60,000 Cambodians who fled recent Vietnamese attacks on border settlements are being moved to a refugee camp deeper in Thai territory, according to international aid workers and Thai officials.   The move came amid signs that the Vietnamese may be preparing to seal the Cambodian-Thai border and stay in the camps abandoned by Cambodian rebels and their civilian supporters since Vietnamese attacks began in mid-November.

headline: Commodore Selects Bates/New York
abstract: After going through an agency competition that involved six shops, Commodore International in West Chester, Pa., the leading marketer of home computers, has decided on Ted Bates Advertising/New York. The billings could be in excess of $50 million and the Bates assignment will be to create all of the advertising but place only the print advertising.

headline: ANGOLA'S BRAZILIAN CONNECTION: SURGING TRADE
abstract: Two thousand Brazilian workers are to build Angola's largest hydroelectric dam under the terms of a $500 million contract that has been signed here.    The dam contract highlights a little- noticed surge in commercial and cultural exchanges between Marxist Angola and capitalist Brazil, a relationship that has been overshadowed in the last decade by the larger presence of Cuban troops and technicians.   In Angola, Brazilians are drilling for oil, repairing telephone lines, rewiring power systems, maintaining freight trains and selling food, films and trucks. This two-way trade jumped from $4 million in 1973 to $230 million in 1984. Brazil is now Angola's third largest trading partner, after the United States and the Netherlands.

headline: Texas Commerce Rating Lowered
abstract: Texas Commerce Bancshares, whose debt rating was one of the highest assigned to a banking company, was downgraded yesterday by Duff & Phelps, a Chicago rating agency, to D.& P. 3 from D.& P. 2. The only remaining bank holding companies with the D.&P. 2 rating are the P.N.C. Corporation, holding company for Pittsburgh National Bank, J.P. Morgan, and Bancorp Hawaii.    The Texas bank's rating was reduced following a recent announcement of an increase in its nonperforming loans.

headline: PRODUCT ABANDONED BY DIGITAL
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation, responding to reports that one of its key manufacturing facilities was being dismantled, conceded yesterday that it has ceased production of its Rainbow personal computer.   The move appeared to mark the company's admission of defeat in its effort to break into the personal computer field dominated by International Business Machines Corporation and Apple Computer Inc., among others. But officials of Digital, the world's second-largest computer maker, hinted late yesterday that they might eventually make another attempt in the field.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Floods Kill at Least 71 In Southern Brazil
abstract: Floods caused by monthlong rains have killed at least 71 people and left thousands homeless in three southeastern Brazilian states, civil defense spokesmen said today.   Damage and death tolls are expected to rise if forecasts of several more weeks of rain prove correct.

headline: 'STAR WARS' PLAN FOR EUROPE IS URGED
abstract: A French general has called for France to lead Western Europe in the development of its own space-based missile defense program.    The program would be separate from the United States Strategic Defense Initiative, popularly known as ''Star Wars.''    The call appears to reflect what a French official described as a ''European current of opinion'' moving away from the skepticism shown about the feasibility of the American program.   The general's remarks were contained in a front-page article published this week by Le Monde. The general used the pseudonyn Hoplites to sign the article, but its authenticity was verified by officials of the French Foreign Ministry and Defense Ministry.

headline: PATENTS;  Spark Plug Heat Range Is Varied Automatically
abstract: William F. Strumbos of Northport, L.I., was granted a patent this week for a multiple heat-range spark plug. According to patent 4,491,101, the heat pipe at the lower end varies the heat range of the spark plug automatically.  The inventor has explained that at higher cylinder temperatures a pipe efficiently transfers heat away from the firing end of the plug to prevent overheating and destruction of the electrodes that might cause detonation.

headline: Peasants in BoliviaThreaten to Block Cities
abstract: Militant peasants, supporting a three- day-old general strike, threatened today to block all roads leading into the cities of Bolivia. The army said it would intervene if they tried to halt food shipments.

headline: PEOPLE
abstract: *       Barbara Hill, Lawrence M. Riegel and       E. Bingo Wyer have been named senior vice presidents, management supervisors for Avrett, Free & Ginsberg.

headline: LATIN PEACE GROUP CANCELS MEETING
abstract: A bitter diplomatic dispute between Costa Rica and Nicaragua led the Contadora group today to cancel its latest effort to negotiate a peace treaty for Central America.    Representatives of the five Central American nations and the Contadora Group - Colombia, Mexico, Panama and Venezuela - were to have met in Panama on Thursday and Friday. Their plan was to work out a new section on verification and control of the arms reduction plans included in the peace treaty.

headline: SCHLESINGER SAYS DISTRUST HINDERS FOREIGN POLICY
abstract: Former Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger asserted today that President Reagan's main difficulty in winning support for his Pentagon budget, Nicaragua policy and missile defense proposal was Congressional distrust of Administration objectives and credibility.    ''A national consensus cannot simply be wished into being,'' he told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ''It can be restored only gradually over time, if at all. It will come about only through the development of mutual trust, reasonable success and the sustained credibility of the executive branch.''

headline: Settlement Backed
abstract: The Indian Government is prepared to forgo litigation and settle with the Union Carbide Corporation on compensation for the victims of the gas leak in Bhopal, a senior official said today.   Minister of Law Asoke Sen said in an interview that a settlement depended on the compensation offered by Union Carbide, whose Indian subsidiary owns the pesticide plant where the leak occurred.

headline: 2 Units to Merge At Doyle Dane
abstract: Barry E. Loughrane, president of Doyle Dane Bernbach International, has decided to merge DDB Telephone Marketing Services, its 11-year-old Yellow Pages advertising specialty firm, into Bernard Hodes Advertising, a recruitment advertising agency it acquired in 1980.

headline: Peat Marwick Loses Plea
abstract: Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court refused today to shield Peat Marwick from having to disclose an internal study of its 1981 audit of an Oklahoma City bank that was closed the next year.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;Norfolk's Chairman Has Conrail Plans
abstract: After learning Friday afternoon that the Norfolk Southern Corporation was the Transportation Department's choice to buy Conrail and may become the country's largest rail system, the chairman, Robert B. Claytor, spoke briefly with President Reagan.         ''He said in effect he was delighted that a step had been taken to return Conrail to the private sector where it belongs,'' Mr. Claytor recalled. ''And I  replied, maybe brashly, looking back on it, that I appreciated the confidence the D.O.T. had placed in us and I was certain we could do a better job than the  Government.''

headline: RRIGHTS REPORT ON NICARAGUA CITES RECENT REBEL ACTIVITIES
abstract: A new report from a private human rights group is sharply critical of rights abuses by the American-backed Nicaraguan rebels.  It also assails abuses by the Nicaraguan Army but says there has been ''a sharp decline'' in violations by the army since 1982.     The report, by Americas Watch, says the most serious abuses by the Nicaraguan Government occurred in 1981 and 1982.   But throughout 1984 and as recently as early 1985, the report says, the anti- Government rebels have kidnapped, tortured, raped, mutilated and murdered numerous unarmed civilians, including women and children ''who were fleeing.''

headline: 3D POLE TELLS OF ROLE IN KILLING
abstract: The key defendant in the trial of the former security policemen charged in the killing of a pro- Solidarity priest testified today that he had beaten the priest and helped throw his bound body into a reservoir. But he would not admit that he was guilty of the specific charges against him contained in a 60-page indictment.    The defendant, Grzegorz Piotrowski, a former captain, was the commanding officer of the October operation in which the priest, the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, was kidnapped and killed. The defendant startled many in the court when he testified in a firm voice that ''I do admit to the guilt for some of the deeds.''

headline: British Aide Visits Zimbabwe
abstract: Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Foreign Secretary, arrived here today for talks. Diplomatic sources said his visit was designed to emphasize to America's sincerity in helping negotiate independence for South-West Africa, the disputed territory also known as Namibia, and to address relations between white-ruled South Africa and independent black nations.

headline: 2 Germanys' Leaders Meet in Soviet Capital
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany and Erich Honecker, the East German leader, met today for more than two hours and pledged in a statement to work toward better relations.   The two leaders, whose planned meeting last fall was canceled, also said the new Geneva arms control talks could bring a new era of smoother relations between East and West.

headline: West Germans Uneasy, But Trade Is Booming
abstract: At an economic policy meeting of the opposition Social Democrats last week, former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt called for Western European nations to join forces to combat United States interest-rate and deficit policies that he said were creating a dollar overvalued by about 30 percent, draining needed capital from European industry and dramatically worsening the debt situation in Latin America.   At the same meeting, Wolfgang Roth, chairman of the Social Democrats' economic policy committee, called the dramatic drop of the mark against the dollar a daily vote of ''no confidence'' by the world of international finance against the economic policies of Chancellor Helmut Kohl and the Christian Democrats.    The Bundesbank's president, Karl Otto P"ohl, and the Minister of Finance, Gerhard Stoltenberg, have also bemoaned the dollar's climb and predicted severe consequences for West Germany's economy and that of the United States as well.

headline: High-Tech Squadron Delivers for Pacific Bell
abstract: It was a ''cadre of very high-tech people'' who were responsible for the news last week that Pacific Bell had filed for a patent on a technology that would allow a single telephone line to carry two voice conversations and five streams of data at the same time.   Users of home information services cannot now speak on the telephone line while their home computer or terminal is using the line.

headline: Low Inflation in Japan
abstract: Lower oil prices helped Japan record a 2.2 percent inflation rate in 1984, its second lowest in 25 years, the Government reported today. The Management and Coordination Agency said 1984's 2.2 percent rise in nationwide consumer prices was slightly higher than the 1.9 percent of 1983, but was the second lowest since a 1 percent increase in 1959.

headline: Cloud of Toxic Gas In Sweden Dissipates
abstract: Most of the huge cloud of sulfuric acid that leaked from a chemical plant here Thursday had dissipated by tonight, 24 hours after it spewed into the air, authorities said.    Life in this central Swedish city was near normal this evening, the authorities said, adding that all but one of about 20 people treated at a hospital for eye and respiratory irritations had been discharged.

headline: Cruise Missile Tested Over Canadian Arctic
abstract: An unarmed cruise missile was successfully launched over the Beaufort Sea today in the weapon's second free-flight test over the Canadian Arctic in less than a week.   A B-52 bomber from the Grand Forks Air Force Base in North Dakota released the low-flying missile ''on course and on schedule,'' a Canadian military spokesman said.   A similar missile completed the first free-flight test of the weapon over Canada last Tuesday.

headline: French Will Bolster Guadeloupe Forces
abstract: -A-PITRE, Guadeloupe, March 14 (AP) - France said today that it was sending 60 paramilitary policemen to bolster security forces in Guadeloupe, where a bomb attack Wednesday killed one person and wounded 11, including four Americans.

headline: McCann-Erickson Gets Two Deputy Managers
abstract: Although McCann-Erickson, New York, has not named a replacement for James Kuras, its general manager who left to take over the New York office of Needham Harper Worldwide, it has just appointed two deputy managers who will report directly to Robert L. James, president of the worldwide company. Both senior vice presidents, they are John J. Dooner Jr., 36 years old, and Michael A. Sennott, 43.   Additionally, Ian Hooper, 43, also a senior vice president, and a management representative, has been given the added responsibility for March Direct Marketing, a subsidiary of McCann, which is one of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Indonesia Rains Kill 21
abstract: A landslide during a monsoon was reported to have killed at least 11 people when it buried four homes on the island of Lombok Thursday night, and The Jakarta Post said 10 other people had been reported dead since Wednesday in floods in central and eastern Java and the country's eastern islands. According to news reports, 11 bodies have been recovered since the landslide and two people are still missing.

headline: Acid Rain to be Issue
abstract: Canadian officials said today they expect this weekend's meeting between President Reagan and Prime Minister Mulroney to achieve progress on cleaning up acid rain.    Canada's foreign, defense, trade and environment ministers held a joint news conference to tell about their expectations for the meeting scheduled for Sunday and Monday in Quebec.

headline: No 'Common Ground' For Kennedy in Pretoria
abstract: Senator Edward M. Kennedy met with Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa for an hour today to discuss apartheid, but they were unable to reach ''common ground.''   The Massachusetts Democrat also visited the town of Mathopestad, where some 2,000 blacks are threatened with eviction.

headline: Shultz Names Committee
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has appointed a 10-member committee headed by Leonard H. Marks, a Washington lawyer, to assess the efforts to usher in policy changes at Unesco.    Mr. Marks said Wednesday: ''My purpose, with the rest of the committee, is to determine what changes are to be made and whether or not we should return.

headline: 3 Frozen Bolivian Accounts
abstract: Three bank accounts of the Bolivian Embassy in Washington have been frozen by a United States District Court in a tangled lawsuit by an American company that contends Bolivia owes it money. The case demonstrates the difficulties that might face American banks if they sought to attach assets of debtor countries.   Four years ago, a Washington consulting company called Practical Concepts Inc. worked on a Bolivian project financed by the United States Agency for International Development. There was a dispute, the company was not paid as much as it said it should have been and it sued in December 1982. Bolivia responded with a telegram, rather than a lawyer, and Practical Concepts won $1.69 million in a default judgment.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV SPEECH TO COMMUNIST PARTY CENTRAL COMMITTEE
abstract: Following are excerpts from the official text of Mikhail S.  Gorbachev's speech yeterday to the Central Committee as translated and distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency:      Dear Comrades,   All of us, all our party and country are in deep grief. Konstantin Ustinovich Chernenko, a true Leninist, an outstanding figure of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union and the Soviet state, of the international Communist movement, a person with a responsive heart and of a big organizational talent, has passed away.   Konstantin Ustinovich traversed a long and glorious road. Every post, assigned to him by the party, ever fuller revealed his talent, ability to work with people, at the post of the General Secretary of the C.P.S.U. Central Committee and the president of the Presidium of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet, Konstantin Ustinovich Chernenko devoted all his efforts and knowledge to developing the economy of the country, raising the well-being and cultural level of the people, insuring the security of motherland, preserving and consolidating peace on earth.

headline: President Calls Sandinista Foes Our Brothers
abstract: President Reagan, seeking to mobilize Congressional support for aid to Nicaraguan rebels, today called the insurgents ''our brothers'' and compared them to such ''freedom fighters'' as Lafayette, Bolivar, von Steuben and Kosciusko.   ''We must remember that if the Sandinistas are not stopped now, they will, as they have sworn, attempt to spread Communism to El Salvador, Costa Rica, Honduras and elsewhere,'' Mr. Reagan said in a radio speech from his hilltop ranch home 26 miles northwest of here. The President is to return to Washington on Sunday.      Sandinistas Denounced    Mr. Reagan's speech was marked by some of his strongest language to date about Nicaragua's Sandinista Government, as well as a blunt assertion that Congressional resistance to covert aid for the rebels could lead to Communist gains in Central America.

headline: END OF BAR TO JAPAN'S CARS URGED
abstract: Most of President Reagan's Cabinet advisers are urging an end to import quotas on Japanese cars, and a final decision may be made as early as next week, Administration officials said today.   ''I can't find anyone making the case for continuation of the quotas,'' said one highly placed official who asked not to be identified. ''I'd bet any reasonable sum that they come off.''    A senior official from another department said it was no longer a question of whether the restrictions would be lifted, but what trade concessions Washington could extract from Tokyo in return for the suspension. ''It's the question of how you do it,'' said this official, who also spoke on condition he not be identified.

headline: BRITISH GENERAL IN WORLD WAR II
abstract: Sir Brian Horrocks, the World War II general who helped take North Africa from the Germans, died Sunday night, his family announced today. He was 89 years old.    Sir Brian, who was also a prominent television personality, died at a nursing home in this village near England's south coast, a family spokesman said.

headline: ENVOY ACCUSED IN NEW CALEDONIA
abstract: A key leader of the pro-independence movement here, killed in a shootout with French security forces on Saturday, was buried in his home village today as his party accused a special French envoy of responsibility for his death.    The slaying of the leader, Eloi Machoro, is widely expected to jeopardize efforts by the French Government to negotiate an accord between the indigenous Melanesians, known as Kanakas, and the white settlers who want this South Pacific island territory to remain a part of France.

headline: 21.42 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,271.09
abstract: Technology and gold issues yesterday joined media stocks in a rally that gave Wall Street its best gain in two months.     The Dow Jones industrial average improved 21.42 points, to 1,271.09, after rising 2.32 points on Monday.   The New York Stock Exchange index rose 1.40 points, to 103.91, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumped 2.66 points, to 179.54. The average price per share rose 46 cents.

headline: Resources, Coastal In Court in 2 States
abstract: The Coastal Corporation and the American Natural Resources Company conducted legal skirmishes in two states yesterday as they continued their battle over Coastal's $2.3 billion acquisition bid.    A hearing in Federal District Court in Detroit was adjourned when American Natural Resources declared it would not invoke a Michigan state law concerning corporate takeovers to fend off Coastal.

headline: NEW HOUSE MAKES OFFER FOR THE NEW YORKER
abstract: Samuel I. Newhouse Jr., whose company publishes Vogue, Mademoiselle, Vanity Fair and other magazines as well as more than 20 newspapers, has offered to buy The New Yorker magazine.    In a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Newhouse said he would pay $180 a share in cash for The New Yorker Magazine Inc., whose principal publication has long been a showcase for some of the finest writers in America.   Mr. Newhouse already owns about 17 percent of The New Yorker Magazine Inc. - 142,000 of the company's 833,000 outstanding shares. He now is proposing to acquire the remaining 691,000 shares for a total price of about $124 million.

headline: Hundreds Flee Fires In Galapagos Islands
abstract: Brush fires have burned for three days on one of the Galapagos Islands, the site of rare plant and animal species, the islands' Governor, Washington Freire, said today.

headline: Brazil's Leader Has Surgery
abstract: President Joao Baptista Figueiredo underwent surgery today to relieve severe back pains.

headline: U.S. PLANE DOWN IN HONDURAS
abstract: A United States Air Force transport plane carrying 21 American soldiers crashed today off the northern coast of Honduras, a Pentagon spokesman said tonight.   The spokesman, Lieut. Col. Gene C. Sands, said a thick fog had prevented rescuers from reaching the downed C-130A transport in the water to determine the fate of the passengers.

headline: Local Costs Up by 0.6%
abstract: Consumer prices in the New York- northeastern New Jersey area rose six-tenths of 1 percent in February, double the national increase, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.    Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional director of the bureau, attributed the rise to dramatically increased costs of fruit and vegetables, medical care and women's clothing.   Produce prices, which increased 4.7 percent, rose the sharpest. Although increases in the prices of produce are common in winter months, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, cold weather in Southern states, particularly Florida, helped account for the higher prices.

headline: ATOMIC REACTOR SHUT IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: South Africa's only nuclear power station, which employs some American personnel, has been closed indefinitely because of flaws in water-carrying stainless steel pipes, the state-run company that operates it said today.   Environmentalist groups opposed to the Koeberg plant, 20 miles north of Cape Town, expressed concern about the shutdown, but the South African Electricity Supply Commission said the problem was not serious.   ''We could probably have run for years with these faults and nothing would happen,'' a spokesman for the commission said.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Advanced Polymer Systems Inc.  of Redwood City, Calif., which manufactures programmable polymers used to deliver cosmetic and therapeutic agents to the skin, announced that Dr. Martin Katz had been named senior vice president and director of research and development.     *       John Blair & Co., a marketing and communications concern, has elected Richard Leberman chief financial officer and vice president, succeeding James A. Jurist, who has retired.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Jan. 18, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   International Trade Law Commission on Negotiable Instruments - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: FOOD PRICE RIOTING PERSISTS IN SUDAN
abstract: Riots over food price increases erupted here for the second day today. Three people have been killed, 1,400 arrested and the windows of several United States Embassy cars smashed.   The riots began Wednesday as President Gaafar el-Nimeiry left for talks in the United States.

headline: ARMS TALKS: A SIGNAL AND A BEGINNING
abstract: The meeting between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko was in the end as much a foreign policy signal as it was a starting point for arms control.  As detente unfolded in the early 1970's, arms control negotiations led the way. As the two sides reach out toward each other this time, the thrust is more diffuse, and both are warier of arms limitations.    Diplomats on both sides intended the Geneva sessions as an unmistakable sign that after five years of saber-rattling and recriminations, the two superpowers are going to try to get along.

headline: New Yorker Profits Increased 5.7% in 1984
abstract: The New Yorker Magazine Inc., which Samuel I. Newhouse Jr. has offered to acquire, yesterday reported a 5.7 percent increase in net income for 1984.    Earnings rose to $5.6 million, or $6.75 a share, from $5.3 million, or $6.52 a share, in 1983.

headline: Rightist Parties in Salvador Seek Delay in March Voting
abstract: Three rightist political parties have asked the Central Elections Council to postpone the March 17 elections until the Supreme Court resolves a dispute over the election law.

headline: Compucorp Has Loan Agreement
abstract: Compucorp said it had reached agreements with bank lenders and a private investor that end a default on previous loan covenants and that should help it return to profitability.

headline: Argentine Devaluation
abstract: The Argentine central bank reduced the value of the peso by 4 percent today, putting it at 268.15 pesos to the dollar. It was the latest in a long series of small, periodic devaluations and the fourth this year to exceed the average daily decline of 0.76 percent.

headline: Mexico's Austerity Plans
abstract: The Mexican Government said today it would cut public spending by about $470 million and sell 236 state-run enterprises as part of its economic austerity program.   Officials said the measures, announced in a statement, aimed to compensate for a fall in dollar revenues caused by a drop in oil prices.

headline: KOMATSU PLANS TO MAKE EQUIPMENT IN U.S. PLANT
abstract: Komatsu Ltd., the world's second-largest construction equipment manufacturer, after the Caterpillar Tractor Company, announced today that it would build its first United States assembly plant. The Tokyo-based company said that it was negotiating for a plant site in Chattanooga, Tenn.   Analysts said Komatsu, which has about 7.5 percent of the American construction equipment market, is expected to build even more plants in the United States as the company tries to meet its goal of capturing 20 percent of the American market.    ''They're trying to convince dealers that they are making more of a commitment to the United States,'' said Andrew Silver, an analyst with the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. ''They want to show that they will be close to the market and will be ready to respond to it.''
